Definition: a mordant largely employed in calico printing and dyeing, known as "red liquor" in the trade; commonly made by (i) dissolving alumina in acetic acid, (2) mixing together solutions of lime acetate and aluminium sulphate, (3) mixing lead acetate with alum or sulphate of alumina.

Author: William S. Murphy

Definition: chemically described as methul-formic acid, and formed by acetous fermentations of alcohol, acetic acid is one of the most useful agents used by calico printers and dyers, because it is a solvent of aniline dyes as well as of metallic oxides and colour lakes; used largely in wool dyeing with acid colours.

Author: William S. Murphy

Definition: oxide of barium, the salts of which are employed in several ways, viz.: (i) barytes, the sulphate of the metal barium, g-round fine and treated with hydrochloric acid; (2) barium carbonate, a costly weig-hting material used by cotton finishers, obtained by precipitating barium chloride with carbonate of soda; (3) barium chloride, a colourless salt sometimes used as a filling-, but more commonly used for making barium carbonate; (4) barium chromate, sometimes employed as a yellow pigment by calico printers.

Definition: a term applied to any loom cylinder, viz.: (i) warp beam, the roller upon which the warp is wound and fixed in the loom; (2) cloth beam, the roller upon which the woven cloth is wound; (3) breast beam, which is placed in the front of the loom to guide the cloth on to the beam ; (4) back beam, which guides the warp from the warp beam slung below to the back of the heald shafts.

Definition: a fibre obtained from the leaf stalks of the " mussa textilis," a plant found native in the philippine islands. it is strong, has great durability, varies from 40in. to 80in. in length, yellowish-white in colour, and has a lustrous appearance. it is light but rather stiff in handle. in india the inner fibres of the leaf stalk are much used for making fine cloths, the outer and coarser fibres being used in the manufacture of matting for floor cover- ings, cordage, canvas, etc. the fibre (fine quality) is also used as weft in some fabrics for upholstery, chiefly on account of its colour and lustre. there are many varieties, ranging from fine to coarse, obtained from the several species of banana and pineapple plants. manilla hats are made from these fibres. it is a tall plant, growing from 16 to 22 feet, and has a stem up to 12in. diameter. this is one of the most important fibres cultivated in the tropics.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ABACA OR MANILLA HEMP: A fibre obtained from the leaf stalks of the " mussa textilis," a plant found native in the Philippine Islands. It is strong, has great durability, varies from 40in. to 80in. in length, yellowish-white in colour, and has a lustrous appearance. It is light but rather stiff in handle. In India the inner fibres of the leaf stalk are much used for making fine cloths, the outer and coarser fibres being used in the manufacture of matting for floor cover- ings, cordage, canvas, etc. The fibre (fine quality) is also used as weft in some fabrics for upholstery, chiefly on account of its colour and lustre. There are many varieties, ranging from fine to coarse, obtained from the several species of banana and pineapple plants. Manilla hats are made from these fibres. It is a tall plant, growing from 16 to 22 feet, and has a stem up to 12in. diameter. This is one of the most important fibres cultivated in the tropics.
text: ABACA OR MANILLA HEMP: A fibre obtained from the leaf stalks of the " mussa textilis," a plant found native in the Philippine Islands. It is strong, has great durability, varies from 40in. to 80in. in length, yellowish-white in colour, and has a lustrous appearance. It is light but rather stiff in handle. In India the inner fibres of the leaf stalk are much used for making fine cloths, the outer and coarser fibres being used in the manufacture of matting for floor cover- ings, cordage, canvas, etc. The fibre (fine quality) is also used as weft in some fabrics for upholstery, chiefly on account of its colour and lustre. There are many varieties, ranging from fine to coarse, obtained from the several species of banana and pineapple plants. Manilla hats are made from these fibres. It is a tall plant, growing from 16 to 22 feet, and has a stem up to 12in. diameter. This is one of the most important fibres cultivated in the tropics.

Definition: a term used to indicate that the particulars given are to be actual and not nominal. the cotton trade is probably the only trade where the necessity arises to use these terms. in all other textile trades 30 inches wide means 30 in. wide, but in the cotton trade it may mean "nominal " or "actual," namely, 29 in. or 30in. all the particulars required to enable a manufacturer to quote for a cloth may mean either of these terms. for instance, 30/116, 19√ó19, 36/40 should mean 30 inches 116 yards, 19 ends and 19 picks per quarter inch, 36's twist 40's weft. but different makers would read this differently. one maker may quote for actual while another may think nominal particulars are meant, and may quote for 294in. 116 yards, 72in. √ó72in., 38/42, or 36/42. to ensure the required cloth is being quoted for a shipper would send his enquiry on as follows:- 30 full 11636. 76 x 76 full 36/40 actual.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ACTUAL: A term used to indicate that the particulars given are to be actual and not nominal. The cotton trade is probably the only trade where the necessity arises to use these terms. In all other textile trades 30 inches wide means 30 in. wide, but in the cotton trade it may mean "nominal " or "actual," namely, 29 in. or 30in. All the particulars required to enable a manufacturer to quote for a cloth may mean either of these terms. For instance, 30/116, 19√ó19, 36/40 should mean 30 inches 116 yards, 19 ends and 19 picks per quarter inch, 36's twist 40's weft. But different makers would read this differently. One maker may quote for actual while another may think nominal particulars are meant, and may quote for 294in. 116 yards, 72in. √ó72in., 38/42, or 36/42. To ensure the required cloth is being quoted for a shipper would send his enquiry on as follows:- 30 full 11636. 76 x 76 full 36/40 actual.

Definition: plain weave cloths, used for making wings of aero- planes. the cloth must be well woven, and practically without faults. the widths vary from 36 to 56 inches, and up to 160 ends√ó160 picks per inch. a1 a fair quantity has been woven 90/2 reed, 100 picks, from 3/120's warp and weft sea islands cotton. linen yarns made from the best quality of flax have been used in great quantities for the manufacture of these fabrics. often these cloths are boiled after being woven, which process removes impurities not required, and gives greater strength with a minimum weight. finished cloths are afterwards put through a process known as doping.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: AEROPLANE FABRICS: Plain weave cloths, used for making wings of aero- planes. The cloth must be well woven, and practically without faults. The widths vary from 36 to 56 inches, and up to 160 ends√ó160 picks per inch. A1 A fair quantity has been woven 90/2 reed, 100 picks, from 3/120's warp and weft Sea Islands cotton. Linen yarns made from the best quality of flax have been used in great quantities for the manufacture of these fabrics. Often these cloths are boiled after being woven, which process removes impurities not required, and gives greater strength with a minimum weight. Finished cloths are afterwards put through a process known as doping.
text: AEROPLANE FABRICS: Plain weave cloths, used for making wings of aero- planes. The cloth must be well woven, and practically without faults. The widths vary from 36 to 56 inches, and up to 160 ends√ó160 picks per inch. A1 A fair quantity has been woven 90/2 reed, 100 picks, from 3/120's warp and weft Sea Islands cotton. Linen yarns made from the best quality of flax have been used in great quantities for the manufacture of these fabrics. Often these cloths are boiled after being woven, which process removes impurities not required, and gives greater strength with a minimum weight. Finished cloths are afterwards put through a process known as doping.

Definition: a fabric made from loop yarns giving a terry effect and used in the china trade.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: AGARIC: A fabric made from loop yarns giving a terry effect and used in the China trade.
text: AGARIC: A fabric made from loop yarns giving a terry effect and used in the China trade.

Definition: a fibre obtained from the leaf of the agave ameri- cana." white to pale yellow in colour, short in length, hard in feel, is very strong, has much elasticity, and is wavy. used in the manufacture of a lace for decorative uses, and for cordage.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: AGAVE FIBRE, OR PITA, OR ALOE: A fibre obtained from the leaf of the Agave Ameri- cana." White to pale yellow in colour, short in length, hard in feel, is very strong, has much elasticity, and is wavy. Used in the manufacture of a lace for decorative uses, and for cordage.
text: AGAVE FIBRE, OR PITA, OR ALOE: A fibre obtained from the leaf of the Agave Ameri- cana." White to pale yellow in colour, short in length, hard in feel, is very strong, has much elasticity, and is wavy. Used in the manufacture of a lace for decorative uses, and for cordage.

Definition: an open texture cloth with fancy weave, made from worsted warp and weft, used for dress fabrics. also applied to a plain woven cotton cloth of soft fine yarns, piece-dyed black and other solid colours, used for decorations.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ALBATROSS: An open texture cloth with fancy weave, made from worsted warp and weft, used for dress fabrics. Also applied to a plain woven cotton cloth of soft fine yarns, piece-dyed black and other solid colours, used for decorations.
text: ALBATROSS: An open texture cloth with fancy weave, made from worsted warp and weft, used for dress fabrics. Also applied to a plain woven cotton cloth of soft fine yarns, piece-dyed black and other solid colours, used for decorations.

Definition: the cheapest quilt made, and very popular. made all cotton with bold designs. jacquard machines are used. the width of the cloth varies from 100 to 108 inches, and length about 84 inches. standard cloths are:- 1. 108 in. x 84-in., 56/2 reed, 2/26's figuring warp, 2/40's ground warp, 36 picks, 6's condenser weft. 2. 108 in. x 84 in., 56/2 reed, 2/16's figuring and 24's ground warps, 30 picks, 4's or 6's weft, 100 yards of cloth from 120 yards figure, 105 ground. the coloured figuring ends vary from 1 to 4 in a mail of the harness, with one ground end to each mail. two beams are used, one for the coloured warp drawn through the jacquard harness, the other for ground warp drawn through the healds.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ALHAMBRA QUILTS: The cheapest quilt made, and very popular. Made all cotton with bold designs. Jacquard machines are used. The width of the cloth varies from 100 to 108 inches, and length about 84 inches. Standard cloths are:- 1. 108 in. x 84-in., 56/2 reed, 2/26's figuring warp, 2/40's ground warp, 36 picks, 6's condenser weft. 2. 108 in. x 84 in., 56/2 reed, 2/16's figuring and 24's ground warps, 30 picks, 4's or 6's weft, 100 yards of cloth from 120 yards figure, 105 ground. The coloured figuring ends vary from 1 to 4 in a mail of the harness, with one ground end to each mail. Two beams are used, one for the coloured warp drawn through the jacquard harness, the other for ground warp drawn through the healds.
text: ALHAMBRA QUILTS: The cheapest quilt made, and very popular. Made all cotton with bold designs. Jacquard machines are used. The width of the cloth varies from 100 to 108 inches, and length about 84 inches. The coloured figuring ends vary from 1 to 4 in a mail of the harness, with one ground end to each mail. Two beams are used, one for the coloured warp drawn through the jacquard harness, the other for ground warp drawn through the healds.

Definition: a term used in the west african trade to denote cloths 32 in. to 36 in. wide, 20 yards long, made from grey and red yarns in the warp and grey weft. about 16 x 15 per in., and 20's grey, 24's alizarine red, 24's weft. the alizarine red yarn is fast, and similar to turkey- red in shade and properties. usually half colour and half grey yarn is used in the warp, the designs being bold wide stripes and plain weave.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ALIZARINE REDS: A term used in the West African trade to denote cloths 32 in. to 36 in. wide, 20 yards long, made from grey and red yarns in the warp and grey weft. About 16 x 15 per in., and 20's grey, 24's alizarine red, 24's weft. The alizarine red yarn is fast, and similar to Turkey- red in shade and properties. Usually half colour and half grey yarn is used in the warp, the designs being bold wide stripes and plain weave.
text: ALIZARINE REDS: A term used in the West African trade to denote cloths 32 in. to 36 in. wide, 20 yards long, made from grey and red yarns in the warp and grey weft. About 16 x 15 per in., and 20's grey, 24's alizarine red, 24's weft. The alizarine red yarn is fast, and similar to Turkey- red in shade and properties. Usually half colour and half grey yarn is used in the warp, the designs being bold wide stripes and plain weave.

Definition: alpaca "wool" weft is obtained by disintegrating fabrics made of mixture materials, and may contain animal and vegetable fibres. the term is also applied to a lustre fabric woven with a cotton warp and alpaca wool weft, plain weave. when dyed in solid colours it is cross-dyed, the cotton warp being dyed before weaving, and the piece is piece-dyed after leaving the loom. the warp is usually 2/80's egyptian.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ALPACA OR EXTRACT WOOL: Alpaca "wool" weft is obtained by disintegrating fabrics made of mixture materials, and may contain animal and vegetable fibres. The term is also applied to a lustre fabric woven with a cotton warp and alpaca wool weft, plain weave. When dyed in solid colours it is cross-dyed, the cotton warp being dyed before weaving, and the piece is piece-dyed after leaving the loom. The warp is usually 2/80's Egyptian.
text: ALPACA OR EXTRACT WOOL: Alpaca "wool" weft is obtained by disintegrating fabrics made of mixture materials, and may contain animal and vegetable fibres. The term is also applied to a lustre fabric woven with a cotton warp and alpaca wool weft, plain weave. When dyed in solid colours it is cross-dyed, the cotton warp being dyed before weaving, and the piece is piece-dyed after leaving the loom. The warp is usually 2/80's Egyptian.

Definition: this is obtained from the domesticated alpaca, and is variously white, reddish, or black; fibre 6 to 8 inches long, with a uniform diameter, slightly wavy, smooth, and fine. it is chiefly used for ladies' dress cloths and lounge jackets.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ALPACA WOOL: This is obtained from the domesticated alpaca, and is variously white, reddish, or black; fibre 6 to 8 inches long, with a uniform diameter, slightly wavy, smooth, and fine. It is chiefly used for ladies' dress cloths and lounge jackets.
text: ALPACA WOOL: This is obtained from the domesticated alpaca, and is variously white, reddish, or black; fibre 6 to 8 inches long, with a uniform diameter, slightly wavy, smooth, and fine. It is chiefly used for ladies' dress cloths and lounge jackets.

Definition: a good quality cloth, wool warp and worsted weft, 5-end satin weave, with twill running to the left. twist of warp is to the right, and of weft to the left, which gives a smart cloth. made in bradford. 80 ends, 44 to 56 picks per inch, from 2/60 botany warp, 40's or 42's worsted weft. widths 46 to 56 inches. when finished the shrinkage is about 10 to 12 per cent. in warp and 12 to 16 in weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: AMAZONS: A good quality cloth, wool warp and worsted weft, 5-end satin weave, with twill running to the left. Twist of warp is to the right, and of weft to the left, which gives a smart cloth. Made in Bradford. 80 ends, 44 to 56 picks per inch, from 2/60 botany warp, 40's or 42's worsted weft. Widths 46 to 56 inches. When finished the shrinkage is about 10 to 12 per cent. in warp and 12 to 16 in weft.
text: AMAZONS: A good quality cloth, wool warp and worsted weft, 5-end satin weave, with twill running to the left. Twist of warp is to the right, and of weft to the left, which gives a smart cloth. Made in Bradford. 80 ends, 44 to 56 picks per inch, from 2/60 botany warp, 40's or 42's worsted weft. Widths 46 to 56 inches. When finished the shrinkage is about 10 to 12 per cent. in warp and 12 to 16 in weft.

Definition: low grey cloths, 30 inches wide, 36 to 40 yards, 52 ends, 44 picks, 27's twist, 18's weft, sized twist and woven with headings of a pick or two of colour such as 2 picks blue. bacup manufacturers make a large quantity. this cloth is shipped in the loom state to the west african and china markets.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: AMERICANS: Low grey cloths, 30 inches wide, 36 to 40 yards, 52 ends, 44 picks, 27's twist, 18's weft, sized twist and woven with headings of a pick or two of colour such as 2 picks blue. Bacup manufacturers make a large quantity. This cloth is shipped in the loom state to the West African and China markets.
text: AMERICANS: Low grey cloths, 30 inches wide, 36 to 40 yards, 52 ends, 44 picks, 27's twist, 18's weft, sized twist and woven with headings of a pick or two of colour such as 2 picks blue. Bacup manufacturers make a large quantity. This cloth is shipped in the loom state to the West African and China markets.

Definition: the cloth described as "americans is also known under this style, but it is not correct, as a sheeting is a twill cloth and very much wider. the term cabot is also given to the cloth (see cabot).
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: AMERICAN SHEETINGS: The cloth described as "Americans is also known under this style, but it is not correct, as a sheeting is a twill cloth and very much wider. The term Cabot is also given to the cloth (see Cabot).
text: AMERICAN SHEETINGS: The cloth described as "Americans is also known under this style, but it is not correct, as a sheeting is a twill cloth and very much wider. The term Cabot is also given to the cloth (see Cabot).

Definition: the name given to the ordinary twill weave 2/2 by the american traders. "shalloon" applied to this twill is not correct, since a shalloon is a very good quality woollen cloth (see shalloon), whereas american twills are cotton fabrics.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: AMERICAN TWILL, WRONGLY CALLED "SHALLOON ": The name given to the ordinary twill weave 2/2 by the American traders. "Shalloon" applied to this twill is not correct, since a shalloon is a very good quality woollen cloth (see Shalloon), whereas American twills are cotton fabrics.
text: AMERICAN TWILL, WRONGLY CALLED "SHALLOON ": The name given to the ordinary twill weave 2/2 by the American traders. "Shalloon" applied to this twill is not correct, since a shalloon is a very good quality woollen cloth (see Shalloon), whereas American twills are cotton fabrics.

Definition: plain or twill fabric, woven from a cotton warp and an angola yarn weft. principally used as shirting cloths for the home trade.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ANGOLA: Plain or twill fabric, woven from a cotton warp and an angola yarn weft. Principally used as shirting cloths for the home trade.
text: ANGOLA: Plain or twill fabric, woven from a cotton warp and an angola yarn weft. Principally used as shirting cloths for the home trade.

Definition: a yarn spun from a mixture of wool and cotton, generally 80 per cent. wool, 20 per cent. cotton. this quality is known as "80/20" angola." the percentage varies.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ANGOLA YARN: A yarn spun from a mixture of wool and cotton, generally 80 per cent. wool, 20 per cent. cotton. This quality is known as "80/20" angola." The percentage varies.
text: ANGOLA YARN: A yarn spun from a mixture of wool and cotton, generally 80 per cent. wool, 20 per cent. cotton. This quality is known as "80/20" angola." The percentage varies.

Definition: the hair or wool of the goat of that name. more generally known as mohair. the animal originally had its home in asia minor. about 1858 it was introduced into cape colony, from which country we now get a large supply. the natives of asia minor made shawls from the wool, which resembled cashmere shawls. in colour it is white, average length of hair is 6 to 8 inches, and has a curly structure. it is a very useful fibre, and largely used by the manufacturers of astrakhan, wool crepons, plushes, and cashmeres; also used in many silk cloths. the french use the fibre in a cloth named " poil de ch√®vre,' which has a fine spun silk coloured warp and angora weft. bradford imitates this cloth with a fine cotton warp it has more lustre than wool, but is not so warm. sir titus salt, by introducing the manufacture of goods made from mohair into the town of saltaire, raised saltaire into a town from a village.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ANGORA OR "MOHAIR ": The hair or wool of the goat of that name. More generally known as mohair. The animal originally had its home in Asia Minor. About 1858 it was introduced into Cape Colony, from which country we now get a large supply. The natives of Asia Minor made shawls from the wool, which resembled Cashmere shawls. In colour it is white, average length of hair is 6 to 8 inches, and has a curly structure. It is a very useful fibre, and largely used by the manufacturers of Astrakhan, wool crepons, plushes, and cashmeres; also used in many silk cloths. The French use the fibre in a cloth named " poil de ch√®vre,' which has a fine spun silk coloured warp and angora weft. Bradford imitates this cloth with a fine cotton warp It has more lustre than wool, but is not so warm. Sir Titus Salt, by introducing the manufacture of goods made from mohair into the town of Saltaire, raised Saltaire into a town from a village.
text: ANGORA OR "MOHAIR ": The hair or wool of the goat of that name. More generally known as mohair. The animal originally had its home in Asia Minor. About 1858 it was introduced into Cape Colony, from which country we now get a large supply. The natives of Asia Minor made shawls from the wool, which resembled Cashmere shawls. In colour it is white, average length of hair is 6 to 8 inches, and has a curly structure. It is a very useful fibre, and largely used by the manufacturers of Astrakhan, wool crepons, plushes, and cashmeres; also used in many silk cloths. The French use the fibre in a cloth named " poil de ch√®vre,' which has a fine spun silk coloured warp and angora weft. Bradford imitates this cloth with a fine cotton warp It has more lustre than wool, but is not so warm. Sir Titus Salt, by introducing the manufacture of goods made from mohair into the town of Saltaire, raised Saltaire into a town from a village.

Definition: a variety grown in the west indies, and very similar to sea islands. from this variety the latter is said to owe its origin. it is not much grown at the present time.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ANGUILLA COTTON: A variety grown in the West Indies, and very similar to Sea Islands. From this variety the latter is said to owe its origin. It is not much grown at the present time.
text: ANGUILLA COTTON: A variety grown in the West Indies, and very similar to Sea Islands. From this variety the latter is said to owe its origin. It is not much grown at the present time.

Definition: plain woven coloured cloths in stripes and checks. colours are usually blues and blacks, with a side border differently coloured of bolder stripe or of figuring worked on the dhootie principle; 34 to 38 in. wide, 64 ends and picks to 72 ends and picks, 28's to 36's warp and weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: APRON CLOTH, APRON CHECKS: Plain woven coloured cloths in stripes and checks. Colours are usually blues and blacks, with a side border differently coloured of bolder stripe or of figuring worked on the dhootie principle; 34 to 38 in. wide, 64 ends and picks to 72 ends and picks, 28's to 36's warp and weft.
text: APRON CLOTH, APRON CHECKS: Plain woven coloured cloths in stripes and checks. Colours are usually blues and blacks, with a side border differently coloured of bolder stripe or of figuring worked on the dhootie principle; 34 to 38 in. wide, 64 ends and picks to 72 ends and picks, 28's to 36's warp and weft.

Definition: also known as austrias or austrian twill. this cloth is a jean, 2 x 1 weave, made 44 in. 90 yds., (ls), 72 √ó 84, 34's/20's, 33¬ω lb. super weft. a large trade is done in the cloth with the near east markets. shipped in the dyed state, principally black.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ARGENTINAS: Also known as Austrias or Austrian Twill. This cloth is a jean, 2 x 1 weave, made 44 in. 90 yds., (LS), 72 √ó 84, 34's/20's, 33¬Ω lb. super weft. A large trade is done in the cloth with the Near East markets. Shipped in the dyed state, principally black.
text: ARGENTINAS: Also known as Austrias or Austrian Twill. This cloth is a jean, 2 x 1 weave, made 44 in. 90 yds., (LS), 72 √ó 84, 34's/20's, 33¬Ω lb. super weft. A large trade is done in the cloth with the Near East markets. Shipped in the dyed state, principally black.

Definition: a name applied to weaves of an irregular or broken character, giving a pebbled surface. it is more pronounced than a crep–µ. woven in a dobby loom from 12 to 20 staves.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ARMURE: A name applied to weaves of an irregular or broken character, giving a pebbled surface. It is more pronounced than a crep–µ. Woven in a dobby loom from 12 to 20 staves.
text: ARMURE: A name applied to weaves of an irregular or broken character, giving a pebbled surface. It is more pronounced than a crep–µ. Woven in a dobby loom from 12 to 20 staves.

Definition: a heavy plain cloth used for army shirts. also known "silver greys." generally made from all cotton, but a few cloths have had about 5 to 10 per cent. of wool in the weft. after weaving, they are soft finished and brush raised. a standard cloth is 30 in., 120 yards, 44 ends, 48 picks, 2/18's twist, 12's lavender-dyed weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ARMY GREYS: A heavy plain cloth used for army shirts. Also known "silver greys." Generally made from all cotton, but a few cloths have had about 5 to 10 per cent. of wool in the weft. After weaving, they are soft finished and brush raised. A standard cloth is 30 in., 120 yards, 44 ends, 48 picks, 2/18's twist, 12's lavender-dyed weft.
text: ARMY GREYS: A heavy plain cloth used for army shirts. Also known "silver greys." Generally made from all cotton, but a few cloths have had about 5 to 10 per cent. of wool in the weft. After weaving, they are soft finished and brush raised. A standard cloth is 30 in., 120 yards, 44 ends, 48 picks, 2/18's twist, 12's lavender-dyed weft.

Definition: (see herringbone twills)‚äî another name for the herringbone style of twill.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ARROWHEAD TWILLS : (See Herringbone Twills)‚Äî Another name for the herringbone style of twill.
text: ARROWHEAD TWILLS : (See Herringbone Twills)‚Äî Another name for the herringbone style of twill.

Definition: this is prepared from the barked trunks of pine trees by the reduction of thin shavings into wood-wool, which is washed, then acted upon by steam, and heated with caustic soda under pressure, being thus converted into cellulose. this paste-like substance is reheated and pressed through a form of sieve into threads. by treating with ammonia and sprinkling with water these threads are made flexible and as easy to work as cotton. the wood is not abundant, and the cost of production is very heavy, which tends to prevent this fibre becoming a commercial success.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ARTIFICIAL COTTON: This is prepared from the barked trunks of pine trees by the reduction of thin shavings into wood-wool, which is washed, then acted upon by steam, and heated with caustic soda under pressure, being thus converted into cellulose. This paste-like substance is reheated and pressed through a form of sieve into threads. By treating with ammonia and sprinkling with water these threads are made flexible and as easy to work as cotton. The wood is not abundant, and the cost of production is very heavy, which tends to prevent this fibre becoming a commercial success.
text: ARTIFICIAL COTTON: This is prepared from the barked trunks of pine trees by the reduction of thin shavings into wood-wool, which is washed, then acted upon by steam, and heated with caustic soda under pressure, being thus converted into cellulose. This paste-like substance is reheated and pressed through a form of sieve into threads. By treating with ammonia and sprinkling with water these threads are made flexible and as easy to work as cotton. The wood is not abundant, and the cost of production is very heavy, which tends to prevent this fibre becoming a commercial success.

Definition: several varieties are manufactured, such as donnet silk,' "paris silk,' "viscose silk, silk," etc.-all of them termed silks," although not silks at all, but substitutes. the term " silk" applied to fabrics made of "artificial silk" is now illegal, except when used with the word " artificial." one preparation is cellulose prepared from cotton by the action of nitric acid, which converts the cotton into nitro-cellulose, and, by dissolving this in ether or alcohol and forcing the liquid through very fine holes in a platinum plate, threads are formed as fine as 1-250th inch diameter. a very lustrous fibre results, which is much used as ornament with cotton and wool warps. "char- "vandura
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis

The term " silk" applied to fabrics made of "artificial silk" is now illegal, except when used with the word " artificial." One preparation is cellulose prepared from cotton by the action of nitric acid, which converts the cotton into nitro-cellulose, and, by dissolving this in ether or alcohol and forcing the liquid through very fine holes in a platinum plate, threads are formed as fine as 1-250th inch diameter. A very lustrous fibre results, which is much used as ornament with cotton and wool warps. "Char- "Vandura

One preparation is cellulose prepared from cotton by the action of nitric acid, which converts the cotton into nitro-cellulose, and, by dissolving this in ether or alcohol and forcing the liquid through very fine holes in a platinum plate, threads are formed as fine as 1-250th inch diameter. A very lustrous fibre results, which is much used as ornament with cotton and wool warps. "Char- "Vandura

Definition: the number of deniers that 476 metres (or 520 yards) weighs gives the counts. there are 533 deniers in one ounce, or 8,533 deniers to one pound avoirdupois.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ARTIFICIAL SILK COUNTS: The number of deniers that 476 metres (or 520 yards) weighs gives the counts. There are 533 deniers in one ounce, or 8,533 deniers to one pound avoirdupois.
text: ARTIFICIAL SILK COUNTS: The number of deniers that 476 metres (or 520 yards) weighs gives the counts. There are 533 deniers in one ounce, or 8,533 deniers to one pound avoirdupois.

Definition: is really a recovered waste product, and has grown to an important branch of the textile industry. a large quantity of cheap suits are made from these yarns, of which there are several varieties, known as mungo, shoddy, extract wool, etc. they are manufactured from rags and waste materials containing wool. cotton, and even silk, is found in some of them. (see also under mungo, shoddy, extract wool.)
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ARTIFICIAL WOOL: Is really a recovered waste product, and has grown to an important branch of the textile industry. A large quantity of cheap suits are made from these yarns, of which there are several varieties, known as mungo, shoddy, extract wool, etc. They are manufactured from rags and waste materials containing wool. Cotton, and even silk, is found in some of them. (See also under Mungo, Shoddy, Extract Wool.)
text: ARTIFICIAL WOOL: Is really a recovered waste product, and has grown to an important branch of the textile industry. A large quantity of cheap suits are made from these yarns, of which there are several varieties, known as mungo, shoddy, extract wool, etc. They are manufactured from rags and waste materials containing wool. Cotton, and even silk, is found in some of them. (See also under Mungo, Shoddy, Extract Wool.)

Definition: is a mineral substance resisting the action of fire, and is the only mineral utilised commercially as a textile fibre. canadian asbestos is the most valuable for textile purposes, as it gives a curly fibre which is more easy to spin into threads than any other. it is a long, white, lustrous fibre, difficult to spin alone, so a little cotton is mixed with it, the cotton eventually being burnt away. used for making fireproof curtains, for packing purposes, gloves, clothing for firemen, and workers in furnaces, etc.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ASBESTOS (MOUNTAIN FLAX): Is a mineral substance resisting the action of fire, and is the only mineral utilised commercially as a textile fibre. Canadian asbestos is the most valuable for textile purposes, as it gives a curly fibre which is more easy to spin into threads than any other. It is a long, white, lustrous fibre, difficult to spin alone, so a little cotton is mixed with it, the cotton eventually being burnt away. Used for making fireproof curtains, for packing purposes, gloves, clothing for firemen, and workers in furnaces, etc.
text: ASBESTOS (MOUNTAIN FLAX): Is a mineral substance resisting the action of fire, and is the only mineral utilised commercially as a textile fibre. Canadian asbestos is the most valuable for textile purposes, as it gives a curly fibre which is more easy to spin into threads than any other. It is a long, white, lustrous fibre, difficult to spin alone, so a little cotton is mixed with it, the cotton eventually being burnt away. Used for making fireproof curtains, for packing purposes, gloves, clothing for firemen, and workers in furnaces, etc.

Definition: a fancy twill on 6 shafts, usually 31 inches, 100 yards, 56 ends, 200 picks, 16's warp, 28's weft. a very good velvet weft required, woven in a velvet loom. the rib stands up boldly, and a thick heavy cloth results.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ALBERT DIAGONAL: A fancy twill on 6 shafts, usually 31 inches, 100 yards, 56 ends, 200 picks, 16's warp, 28's weft. A very good velvet weft required, woven in a velvet loom. The rib stands up boldly, and a thick heavy cloth results.
text: ALBERT DIAGONAL: A fancy twill on 6 shafts, usually 31 inches, 100 yards, 56 ends, 200 picks, 16's warp, 28's weft. A very good velvet weft required, woven in a velvet loom. The rib stands up boldly, and a thick heavy cloth results.

Definition: a soft, curly, strong wool, obtained from a sheep reared in astrakhan, persia, and other asiatic districts. a cloth of silk and worsted, or all worsted, with a long loosely curled pile, and put on the market as an imitation of real astrakhan. mohair yarn is largely used. the mohair weft yarn is curled before using, which when cut (similar to velveteen) causes the free ends of the tufts to curl on the face of the cloth. sometimes the pile is left uncut. a good quality cloth is made 48 in. wide, 48 ends, 150 picks per inch, 2/30's cotton warp, one pick 24's cotton weft, and two picks 8's mohair. a knitted fabric is also on the market as an imitation astrakhan. this is the cheapest method, but does not give the same weight or wearing quality.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ASTRAKHAN: A soft, curly, strong wool, obtained from a sheep reared in Astrakhan, Persia, and other Asiatic districts. A cloth of silk and worsted, or all worsted, with a long loosely curled pile, and put on the market as an imitation of real astrakhan. Mohair yarn is largely used. The mohair weft yarn is curled before using, which when cut (similar to velveteen) causes the free ends of the tufts to curl on the face of the cloth. Sometimes the pile is left uncut. A good quality cloth is made 48 in. wide, 48 ends, 150 picks per inch, 2/30's cotton warp, one pick 24's cotton weft, and two picks 8's mohair. A knitted fabric is also on the market as an imitation astrakhan. This is the cheapest method, but does not give the same weight or wearing quality.
text: ASTRAKHAN: A soft, curly, strong wool, obtained from a sheep reared in Astrakhan, Persia, and other Asiatic districts. A cloth of silk and worsted, or all worsted, with a long loosely curled pile, and put on the market as an imitation of real astrakhan. Mohair yarn is largely used. The mohair weft yarn is curled before using, which when cut (similar to velveteen) causes the free ends of the tufts to curl on the face of the cloth. Sometimes the pile is left uncut. A good quality cloth is made 48 in. wide, 48 ends, 150 picks per inch, 2/30's cotton warp, one pick 24's cotton weft, and two picks 8's mohair. A knitted fabric is also on the market as an imitation astrakhan. This is the cheapest method, but does not give the same weight or wearing quality.

Definition: the german, dutch, russian, and danish name for the 5-end satin weave. also signifies a satin cloth. the term is used to indicate the satin ground weave used in damasks, thus:-the 5-end atlas is the ordinary 5-end satin, and so on to 16-end atlas.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ATLAS: The German, Dutch, Russian, and Danish name for the 5-end satin weave. Also signifies a satin cloth. The term is used to indicate the satin ground weave used in damasks, thus:-the 5-end atlas is the ordinary 5-end satin, and so on to 16-end atlas.
text: ATLAS: The German, Dutch, Russian, and Danish name for the 5-end satin weave. Also signifies a satin cloth. The term is used to indicate the satin ground weave used in damasks, thus:-the 5-end atlas is the ordinary 5-end satin, and so on to 16-end atlas.

Definition: heavy cloths used for shop blinds, garden tents and chairs, etc. widths vary from 26 inches up to 90 inches and over. weave generally plain or 2/1 twill. heavy yarns, 14's or 16's warp, 10's to 16's weft, in broad grey and colour stripes. colours fast red or blue.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: AWNINGS: Heavy cloths used for shop blinds, garden tents and chairs, etc. Widths vary from 26 inches up to 90 inches and over. Weave generally plain or 2/1 twill. Heavy yarns, 14's or 16's warp, 10's to 16's weft, in broad grey and colour stripes. Colours fast red or blue.
text: AWNINGS: Heavy cloths used for shop blinds, garden tents and chairs, etc. Widths vary from 26 inches up to 90 inches and over. Weave generally plain or 2/1 twill. Heavy yarns, 14's or 16's warp, 10's to 16's weft, in broad grey and colour stripes. Colours fast red or blue.

Definition: carpets made from hank-dyed yarn with a cut pile surface, and any number of colours can be used. generally woven in one piece to fit any size room, hall, or stairs. the genuine axminster" is an oriental fabric woven on a plain loom, and the tufts that form the pattern are produced by hand. made from linen or jute warp and binding weft, and wool pile weft, the pile being small tufts inserted singly. these carpets were first made in the town of axminster about 1755.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: AXMINSTERS, AXMINSTER CARPETS: Carpets made from hank-dyed yarn with a cut pile surface, and any number of colours can be used. Generally woven in one piece to fit any size room, hall, or stairs. The genuine Axminster" is an oriental fabric woven on a plain loom, and the tufts that form the pattern are produced by hand. Made from linen or jute warp and binding weft, and wool pile weft, the pile being small tufts inserted singly. These carpets were first made in the town of Axminster about 1755.
text: AXMINSTERS, AXMINSTER CARPETS: Carpets made from hank-dyed yarn with a cut pile surface, and any number of colours can be used. Generally woven in one piece to fit any size room, hall, or stairs. The genuine Axminster" is an oriental fabric woven on a plain loom, and the tufts that form the pattern are produced by hand. Made from linen or jute warp and binding weft, and wool pile weft, the pile being small tufts inserted singly. These carpets were first made in the town of Axminster about 1755.

Definition: a machine-made tufted-pile fabric, the tufts shewing on the surface above a foundation cloth. the tuft weft is a chenille, and is woven first, then cut. (see chenille.) this chenille weft is then inserted by hand, the weaver using a different shuttle for each colour. any number of colours can be used. the chenille is bound into the foundation cloth in several ways. warp may be linen or cotton. up to 12 weft threads per inch are made, with 2 to 4 picks of ground per chenille weft pick. the designs may repeat two or three times across the width, but usually extend the full length.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: AXMINSTER PATENT CARPETS: A machine-made tufted-pile fabric, the tufts shewing on the surface above a foundation cloth. The tuft weft is a chenille, and is woven first, then cut. (See Chenille.) This chenille weft is then inserted by hand, the weaver using a different shuttle for each colour. Any number of colours can be used. The chenille is bound into the foundation cloth in several ways. Warp may be linen or cotton. Up to 12 weft threads per inch are made, with 2 to 4 picks of ground per chenille weft pick. The designs may repeat two or three times across the width, but usually extend the full length.
text: AXMINSTER PATENT CARPETS: A machine-made tufted-pile fabric, the tufts shewing on the surface above a foundation cloth. The tuft weft is a chenille, and is woven first, then cut. (See Chenille.) This chenille weft is then inserted by hand, the weaver using a different shuttle for each colour. Any number of colours can be used. The chenille is bound into the foundation cloth in several ways. Warp may be linen or cotton. Up to 12 weft threads per inch are made, with 2 to 4 picks of ground per chenille weft pick. The designs may repeat two or three times across the width, but usually extend the full length.

Definition: is a chenille weft carpet woven on a patent loom known as the crompton loom, patented in america. it is a good imitation of the hand-woven carpet. this is the axminster carpet of commercial use.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: AXMINSTER ROYAL CARPET OR MOQUETTE: Is a chenille weft carpet woven on a patent loom known as the Crompton loom, patented in America. It is a good imitation of the hand-woven carpet. This is the Axminster carpet of commercial use.
text: AXMINSTER ROYAL CARPET OR MOQUETTE: Is a chenille weft carpet woven on a patent loom known as the Crompton loom, patented in America. It is a good imitation of the hand-woven carpet. This is the Axminster carpet of commercial use.

Definition: the underside of cloth as woven in the loom. some cloths are woven face down for ease in weaving, as, for instance, warp satins in which the lift is 4/1, by weaving face down only one thread is lifted and four remain down.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BACK: The underside of cloth as woven in the loom. Some cloths are woven face down for ease in weaving, as, for instance, warp satins in which the lift is 4/1, by weaving face down only one thread is lifted and four remain down.
text: BACK: The underside of cloth as woven in the loom. Some cloths are woven face down for ease in weaving, as, for instance, warp satins in which the lift is 4/1, by weaving face down only one thread is lifted and four remain down.

Definition: an unbleached all-cotton plain cloth, used as a re- inforcing cloth for calico printing to support the fabric being printed.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BACK CLOTH: An unbleached all-cotton plain cloth, used as a re- inforcing cloth for calico printing to support the fabric being printed.
text: BACK CLOTH: An unbleached all-cotton plain cloth, used as a re- inforcing cloth for calico printing to support the fabric being printed.

Definition: a single texture cloth with extra threads of either warp or weft, generally inferior in quality to the face yarns, and woven so as to shew only on the back. used to add weight to the fabric. this allows a cloth to have a fine face weave, and yet be any desired weight.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BACKED CLOTHS: A single texture cloth with extra threads of either warp or weft, generally inferior in quality to the face yarns, and woven so as to shew only on the back. Used to add weight to the fabric. This allows a cloth to have a fine face weave, and yet be any desired weight.
text: BACKED CLOTHS: A single texture cloth with extra threads of either warp or weft, generally inferior in quality to the face yarns, and woven so as to shew only on the back. Used to add weight to the fabric. This allows a cloth to have a fine face weave, and yet be any desired weight.

Definition: a system of finishing cloths without the finish appear- ing on the face. this is done on the " back-filling mangle, which lays the starch or other finish on one side only and protects the other side. cloths with a pattern such as piques, coloured stripes, etc., are finished this way to give firmness.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BACK-FILLED FINISH: A system of finishing cloths without the finish appear- ing on the face. This is done on the " back-filling mangle, which lays the starch or other finish on one side only and protects the other side. Cloths with a pattern such as piques, coloured stripes, etc., are finished this way to give firmness.
text: BACK-FILLED FINISH: A system of finishing cloths without the finish appear- ing on the face. This is done on the " back-filling mangle, which lays the starch or other finish on one side only and protects the other side. Cloths with a pattern such as piques, coloured stripes, etc., are finished this way to give firmness.

Definition: plain weave cloths, bleached or dyed blue. blue bafts is the west african term for this style, and are plain cloths dyed blue.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BAFFETAS: Plain weave cloths, bleached or dyed blue. Blue bafts is the West African term for this style, and are plain cloths dyed blue.
text: BAFFETAS: Plain weave cloths, bleached or dyed blue. Blue bafts is the West African term for this style, and are plain cloths dyed blue.

Definition: the south african term for a varied assortment of plain and simple fancy cloths. made up in 12 yard lengths.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BAFTAS: The South African term for a varied assortment of plain and simple fancy cloths. Made up in 12 yard lengths.
text: BAFTAS: The South African term for a varied assortment of plain and simple fancy cloths. Made up in 12 yard lengths.

Definition: the name originally applied on the west african coast to nearly all classes of plain and coloured goods when made up in short lengths of 6 yards, 8 yards, and upwards. the term is now usually used only for narrow grey cloths about 27 inches wide, 27 yards long, 60 x 64, 18's/24's, heavy sized, and shipped both loom state and finished.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BAFTS: The name originally applied on the West African coast to nearly all classes of plain and coloured goods when made up in short lengths of 6 yards, 8 yards, and upwards. The term is now usually used only for narrow grey cloths about 27 inches wide, 27 yards long, 60 x 64, 18's/24's, heavy sized, and shipped both loom state and finished.
text: BAFTS: The name originally applied on the West African coast to nearly all classes of plain and coloured goods when made up in short lengths of 6 yards, 8 yards, and upwards. The term is now usually used only for narrow grey cloths about 27 inches wide, 27 yards long, 60 x 64, 18's/24's, heavy sized, and shipped both loom state and finished.

Definition: see "ganny.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BAGS, GUNNY: See "Ganny.
text: BAGS, GUNNY: See "Ganny.

Definition: are all types of double cloths, usually woven with tappets similar to smalley's, or on a dobby loom. a special loom is now made for these fabrics. if one bag only is woven in the width 4 healds are required; if several in the width then 2 extra or 4 extra shafts would be needed to weave the plain between the bags. the warp requires special controlling, as greater ten- sion is necessary when the bottom of the bag is being woven. a pillow case cloth is made 108 ends, 4 in a dent, 120 picks, 24's warp, 16's weft. ends and picks are total of both folds.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BAGS, TUBULAR CLOTHS, POCKETS, PILLOW CASES: Are all types of double cloths, usually woven with tappets similar to Smalley's, or on a dobby loom. A special loom is now made for these fabrics. If one bag only is woven in the width 4 healds are required; if several in the width then 2 extra or 4 extra shafts would be needed to weave the plain between the bags. The warp requires special controlling, as greater ten- sion is necessary when the bottom of the bag is being woven. A pillow case cloth is made 108 ends, 4 in a dent, 120 picks, 24's warp, 16's weft. Ends and picks are total of both folds.
text: BAGS, TUBULAR CLOTHS, POCKETS, PILLOW CASES: Are all types of double cloths, usually woven with tappets similar to Smalley's, or on a dobby loom. A special loom is now made for these fabrics. If one bag only is woven in the width 4 healds are required; if several in the width then 2 extra or 4 extra shafts would be needed to weave the plain between the bags. The warp requires special controlling, as greater ten- sion is necessary when the bottom of the bag is being woven. A pillow case cloth is made 108 ends, 4 in a dent, 120 picks, 24's warp, 16's weft. Ends and picks are total of both folds.

Definition: a heavy woollen cloth made from coarse warp and weft and felted, usually dyed green or red, has a harsh feel, is loosely woven, with a long nap on both sides, and used for coverings for tables, screens, etc. 66 to 68 inches is the general width.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BAIZE: A heavy woollen cloth made from coarse warp and weft and felted, usually dyed green or red, has a harsh feel, is loosely woven, with a long nap on both sides, and used for coverings for tables, screens, etc. 66 to 68 inches is the general width.
text: BAIZE: A heavy woollen cloth made from coarse warp and weft and felted, usually dyed green or red, has a harsh feel, is loosely woven, with a long nap on both sides, and used for coverings for tables, screens, etc. 66 to 68 inches is the general width.

Definition: a cloth that contains the maximum number of ends and picks per inch of equal counts, such as aeroplane fabrics, where the greatest strength is a necessity.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BALANCED CLOTH: A cloth that contains the maximum number of ends and picks per inch of equal counts, such as aeroplane fabrics, where the greatest strength is a necessity.
text: BALANCED CLOTH: A cloth that contains the maximum number of ends and picks per inch of equal counts, such as aeroplane fabrics, where the greatest strength is a necessity.

Definition: a cotton hosiery style named after the town of that name in ireland, where it was first made. the name later was given to knitted underwear of similar quality. to-day it is applied to light-weight flat underwear made from yarn dyed a drab shade. on
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BALBRIGGAN: A cotton hosiery style named after the town of that name in Ireland, where it was first made. The name later was given to knitted underwear of similar quality. To-day it is applied to light-weight flat underwear made from yarn dyed a drab shade. on
text: BALBRIGGAN: A cotton hosiery style named after the town of that name in Ireland, where it was first made. The name later was given to knitted underwear of similar quality. To-day it is applied to light-weight flat underwear made from yarn dyed a drab shade. on

Definition: a package of raw cotton, weighing for american about 500 lb., egyptian 700 lb., brazilian 250 lb., and east indian 400 lb.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BALE, COTTON: A package of raw cotton, weighing for American about 500 lb., Egyptian 700 lb., Brazilian 250 lb., and East Indian 400 lb.
text: BALE, COTTON: A package of raw cotton, weighing for American about 500 lb., Egyptian 700 lb., Brazilian 250 lb., and East Indian 400 lb.

Definition: a coarse canvas fabric made from jute, flax, etc., yarns, and used for tailors' linings, upholstery coverings, etc.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BALINE: A coarse canvas fabric made from jute, flax, etc., yarns, and used for tailors' linings, upholstery coverings, etc.
text: BALINE: A coarse canvas fabric made from jute, flax, etc., yarns, and used for tailors' linings, upholstery coverings, etc.

Definition: coiling warp sections into balls. finished twine. winding thread into balling machine.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BALLING: Coiling warp sections into balls. finished twine. Winding thread into balling machine.
text: BALLING: Coiling warp sections into balls. finished twine. Winding thread into balling machine.

Definition: making balls of a balls on a special consists of three processes, sizing, drying, and beam- ing. used for coloured warps or for grey warps about 24's and lower that are to be heavy sized, such as for heavy domestics, wigans, etc. this system gives a leather-like feel to the yarn and cloth, and is much used in the rochdale district. the yarn is not flattened as it is in tape sizing. for coloured work it is very suitable, owing to the shorter length, various colours, etc.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BALL SIZING: Making balls of a balls on a special Consists of three processes, sizing, drying, and beam- ing. Used for coloured warps or for grey warps about 24's and lower that are to be heavy sized, such as for heavy domestics, Wigans, etc. This system gives a leather-like feel to the yarn and cloth, and is much used in the Rochdale district. The yarn is not flattened as it is in tape sizing. For coloured work it is very suitable, owing to the shorter length, various colours, etc.
text: BALL SIZING: Making balls of a balls on a special Consists of three processes, sizing, drying, and beam- ing. Used for coloured warps or for grey warps about 24's and lower that are to be heavy sized, such as for heavy domestics, Wigans, etc. This system gives a leather-like feel to the yarn and cloth, and is much used in the Rochdale district. The yarn is not flattened as it is in tape sizing. For coloured work it is very suitable, owing to the shorter length, various colours, etc.

Definition: the oldest system of warping, and not much used to-day. it is used for some coloured work, and where the warps are to be shipped or sold as ball warps. a number of threads are drawn from the warper's bobbins and gathered into a form of rope of untwisted strands. this can be done direct from the bobbins on the old-fashioned warping mill, or from sections from the sectional warper.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BALL WARPING: The oldest system of warping, and not much used to-day. It is used for some coloured work, and where the warps are to be shipped or sold as ball warps. A number of threads are drawn from the warper's bobbins and gathered into a form of rope of untwisted strands. This can be done direct from the bobbins on the old-fashioned warping mill, or from sections from the sectional warper.
text: BALL WARPING: The oldest system of warping, and not much used to-day. It is used for some coloured work, and where the warps are to be shipped or sold as ball warps. A number of threads are drawn from the warper's bobbins and gathered into a form of rope of untwisted strands. This can be done direct from the bobbins on the old-fashioned warping mill, or from sections from the sectional warper.

Definition: a cotton fabric produced by a jacquard with gauze combined with figuring.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BALZARINE BROCADES: A cotton fabric produced by a jacquard with gauze combined with figuring.
text: BALZARINE BROCADES: A cotton fabric produced by a jacquard with gauze combined with figuring.

Definition: this is a waste weft cloth made in the rawtenstall and rochdale districts. widths about 50 in. to 54 in. finished. lengths 10 and 6 yards. designs all blue and white stripes. finished with a stiff finish to weigh about 32 lb. for 53 in. 10 yards (56 in. soft). a popular cloth is 56 in., 100 yards (soft), 48 √ó 40 per inch, 30's/8's conden- ser. the twist is heavily sized. ends per inch vary from 48 to 56, and picks from 36 to 44. twist nearly always 30's, and weft 7's, 8's, or 9's. the colour is indigo blue.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BANDA STRIPES: This is a waste weft cloth made in the Rawtenstall and Rochdale districts. Widths about 50 in. to 54 in. finished. Lengths 10 and 6 yards. Designs all blue and white stripes. Finished with a stiff finish to weigh about 32 lb. for 53 in. 10 yards (56 in. soft). A popular cloth is 56 in., 100 yards (soft), 48 √ó 40 per inch, 30's/8's conden- ser. The twist is heavily sized. Ends per inch vary from 48 to 56, and picks from 36 to 44. Twist nearly always 30's, and weft 7's, 8's, or 9's. The colour is indigo blue.
text: BANDA STRIPES: This is a waste weft cloth made in the Rawtenstall and Rochdale districts. Widths about 50 in. to 54 in. finished. Lengths 10 and 6 yards. Designs all blue and white stripes. Finished with a stiff finish to weigh about 32 lb. for 53 in. 10 yards (56 in. soft). A popular cloth is 56 in., 100 yards (soft), 48 √ó 40 per inch, 30's/8's conden- ser. The twist is heavily sized. Ends per inch vary from 48 to 56, and picks from 36 to 44. Twist nearly always 30's, and weft 7's, 8's, or 9's. The colour is indigo blue.

Definition: originated in india as bright coloured handkerchiefs of silk and cotton with spots in white on coloured grounds, chiefly red and blue. the silk styles were made of the finest quality yarns, and were very popular. bandanna prints for clothing were first produced in glasgow from cotton yarns, and are now made in many qualities. the term, at present, generally means a fabric in printed styles, whether silk, silk and cotton, or all cotton.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BANDANNA: Originated in India as bright coloured handkerchiefs of silk and cotton with spots in white on coloured grounds, chiefly red and blue. The silk styles were made of the finest quality yarns, and were very popular. Bandanna prints for clothing were first produced in Glasgow from cotton yarns, and are now made in many qualities. The term, at present, generally means a fabric in printed styles, whether silk, silk and cotton, or all cotton.
text: BANDANNA: Originated in India as bright coloured handkerchiefs of silk and cotton with spots in white on coloured grounds, chiefly red and blue. The silk styles were made of the finest quality yarns, and were very popular. Bandanna prints for clothing were first produced in Glasgow from cotton yarns, and are now made in many qualities. The term, at present, generally means a fabric in printed styles, whether silk, silk and cotton, or all cotton.

Definition: a very heavy fustian cloth of cotton from about 14's warp, 10's weft. pattern on 12 ends, 12 picks; stitching ends are used. going out of favour owing to its weight.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BANG-UP-CORD: A very heavy fustian cloth of cotton from about 14's warp, 10's weft. Pattern on 12 ends, 12 picks; stitching ends are used. Going out of favour owing to its weight.
text: BANG-UP-CORD: A very heavy fustian cloth of cotton from about 14's warp, 10's weft. Pattern on 12 ends, 12 picks; stitching ends are used. Going out of favour owing to its weight.

Definition: the original name of american cotton, which was first introduced into america from the islands of the barbadoes group. it grows freely in the west indies, and gives a long staple fibre, is silky, fair colour, and fine quality.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BARBADOES COTTON: The original name of American cotton, which was first introduced into America from the islands of the Barbadoes group. It grows freely in the West Indies, and gives a long staple fibre, is silky, fair colour, and fine quality.
text: BARBADOES COTTON: The original name of American cotton, which was first introduced into America from the islands of the Barbadoes group. It grows freely in the West Indies, and gives a long staple fibre, is silky, fair colour, and fine quality.

Definition: a style of matt weave, giving small geometrical figures, on 6√ó6, 6√ó8, 8√ó8 ends and picks. much used as ground weaves, because they give a firmness to the cloth.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BARLEY-CORN WEAVES: A style of matt weave, giving small geometrical figures, on 6√ó6, 6√ó8, 8√ó8 ends and picks. Much used as ground weaves, because they give a firmness to the cloth.
text: BARLEY-CORN WEAVES: A style of matt weave, giving small geometrical figures, on 6√ó6, 6√ó8, 8√ó8 ends and picks. Much used as ground weaves, because they give a firmness to the cloth.

Definition: a coarse linen fabric similar to sack cloth; first pro- duced in holland. not much used to-day.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BARRAS, DUTCH BARRAS: A coarse linen fabric similar to sack cloth; first pro- duced in Holland. Not much used to-day.
text: BARRAS, DUTCH BARRAS: A coarse linen fabric similar to sack cloth; first pro- duced in Holland. Not much used to-day.

Definition: a cross-over stripe cloth with stripes formed by wefts from selvedge to selvedge. either woven or printed.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BARRE, BARRI: A cross-over stripe cloth with stripes formed by wefts from selvedge to selvedge. Either woven or printed.
text: BARRE, BARRI: A cross-over stripe cloth with stripes formed by wefts from selvedge to selvedge. Either woven or printed.

Definition: a mixture cloth of silk warp and wool weft with an open or gauze weave. chiefly used as head coverings in religious ceremonies. imitated recently with cotton warps.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BARREGE: A mixture cloth of silk warp and wool weft with an open or gauze weave. Chiefly used as head coverings in religious ceremonies. Imitated recently with cotton warps.
text: BARREGE: A mixture cloth of silk warp and wool weft with an open or gauze weave. Chiefly used as head coverings in religious ceremonies. Imitated recently with cotton warps.

Definition: are reeds not in general use, and are made to give odd numbers of ends per inch, such as 69 and 71. much used in the nelson district for sateens.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BASTARD REEDS: Are reeds not in general use, and are made to give odd numbers of ends per inch, such as 69 and 71. Much used in the Nelson district for sateens.
text: BASTARD REEDS: Are reeds not in general use, and are made to give odd numbers of ends per inch, such as 69 and 71. Much used in the Nelson district for sateens.

Definition: hand-made fabrics from williamsbridge, new york. not often seen in england.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BAUMGARTEN TAPESTRIES: Hand-made fabrics from Williamsbridge, New York. Not often seen in England.
text: BAUMGARTEN TAPESTRIES: Hand-made fabrics from Williamsbridge, New York. Not often seen in England.

Definition: a cotton fabric of the fancy matt style, with 2, 3, or 4 ends and picks working together of heavy yarns. an average cloth is made 42 in., 48 ends, 34 picks per inch, 2/20's warp, 8's weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BASKET CLOTH: A cotton fabric of the fancy matt style, with 2, 3, or 4 ends and picks working together of heavy yarns. An average cloth is made 42 in., 48 ends, 34 picks per inch, 2/20's warp, 8's weft.
text: BASKET CLOTH: A cotton fabric of the fancy matt style, with 2, 3, or 4 ends and picks working together of heavy yarns. An average cloth is made 42 in., 48 ends, 34 picks per inch, 2/20's warp, 8's weft.

Definition: an extension of the plain weave, both in the length and width, and giving a matt weave; also known as hopsack weave.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BASKET WEAVES: An extension of the plain weave, both in the length and width, and giving a matt weave; also known as hopsack weave.
text: BASKET WEAVES: An extension of the plain weave, both in the length and width, and giving a matt weave; also known as hopsack weave.

Definition: the fibres obtained from the inner bark of flax, hemp, jute, ramie, and other plants and shrubs.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BAST FIBRES: The fibres obtained from the inner bark of flax, hemp, jute, ramie, and other plants and shrubs.
text: BAST FIBRES: The fibres obtained from the inner bark of flax, hemp, jute, ramie, and other plants and shrubs.

Definition: is a cloth of french origin. the term is now applied to a light swiss finished cloth, made from ecru coloured yarns when cotton, and grey yarns when flax is used. it is very fine in quality, and as many as 15 yards of 32 in. cloth are required to weigh 1 lb. 80's to 100's warp and 100's to 160's weft are used in the cotton variety. a wool bastiste is also made. same as barr√©.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BAYADERE- BASTISTE, BATISTE: Is a cloth of French origin. The term is now applied to a light Swiss finished cloth, made from ecru coloured yarns when cotton, and grey yarns when flax is used. It is very fine in quality, and as many as 15 yards of 32 in. cloth are required to weigh 1 lb. 80's to 100's warp and 100's to 160's weft are used in the cotton variety. A wool bastiste is also made. Same as Barr√©.
text: BAYADERE- BASTISTE, BATISTE: Is a cloth of French origin. The term is now applied to a light Swiss finished cloth, made from ecru coloured yarns when cotton, and grey yarns when flax is used.
