A wool bastiste is also made. Same as Barr√©.

Definition: the bayeaux tapestry is an historic fabric, supposed to have been the work of matilda, wife of the conqueror, and of which a photograph can be seen in the kensington museum. the term is applied to tapestries of present-day make which are similar in colouring to the historic one.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BAYEAUX TAPESTRY: The Bayeaux Tapestry is an historic fabric, supposed to have been the work of Matilda, wife of the Conqueror, and of which a photograph can be seen in the Kensington Museum. The term is applied to tapestries of present-day make which are similar in colouring to the historic one.
text: BAYEAUX TAPESTRY: The Bayeaux Tapestry is an historic fabric, supposed to have been the work of Matilda, wife of the Conqueror, and of which a photograph can be seen in the Kensington Museum. The term is applied to tapestries of present-day make which are similar in colouring to the historic one.

Definition: the spanish name for baize, which see.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BAYETAS: The Spanish name for baize, which see.
text: BAYETAS: The Spanish name for baize, which see.

Definition: a cloth very similar to baize, but lighter. this is an old-time name.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BAYS: A cloth very similar to baize, but lighter. This is an old-time name.
text: BAYS: A cloth very similar to baize, but lighter. This is an old-time name.

Definition: warp beam: the roller upon which the warp yarn is wound, and fitted in the loom at the back. cloth beam: a roller fitted in the front of the loom, upon which the cloth is wound when weaving. breast beam: is a bar fixed in front of the loom with the purpose of acting as a guide for the cloth on to the cloth beam. back beam: is a fixed bar at the back of the loom, which guides the yarn from the warp beam to the healds.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BEAM: Warp Beam: The roller upon which the warp yarn is wound, and fitted in the loom at the back. Cloth Beam: A roller fitted in the front of the loom, upon which the cloth is wound when weaving. Breast Beam: Is a bar fixed in front of the loom with the purpose of acting as a guide for the cloth on to the cloth beam. Back Beam: Is a fixed bar at the back of the loom, which guides the yarn from the warp beam to the healds.
text: BEAM: Warp Beam: The roller upon which the warp yarn is wound, and fitted in the loom at the back. Cloth Beam: A roller fitted in the front of the loom, upon which the cloth is wound when weaving. Breast Beam: Is a bar fixed in front of the loom with the purpose of acting as a guide for the cloth on to the cloth beam. Back Beam: Is a fixed bar at the back of the loom, which guides the yarn from the warp beam to the healds.

Definition: the process of putting warp yarn on a beam. one of the most important operations in weaving, and yet one of the simplest. after spinning the yarn the spinner puts it on a beam when required for warps, and this is his last operation. beams must be well made and tight. very faulty cloth results if the yarn does not come off the beam regularly.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BEAMING: The process of putting warp yarn on a beam. One of the most important operations in weaving, and yet one of the simplest. After spinning the yarn the spinner puts it on a beam when required for warps, and this is his last operation. Beams must be well made and tight. Very faulty cloth results if the yarn does not come off the beam regularly.
text: BEAMING: The process of putting warp yarn on a beam. One of the most important operations in weaving, and yet one of the simplest. After spinning the yarn the spinner puts it on a beam when required for warps, and this is his last operation. Beams must be well made and tight. Very faulty cloth results if the yarn does not come off the beam regularly.

Definition: the transferring of yarn from warper's bobbins on to a large flanged beam in the form of a wide sheet. used when preparing back beams for sizing on the slasher when several beams are run together. each beam contains up to 500 threads with a length of 15,000 yards or more. if four beams are used of 500 threads then 4 √ó 500 = 2,000 threads or ends on the weaver's or back beam. this is termed a "" set." beam warping is also used for making beams of simple stripes in coloured work.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BEAM WARPING: The transferring of yarn from warper's bobbins on to a large flanged beam in the form of a wide sheet. Used when preparing back beams for sizing on the slasher when several beams are run together. Each beam contains up to 500 threads with a length of 15,000 yards or more. If four beams are used of 500 threads then 4 √ó 500 = 2,000 threads or ends on the weaver's or back beam. This is termed a "" set." Beam warping is also used for making beams of simple stripes in coloured work.
text: BEAM WARPING: The transferring of yarn from warper's bobbins on to a large flanged beam in the form of a wide sheet. Used when preparing back beams for sizing on the slasher when several beams are run together. Each beam contains up to 500 threads with a length of 15,000 yards or more. If four beams are used of 500 threads then 4 √ó 500 = 2,000 threads or ends on the weaver's or back beam. This is termed a "" set." Beam warping is also used for making beams of simple stripes in coloured work.

Definition: the third primary movement of the loom when making cloth, and is the action of the reed as it drives each pick of weft to the fell of the cloth. the three primary movements are shedding, picking, and beating-up.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BEATING-UP: The third primary movement of the loom when making cloth, and is the action of the reed as it drives each pick of weft to the fell of the cloth. The three primary movements are shedding, picking, and beating-up.
text: BEATING-UP: The third primary movement of the loom when making cloth, and is the action of the reed as it drives each pick of weft to the fell of the cloth. The three primary movements are shedding, picking, and beating-up.

Definition: american terms for an overcoating cloth of shaggy face. it is not applied to any particular cloth.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BEARSKIN, DREADNAUGHT, FEARNAUGHT: American terms for an overcoating cloth of shaggy face. It is not applied to any particular cloth.
text: BEARSKIN, DREADNAUGHT, FEARNAUGHT: American terms for an overcoating cloth of shaggy face. It is not applied to any particular cloth.

Definition: a 5-shaft twill weave cloth with a weft face used for both shipping and home trade as a lining, generally dyed in black. 56 in. 90 yds. (ls), 72 ends, 120 picks, 36's/34's twist way super weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BEATRICE TWILL: A 5-shaft twill weave cloth with a weft face used for both shipping and home trade as a lining, generally dyed in black. 56 in. 90 yds. (LS), 72 ends, 120 picks, 36's/34's twist way super weft.
text: BEATRICE TWILL: A 5-shaft twill weave cloth with a weft face used for both shipping and home trade as a lining, generally dyed in black. 56 in. 90 yds. (LS), 72 ends, 120 picks, 36's/34's twist way super weft.

Definition: an overcoating cloth with one face sheared, heavily milled, and nap raised finish. it has a soft handle, and made of fine grade wool as an imitation of beaver's fur. now used for making hats.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BEAVER OR CASTOR: An overcoating cloth with one face sheared, heavily milled, and nap raised finish. It has a soft handle, and made of fine grade wool as an imitation of beaver's fur. Now used for making hats.
text: BEAVER OR CASTOR: An overcoating cloth with one face sheared, heavily milled, and nap raised finish. It has a soft handle, and made of fine grade wool as an imitation of beaver's fur. Now used for making hats.

Definition: a heavy twill, all cotton, of about 2/16's or 2/18's warp, and 14's to 16's weft. of the fustian variety, with an uncut pile, dyed tan or light brown shades, has a short nap, and designed to stand hard wear as clothing. usually woven 3 face to 1 back picks.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BEAVERTEEN: A heavy twill, all cotton, of about 2/16's or 2/18's warp, and 14's to 16's weft. Of the fustian variety, with an uncut pile, dyed tan or light brown shades, has a short nap, and designed to stand hard wear as clothing. Usually woven 3 face to 1 back picks.
text: BEAVERTEEN: A heavy twill, all cotton, of about 2/16's or 2/18's warp, and 14's to 16's weft. Of the fustian variety, with an uncut pile, dyed tan or light brown shades, has a short nap, and designed to stand hard wear as clothing. Usually woven 3 face to 1 back picks.

Definition: fabrics having cords or ribs in the direction of the warp, produced by interweaving the weft in plain or twill order, with alternate groups of warp threads. the ribs may be emphasised by the addition of wadding or stuffing warp threads. generally woven in dobby looms. all cotton, all wool, or mixed.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BEDFORD CORDS: Fabrics having cords or ribs in the direction of the warp, produced by interweaving the weft in plain or twill order, with alternate groups of warp threads. The ribs may be emphasised by the addition of wadding or stuffing warp threads. Generally woven in dobby looms. All cotton, all wool, or mixed.
text: BEDFORD CORDS: Fabrics having cords or ribs in the direction of the warp, produced by interweaving the weft in plain or twill order, with alternate groups of warp threads. The ribs may be emphasised by the addition of wadding or stuffing warp threads. Generally woven in dobby looms. All cotton, all wool, or mixed.

Definition: a term denoting 40 threads of warp drawn in 20 dents of the reed. a warp is said to consist of so many beers.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BEER (BIER): A term denoting 40 threads of warp drawn in 20 dents of the reed. A warp is said to consist of so many beers.
text: BEER (BIER): A term denoting 40 threads of warp drawn in 20 dents of the reed. A warp is said to consist of so many beers.

Definition: a machine employed to give the "beetle finish" to cloths by delivering a rapid succession of blows from wooden hammers upon the cloth wound upon rollers or cylinders.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BEETLE, BEETLING MACHINE: A machine employed to give the "Beetle Finish" to cloths by delivering a rapid succession of blows from wooden hammers upon the cloth wound upon rollers or cylinders.
text: BEETLE, BEETLING MACHINE: A machine employed to give the "Beetle Finish" to cloths by delivering a rapid succession of blows from wooden hammers upon the cloth wound upon rollers or cylinders.

Definition: the american term for a dress fabric made from a print or grandrelle yarn. a dress fabric, twill weave, made of fibres dyed before spinning. different coloured fibres may be mixed, result- ing in a mottled yarn.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BEIGE: The American term for a dress fabric made from a print or grandrelle yarn. A dress fabric, twill weave, made of fibres dyed before spinning. Different coloured fibres may be mixed, result- ing in a mottled yarn.
text: BEIGE: The American term for a dress fabric made from a print or grandrelle yarn. A dress fabric, twill weave, made of fibres dyed before spinning. Different coloured fibres may be mixed, result- ing in a mottled yarn.

Definition: a silk fabric with cords across the piece as in a poplin. the cords are of wool, cotton, or silk. if all silk, known as bengaline de soie. a cotton bengaline is made of all cotton, with a 2/60's warp and 6's or 8's weft. mercerised finish.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BENGALINE: A silk fabric with cords across the piece as in a poplin. The cords are of wool, cotton, or silk. If all silk, known as Bengaline de Soie. A cotton bengaline is made of all cotton, with a 2/60's warp and 6's or 8's weft. Mercerised finish.
text: BENGALINE: A silk fabric with cords across the piece as in a poplin. The cords are of wool, cotton, or silk. If all silk, known as Bengaline de Soie. A cotton bengaline is made of all cotton, with a 2/60's warp and 6's or 8's weft. Mercerised finish.

Definition: all cotton cloth, matting weave, white and blue stripes, usually bleached yarns, and the cloth soft finished. 34 in. to 36 in. wide, and made up to 10 or 12 yard ends. 60 ends, 36 picks, 24's white, 4 ends, 20's opal blue per inch, 14's or 16's weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BENGAL STRIPES: All cotton cloth, matting weave, white and blue stripes, usually bleached yarns, and the cloth soft finished. 34 in. to 36 in. wide, and made up to 10 or 12 yard ends. 60 ends, 36 picks, 24's white, 4 ends, 20's opal blue per inch, 14's or 16's weft.
text: BENGAL STRIPES: All cotton cloth, matting weave, white and blue stripes, usually bleached yarns, and the cloth soft finished. 34 in. to 36 in. wide, and made up to 10 or 12 yard ends. 60 ends, 36 picks, 24's white, 4 ends, 20's opal blue per inch, 14's or 16's weft.

Definition: a cheap tapestry fabric from italy, with a cotton or flax warp and goat's weft, or mixed weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BERGAMOT: A cheap tapestry fabric from Italy, with a cotton or flax warp and goat's weft, or mixed weft.
text: BERGAMOT: A cheap tapestry fabric from Italy, with a cotton or flax warp and goat's weft, or mixed weft.

Definition: a swiss muslin fabric woven from bleached yarns with an openwork design formed by empty dents in the reed. sometimes figured or ornamented by colour yarns. largely shipped to the philippines in 21 in. to 41 in. widths.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BETILLES: A Swiss muslin fabric woven from bleached yarns with an openwork design formed by empty dents in the reed. Sometimes figured or ornamented by colour yarns. Largely shipped to the Philippines in 21 in. to 41 in. widths.
text: BETILLES: A Swiss muslin fabric woven from bleached yarns with an openwork design formed by empty dents in the reed. Sometimes figured or ornamented by colour yarns. Largely shipped to the Philippines in 21 in. to 41 in. widths.

Definition: a variety of cotton grown in italy from american seed.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BIANCAVILLE COTTON: A variety of cotton grown in Italy from American seed.
text: BIANCAVILLE COTTON: A variety of cotton grown in Italy from American seed.

Definition: a reversible woollen cloth with a weft cord stripe and warp repp. the weave is a weft float over 4 warp ends, and each alternate stripe bound plain on the face, the other being bound on the back.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BIARRITZ CLOTH: A reversible woollen cloth with a weft cord stripe and warp repp. The weave is a weft float over 4 warp ends, and each alternate stripe bound plain on the face, the other being bound on the back.
text: BIARRITZ CLOTH: A reversible woollen cloth with a weft cord stripe and warp repp. The weave is a weft float over 4 warp ends, and each alternate stripe bound plain on the face, the other being bound on the back.

Definition: the best quality of felt made, and has a soft, smooth, and elastic surface. owing to its excellent quality, the temperature variations do not change its firmness. generally fast dyed green.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BILLIARD CLOTH OR FELT: The best quality of felt made, and has a soft, smooth, and elastic surface. Owing to its excellent quality, the temperature variations do not change its firmness. Generally fast dyed green.
text: BILLIARD CLOTH OR FELT: The best quality of felt made, and has a soft, smooth, and elastic surface. Owing to its excellent quality, the temperature variations do not change its firmness. Generally fast dyed green.

Definition: the back warp of double cloths. the interior warp of pile fabrics, used to bind the pile threads together.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BINDER, OR BINDING WARP: The back warp of double cloths. The interior warp of pile fabrics, used to bind the pile threads together.
text: BINDER, OR BINDING WARP: The back warp of double cloths. The interior warp of pile fabrics, used to bind the pile threads together.

Definition: bookbinders' cloth of muslin character, dyed, and embossed. very stiffly finished.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BINDING CLOTHS: Bookbinders' cloth of muslin character, dyed, and embossed. Very stiffly finished.
text: BINDING CLOTHS: Bookbinders' cloth of muslin character, dyed, and embossed. Very stiffly finished.

Definition: a small design based on the diamond principle, with a small dot in the centre of each figure. used for dobby and jacquard effects as a ground weave.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BIRD'S-EYE PATTERN: A small design based on the diamond principle, with a small dot in the centre of each figure. Used for dobby and jacquard effects as a ground weave.
text: BIRD'S-EYE PATTERN: A small design based on the diamond principle, with a small dot in the centre of each figure. Used for dobby and jacquard effects as a ground weave.

Definition: a swiss finished light muslin of a weight greater than ordinary mulls. it is really a heavy mull.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BISHOP'S LAWN: A Swiss finished light muslin of a weight greater than ordinary mulls. It is really a heavy mull.
text: BISHOP'S LAWN: A Swiss finished light muslin of a weight greater than ordinary mulls. It is really a heavy mull.

Definition: plain or twill weave cotton cloths, 60 inches and upwards in width, and 80 inches and upwards in length. made from coarse yarns. very coarse reeds are used. a soft spun coarse weft from 1's to 8's counts is usual; sometimes a bump yarn weft. special shuttles are required to take the large or "jumbo' cops. coloured weft headings are put in at each end. the fabrics are raised on both sides by passing several times through the raising machine.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BLANKETS (COTTON): Plain or twill weave cotton cloths, 60 inches and upwards in width, and 80 inches and upwards in length. Made from coarse yarns. Very coarse reeds are used. A soft spun coarse weft from 1's to 8's counts is usual; sometimes a bump yarn weft. Special shuttles are required to take the large or "jumbo' cops. Coloured weft headings are put in at each end. The fabrics are raised on both sides by passing several times through the raising machine.
text: BLANKETS (COTTON): Plain or twill weave cotton cloths, 60 inches and upwards in width, and 80 inches and upwards in length. Made from coarse yarns. Very coarse reeds are used. A soft spun coarse weft from 1's to 8's counts is usual; sometimes a bump yarn weft. Special shuttles are required to take the large or "jumbo' cops. Coloured weft headings are put in at each end. The fabrics are raised on both sides by passing several times through the raising machine.

Definition: the ordinary 2/2 twill, and is probably the commonest weave used in the woollen trade. it is known under other names in various districts, such as serge, cassimere, shalloon, two-and-two twill.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BLANKET TWILL: The ordinary 2/2 twill, and is probably the commonest weave used in the woollen trade. It is known under other names in various districts, such as serge, cassimere, shalloon, two-and-two twill.
text: BLANKET TWILL: The ordinary 2/2 twill, and is probably the commonest weave used in the woollen trade. It is known under other names in various districts, such as serge, cassimere, shalloon, two-and-two twill.

Definition: the series of operations through which grey cloths pass in order to whiten them. in the early history of bleaching the process was carried out in open fields, and it was only possible to bleach fabrics in the summer months. all fibres have some colour, and to obtain a pure white cloth this natural colouring matter has to be bleached out.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BLEACHING: The series of operations through which grey cloths pass in order to whiten them. In the early history of bleaching the process was carried out in open fields, and it was only possible to bleach fabrics in the summer months. All fibres have some colour, and to obtain a pure white cloth this natural colouring matter has to be bleached out.
text: BLEACHING: The series of operations through which grey cloths pass in order to whiten them. In the early history of bleaching the process was carried out in open fields, and it was only possible to bleach fabrics in the summer months. All fibres have some colour, and to obtain a pure white cloth this natural colouring matter has to be bleached out.

Definition: a plain weave cloth made from coloured yarns in large check designs with a loose dyed yarn overchecking. during the finishing process this loose dye bleeds off and tints the fabric.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BLEEDING CHECKS: A plain weave cloth made from coloured yarns in large check designs with a loose dyed yarn overchecking. During the finishing process this loose dye bleeds off and tints the fabric.
text: BLEEDING CHECKS: A plain weave cloth made from coloured yarns in large check designs with a loose dyed yarn overchecking. During the finishing process this loose dye bleeds off and tints the fabric.

Definition: a 4/2 twill weave used in the making of whipcord fabrics. the firm of messrs. w. bliss and sons introduced the weave.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BLISS TWILL: A 4/2 twill weave used in the making of whipcord fabrics. The firm of Messrs. W. Bliss and Sons introduced the weave.
text: BLISS TWILL: A 4/2 twill weave used in the making of whipcord fabrics. The firm of Messrs. W. Bliss and Sons introduced the weave.

Definition: a process of printing fabrics by hand with the aid of wooden blocks. the pattern is either engraved on the wood or built up by means of copper wire. the cloth is stretched over a firm level table, generally of stone, and the block dipped into colour and then impressed upon the cloth. each colour requires a separate block.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BLOCK PRINTING: A process of printing fabrics by hand with the aid of wooden blocks. The pattern is either engraved on the wood or built up by means of copper wire. The cloth is stretched over a firm level table, generally of stone, and the block dipped into colour and then impressed upon the cloth. Each colour requires a separate block.
text: BLOCK PRINTING: A process of printing fabrics by hand with the aid of wooden blocks. The pattern is either engraved on the wood or built up by means of copper wire. The cloth is stretched over a firm level table, generally of stone, and the block dipped into colour and then impressed upon the cloth. Each colour requires a separate block.

Definition: a favourite and old pattern, very popular among the better class of west arfican natives for dress purposes. the design effect is obtained from a printed warp, and looks as if a large quantity of deep blue ink has been splashed on it in big blotches. the checking is 2 white, 2 blue, the warp also being 2 blue and 2 white. a good quality is 30 in., 20 yards, 9's blue, 40's white warps, 11's blue, 32's white wefts. usual 3 green, 1 red heading each end. finished stiff finish. made in radcliffe and rochdale.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BLOTCH CHECKS: A favourite and old pattern, very popular among the better class of West Arfican natives for dress purposes. The design effect is obtained from a printed warp, and looks as if a large quantity of deep blue ink has been splashed on it in big blotches. The checking is 2 white, 2 blue, the warp also being 2 blue and 2 white. A good quality is 30 in., 20 yards, 9's blue, 40's white warps, 11's blue, 32's white wefts. Usual 3 green, 1 red heading each end. Finished stiff finish. Made in Radcliffe and Rochdale.
text: BLOTCH CHECKS: A favourite and old pattern, very popular among the better class of West Arfican natives for dress purposes. The design effect is obtained from a printed warp, and looks as if a large quantity of deep blue ink has been splashed on it in big blotches. The checking is 2 white, 2 blue, the warp also being 2 blue and 2 white. A good quality is 30 in., 20 yards, 9's blue, 40's white warps, 11's blue, 32's white wefts. Usual 3 green, 1 red heading each end. Finished stiff finish. Made in Radcliffe and Rochdale.

Definition: a heavy cloth used for overalls woven in the 2 x 1 twill weave from dyed warp and weft yarns, narrow widths. a sample cloth is 28 in. wide, 68 ends 52 picks, 20's warp 20's weft. b1
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BLUE DUNGAREE: A heavy cloth used for overalls woven in the 2 x 1 twill weave from dyed warp and weft yarns, narrow widths. A sample cloth is 28 in. wide, 68 ends 52 picks, 20's warp 20's weft. B1
text: BLUE DUNGAREE: A heavy cloth used for overalls woven in the 2 x 1 twill weave from dyed warp and weft yarns, narrow widths. A sample cloth is 28 in. wide, 68 ends 52 picks, 20's warp 20's weft. B1

Definition: a much used term indicating that a cloth is hard and boardy to the feel. it is only found in heavy sized or finished fabrics, and is directly opposite to a clothy feel.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BOARDY FEEL: A much used term indicating that a cloth is hard and boardy to the feel. It is only found in heavy sized or finished fabrics, and is directly opposite to a clothy feel.
text: BOARDY FEEL: A much used term indicating that a cloth is hard and boardy to the feel. It is only found in heavy sized or finished fabrics, and is directly opposite to a clothy feel.

Definition: a machine-made cotton lace net produced by the bobbinet frame. heathcote, about the year 1809, seems to be the first inventor of this frame, which has since had many improvements, though the principle remains.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BOBBINET (BOBBIN-NET): A machine-made cotton lace net produced by the bobbinet frame. Heathcote, about the year 1809, seems to be the first inventor of this frame, which has since had many improvements, though the principle remains.
text: BOBBINET (BOBBIN-NET): A machine-made cotton lace net produced by the bobbinet frame. Heathcote, about the year 1809, seems to be the first inventor of this frame, which has since had many improvements, though the principle remains.

Definition: the american term for the brussels carpet in which the worsted yarn is woven through the body of the fabric from back to front, and is actually a compound part of the cloth. in england the carpet is known simply as brussels carpet." "6
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BODY BRUSSELS CARPETS: The American term for the Brussels carpet in which the worsted yarn is woven through the body of the fabric from back to front, and is actually a compound part of the cloth. In England the carpet is known simply as Brussels carpet." "6
text: BODY BRUSSELS CARPETS: The American term for the Brussels carpet in which the worsted yarn is woven through the body of the fabric from back to front, and is actually a compound part of the cloth. In England the carpet is known simply as Brussels carpet." "6

Definition: silk which has had the natural gum removed by boil- ing in soap solution.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BOILED-OFF SILK: Silk which has had the natural gum removed by boil- ing in soap solution.
text: BOILED-OFF SILK: Silk which has had the natural gum removed by boil- ing in soap solution.

Definition: a coarse cotton grown in turkestan and other districts of central asia. it is principally used locally.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BOKHARA COTTON: A coarse cotton grown in Turkestan and other districts of Central Asia. It is principally used locally.
text: BOKHARA COTTON: A coarse cotton grown in Turkestan and other districts of Central Asia. It is principally used locally.

Definition: a black fabric, first made in norwich 450 years ago and used for mourning. it is now made from a silk warp and worsted weft in a fine open twill weave.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BOMBAZINE: A black fabric, first made in Norwich 450 years ago and used for mourning. It is now made from a silk warp and worsted weft in a fine open twill weave.
text: BOMBAZINE: A black fabric, first made in Norwich 450 years ago and used for mourning. It is now made from a silk warp and worsted weft in a fine open twill weave.

Definition: a finisher's term to indicate that the cloth has to be folded in such a way as to open like a book from the centre, with the folds resembling the leaves of a book.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BOOK-FOLD: A finisher's term to indicate that the cloth has to be folded in such a way as to open like a book from the centre, with the folds resembling the leaves of a book.
text: BOOK-FOLD: A finisher's term to indicate that the cloth has to be folded in such a way as to open like a book from the centre, with the folds resembling the leaves of a book.

Definition: a very light cotton fabric of gauze weave, one end crossing one. stiff finished. used as binding cloths by bookbinders, also as linings for cheap clothing. the term is also applied to a coarse leno cloth shipped to india, about 35 inches wide, 10 yards long, 36 x 28 per inch, from 32's/16's, and bleached and finished stiffly.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BOOK MUSLIN: A very light cotton fabric of gauze weave, one end crossing one. Stiff finished. Used as binding cloths by bookbinders, also as linings for cheap clothing. The term is also applied to a coarse leno cloth shipped to India, about 35 inches wide, 10 yards long, 36 x 28 per inch, from 32's/16's, and bleached and finished stiffly.
text: BOOK MUSLIN: A very light cotton fabric of gauze weave, one end crossing one. Stiff finished. Used as binding cloths by bookbinders, also as linings for cheap clothing. The term is also applied to a coarse leno cloth shipped to India, about 35 inches wide, 10 yards long, 36 x 28 per inch, from 32's/16's, and bleached and finished stiffly.

Definition: a matting cloth made from bleached yarn with a red stripe of 2 ends colour every half inch. usually 36 inches 6 yards, 72 x 32, 20's/16's. firmly finished, and shipped to south america.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BORNEO STRIPES: A matting cloth made from bleached yarn with a red stripe of 2 ends colour every half inch. Usually 36 inches 6 yards, 72 x 32, 20's/16's. Firmly finished, and shipped to South America.
text: BORNEO STRIPES: A matting cloth made from bleached yarn with a red stripe of 2 ends colour every half inch. Usually 36 inches 6 yards, 72 x 32, 20's/16's. Firmly finished, and shipped to South America.

Definition: the finest of worsted yarns, and used for the best fabrics. a term applied to fine australian wools of best quality.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BOTANY: The finest of worsted yarns, and used for the best fabrics. A term applied to fine Australian wools of best quality.
text: BOTANY: The finest of worsted yarns, and used for the best fabrics. A term applied to fine Australian wools of best quality.

Definition: an imitation astrakhan or cloth having knots, loops, or curls on the surface.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BOUCLE: An imitation astrakhan or cloth having knots, loops, or curls on the surface.
text: BOUCLE: An imitation astrakhan or cloth having knots, loops, or curls on the surface.

Definition: an ancient term used for silk brocades in the persian trade. rarely used to-day.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BOUDEKIN OR BOLDEKIN: An ancient term used for silk brocades in the Persian trade. Rarely used to-day.
text: BOUDEKIN OR BOLDEKIN: An ancient term used for silk brocades in the Persian trade. Rarely used to-day.

Definition: a dress material in which a rough surface is produced by using lumpy knotted yarns. the roughness is in the warp only, and thus forms stripes.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BOURETTE: A dress material in which a rough surface is produced by using lumpy knotted yarns. The roughness is in the warp only, and thus forms stripes.
text: BOURETTE: A dress material in which a rough surface is produced by using lumpy knotted yarns. The roughness is in the warp only, and thus forms stripes.

Definition: is uplands cotton from georgia, virginia, and alabama. principally used for a good type of weft yarn from 30's to 40's. usually very clean.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BOWEDS COTTON: Is Uplands cotton from Georgia, Virginia, and Alabama. Principally used for a good type of weft yarn from 30's to 40's. Usually very clean.
text: BOWEDS COTTON: Is Uplands cotton from Georgia, Virginia, and Alabama. Principally used for a good type of weft yarn from 30's to 40's. Usually very clean.

Definition: is a harsh, wiry cotton, and used for mixing with certain wools for the hosiery trade.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BRAZILIAN COTTON: Is a harsh, wiry cotton, and used for mixing with certain wools for the hosiery trade.
text: BRAZILIAN COTTON: Is a harsh, wiry cotton, and used for mixing with certain wools for the hosiery trade.

Definition: a honeycomb effect formed from a diamond style of weave of a more complex form than honeycombs. they are not reversible. the smallest pattern is on 8√ó8 ends and picks, and as many as 16 ends and picks are used.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BRIGHTON WEAVES: A honeycomb effect formed from a diamond style of weave of a more complex form than honeycombs. They are not reversible. The smallest pattern is on 8√ó8 ends and picks, and as many as 16 ends and picks are used.
text: BRIGHTON WEAVES: A honeycomb effect formed from a diamond style of weave of a more complex form than honeycombs. They are not reversible. The smallest pattern is on 8√ó8 ends and picks, and as many as 16 ends and picks are used.

Definition: originally a brocade with a soft finish, made from cotton yarns. to-day they are also made in dobby looms. the designs are simple spot effects. the cloth is bleached or dyed. a large quantity is shipped to egypt, india, and other eastern markets. 28 to 30 inches wide, 14 lb. for 105 yards, 56 ends, 52 picks, 36's warp, 24's weft, 12 to 14 staves.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BRILLIANTE: Originally a brocade with a soft finish, made from cotton yarns. To-day they are also made in dobby looms. The designs are simple spot effects. The cloth is bleached or dyed. A large quantity is shipped to Egypt, India, and other Eastern markets. 28 to 30 inches wide, 14 lb. for 105 yards, 56 ends, 52 picks, 36's warp, 24's weft, 12 to 14 staves.
text: BRILLIANTE: Originally a brocade with a soft finish, made from cotton yarns. To-day they are also made in dobby looms. The designs are simple spot effects. The cloth is bleached or dyed. A large quantity is shipped to Egypt, India, and other Eastern markets. 28 to 30 inches wide, 14 lb. for 105 yards, 56 ends, 52 picks, 36's warp, 24's weft, 12 to 14 staves.

Definition: a dress cloth of cotton warp and lustre worsted weft; about 24's cotton, 24's worsted. generally of a plain weave, but jacquard designs are sometimes used. a soft calender finish is put on the cloth.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BRILLIANTINE: A dress cloth of cotton warp and lustre worsted weft; about 24's cotton, 24's worsted. Generally of a plain weave, but jacquard designs are sometimes used. A soft calender finish is put on the cloth.
text: BRILLIANTINE: A dress cloth of cotton warp and lustre worsted weft; about 24's cotton, 24's worsted. Generally of a plain weave, but jacquard designs are sometimes used. A soft calender finish is put on the cloth.

Definition: a finish for muslin, jaconets, etc., and is a special one to keep the fabric soft and clothy, leaving yarns round. drying is done on stenters, and the cloth moving all the time.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BRISE OR ELASTIC FINISH: A finish for muslin, jaconets, etc., and is a special one to keep the fabric soft and clothy, leaving yarns round. Drying is done on stenters, and the cloth moving all the time.
text: BRISE OR ELASTIC FINISH: A finish for muslin, jaconets, etc., and is a special one to keep the fabric soft and clothy, leaving yarns round. Drying is done on stenters, and the cloth moving all the time.

Definition: an indian variety, with a fairly white and good staple. one of the best produced in india. has a soft fibre, and is best used for 14's and coarser warp yarns, and 22's and coarser weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BROACH COTTON: An Indian variety, with a fairly white and good staple. One of the best produced in India. Has a soft fibre, and is best used for 14's and coarser warp yarns, and 22's and coarser weft.
text: BROACH COTTON: An Indian variety, with a fairly white and good staple. One of the best produced in India. Has a soft fibre, and is best used for 14's and coarser warp yarns, and 22's and coarser weft.

Definition: a term that in many districts was used to indicate garments worn by the clergy. it is a stout wool cloth, very soft and silky, and has an even nappy satin finish. twill or plain weave, wider than 27 inches, and fine reed and pick. dyed good black or indigo.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BROADCLOTH: A term that in many districts was used to indicate garments worn by the clergy. It is a stout wool cloth, very soft and silky, and has an even nappy satin finish. Twill or plain weave, wider than 27 inches, and fine reed and pick. Dyed good black or indigo.
text: BROADCLOTH: A term that in many districts was used to indicate garments worn by the clergy. It is a stout wool cloth, very soft and silky, and has an even nappy satin finish. Twill or plain weave, wider than 27 inches, and fine reed and pick. Dyed good black or indigo.

Definition: originally meant a silk cloth with figuring threads of gold and silver. at the present time it indicates a figured fabric of single texture, with the figure developed or bound in a more or less irregular order, and the ground formed by a weave of a simple character. cotton brocades have only one warp and one weft. silk and upholstery brocades may have several wefts of different colours. name is derived from the spanish "brocade" (to figure).
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BROCADES: Originally meant a silk cloth with figuring threads of gold and silver. At the present time it indicates a figured fabric of single texture, with the figure developed or bound in a more or less irregular order, and the ground formed by a weave of a simple character. Cotton brocades have only one warp and one weft. Silk and upholstery brocades may have several wefts of different colours. Name is derived from the Spanish "brocade" (to figure).
text: BROCADES: Originally meant a silk cloth with figuring threads of gold and silver. At the present time it indicates a figured fabric of single texture, with the figure developed or bound in a more or less irregular order, and the ground formed by a weave of a simple character. Cotton brocades have only one warp and one weft. Silk and upholstery brocades may have several wefts of different colours. Name is derived from the Spanish "brocade" (to figure).

Definition: a heavy cloth used as a tapestry. it has a rich coloured raised figure of silk warp and weft interwoven satin order on a ground fabric formed by a linen weft and a special binder warp. the term is also applied to a quilt made with a coarse weft and two warps of different colours. the warps change places to make the figure.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BROCATELLE: A heavy cloth used as a tapestry. It has a rich coloured raised figure of silk warp and weft interwoven satin order on a ground fabric formed by a linen weft and a special binder warp. The term is also applied to a quilt made with a coarse weft and two warps of different colours. The warps change places to make the figure.
text: BROCATELLE: A heavy cloth used as a tapestry. It has a rich coloured raised figure of silk warp and weft interwoven satin order on a ground fabric formed by a linen weft and a special binder warp. The term is also applied to a quilt made with a coarse weft and two warps of different colours. The warps change places to make the figure.

Definition: the french word for brocade. a loom embroidered fabric with swivel figuring.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BROCH√â: The French word for brocade. A loom embroidered fabric with swivel figuring.
text: BROCH√â: The French word for brocade. A loom embroidered fabric with swivel figuring.

Definition: this is a cloth with a jacquard figure on a satin ground.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BROCH√â SATIN: This is a cloth with a jacquard figure on a satin ground.
text: BROCH√â SATIN: This is a cloth with a jacquard figure on a satin ground.

Definition: a weaving fault caused by threads of warp breaking whilst in the loom. this is a serious defect when the cloth has a pattern or when coloured ends are used.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BROKEN ENDS: A weaving fault caused by threads of warp breaking whilst in the loom. This is a serious defect when the cloth has a pattern or when coloured ends are used.
text: BROKEN ENDS: A weaving fault caused by threads of warp breaking whilst in the loom. This is a serious defect when the cloth has a pattern or when coloured ends are used.

Definition: a term applied to sateens made so that the weave effect is broken up. the face is broken by using weft- way weft, and having the twill to the right, or by using tw weft and twill to left.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BROKEN FACE: A term applied to sateens made so that the weave effect is broken up. The face is broken by using weft- way weft, and having the twill to the right, or by using TW weft and twill to left.
text: BROKEN FACE: A term applied to sateens made so that the weave effect is broken up. The face is broken by using weft- way weft, and having the twill to the right, or by using TW weft and twill to left.

Definition: caused by the weft breaking as the shuttle passes through the shed, or by the shuttle running to the last few feet of weft. weavers by finding the pick can remedy this fault.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BROKEN PICKS: Caused by the weft breaking as the shuttle passes through the shed, or by the shuttle running to the last few feet of weft. Weavers by finding the pick can remedy this fault.
text: BROKEN PICKS: Caused by the weft breaking as the shuttle passes through the shed, or by the shuttle running to the last few feet of weft. Weavers by finding the pick can remedy this fault.

Definition: the sateen weave with the twill reversed.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BROKEN SATEEN: The sateen weave with the twill reversed.
text: BROKEN SATEEN: The sateen weave with the twill reversed.

Definition: a weave in which the twill line is broken by a devia- tion from a regular step, as in the satin weave.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BROKEN TWILL: A weave in which the twill line is broken by a devia- tion from a regular step, as in the satin weave.
text: BROKEN TWILL: A weave in which the twill line is broken by a devia- tion from a regular step, as in the satin weave.

Definition: plain grey cloths, unfinished, of all weights, and 30 inches wide and upwards. a general term.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BROWN SHEETING: Plain grey cloths, unfinished, of all weights, and 30 inches wide and upwards. A general term.
text: BROWN SHEETING: Plain grey cloths, unfinished, of all weights, and 30 inches wide and upwards. A general term.

Definition: plain grey cotton cloths, 26 to 40 inches wide, sized warps, and in all weights. a general term.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BROWN SHIRTING: Plain grey cotton cloths, 26 to 40 inches wide, sized warps, and in all weights. A general term.
text: BROWN SHIRTING: Plain grey cotton cloths, 26 to 40 inches wide, sized warps, and in all weights. A general term.

Definition: uncut pile fabrics, in which the worsted yarn used forms part of the fabric itself as well as figure, and is woven through the cloth from back to face. these carpets are known as 3-frame, 4-frame. 5-frame, etc., carpets. each frame has a capacity of 256 bobbins of one colour, so in a 5-frame fabric there are five colours, and in each dent of the reed there are five pile threads and two ground threads. the 5-frame brussels thus means five colours are used for figuring. round wires are used (up to nine per inch) to form the pile, and these are withdrawn from the side of the cloth.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BRUSSELS CARPETS: Uncut pile fabrics, in which the worsted yarn used forms part of the fabric itself as well as figure, and is woven through the cloth from back to face. These carpets are known as 3-frame, 4-frame. 5-frame, etc., carpets. Each frame has a capacity of 256 bobbins of one colour, so in a 5-frame fabric there are five colours, and in each dent of the reed there are five pile threads and two ground threads. The 5-frame Brussels thus means five colours are used for figuring. Round wires are used (up to nine per inch) to form the pile, and these are withdrawn from the side of the cloth.
text: BRUSSELS CARPETS: Uncut pile fabrics, in which the worsted yarn used forms part of the fabric itself as well as figure, and is woven through the cloth from back to face. These carpets are known as 3-frame, 4-frame. 5-frame, etc., carpets. Each frame has a capacity of 256 bobbins of one colour, so in a 5-frame fabric there are five colours, and in each dent of the reed there are five pile threads and two ground threads. The 5-frame Brussels thus means five colours are used for figuring. Round wires are used (up to nine per inch) to form the pile, and these are withdrawn from the side of the cloth.

Definition: the 8-end sateen weave, but each warp end is lifted for two picks instead of one.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BUCKSKIN WEAVE: The 8-end sateen weave, but each warp end is lifted for two picks instead of one.
text: BUCKSKIN WEAVE: The 8-end sateen weave, but each warp end is lifted for two picks instead of one.

Definition: a a strong linen cloth, plain weave, stiffened with flour paste, china clay, and glue. a very low open tex- ture cotton cloth used for hat linings, and is very heavily finished. about 42 inches wide, 14 ends, 14 picks per inch, 8's warp, 12's weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BUCKRAM: a A strong linen cloth, plain weave, stiffened with flour paste, china clay, and glue. A very low open tex- ture cotton cloth used for hat linings, and is very heavily finished. About 42 inches wide, 14 ends, 14 picks per inch, 8's warp, 12's weft.
text: BUCKRAM: a A strong linen cloth, plain weave, stiffened with flour paste, china clay, and glue. A very low open tex- ture cotton cloth used for hat linings, and is very heavily finished. About 42 inches wide, 14 ends, 14 picks per inch, 8's warp, 12's weft.

Definition: a fine cotton sarong with one border. two pieces are usually sewn together, giving a double width cloth with borders at each selvedge.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BUGIS: A fine cotton sarong with one border. Two pieces are usually sewn together, giving a double width cloth with borders at each selvedge.
text: BUGIS: A fine cotton sarong with one border. Two pieces are usually sewn together, giving a double width cloth with borders at each selvedge.

Definition: a very heavy cotton fabric woven on fustian looms. it has a warp face with a twill weave. each warp end floats over six picks. the cloth is pile finished. much used for cheap hats.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BULL-HIDE, OR REFORMER: A very heavy cotton fabric woven on fustian looms. It has a warp face with a twill weave. Each warp end floats over six picks. The cloth is pile finished. Much used for cheap hats.
text: BULL-HIDE, OR REFORMER: A very heavy cotton fabric woven on fustian looms. It has a warp face with a twill weave. Each warp end floats over six picks. The cloth is pile finished. Much used for cheap hats.

Definition: cotton yarns below 4's counts, that is, where less than 4√ó 840 3,360 yards to go to make a pound. the counts are denoted by the number of yards per ounce. thus, 60- yards per ounce = 60's bump.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BUMP YARNS: Cotton yarns below 4's counts, that is, where less than 4√ó 840 3,360 yards to go to make a pound. The counts are denoted by the number of yards per ounce. Thus, 60- yards per ounce = 60's bump.
text: BUMP YARNS: Cotton yarns below 4's counts, that is, where less than 4√ó 840 3,360 yards to go to make a pound. The counts are denoted by the number of yards per ounce. Thus, 60- yards per ounce = 60's bump.

Definition: a local name in scotland, and indicates a scotch- woven shawl. the term is often applied to fabrics imita- ting the real article.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BUNGOES: A local name in Scotland, and indicates a Scotch- woven shawl. The term is often applied to fabrics imita- ting the real article.
text: BUNGOES: A local name in Scotland, and indicates a Scotch- woven shawl. The term is often applied to fabrics imita- ting the real article.

Definition: a plain, loose, even thread weave of mohair wool, and used for flags. the fabric dyes with brilliant effects. the cotton bunting is a low make of cloth from poor yarns, and is an entirely wrong term.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BUNTING: A plain, loose, even thread weave of mohair wool, and used for flags. The fabric dyes with brilliant effects. The cotton bunting is a low make of cloth from poor yarns, and is an entirely wrong term.
text: BUNTING: A plain, loose, even thread weave of mohair wool, and used for flags. The fabric dyes with brilliant effects. The cotton bunting is a low make of cloth from poor yarns, and is an entirely wrong term.

Definition: the trade name for a sack cloth of oriental character.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BURLINGHAM: The trade name for a sack cloth of Oriental character.
text: BURLINGHAM: The trade name for a sack cloth of Oriental character.

Definition: a plain, coarse, heavy yarn cloth, used for wrappers and upholstery. generally made from jute, hemp, or flax yarns.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BURLAPS: A plain, coarse, heavy yarn cloth, used for wrappers and upholstery. Generally made from jute, hemp, or flax yarns.
text: BURLAPS: A plain, coarse, heavy yarn cloth, used for wrappers and upholstery. Generally made from jute, hemp, or flax yarns.

Definition: a plain weave cotton cloth for printing. also shipped grey to many markets. burnley printers are not con- sidered of as good yarns or make as cheshire printers. the cheshire makers generally spin their own yarns, which are of the counts desired, and give the actual reed and pick. burnley makers do not spin, but may buy any yarn; thus a character is not given to their cloths. standard burnley cloth is 32 inches, 116 yards/l.s., 64 √ó 64, 36/38. a
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BURNLEY PRINTERS: A plain weave cotton cloth for printing. Also shipped grey to many markets. Burnley printers are not con- sidered of as good yarns or make as Cheshire printers. The Cheshire makers generally spin their own yarns, which are of the counts desired, and give the actual reed and pick. Burnley makers do not spin, but may buy any yarn; thus a character is not given to their cloths. standard Burnley cloth is 32 inches, 116 yards/L.S., 64 √ó 64, 36/38. A
text: BURNLEY PRINTERS: A plain weave cotton cloth for printing. Also shipped grey to many markets. Burnley printers are not con- sidered of as good yarns or make as Cheshire printers. The Cheshire makers generally spin their own yarns, which are of the counts desired, and give the actual reed and pick. Burnley makers do not spin, but may buy any yarn; thus a character is not given to their cloths. standard Burnley cloth is 32 inches, 116 yards/L.S., 64 √ó 64, 36/38. A

Definition: a coarse, heavy, plain weave cloth of linen.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: BUTCHER'S LINEN: A coarse, heavy, plain weave cloth of linen.
text: BUTCHER'S LINEN: A coarse, heavy, plain weave cloth of linen.

Definition: by this term is meant the redoubling of doubled threads. in a 6-cord yarn three twofold threads will be doubled or cabled together. the 6-cord yarn could be made by using six single threads, but the resulting cabled yarn would not be as satisfactory as when twofold threads are used.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CABLED YARNS: By this term is meant the redoubling of doubled threads. In a 6-cord yarn three twofold threads will be doubled or cabled together. The 6-cord yarn could be made by using six single threads, but the resulting cabled yarn would not be as satisfactory as when twofold threads are used.
text: CABLED YARNS: By this term is meant the redoubling of doubled threads. In a 6-cord yarn three twofold threads will be doubled or cabled together. The 6-cord yarn could be made by using six single threads, but the resulting cabled yarn would not be as satisfactory as when twofold threads are used.

Definition: a coarse plain weave grey cloth, usually 30 to 32 inches wide, 40 yards long, 48 ends, 40 picks, 20's/22's, 12 lb. yarns, ends, and picks vary. the cloth is shipped grey to the levant. generally heavily sized warp is used. the american manufacturers make a similar cloth in 36 inches, 40 yards, and ship it as ‚äúamerican sheeting" to china and other markets.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CABOTS: A coarse plain weave grey cloth, usually 30 to 32 inches wide, 40 yards long, 48 ends, 40 picks, 20's/22's, 12 lb. Yarns, ends, and picks vary. The cloth is shipped grey to the Levant. Generally heavily sized warp is used. The American manufacturers make a similar cloth in 36 inches, 40 yards, and ship it as ‚ÄúAmerican sheeting" to China and other markets.
text: CABOTS: A coarse plain weave grey cloth, usually 30 to 32 inches wide, 40 yards long, 48 ends, 40 picks, 20's/22's, 12 lb. Yarns, ends, and picks vary. The cloth is shipped grey to the Levant. Generally heavily sized warp is used. The American manufacturers make a similar cloth in 36 inches, 40 yards, and ship it as ‚ÄúAmerican sheeting" to China and other markets.

Definition: the finishing of cloth by means of heated rollers- the cloth being under pressure between the rollers or bowls. the heat is applied by gas or steam. the number of bowls varies according to the kind of finish required, such as dull, glazed, watered, moire, etc.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CALENDERING: The finishing of cloth by means of heated rollers- the cloth being under pressure between the rollers or bowls. The heat is applied by gas or steam. The number of bowls varies according to the kind of finish required, such as dull, glazed, watered, moire, etc.
text: CALENDERING: The finishing of cloth by means of heated rollers- the cloth being under pressure between the rollers or bowls. The heat is applied by gas or steam. The number of bowls varies according to the kind of finish required, such as dull, glazed, watered, moire, etc.

Definition: in lancashire this name is applied generally to any plain weave cloth coarser than muslin. originally meant a printed cotton cloth. the name came from calicut (india), where the art of colour print- ing was first practised. printed calicoes now generally pass under the name of chintz.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CALICO: In Lancashire this name is applied generally to any plain weave cloth coarser than muslin. Originally meant a printed cotton cloth. The name came from Calicut (India), where the art of colour print- ing was first practised. Printed calicoes now generally pass under the name of chintz.
text: CALICO: In Lancashire this name is applied generally to any plain weave cloth coarser than muslin. Originally meant a printed cotton cloth. The name came from Calicut (India), where the art of colour print- ing was first practised. Printed calicoes now generally pass under the name of chintz.

Definition: a plain weave back; also known as tabby-back."
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CALICO-BACK: A plain weave back; also known as tabby-back."
text: CALICO-BACK: A plain weave back; also known as tabby-back."

Definition: plain weave fabrics, printed or bleached, and intended for shirts.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CALICO SHIRTING: Plain weave fabrics, printed or bleached, and intended for shirts.
text: CALICO SHIRTING: Plain weave fabrics, printed or bleached, and intended for shirts.

Definition: highly glazed cloth with broad coloured stripes, plain weave, usually 25 inches wide, and used for skirtings.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CALIMANCOES: Highly glazed cloth with broad coloured stripes, plain weave, usually 25 inches wide, and used for skirtings.
text: CALIMANCOES: Highly glazed cloth with broad coloured stripes, plain weave, usually 25 inches wide, and used for skirtings.

Definition: a light plain cloth, fine reed, pick, and yarns, such as 100 √ó 80, 60's/80's. both american and egyptian yarns are used. it is difficult to say where a muslin ends and a cambric begins because of their great similarity. cambric originally meant a fine linen cloth.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CAMBRIC: A light plain cloth, fine reed, pick, and yarns, such as 100 √ó 80, 60's/80's. Both American and Egyptian yarns are used. It is difficult to say where a muslin ends and a cambric begins because of their great similarity. Cambric originally meant a fine linen cloth.
text: CAMBRIC: A light plain cloth, fine reed, pick, and yarns, such as 100 √ó 80, 60's/80's. Both American and Egyptian yarns are used. It is difficult to say where a muslin ends and a cambric begins because of their great similarity. Cambric originally meant a fine linen cloth.

Definition: a very fine fabric, without any weaving faults, used for neckties and scarves.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CAMBRIC (FRENCH): A very fine fabric, without any weaving faults, used for neckties and scarves.
text: CAMBRIC (FRENCH): A very fine fabric, without any weaving faults, used for neckties and scarves.

Definition: a true cambric, being an all-linen fabric, plain weave. used for underclothing and many dress purposes.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CAMBRIC (IRISH): A true cambric, being an all-linen fabric, plain weave. Used for underclothing and many dress purposes.
text: CAMBRIC (IRISH): A true cambric, being an all-linen fabric, plain weave. Used for underclothing and many dress purposes.

Definition: a soft finished fabric used for dress linings in various colours and weights.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CAMBRIC (KID-FINISHED): A soft finished fabric used for dress linings in various colours and weights.
text: CAMBRIC (KID-FINISHED): A soft finished fabric used for dress linings in various colours and weights.

Definition: the soft downy hair from the haunches and under part of the camel.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CAMEL'S HAIR: The soft downy hair from the haunches and under part of the camel.
text: CAMEL'S HAIR: The soft downy hair from the haunches and under part of the camel.

Definition: a fine thin plain weave cloth, woven from camlet yarns, 30 inches, 60 yards, usually dyed bright red. cam- let yarn is spun from lustrous wool, lincoln or leicester. the dutch introduced the cloth, but they used camel hair.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CAMLET: A fine thin plain weave cloth, woven from camlet yarns, 30 inches, 60 yards, usually dyed bright red. Cam- let yarn is spun from lustrous wool, Lincoln or Leicester. The Dutch introduced the cloth, but they used camel hair.
text: CAMLET: A fine thin plain weave cloth, woven from camlet yarns, 30 inches, 60 yards, usually dyed bright red. Cam- let yarn is spun from lustrous wool, Lincoln or Leicester. The Dutch introduced the cloth, but they used camel hair.

Definition: a weave largely used in the woollen trade on 8 ends and 8 picks.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CAMPBELL TWILL, ALSO CALLED MAYO TWILL: A weave largely used in the woollen trade on 8 ends and 8 picks.
text: CAMPBELL TWILL, ALSO CALLED MAYO TWILL: A weave largely used in the woollen trade on 8 ends and 8 picks.

Definition: a curl wool fabric, introduced by the french, giving an effect somewhat similar to the caniche (french poodle).
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CANICHE: A curl wool fabric, introduced by the French, giving an effect somewhat similar to the caniche (French poodle).
text: CANICHE: A curl wool fabric, introduced by the French, giving an effect somewhat similar to the caniche (French poodle).

Definition: a fine corded dress cloth similar to poplins. italian make, about 50 inches wide, and shipped to india.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CANNETTE: A fine corded dress cloth similar to poplins. Italian make, about 50 inches wide, and shipped to India.
text: CANNETTE: A fine corded dress cloth similar to poplins. Italian make, about 50 inches wide, and shipped to India.

Definition: a strong twill cloth, all cotton, grey or bleached, and raised on one side. about 27 to 30 inches wide, and dyed bright colours. the heavier make is the 2-and-2 twill, and the lighter one 2-and-1 twill. it was first shipped to can- ton, whence it got its name.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CANTON: A strong twill cloth, all cotton, grey or bleached, and raised on one side. About 27 to 30 inches wide, and dyed bright colours. The heavier make is the 2-and-2 twill, and the lighter one 2-and-1 twill. It was first shipped to Can- ton, whence it got its name.
text: CANTON: A strong twill cloth, all cotton, grey or bleached, and raised on one side. About 27 to 30 inches wide, and dyed bright colours. The heavier make is the 2-and-2 twill, and the lighter one 2-and-1 twill. It was first shipped to Can- ton, whence it got its name.

Definition: a very strong fustian woven to give a bold cord on the face and a satin on the back. about 54 ends of 2/16's or 2/20's, and 400 picks, 28's to 36's weft; all cotton. much used for hangings, riding, and sporting garments.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CANTOON: A very strong fustian woven to give a bold cord on the face and a satin on the back. About 54 ends of 2/16's or 2/20's, and 400 picks, 28's to 36's weft; all cotton. Much used for hangings, riding, and sporting garments.
text: CANTOON: A very strong fustian woven to give a bold cord on the face and a satin on the back. About 54 ends of 2/16's or 2/20's, and 400 picks, 28's to 36's weft; all cotton. Much used for hangings, riding, and sporting garments.

Definition: the principal there are many fabrics termed canvas. kinds are:- cloths for embroidering, which are very strong, plain weave, from 2, 3, or 4 fold yarns, and a more or less open plain weave. java canvas is a fabric made from hard twist yarns (both warp and weft) and a mock leno weave. a canvas which is shipped grey or finished, and made from coarse yarns, hard twist, about 8's warp, 12's weft, 40 ends, 34 picks, in widths 26 to 32 inches in plain weave. sail canvas is a stout built cloth from two-fold linen warp and coarse cotton weft. a dress canvas woven from linen warp and cotton weft, such as 60's linen and 32's cotton, 74 ends, 76 picks, 39 inches wide. dyed in many colours.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CANVAS: The principal There are many fabrics termed canvas. kinds are:- Cloths for embroidering, which are very strong, plain weave, from 2, 3, or 4 fold yarns, and a more or less open plain weave. Java canvas is a fabric made from hard twist yarns (both warp and weft) and a mock leno weave. A canvas which is shipped grey or finished, and made from coarse yarns, hard twist, about 8's warp, 12's weft, 40 ends, 34 picks, in widths 26 to 32 inches in plain weave. Sail canvas is a stout built cloth from two-fold linen warp and coarse cotton weft. A dress canvas woven from linen warp and cotton weft, such as 60's linen and 32's cotton, 74 ends, 76 picks, 39 inches wide. Dyed in many colours.

Sail canvas is a stout built cloth from two-fold linen warp and coarse cotton weft. A dress canvas woven from linen warp and cotton weft, such as 60's linen and 32's cotton, 74 ends, 76 picks, 39 inches wide. Dyed in many colours.

Definition: a process to remove burrs and vegetable matter from woollen cloths. it is a combination of heat and sulphuric acid.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CARBONISING: A process to remove burrs and vegetable matter from woollen cloths. It is a combination of heat and sulphuric acid.
text: CARBONISING: A process to remove burrs and vegetable matter from woollen cloths. It is a combination of heat and sulphuric acid.

Definition: a very thorough opening-out and separating of the fibres of cotton, together with an effective cleaning. upon the work done by the carder depends the success of the future operations in the making of cloth. this opening and cleaning of the cotton can be so well done by the carding machine that it suffices for all classes of yarn except the very highest quality.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CARDING: A very thorough opening-out and separating of the fibres of cotton, together with an effective cleaning. Upon the work done by the carder depends the success of the future operations in the making of cloth. This opening and cleaning of the cotton can be so well done by the carding machine that it suffices for all classes of yarn except the very highest quality.
text: CARDING: A very thorough opening-out and separating of the fibres of cotton, together with an effective cleaning. Upon the work done by the carder depends the success of the future operations in the making of cloth. This opening and cleaning of the cotton can be so well done by the carding machine that it suffices for all classes of yarn except the very highest quality.

Definition: a check or plaid gingham, about 24 inches wide, 19 yards long, 60 x 44, 22's/26's. shipped to india. print yarn is used in some qualities.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CARRANCLANES: A check or plaid gingham, about 24 inches wide, 19 yards long, 60 x 44, 22's/26's. Shipped to India. Print yarn is used in some qualities.
text: CARRANCLANES: A check or plaid gingham, about 24 inches wide, 19 yards long, 60 x 44, 22's/26's. Shipped to India. Print yarn is used in some qualities.

Definition: a plain weave fabric used for casement window cur- tains, usually white or cream, made from good quality yarns, well woven, mercerised finish. standard qualities are:-40 inches, 120 yards, 48 x 60, 32/18, 29 ƒ∫b.; 48¬ω inches, 120 yards, 50 √ó 92, 28/24, 41 lb. always woven one end in a dent. the 48¬ω inch cloth is a dress casement, and in this quality mohair, alpaca, or super cotton wefts are variously used. these are dyed in many colours.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CASEMENT: A plain weave fabric used for casement window cur- tains, usually white or cream, made from good quality yarns, well woven, mercerised finish. Standard qualities are:-40 inches, 120 yards, 48 x 60, 32/18, 29 ƒ∫b.; 48¬Ω inches, 120 yards, 50 √ó 92, 28/24, 41 lb. Always woven one end in a dent. The 48¬Ω inch cloth is a dress casement, and in this quality mohair, alpaca, or super cotton wefts are variously used. These are dyed in many colours.

Definition: a large trade is done in cotton cashmeres, which are generally dyed black, although colours are sometimes shewn. the following are standard makes:-56 inches full, 90 yards, 52 x 140, 36's/28's, 43 lb.; 41 inches full, 90 yards, 80 √ó 104, 36's/40's, 22¬ω lb.; 32¬ω inches full, 90 yards, 78 √ó 114, 32's/28's, 25 lb. the weave is 2x1 twill, and super weft is used. another cashmere is made with a cotton warp, which is printed before weaving, and either cotton or wool weft. used for dress purposes. the name is obtained from the cashmere goat, whose wool was first used to make cashmeres. this wool cash- mere is still made in yorkshire.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CASHMERE: A large trade is done in cotton cashmeres, which are generally dyed black, although colours are sometimes shewn. The following are standard makes:-56 inches full, 90 yards, 52 x 140, 36's/28's, 43 lb.; 41 inches full, 90 yards, 80 √ó 104, 36's/40's, 22¬Ω lb.; 32¬Ω inches full, 90 yards, 78 √ó 114, 32's/28's, 25 lb. The weave is 2x1 twill, and super weft is used. Another cashmere is made with a cotton warp, which is printed before weaving, and either cotton or wool weft. Used for dress purposes. The name is obtained from the Cashmere goat, whose wool was first used to make cashmeres. This wool cash- mere is still made in Yorkshire.

The weave is 2x1 twill, and super weft is used. Another cashmere is made with a cotton warp, which is printed before weaving, and either cotton or wool weft. Used for dress purposes. Definition: a fine twill cloth with jacquard spots and small figures, made of very fine wool, and used for waistcoats. at times the weft is wool and silk or wool and cotton.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CASSENETTE: A fine twill cloth with jacquard spots and small figures, made of very fine wool, and used for waistcoats. At times the weft is wool and silk or wool and cotton.
text: CASSENETTE: A fine twill cloth with jacquard spots and small figures, made of very fine wool, and used for waistcoats. At times the weft is wool and silk or wool and cotton.

Definition: a woollen cloth with a close weave, 2√ó2 twill, closely sheared to give a smooth face. almost any woollen cloth without a distinguishing name is called cassimer by merchants.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CASSIMERE, CASSIMER: A woollen cloth with a close weave, 2√ó2 twill, closely sheared to give a smooth face. Almost any woollen cloth without a distinguishing name is called cassimer by merchants.
text: CASSIMERE, CASSIMER: A woollen cloth with a close weave, 2√ó2 twill, closely sheared to give a smooth face. Almost any woollen cloth without a distinguishing name is called cassimer by merchants.

Definition: is the ordinary 2√ó2 twill.

Author: H.P. Curtis
