Definition: a variety grown in italy from american seed, and consumed in the local trade.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CASTELLAMARE COTTON: A variety grown in Italy from American seed, and consumed in the local trade.
text: CASTELLAMARE COTTON: A variety grown in Italy from American seed, and consumed in the local trade.

Definition: a term used in the jacquard trade to indicate that some hooks of the machine are not used. this enables a lower reed to be used, as, for instance, with a 400's machine and 100's reed, if 50 ends per repeat are cast out an 87 reed can be used. it is necessary for the designer to know from which part of the machine the hooks are being left out.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CASTING-OUT: A term used in the jacquard trade to indicate that some hooks of the machine are not used. This enables a lower reed to be used, as, for instance, with a 400's machine and 100's reed, if 50 ends per repeat are cast out an 87 reed can be used. It is necessary for the designer to know from which part of the machine the hooks are being left out.
text: CASTING-OUT: A term used in the jacquard trade to indicate that some hooks of the machine are not used. This enables a lower reed to be used, as, for instance, with a 400's machine and 100's reed, if 50 ends per repeat are cast out an 87 reed can be used. It is necessary for the designer to know from which part of the machine the hooks are being left out.

Definition: a leno fabric having an open or cell-like structure, and specially suited for shirtings and underwear. a common style is made 28 inches, 120 yards, 32 √ó 40 per inch, 2/24's/24's, 23 lb. better cloth is made from super yarns such as 2/40's ground and 2/30's crossing warps. the take-up of the crossing warp is about 70 per cent., thus for 100 yards of cloth 170 yards of warp is used. mercerised yarn is introduced to give variety. the cloth known as ventilette" is purely a cellular fabric.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CELLULAR: A leno fabric having an open or cell-like structure, and specially suited for shirtings and underwear. A common style is made 28 inches, 120 yards, 32 √ó 40 per inch, 2/24's/24's, 23 lb. Better cloth is made from super yarns such as 2/40's ground and 2/30's crossing warps. The take-up of the crossing warp is about 70 per cent., thus for 100 yards of cloth 170 yards of warp is used. Mercerised yarn is introduced to give variety. The cloth known as Ventilette" is purely a cellular fabric.
text: CELLULAR: A leno fabric having an open or cell-like structure, and specially suited for shirtings and underwear. A common style is made 28 inches, 120 yards, 32 √ó 40 per inch, 2/24's/24's, 23 lb. Better cloth is made from super yarns such as 2/40's ground and 2/30's crossing warps. The take-up of the crossing warp is about 70 per cent., thus for 100 yards of cloth 170 yards of warp is used. Mercerised yarn is introduced to give variety. The cloth known as Ventilette" is purely a cellular fabric.

Definition: a jacquard design with a border at each side, and the centre portion or body composed of a large pattern which reverses over and over in a circular direction until the complete pattern is built up. seen in tablecloths, counterpanes, rugs, carpets, etc.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CENTRE PATTERNS: A jacquard design with a border at each side, and the centre portion or body composed of a large pattern which reverses over and over in a circular direction until the complete pattern is built up. Seen in tablecloths, counterpanes, rugs, carpets, etc.
text: CENTRE PATTERNS: A jacquard design with a border at each side, and the centre portion or body composed of a large pattern which reverses over and over in a circular direction until the complete pattern is built up. Seen in tablecloths, counterpanes, rugs, carpets, etc.

Definition: are colour stripe fabrics woven from cotton warp and a wool mixture weft, plain weave, used for underclothing and shirts. this name was given to the fabric by messrs. david and john anderson, glasgow, about 1858. the weft is from 60 to 80 per cent. wool. a popular cloth is woven 68 ends, 60 picks, 36's warp, and 22's worsted counts weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CEYLONS: Are colour stripe fabrics woven from cotton warp and a wool mixture weft, plain weave, used for underclothing and shirts. This name was given to the fabric by Messrs. David and John Anderson, Glasgow, about 1858. The weft is from 60 to 80 per cent. wool. A popular cloth is woven 68 ends, 60 picks, 36's warp, and 22's worsted counts weft.
text: CEYLONS: Are colour stripe fabrics woven from cotton warp and a wool mixture weft, plain weave, used for underclothing and shirts. This name was given to the fabric by Messrs. David and John Anderson, Glasgow, about 1858. The weft is from 60 to 80 per cent. wool. A popular cloth is woven 68 ends, 60 picks, 36's warp, and 22's worsted counts weft.

Definition: a grey shirting shipped to india. low in quality, 50 inches wide, with a cord and colour heading at each end of 22 yards. about 52 x 48 per inch, 24's/30's.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CHADAR: A grey shirting shipped to India. low in quality, 50 inches wide, with a cord and colour heading at each end of 22 yards. About 52 x 48 per inch, 24's/30's.
text: CHADAR: A grey shirting shipped to India. low in quality, 50 inches wide, with a cord and colour heading at each end of 22 yards. About 52 x 48 per inch, 24's/30's.

Definition: a plain weave coloured check cloth, with a solid colour border at one side only. the indian natives buy this largely.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CHADUR: A plain weave coloured check cloth, with a solid colour border at one side only. The Indian natives buy this largely.
text: CHADUR: A plain weave coloured check cloth, with a solid colour border at one side only. The Indian natives buy this largely.

Definition: a threefold yarn made from a thick soft spun thread twisted with another thread of finer counts and a medium twist. this doubled thread is again twisted with a third and still finer thread, but with the twist in the reverse way.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CHAIN, OR DIAMOND YARN: A threefold yarn made from a thick soft spun thread twisted with another thread of finer counts and a medium twist. This doubled thread is again twisted with a third and still finer thread, but with the twist in the reverse way.
text: CHAIN, OR DIAMOND YARN: A threefold yarn made from a thick soft spun thread twisted with another thread of finer counts and a medium twist. This doubled thread is again twisted with a third and still finer thread, but with the twist in the reverse way.

Definition: an all-wool muslin delaine, printed in somewhat faint designs. originally the challis was made with a silk warp and worsted weft, but imitations were put on the market, some with cotton warp and wool weft, others had cotton and wool mixed warp and weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CHALLIS: An all-wool muslin delaine, printed in somewhat faint designs. Originally the challis was made with a silk warp and worsted weft, but imitations were put on the market, some with cotton warp and wool weft, others had cotton and wool mixed warp and weft.
text: CHALLIS: An all-wool muslin delaine, printed in somewhat faint designs. Originally the challis was made with a silk warp and worsted weft, but imitations were put on the market, some with cotton warp and wool weft, others had cotton and wool mixed warp and weft.

Definition: a light weight cotton or linen dress fabric weighing 13 or 14 yards to the pound. great similarity to a soft finished cambric fabric, made in 27 to 30 inch widths. a better quality has a silk weft. a gingham style of check or stripe has had this term applied to it, the cloth being plain weave, and printed in checks or stripes with white selvedges.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CHAMBRAY: A light weight cotton or linen dress fabric weighing 13 or 14 yards to the pound. Great similarity to a soft finished cambric fabric, made in 27 to 30 inch widths. A better quality has a silk weft. A gingham style of check or stripe has had this term applied to it, the cloth being plain weave, and printed in checks or stripes with white selvedges.
text: CHAMBRAY: A light weight cotton or linen dress fabric weighing 13 or 14 yards to the pound. Great similarity to a soft finished cambric fabric, made in 27 to 30 inch widths. A better quality has a silk weft. A gingham style of check or stripe has had this term applied to it, the cloth being plain weave, and printed in checks or stripes with white selvedges.

Definition: a silk yarn spun from inferior cocoons and silk spin- ners' waste. used in the manufacture of velvets.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CHAPPE SILK YARN: A silk yarn spun from inferior cocoons and silk spin- ners' waste. Used in the manufacture of velvets.
text: CHAPPE SILK YARN: A silk yarn spun from inferior cocoons and silk spin- ners' waste. Used in the manufacture of velvets.

Definition: a thread made from cotton waste, which is converted into a nitro-cellulose stiff solution known as collodion." the collodion is forced under pressure through small capillary tubes forming very fine threads, which solidify quickly when exposed to air. the threads can then be wound on bobbins.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CHARDONNET ARTIFICIAL SILK: A thread made from cotton waste, which is converted into a nitro-cellulose stiff solution known as collodion." The collodion is forced under pressure through small capillary tubes forming very fine threads, which solidify quickly when exposed to air. The threads can then be wound on bobbins.
text: CHARDONNET ARTIFICIAL SILK: A thread made from cotton waste, which is converted into a nitro-cellulose stiff solution known as collodion." The collodion is forced under pressure through small capillary tubes forming very fine threads, which solidify quickly when exposed to air. The threads can then be wound on bobbins.

Definition: a fine satin from super yarns, as sea islands, with a natural lustre, usually made 41 inches, 90 yards, 120 reed, 180 picks, 80's/100's, or finer. i
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CHARMEUSE: A fine satin from super yarns, as Sea Islands, with a natural lustre, usually made 41 inches, 90 yards, 120 reed, 180 picks, 80's/100's, or finer. I
text: CHARMEUSE: A fine satin from super yarns, as Sea Islands, with a natural lustre, usually made 41 inches, 90 yards, 120 reed, 180 picks, 80's/100's, or finer. I

Definition: fabrics having rectangular patterns formed by cross- ing a striped warp with weft threads coloured in a some- what similar order. box looms are required, as each colour of weft has a separate shuttle.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CHECKS: Fabrics having rectangular patterns formed by cross- ing a striped warp with weft threads coloured in a some- what similar order. Box looms are required, as each colour of weft has a separate shuttle.
text: CHECKS: Fabrics having rectangular patterns formed by cross- ing a striped warp with weft threads coloured in a some- what similar order. Box looms are required, as each colour of weft has a separate shuttle.

Definition: a low plain weave fabric, such as 52 x 48 per inch, 40's/36's, 9 to 12 yards to the pound. sometimes termed 'bunting."
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CHEESE CLOTH: A low plain weave fabric, such as 52 x 48 per inch, 40's/36's, 9 to 12 yards to the pound. Sometimes termed 'bunting."
text: CHEESE CLOTH: A low plain weave fabric, such as 52 x 48 per inch, 40's/36's, 9 to 12 yards to the pound. Sometimes termed 'bunting."

Definition: a large quantity of yarn is wound by this method, both grey and coloured, since the cheeses can be bleached or dyed without reeling or rewinding. a cheese is a form of yarn ball wound in zig-zag crossings, so that it holds firm without a spool.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CHEESE WINDING: A large quantity of yarn is wound by this method, both grey and coloured, since the cheeses can be bleached or dyed without reeling or rewinding. A cheese is a form of yarn ball wound in zig-zag crossings, so that it holds firm without a spool.
text: CHEESE WINDING: A large quantity of yarn is wound by this method, both grey and coloured, since the cheeses can be bleached or dyed without reeling or rewinding. A cheese is a form of yarn ball wound in zig-zag crossings, so that it holds firm without a spool.

Definition: a bordered cloth similar to a dhootie, but with a broader heading and longer length.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CHELAIS: A bordered cloth similar to a dhootie, but with a broader heading and longer length.
text: CHELAIS: A bordered cloth similar to a dhootie, but with a broader heading and longer length.

Definition: this fancy "weft" is made by first weaving a fabric in a loom and then cutting this into strips. it can be woven in an ordinary plain loom fitted with gauze mount- ing. the strips are used as weft in such goods as shawls, carpets, table covers, etc. there are several patented methods of weaving chenille.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CHENILLE: This fancy "weft" is made by first weaving a fabric in a loom and then cutting this into strips. It can be woven in an ordinary plain loom fitted with gauze mount- ing. The strips are used as weft in such goods as shawls, carpets, table covers, etc. There are several patented methods of weaving chenille.
text: CHENILLE: This fancy "weft" is made by first weaving a fabric in a loom and then cutting this into strips. It can be woven in an ordinary plain loom fitted with gauze mount- ing. The strips are used as weft in such goods as shawls, carpets, table covers, etc. There are several patented methods of weaving chenille.

Definition: a a good quality plain cloth used for printing. cheshire printer has come to be recognised in the trade as being super quality. the cloth is made in glossop, mottram, stalybridge, and other cheshire and derbyshire towns. the manufacturers are also spinners, and use their own yarns. a fair sample is 36 inches wide, 125 yards long, 72 √ó 84 per inch, 30's/30's.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CHESHIRES, CHESHIRE PRINTERS: A A good quality plain cloth used for printing. Cheshire printer has come to be recognised in the trade as being super quality. The cloth is made in Glossop, Mottram, Stalybridge, and other Cheshire and Derbyshire towns. The manufacturers are also spinners, and use their own yarns. A fair sample is 36 inches wide, 125 yards long, 72 √ó 84 per inch, 30's/30's.
text: CHESHIRES, CHESHIRE PRINTERS: A A good quality plain cloth used for printing. Cheshire printer has come to be recognised in the trade as being super quality. The cloth is made in Glossop, Mottram, Stalybridge, and other Cheshire and Derbyshire towns. The manufacturers are also spinners, and use their own yarns. A fair sample is 36 inches wide, 125 yards long, 72 √ó 84 per inch, 30's/30's.

Definition: a name generally applied to heavy woollen fabrics that have a rough and shaggy face. the yarns used have a fair proportion of mungo or shoddy and cotton. the term denotes a class of fabrics, and not any particular weave.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CHEVIOT: A name generally applied to heavy woollen fabrics that have a rough and shaggy face. The yarns used have a fair proportion of mungo or shoddy and cotton. The term denotes a class of fabrics, and not any particular weave.
text: CHEVIOT: A name generally applied to heavy woollen fabrics that have a rough and shaggy face. The yarns used have a fair proportion of mungo or shoddy and cotton. The term denotes a class of fabrics, and not any particular weave.

Definition: a super quality all-cotton cloth, either bleached or dyed with a soft finish, principally used in the home trade for shirts. a good sample is 84 √ó 84 per inch, 30's/30's or 2/40's/30's.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CHEVIOT SHIRTING: A super quality all-cotton cloth, either bleached or dyed with a soft finish, principally used in the home trade for shirts. A good sample is 84 √ó 84 per inch, 30's/30's or 2/40's/30's.
text: CHEVIOT SHIRTING: A super quality all-cotton cloth, either bleached or dyed with a soft finish, principally used in the home trade for shirts. A good sample is 84 √ó 84 per inch, 30's/30's or 2/40's/30's.

Definition: a loosely woven all-wool cloth with a shaggy face.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CHEVIOT TWEED: A loosely woven all-wool cloth with a shaggy face.
text: CHEVIOT TWEED: A loosely woven all-wool cloth with a shaggy face.

Definition: the softest and most flimsy of silk cloths, plain weave. the name is derived from " chiffe," the french word for rag or flimsy cloth. chiffonette is a name given to the finest chiffon. the prefix chiffon given to other styles of fabrics indicates the lightest of that style, such as chiffon taffetas, chiffon velours, etc.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CHIFFON: The softest and most flimsy of silk cloths, plain weave. The name is derived from " chiffe," the French word for rag or flimsy cloth. Chiffonette is a name given to the finest chiffon. The prefix chiffon given to other styles of fabrics indicates the lightest of that style, such as chiffon taffetas, chiffon velours, etc.
text: CHIFFON: The softest and most flimsy of silk cloths, plain weave. The name is derived from " chiffe," the French word for rag or flimsy cloth. Chiffonette is a name given to the finest chiffon. The prefix chiffon given to other styles of fabrics indicates the lightest of that style, such as chiffon taffetas, chiffon velours, etc.

Definition: this term is given to both ramie and rhea fibres. there are two chief varieties of the plant producing ramie fibre. one is green-leaved and the other white-leaved. the fibre from the former is rhea, and that from the latter is ramie.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CHINA GRASS: This term is given to both ramie and rhea fibres. There are two chief varieties of the plant producing ramie fibre. One is green-leaved and the other white-leaved. The fibre from the former is rhea, and that from the latter is ramie.
text: CHINA GRASS: This term is given to both ramie and rhea fibres. There are two chief varieties of the plant producing ramie fibre. One is green-leaved and the other white-leaved. The fibre from the former is rhea, and that from the latter is ramie.

Definition: a french-made fabric from silk warp and weft, about 23 to 24 inches wide, and printed black spots on a self- coloured ground, or blue on white. it is woven in water from japanese gum silk.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CHINA GUM CLOTH, OR FOULARD DE CHINE: A French-made fabric from silk warp and weft, about 23 to 24 inches wide, and printed black spots on a self- coloured ground, or blue on white. It is woven in water from Japanese gum silk.
text: CHINA GUM CLOTH, OR FOULARD DE CHINE: A French-made fabric from silk warp and weft, about 23 to 24 inches wide, and printed black spots on a self- coloured ground, or blue on white. It is woven in water from Japanese gum silk.

Definition: an overcoating cloth made from a long fibre wool, rough face, soft, and warm. the roughness is produced by small tufts in the yarn.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CHINCHILLA: An overcoating cloth made from a long fibre wool, rough face, soft, and warm. The roughness is produced by small tufts in the yarn.
text: CHINCHILLA: An overcoating cloth made from a long fibre wool, rough face, soft, and warm. The roughness is produced by small tufts in the yarn.

Definition: a fabric, plain weave, from fine yarns, with a printed warp and white weft. the printing is blurred, and gives an effect as if the colour had run.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CHIN√â, OR SHADOW CRETONNES: A fabric, plain weave, from fine yarns, with a printed warp and white weft. The printing is blurred, and gives an effect as if the colour had run.
text: CHIN√â, OR SHADOW CRETONNES: A fabric, plain weave, from fine yarns, with a printed warp and white weft. The printing is blurred, and gives an effect as if the colour had run.

Definition: is the plural of " chint," the eastern name for a broad gaudily printed fabric of cotton. of recent years the term has meant a plain cotton cloth printed in bright colours. fabrics woven with a print warp are sometimes put under this name, although more generally known as shadow cretonnes.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CHINTZ: Is the plural of " chint," the Eastern name for a broad gaudily printed fabric of cotton. Of recent years the term has meant a plain cotton cloth printed in bright colours. Fabrics woven with a print warp are sometimes put under this name, although more generally known as shadow cretonnes.
text: CHINTZ: Is the plural of " chint," the Eastern name for a broad gaudily printed fabric of cotton. Of recent years the term has meant a plain cotton cloth printed in bright colours. Fabrics woven with a print warp are sometimes put under this name, although more generally known as shadow cretonnes.

Definition: a method of adding ornament to fabrics by replacing one colour of weft with another in succeeding horizontal sections of the design.-called "weft chintzing. utilised in such fabrics as fancy muslins of the better qualities.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CHINTZING: A method of adding ornament to fabrics by replacing one colour of weft with another in succeeding horizontal sections of the design.-called "weft chintzing. Utilised in such fabrics as fancy muslins of the better qualities.
text: CHINTZING: A method of adding ornament to fabrics by replacing one colour of weft with another in succeeding horizontal sections of the design.-called "weft chintzing. Utilised in such fabrics as fancy muslins of the better qualities.

Definition: shawls varying in size and quality and style accord- ing to the market for which intended, with borders, fringe, and headings. constructed of cotton in many widths up to 48 inches x 48 inches.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CHUDDERS: Shawls varying in size and quality and style accord- ing to the market for which intended, with borders, fringe, and headings. Constructed of cotton in many widths up to 48 inches x 48 inches.
text: CHUDDERS: Shawls varying in size and quality and style accord- ing to the market for which intended, with borders, fringe, and headings. Constructed of cotton in many widths up to 48 inches x 48 inches.

Definition: a worsted cloth, diagonal twill weave, similar to a serge cloth, but without gloss. the warp and weft yarns are slackly twisted, which gives a dull face to the cloth. the name was derived from a manufacturer.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CLAYS: A worsted cloth, diagonal twill weave, similar to a serge cloth, but without gloss. The warp and weft yarns are slackly twisted, which gives a dull face to the cloth. The name was derived from a manufacturer.
text: CLAYS: A worsted cloth, diagonal twill weave, similar to a serge cloth, but without gloss. The warp and weft yarns are slackly twisted, which gives a dull face to the cloth. The name was derived from a manufacturer.

Definition: a term given to cloth used for cleaning machinery, usually made from cotton or spun silk waste. of a coarse texture, and plain or leno weave. if leno, a special gauze reed is used, and healds are not necessary. (see sponge cloths)‚äî
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CLEANING CLOTHS : A term given to cloth used for cleaning machinery, usually made from cotton or spun silk waste. Of a coarse texture, and plain or leno weave. If leno, a special gauze reed is used, and healds are not necessary. (See Sponge Cloths)‚Äî
text: CLEANING CLOTHS : A term given to cloth used for cleaning machinery, usually made from cotton or spun silk waste. Of a coarse texture, and plain or leno weave. If leno, a special gauze reed is used, and healds are not necessary. (See Sponge Cloths)‚Äî

Definition: figured muslins ornamented with small detached spots of extra warp and weft, the floating material between the spots being afterwards clipped or sheared off.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CLIP SPOTS: Figured muslins ornamented with small detached spots of extra warp and weft, the floating material between the spots being afterwards clipped or sheared off.
text: CLIP SPOTS: Figured muslins ornamented with small detached spots of extra warp and weft, the floating material between the spots being afterwards clipped or sheared off.

Definition: produced by twisting a fine thread with another thread, which at intervals has a slub formed; the slub is a short fibre twistless sliver. also called "slub" or "flake yarn.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CLOUD YARN: Produced by twisting a fine thread with another thread, which at intervals has a slub formed; the slub is a short fibre twistless sliver. Also called "slub" or "flake yarn.
text: CLOUD YARN: Produced by twisting a fine thread with another thread, which at intervals has a slub formed; the slub is a short fibre twistless sliver. Also called "slub" or "flake yarn.

Definition: a twill cloth made from cotton and silk, worsted and silk, or all worsted. used as a dress fabric, varying in width and quality, and a twill weave on the face.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COBURG: A twill cloth made from cotton and silk, worsted and silk, or all worsted. Used as a dress fabric, varying in width and quality, and a twill weave on the face.
text: COBURG: A twill cloth made from cotton and silk, worsted and silk, or all worsted. Used as a dress fabric, varying in width and quality, and a twill weave on the face.

Definition: originally made from the fibre of the cocoanut, but now made from jute. used for coverings for stone floors.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COCOA MATTING: Originally made from the fibre of the cocoanut, but now made from jute. Used for coverings for stone floors.
text: COCOA MATTING: Originally made from the fibre of the cocoanut, but now made from jute. Used for coverings for stone floors.

Definition: this is a knit goods term, and indicates a knitted neck-band for undervests instead of a cloth band.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COLLARETTE: This is a knit goods term, and indicates a knitted neck-band for undervests instead of a cloth band.
text: COLLARETTE: This is a knit goods term, and indicates a knitted neck-band for undervests instead of a cloth band.

Definition: a term applied to all fabrics in which dyed yarn is used, either in warp or weft or both.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COLOURED GOODS: A term applied to all fabrics in which dyed yarn is used, either in warp or weft or both.
text: COLOURED GOODS: A term applied to all fabrics in which dyed yarn is used, either in warp or weft or both.

Definition: list is another name for selvedge. many cloths, both cotton and woollen, are made with a coloured selvedge. when first used it signified that the fabric was woven from dyed yarn and was not piece-dyed.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COLOURED LISTS: List is another name for selvedge. Many cloths, both cotton and woollen, are made with a coloured selvedge. When first used it signified that the fabric was woven from dyed yarn and was not piece-dyed.
text: COLOURED LISTS: List is another name for selvedge. Many cloths, both cotton and woollen, are made with a coloured selvedge. When first used it signified that the fabric was woven from dyed yarn and was not piece-dyed.

Definition: a twill weave constructed by combining two simple twills together, end and end, or pick and pick.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COMBINED TWILL: A twill weave constructed by combining two simple twills together, end and end, or pick and pick.
text: COMBINED TWILL: A twill weave constructed by combining two simple twills together, end and end, or pick and pick.

Definition: the comber is a carding machine in a more perfect form, doing practically the same work, but doing it much finer than the card. it brings the fibres of cotton parallel, cleans out all neps and fine impurities, and extracts a large proportion of the short fibres. the comber is only used for super quality yarns, enabling finer counts to be spun from the same quality of cotton; the yarn is also stronger and more lustrous.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COMBING: The comber is a carding machine in a more perfect form, doing practically the same work, but doing it much finer than the card. It brings the fibres of cotton parallel, cleans out all neps and fine impurities, and extracts a large proportion of the short fibres. The comber is only used for super quality yarns, enabling finer counts to be spun from the same quality of cotton; the yarn is also stronger and more lustrous.
text: COMBING: The comber is a carding machine in a more perfect form, doing practically the same work, but doing it much finer than the card. It brings the fibres of cotton parallel, cleans out all neps and fine impurities, and extracts a large proportion of the short fibres. The comber is only used for super quality yarns, enabling finer counts to be spun from the same quality of cotton; the yarn is also stronger and more lustrous.

Definition: fabrics in the construction of which more than one warp and one weft are used are termed " compound." a backed cloth is now called compound, although the real compound cloth is composed of two or more distinct cloths.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COMPOUND FABRICS: Fabrics in the construction of which more than one warp and one weft are used are termed " compound." A backed cloth is now called compound, although the real compound cloth is composed of two or more distinct cloths.
text: COMPOUND FABRICS: Fabrics in the construction of which more than one warp and one weft are used are termed " compound." A backed cloth is now called compound, although the real compound cloth is composed of two or more distinct cloths.

Definition: are spun from good quality waste, in counts 5's to 10's, and largely used for cotton blankets, low shirtings, quilts, repps, tussores, etc. they are short in fibre and soft spun.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CONDENSER YARNS: Are spun from good quality waste, in counts 5's to 10's, and largely used for cotton blankets, low shirtings, quilts, repps, tussores, etc. They are short in fibre and soft spun.
text: CONDENSER YARNS: Are spun from good quality waste, in counts 5's to 10's, and largely used for cotton blankets, low shirtings, quilts, repps, tussores, etc. They are short in fibre and soft spun.

Definition: yarn is "conditioned to make it better able to with- stand the subsequent processes, and also to add weight. this weight adding may or may not be honest. the most common method of conditioning is by exposure in a damp cellar for some days damp yarn weaves much better than dry; and shews fewer snarls in the cloth.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CONDITIONING: Yarn is "conditioned to make it better able to with- stand the subsequent processes, and also to add weight. This weight adding may or may not be honest. The most common method of conditioning is by exposure in a damp cellar for some days Damp yarn weaves much better than dry; and shews fewer snarls in the cloth.
text: CONDITIONING: Yarn is "conditioned to make it better able to with- stand the subsequent processes, and also to add weight. This weight adding may or may not be honest. The most common method of conditioning is by exposure in a damp cellar for some days Damp yarn weaves much better than dry; and shews fewer snarls in the cloth.

Definition: very heavy cotton cloths, and are the broadest cords made. heavy fustian looms are required to weave them. the design is usually on 12 ends and 12 picks, requiring 8 staves. a variety made in oldham is 31 inches full, 42 reed, 300 picks, 2/30 twist, 18's weft. the reed and weft vary; every alternate pile pick is securely bound in the cloth, which makes it firm.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CONSTITUTION CORDS: Very heavy cotton cloths, and are the broadest cords made. Heavy fustian looms are required to weave them. The design is usually on 12 ends and 12 picks, requiring 8 staves. A variety made in Oldham is 31 inches full, 42 reed, 300 picks, 2/30 twist, 18's weft. The reed and weft vary; every alternate pile pick is securely bound in the cloth, which makes it firm.
text: CONSTITUTION CORDS: Very heavy cotton cloths, and are the broadest cords made. Heavy fustian looms are required to weave them. The design is usually on 12 ends and 12 picks, requiring 8 staves. A variety made in Oldham is 31 inches full, 42 reed, 300 picks, 2/30 twist, 18's weft. The reed and weft vary; every alternate pile pick is securely bound in the cloth, which makes it firm.

Definition: looms which use one shuttle, and parts that auto- matically eject an exhausted cop, insert a full one, and draw the weft thread into the shuttle eye while the loom is running, such as the northrop.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COP-CHANGING LOOMS: Looms which use one shuttle, and parts that auto- matically eject an exhausted cop, insert a full one, and draw the weft thread into the shuttle eye while the loom is running, such as the Northrop.
text: COP-CHANGING LOOMS: Looms which use one shuttle, and parts that auto- matically eject an exhausted cop, insert a full one, and draw the weft thread into the shuttle eye while the loom is running, such as the Northrop.

Definition: a cone of yarn built upon a paper tube base, and used for shuttles.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COP: A cone of yarn built upon a paper tube base, and used for shuttles.
text: COP: A cone of yarn built upon a paper tube base, and used for shuttles.

Definition: yarn intended for warps, built in cop form.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COP TWIST: Yarn intended for warps, built in cop form.
text: COP TWIST: Yarn intended for warps, built in cop form.

Definition: an american term for kerseys, or kerseymere over- coatings.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CORDILLAS: An American term for kerseys, or kerseymere over- coatings.
text: CORDILLAS: An American term for kerseys, or kerseymere over- coatings.

Definition: plain weave fabrics with a thick cord at regular dis- tances apart. two beams are used, and the best qualities are often dented, one in a dent with the cord ends cram- med, such as 30 inch 100 yards 40 ends 80 picks per inch 50's/50's, with 12 cords 2/40's per inch, 3 in a dent. imitation cord stripes are made in which the same yarn as used for the ground is used, but with 4 or more ends working together. one beam is usual for this style.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CORD STRIPES: Plain weave fabrics with a thick cord at regular dis- tances apart. Two beams are used, and the best qualities are often dented, one in a dent with the cord ends cram- med, such as 30 inch 100 yards 40 ends 80 picks per inch 50's/50's, with 12 cords 2/40's per inch, 3 in a dent. Imitation cord stripes are made in which the same yarn as used for the ground is used, but with 4 or more ends working together. One beam is usual for this style.
text: CORD STRIPES: Plain weave fabrics with a thick cord at regular dis- tances apart. Two beams are used, and the best qualities are often dented, one in a dent with the cord ends cram- med, such as 30 inch 100 yards 40 ends 80 picks per inch 50's/50's, with 12 cords 2/40's per inch, 3 in a dent. Imitation cord stripes are made in which the same yarn as used for the ground is used, but with 4 or more ends working together. One beam is usual for this style.

Definition: a stout cotton cloth used for suitings. it is a cut pile fabric, and has hard wearing qualities. the weave has a cord or rib surface with either round or flat tops- pile formed by the weft. when woven with a twill back it is known as a "genoa back," and when a plain back is used it is termed a tabby back corduroy.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CORDUROY: A stout cotton cloth used for suitings. It is a cut pile fabric, and has hard wearing qualities. The weave has a cord or rib surface with either round or flat tops- pile formed by the weft. When woven with a twill back it is known as a "Genoa back," and when a plain back is used it is termed a Tabby back corduroy.
text: CORDUROY: A stout cotton cloth used for suitings. It is a cut pile fabric, and has hard wearing qualities. The weave has a cord or rib surface with either round or flat tops- pile formed by the weft. When woven with a twill back it is known as a "Genoa back," and when a plain back is used it is termed a Tabby back corduroy.

Definition: is made by twisting two threads of unequal diameters, by twisting two threads delivered at unequal rates, by twisting two threads with unequal twist, or twisting two threads in opposite directions.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CORKSCREW YARN: Is made by twisting two threads of unequal diameters, by twisting two threads delivered at unequal rates, by twisting two threads with unequal twist, or twisting two threads in opposite directions.
text: CORKSCREW YARN: Is made by twisting two threads of unequal diameters, by twisting two threads delivered at unequal rates, by twisting two threads with unequal twist, or twisting two threads in opposite directions.

Definition: a weave largely used by worsted manufacturers for coatings and trouserings. it is based on the sateen prin- ciple on 7, 9, or 11 shafts. a sateen base is used, and one or more dots added to the design, thus lifting a thread more than once. it is really a fancy twill weave, and the name does not describe it. either warp or weft face can be made.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CORKSCREW WEAVE: A weave largely used by worsted manufacturers for coatings and trouserings. It is based on the sateen prin- ciple on 7, 9, or 11 shafts. A sateen base is used, and one or more dots added to the design, thus lifting a thread more than once. It is really a fancy twill weave, and the name does not describe it. Either warp or weft face can be made.
text: CORKSCREW WEAVE: A weave largely used by worsted manufacturers for coatings and trouserings. It is based on the sateen prin- ciple on 7, 9, or 11 shafts. A sateen base is used, and one or more dots added to the design, thus lifting a thread more than once. It is really a fancy twill weave, and the name does not describe it. Either warp or weft face can be made.

Definition: a light cotton fabric, generally 54 inches wide, made splits, to finish 25/6 inch. the designs are a plain stripe inch to 1 inch, with a few ends of 2/60's mercerised yarn, such as 28 ends grey warp and 4 ends mercerised. a stan- dard cloth is 54/120 yards splits, 76 ends grey, 2 ends, 2/60's, 80 picks, 36's and 2/60's warp, 36's weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CORUNNA STRIPES: A light cotton fabric, generally 54 inches wide, made splits, to finish 25/6 inch. The designs are a plain stripe inch to 1 inch, with a few ends of 2/60's mercerised yarn, such as 28 ends grey warp and 4 ends mercerised. A stan- dard cloth is 54/120 yards splits, 76 ends grey, 2 ends, 2/60's, 80 picks, 36's and 2/60's warp, 36's weft.
text: CORUNNA STRIPES: A light cotton fabric, generally 54 inches wide, made splits, to finish 25/6 inch. The designs are a plain stripe inch to 1 inch, with a few ends of 2/60's mercerised yarn, such as 28 ends grey warp and 4 ends mercerised. A stan- dard cloth is 54/120 yards splits, 76 ends grey, 2 ends, 2/60's, 80 picks, 36's and 2/60's warp, 36's weft.

Definition: sometimes called a wool substitute, but contains no wool at all, being manufactured on the continent from the waste of flax, hemp, and jute fabrics.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COSMOS FIBRE: Sometimes called a wool substitute, but contains no wool at all, being manufactured on the continent from the waste of flax, hemp, and jute fabrics.
text: COSMOS FIBRE: Sometimes called a wool substitute, but contains no wool at all, being manufactured on the continent from the waste of flax, hemp, and jute fabrics.

Definition: the most generally use of all vegetable fibres, and is grown in many parts of the world. the chief varieties are:-sea islands, egyptian, american, brazilian, peru- vian, east indian, and african, placed in their order of quality, and each variety has many grades.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COTTON: The most generally use of all vegetable fibres, and is grown in many parts of the world. The chief varieties are:-Sea Islands, Egyptian, American, Brazilian, Peru- vian, East Indian, and African, placed in their order of quality, and each variety has many grades.
text: COTTON: The most generally use of all vegetable fibres, and is grown in many parts of the world. The chief varieties are:-Sea Islands, Egyptian, American, Brazilian, Peru- vian, East Indian, and African, placed in their order of quality, and each variety has many grades.

Definition: a coarse heavy, cotton fabric manufactured as an imitation of cassimere for men's wear, such as 64 ends 68 picks 16's warp 12's weft of very super quality yarns, twill weave.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COTTONADE: A coarse heavy, cotton fabric manufactured as an imitation of cassimere for men's wear, such as 64 ends 68 picks 16's warp 12's weft of very super quality yarns, twill weave.
text: COTTONADE: A coarse heavy, cotton fabric manufactured as an imitation of cassimere for men's wear, such as 64 ends 68 picks 16's warp 12's weft of very super quality yarns, twill weave.

Definition: cotton bought on c.i.f. terms is a method of buying for forward delivery, and the seller paying costs, insurance, and freight up to liverpool. the cotton is not actually in liverpool, and samples cannot be seen at the time of purchase, but there is an understanding that the quality will be equal to a certain standard. ‚äï
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COTTON, C.I.F.: Cotton bought on c.i.f. terms is a method of buying for forward delivery, and the seller paying costs, insurance, and freight up to Liverpool. The cotton is not actually in Liverpool, and samples cannot be seen at the time of purchase, but there is an understanding that the quality will be equal to a certain standard. ‚Äï
text: COTTON, C.I.F.: Cotton bought on c.i.f. terms is a method of buying for forward delivery, and the seller paying costs, insurance, and freight up to Liverpool. The cotton is not actually in Liverpool, and samples cannot be seen at the time of purchase, but there is an understanding that the quality will be equal to a certain standard. ‚Äï

Definition: an imitation of wool flannel in all cotton, either plain or twill weave, and raised one or both sides; 6's to 10's weft used, 30's to 36's twist.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COTTON FLANNEL: An imitation of wool flannel in all cotton, either plain or twill weave, and raised one or both sides; 6's to 10's weft used, 30's to 36's twist.
text: COTTON FLANNEL: An imitation of wool flannel in all cotton, either plain or twill weave, and raised one or both sides; 6's to 10's weft used, 30's to 36's twist.

Definition: when a spinner books a large order for yarn, with delivery extending to, say, 3 or 4 months, he will base the cost on the day's price of cotton, and to cover himself against loss he ought to buy enough cotton to complete the order. if for some reason he cannot buy all "spot," he will buy "futures" as a cover pure and simple. sup- pose 600 bales are required, then he may buy 200 july, 200 august, and 200 september. thus he does not buy any actual cotton; the deal is only on paper, but the spinner has covered his requirements to complete his order, and at the price quoted when he buys. when he wants the cotton he sells his "futures" and buys spot" or actual cotton.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COTTON FUTURES: When a spinner books a large order for yarn, with delivery extending to, say, 3 or 4 months, he will base the cost on the day's price of cotton, and to cover himself against loss he ought to buy enough cotton to complete the order. If for some reason he cannot buy all "spot," he will buy "futures" as a cover pure and simple. Sup- pose 600 bales are required, then he may buy 200 July, 200 August, and 200 September. Thus he does not buy any actual cotton; the deal is only on paper, but the spinner has covered his requirements to complete his order, and at the price quoted when he buys. When he wants the cotton he sells his "futures" and buys spot" or actual cotton.
text: COTTON FUTURES: When a spinner books a large order for yarn, with delivery extending to, say, 3 or 4 months, he will base the cost on the day's price of cotton, and to cover himself against loss he ought to buy enough cotton to complete the order. If for some reason he cannot buy all "spot," he will buy "futures" as a cover pure and simple. Sup- pose 600 bales are required, then he may buy 200 July, 200 August, and 200 September. Thus he does not buy any actual cotton; the deal is only on paper, but the spinner has covered his requirements to complete his order, and at the price quoted when he buys. When he wants the cotton he sells his "futures" and buys spot" or actual cotton.

Definition: this is a cotton with a hard, harsh, wiry nature, such as rough peruvian and brazilian, which gives a loose, spongy, but more or less harsh appearance to the yarn.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COTTON-HARD: This is a cotton with a hard, harsh, wiry nature, such as rough Peruvian and Brazilian, which gives a loose, spongy, but more or less harsh appearance to the yarn.
text: COTTON-HARD: This is a cotton with a hard, harsh, wiry nature, such as rough Peruvian and Brazilian, which gives a loose, spongy, but more or less harsh appearance to the yarn.

Definition: this is damaged cotton, and may be due to defective baling, whereby the fibre is exposed to bad weather during transit. bad weather before the cotton is picked, and when the ripe bolls are open, also causes this defect.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COTTON-RUSTY: This is damaged cotton, and may be due to defective baling, whereby the fibre is exposed to bad weather during transit. Bad weather before the cotton is picked, and when the ripe bolls are open, also causes this defect.
text: COTTON-RUSTY: This is damaged cotton, and may be due to defective baling, whereby the fibre is exposed to bad weather during transit. Bad weather before the cotton is picked, and when the ripe bolls are open, also causes this defect.

Definition: is smooth and soft in feel and fairly clean, such as smooth peruvian, ordinary american, egyptian, etc.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COTTON-SOFT: Is smooth and soft in feel and fairly clean, such as Smooth Peruvian, Ordinary American, Egyptian, etc.
text: COTTON-SOFT: Is smooth and soft in feel and fairly clean, such as Smooth Peruvian, Ordinary American, Egyptian, etc.

Definition: cotton actually in stock in the market, as at liver- pool, and of which samples may be inspected by the spin- ner is termed spot cotton." "" this cotton can also be bought on call," that is, the buyer selects a "lot" of cotton, and the basis is then fixed that he will pay for a stated quantity; the final price is known only when he actually calls his cotton for use.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COTTON-SPOT: Cotton actually in stock in the market, as at Liver- pool, and of which samples may be inspected by the spin- ner is termed Spot Cotton." "" This cotton can also be bought on call," that is, the buyer selects a "lot" of cotton, and the basis is then fixed that he will pay for a stated quantity; the final price is known only when he actually calls his cotton for use.
text: COTTON-SPOT: Cotton actually in stock in the market, as at Liver- pool, and of which samples may be inspected by the spin- ner is termed Spot Cotton." "" This cotton can also be bought on call," that is, the buyer selects a "lot" of cotton, and the basis is then fixed that he will pay for a stated quantity; the final price is known only when he actually calls his cotton for use.

Definition: staple means the length of the fibre, a good staple is a long fibre, and a short staple is a short fibre.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COTTON STAPLE: Staple means the length of the fibre, a good staple is a long fibre, and a short staple is a short fibre.
text: COTTON STAPLE: Staple means the length of the fibre, a good staple is a long fibre, and a short staple is a short fibre.

Definition: 54 in. 1 thread (circumference of wrap reel). 80 threads 1 lea 120 yards. 7 leas 1 hank 840 yards. 1 bundle 10 lb. (usually).
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COTTON YARN MEASURES: 54 in. 1 thread (circumference of wrap reel). 80 threads 1 lea 120 yards. 7 leas 1 hank 840 yards. 1 bundle 10 lb. (usually).
text: COTTON YARN MEASURES: 54 in. 1 thread (circumference of wrap reel). 80 threads 1 lea 120 yards. 7 leas 1 hank 840 yards. 1 bundle 10 lb. (usually).

Definition: the numbering of yarns is termed the counts." the cotton system is based on 840 yards to the hank, and the number of hanks that weigh 1 lb. (7,000 grains), equals the counts, thus, 10's cotton 10 x 840 yards per lb.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COUNTS: The numbering of yarns is termed the counts." The cotton system is based on 840 yards to the hank, and the number of hanks that weigh 1 lb. (7,000 grains), equals the counts, thus, 10's cotton 10 x 840 yards per lb.
text: COUNTS: The numbering of yarns is termed the counts." The cotton system is based on 840 yards to the hank, and the number of hanks that weigh 1 lb. (7,000 grains), equals the counts, thus, 10's cotton 10 x 840 yards per lb.

Definition: a strong herring-bone twill cloth used for corset making. a standard cloth is 34 inches, 100 yards, 96 √ó 64, 22/22, 31 lb., and in 56 inches 51 lb., woven in a dobby loom on six shafts. dyed drab or french grey. tinted yarn is used for some cloths-generally french or silver grey.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COUTIL: A strong herring-bone twill cloth used for corset making. A standard cloth is 34 inches, 100 yards, 96 √ó 64, 22/22, 31 lb., and in 56 inches 51 lb., woven in a dobby loom on six shafts. Dyed drab or French grey. Tinted yarn is used for some cloths-generally French or silver grey.
text: COUTIL: A strong herring-bone twill cloth used for corset making. A standard cloth is 34 inches, 100 yards, 96 √ó 64, 22/22, 31 lb., and in 56 inches 51 lb., woven in a dobby loom on six shafts. Dyed drab or French grey. Tinted yarn is used for some cloths-generally French or silver grey.

Definition: by cover of cloth " is meant the full uniform appear- ance that all plain goods should have, in which every end and pick spreads out equidistant from each other. a well-covered cloth is the opposite to a reedy cloth, which shews the ends in pairs. a reedy cloth when bad is often called " grinny." a reedy cloth is caused by careless weaving, and can be stopped if the loom is pro- perly set.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COVER: By cover of cloth " is meant the full uniform appear- ance that all plain goods should have, in which every end and pick spreads out equidistant from each other. A well-covered cloth is the opposite to a reedy cloth, which shews the ends in pairs. A reedy cloth when bad is often called " grinny." A reedy cloth is caused by careless weaving, and can be stopped if the loom is pro- perly set.
text: COVER: By cover of cloth " is meant the full uniform appear- ance that all plain goods should have, in which every end and pick spreads out equidistant from each other. A well-covered cloth is the opposite to a reedy cloth, which shews the ends in pairs. A reedy cloth when bad is often called " grinny." A reedy cloth is caused by careless weaving, and can be stopped if the loom is pro- perly set.

Definition: a woollen cloth of twofold yarns, warp and weft, fine twill, very closely woven. it is a warp twill weave, and weft does not shew on the face. venetian coverts are a rib twill weave.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: COVERT CLOTH: A woollen cloth of twofold yarns, warp and weft, fine twill, very closely woven. It is a warp twill weave, and weft does not shew on the face. Venetian coverts are a rib twill weave.
text: COVERT CLOTH: A woollen cloth of twofold yarns, warp and weft, fine twill, very closely woven. It is a warp twill weave, and weft does not shew on the face. Venetian coverts are a rib twill weave.

Definition: a term given to the process through which the woollen fabric passes to fix the finished width. the cloth is tightly wound on to a roller with a hollow core; steam passing through the core and cloth sets the width.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CRABBING: A term given to the process through which the woollen fabric passes to fix the finished width. The cloth is tightly wound on to a roller with a hollow core; steam passing through the core and cloth sets the width.
text: CRABBING: A term given to the process through which the woollen fabric passes to fix the finished width. The cloth is tightly wound on to a roller with a hollow core; steam passing through the core and cloth sets the width.

Definition: these are stripes produced in fabrics by cramming ends in the reed. one portion of the cloth will thus have a greater number of ends per inch than another.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CRAMMED STRIPES: These are stripes produced in fabrics by cramming ends in the reed. One portion of the cloth will thus have a greater number of ends per inch than another.
text: CRAMMED STRIPES: These are stripes produced in fabrics by cramming ends in the reed. One portion of the cloth will thus have a greater number of ends per inch than another.

Definition: this is one of the oldest cloths made for west africa, and still finds a sale. it is a blue and white check, with design about two inches square, coarse yarns all through. the sketch shews the style of checking, in which the lines e mee indicate blue over white. generally 36 inches finished, 20 yards, headed each end with the three green one red heading. the finish is the usual stiff finish, and a good quality is 37 inches soft, 20 yards, 89/3 x 24, 16's grey, 16 indigo twist, 16's indigo, 18's cop weft. made in rad- cliffe and rochdale.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CRANKY CHECKS: This is one of the oldest cloths made for West Africa, and still finds a sale. It is a blue and white check, with design about two inches square, coarse yarns all through. The sketch shews the style of checking, in which the lines E MEE indicate blue over white. Generally 36 inches finished, 20 yards, headed each end with the three green one red heading. The finish is the usual stiff finish, and a good quality is 37 inches soft, 20 yards, 89/3 x 24, 16's grey, 16 indigo twist, 16's indigo, 18's cop weft. Made in Rad- cliffe and Rochdale.
text: CRANKY CHECKS: This is one of the oldest cloths made for West Africa, and still finds a sale. It is a blue and white check, with design about two inches square, coarse yarns all through. The sketch shews the style of checking, in which the lines E MEE indicate blue over white. Generally 36 inches finished, 20 yards, headed each end with the three green one red heading. The finish is the usual stiff finish, and a good quality is 37 inches soft, 20 yards, 89/3 x 24, 16's grey, 16 indigo twist, 16's indigo, 18's cop weft. Made in Rad- cliffe and Rochdale.

Definition: a linen fabric, plain weave, woven with very uneven weft, which gives a rough surface to the cloth; used for towels. a finer quality is woven for use as dress goods. irregular weaves of the crepe type are often used. a cotton imitation is on the market, but is a very poor substitute, made 56 √ó 56, 20's/8's colour weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CRASH: A linen fabric, plain weave, woven with very uneven weft, which gives a rough surface to the cloth; used for towels. A finer quality is woven for use as dress goods. Irregular weaves of the crepe type are often used. A cotton imitation is on the market, but is a very poor substitute, made 56 √ó 56, 20's/8's colour weft.
text: CRASH: A linen fabric, plain weave, woven with very uneven weft, which gives a rough surface to the cloth; used for towels. A finer quality is woven for use as dress goods. Irregular weaves of the crepe type are often used. A cotton imitation is on the market, but is a very poor substitute, made 56 √ó 56, 20's/8's colour weft.

Definition: a finishing process which is supposed to make the fabric waterproof, rainproof, and spotproof.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CRAVENETTE: A finishing process which is supposed to make the fabric waterproof, rainproof, and spotproof.
text: CRAVENETTE: A finishing process which is supposed to make the fabric waterproof, rainproof, and spotproof.

Definition: originally called crapes, and were always black and used for mourning purposes. it is a puckered or crinkled fabric. special hard-twisted yarns are used, and when the cloth is washed or finished a crepe effect is produced which is permanent, due to the shrinkage of the special yarns. the cloths produced by what is termed crepe weaves are not true crepes, since the cloth does not pucker. (see crepon.)
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CREPE. FANCY CREPE. CRAPE: Originally called crapes, and were always black and used for mourning purposes. It is a puckered or crinkled fabric. Special hard-twisted yarns are used, and when the cloth is washed or finished a crepe effect is produced which is permanent, due to the shrinkage of the special yarns. The cloths produced by what is termed crepe weaves are not true crepes, since the cloth does not pucker. (See Crepon.)
text: CREPE. FANCY CREPE. CRAPE: Originally called crapes, and were always black and used for mourning purposes. It is a puckered or crinkled fabric. Special hard-twisted yarns are used, and when the cloth is washed or finished a crepe effect is produced which is permanent, due to the shrinkage of the special yarns. The cloths produced by what is termed crepe weaves are not true crepes, since the cloth does not pucker. (See Crepon.)

Definition: a style of crepe, plain, figured, or printed, exceedingly soft or drapy-woven from a fine silk warp, and open band and cross band tightly twisted worsted weft, which shrinks to a permanent crinkled effect when finished. a lustre is always visible owing to the fine silk warp.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CREPE-DE-CHINE: A style of crepe, plain, figured, or printed, exceedingly soft or drapy-woven from a fine silk warp, and open band and cross band tightly twisted worsted weft, which shrinks to a permanent crinkled effect when finished. A lustre is always visible owing to the fine silk warp.
text: CREPE-DE-CHINE: A style of crepe, plain, figured, or printed, exceedingly soft or drapy-woven from a fine silk warp, and open band and cross band tightly twisted worsted weft, which shrinks to a permanent crinkled effect when finished. A lustre is always visible owing to the fine silk warp.

Definition: cotton yarn six to nine fold, and very hard twisted.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CREPE YARN: Cotton yarn six to nine fold, and very hard twisted.
text: CREPE YARN: Cotton yarn six to nine fold, and very hard twisted.

Definition: the name given to a warp rib fabric in which the weave is so broken up that a crepe effect is seen. some- times called "rib crepes.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CREPOLINE: The name given to a warp rib fabric in which the weave is so broken up that a crepe effect is seen. Some- times called "rib crepes.
text: CREPOLINE: The name given to a warp rib fabric in which the weave is so broken up that a crepe effect is seen. Some- times called "rib crepes.

Definition: a crepe-like structure obtained in several ways, such as (1) a combination of materials; (2) combination of weaves; (3) combination of materials and weaves; (4) by special chemical processes. crepons are true crepes, be- cause the fabric when finished is crinkled. the terms crepe" and crepon are now used for any fabric of the crepe style produced by any of the four methods given above. cloths produced by method 2 are not true crepons. the crepes made for shipping to india, china, south america, and other markets in cotton are produced by method 2 in dobby looms and from 6 to 16 shafts used. standard makes are as follow:-34/120 yards, 58 √ó 62, 34/16. 29¬ω lb. 12 shafts; 35/120 yards, 68 √ó 68, 36/22. 28 lb. 8 shafts; 56/120 yards, 72 x 76, 36/24. 46 lb. 8 shafts.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CREPON: A crepe-like structure obtained in several ways, such as (1) a combination of materials; (2) combination of weaves; (3) combination of materials and weaves; (4) by special chemical processes. Crepons are true crepes, be- cause the fabric when finished is crinkled. The terms crepe" and crepon are now used for any fabric of the crepe style produced by any of the four methods given above. Cloths produced by method 2 are not true crepons. The crepes made for shipping to India, China, South America, and other markets in cotton are produced by method 2 in dobby looms and from 6 to 16 shafts used. Standard makes are as follow:-34/120 yards, 58 √ó 62, 34/16. 29¬Ω lb. 12 shafts; 35/120 yards, 68 √ó 68, 36/22. 28 lb. 8 shafts; 56/120 yards, 72 x 76, 36/24. 46 lb. 8 shafts.
text: CREPON: A crepe-like structure obtained in several ways, such as (1) a combination of materials; (2) combination of weaves; (3) combination of materials and weaves; (4) by special chemical processes. Crepons are true crepes, be- cause the fabric when finished is crinkled. The terms crepe" and crepon are now used for any fabric of the crepe style produced by any of the four methods given above. Cloths produced by method 2 are not true crepons. The crepes made for shipping to India, China, South America, and other markets in cotton are produced by method 2 in dobby looms and from 6 to 16 shafts used. Standard makes are as follow:-34/120 yards, 58 √ó 62, 34/16. 29¬Ω lb. 12 shafts; 35/120 yards, 68 √ó 68, 36/22. 28 lb. 8 shafts; 56/120 yards, 72 x 76, 36/24. 46 lb. 8 shafts.

Definition: the italian name for crepon, and made from silk warp, wool weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CRESHI: The Italian name for crepon, and made from silk warp, wool weft.
text: CRESHI: The Italian name for crepon, and made from silk warp, wool weft.

Definition: these are figured muslins with a plain ground and coloured ornament such as flowers. generally used for curtains. woven in jacquard looms.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CRETES: These are figured muslins with a plain ground and coloured ornament such as flowers. Generally used for curtains. Woven in jacquard looms.
text: CRETES: These are figured muslins with a plain ground and coloured ornament such as flowers. Generally used for curtains. Woven in jacquard looms.

Definition: a printed cotton cloth, 30's to 40's warp, 6's to 10's weft (condenser), plain or twill weave. printed in bold patterns, the fabric being covered with pattern. used for curtains and furniture cloths. widths up to 50 inches. satin and oatmeal weaves are sometimes used, but the bulk of the trade is plain or 2 x 2 twill. indian cretonnes are usually 42 inches wide when finished, 48 ends, 32 picks, 36's warp, 8's weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CRETONNE: A printed cotton cloth, 30's to 40's warp, 6's to 10's weft (condenser), plain or twill weave. Printed in bold patterns, the fabric being covered with pattern. Used for curtains and furniture cloths. Widths up to 50 inches. Satin and oatmeal weaves are sometimes used, but the bulk of the trade is plain or 2 x 2 twill. Indian cretonnes are usually 42 inches wide when finished, 48 ends, 32 picks, 36's warp, 8's weft.
text: CRETONNE: A printed cotton cloth, 30's to 40's warp, 6's to 10's weft (condenser), plain or twill weave. Printed in bold patterns, the fabric being covered with pattern. Used for curtains and furniture cloths. Widths up to 50 inches. Satin and oatmeal weaves are sometimes used, but the bulk of the trade is plain or 2 x 2 twill. Indian cretonnes are usually 42 inches wide when finished, 48 ends, 32 picks, 36's warp, 8's weft.

Definition: a plain weave cloth woven from two beams, usually differently weighted, and different counts of yarn. the finer warp is tight and the coaser slack. this difference in counts and tension causes the coarse parts to crimp and become prominent. coloured yarns are often used. a great variety of qualities are made.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CRIMPS: A plain weave cloth woven from two beams, usually differently weighted, and different counts of yarn. The finer warp is tight and the coaser slack. This difference in counts and tension causes the coarse parts to crimp and become prominent. Coloured yarns are often used. A great variety of qualities are made.
text: CRIMPS: A plain weave cloth woven from two beams, usually differently weighted, and different counts of yarn. The finer warp is tight and the coaser slack. This difference in counts and tension causes the coarse parts to crimp and become prominent. Coloured yarns are often used. A great variety of qualities are made.

Definition: originally meant a silk fabric with flat and puckered stripes alternating across the fabric. now applied to cotton dress fabrics of the better quality crimp styles.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CRINKLE OR SEERSUCKER: Originally meant a silk fabric with flat and puckered stripes alternating across the fabric. Now applied to cotton dress fabrics of the better quality crimp styles.
text: CRINKLE OR SEERSUCKER: Originally meant a silk fabric with flat and puckered stripes alternating across the fabric. Now applied to cotton dress fabrics of the better quality crimp styles.

Definition: an a fabric used as stiffening for dress purposes; widths 18 inches to 22 inches; horsehair and cotton yarns. all-cotton variety is made with a hard twist warp.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CRINOLINE: An A fabric used as stiffening for dress purposes; widths 18 inches to 22 inches; horsehair and cotton yarns. all-cotton variety is made with a hard twist warp.
text: CRINOLINE: An A fabric used as stiffening for dress purposes; widths 18 inches to 22 inches; horsehair and cotton yarns. all-cotton variety is made with a hard twist warp.

Definition: the dyeing of a mixture fabric composed of, say, cotton warp and wool weft; the cotton warp has been yarn dyed, and the cloth is dyed when woven in order to dye the weft; such as alpacas, mohairs, lustres, etc. all grey yarn may be used, and the cloth put through two dyeing processes when woven.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CROSS-DYED: The dyeing of a mixture fabric composed of, say, cotton warp and wool weft; the cotton warp has been yarn dyed, and the cloth is dyed when woven in order to dye the weft; such as alpacas, mohairs, lustres, etc. All grey yarn may be used, and the cloth put through two dyeing processes when woven.
text: CROSS-DYED: The dyeing of a mixture fabric composed of, say, cotton warp and wool weft; the cotton warp has been yarn dyed, and the cloth is dyed when woven in order to dye the weft; such as alpacas, mohairs, lustres, etc. All grey yarn may be used, and the cloth put through two dyeing processes when woven.

Definition: a fabric of a stripe character in which the stripes are produced in the weft; generally the stripes are coloured, but different weaves have been used on dobby looms. africa (west and south) and south america use a large quantity of the coloured crossovers in 30 inch and 37 inch 46 √ó 60, 30's twist, 9's colour, and 12's grey wefts, 8 ounces per yard for 37 inch soft finish.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CROSSOVER: A fabric of a stripe character in which the stripes are produced in the weft; generally the stripes are coloured, but different weaves have been used on dobby looms. Africa (West and South) and South America use a large quantity of the coloured crossovers in 30 inch and 37 inch 46 √ó 60, 30's twist, 9's colour, and 12's grey wefts, 8 ounces per yard for 37 inch soft finish.
text: CROSSOVER: A fabric of a stripe character in which the stripes are produced in the weft; generally the stripes are coloured, but different weaves have been used on dobby looms. Africa (West and South) and South America use a large quantity of the coloured crossovers in 30 inch and 37 inch 46 √ó 60, 30's twist, 9's colour, and 12's grey wefts, 8 ounces per yard for 37 inch soft finish.

Definition: in reeling, the yarn is wound from bobbins on to a revolving reel in the form of a skein or hank, in which form it is best suitable for bleaching, dyeing, or merceris- ing. by cross-reeling the thread is traversed in the wind- ing on to the reel, which makes the hank firmer.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CROSS-REELED: In reeling, the yarn is wound from bobbins on to a revolving reel in the form of a skein or hank, in which form it is best suitable for bleaching, dyeing, or merceris- ing. By cross-reeling the thread is traversed in the wind- ing on to the reel, which makes the hank firmer.
text: CROSS-REELED: In reeling, the yarn is wound from bobbins on to a revolving reel in the form of a skein or hank, in which form it is best suitable for bleaching, dyeing, or merceris- ing. By cross-reeling the thread is traversed in the wind- ing on to the reel, which makes the hank firmer.

Definition: is a style of weaving which produces open work effects such as seen in gauzes and lenos. it is produced by cross- ing one warp thread with another, first to one side and then to the other in some definite order. (see lenos.)
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CROSS-WEAVING: Is a style of weaving which produces open work effects such as seen in gauzes and lenos. It is produced by cross- ing one warp thread with another, first to one side and then to the other in some definite order. (See Lenos.)
text: CROSS-WEAVING: Is a style of weaving which produces open work effects such as seen in gauzes and lenos. It is produced by cross- ing one warp thread with another, first to one side and then to the other in some definite order. (See Lenos.)

Definition: a name given to the ordinary 3 √ó 1 twill by the wool and worsted trade.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CROW-TWILL: A name given to the ordinary 3 √ó 1 twill by the wool and worsted trade.
text: CROW-TWILL: A name given to the ordinary 3 √ó 1 twill by the wool and worsted trade.

Definition: a home trade term for good qualities plain cloths 34 in. to 36 in. wide, bleached, and calendered. a standard make is 72 ends, 72 picks, 36's warp, 30's weft. african croydons are a low make of cloth, 28 inches, 125 yards, 48 √ó 50, 50 x 52, or 52 √ó 56, 28's/14's, 28's/20's, bleached and croydon finish.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CROYDONS: A home trade term for good qualities plain cloths 34 in. to 36 in. wide, bleached, and calendered. A standard make is 72 ends, 72 picks, 36's warp, 30's weft. African croydons are a low make of cloth, 28 inches, 125 yards, 48 √ó 50, 50 x 52, or 52 √ó 56, 28's/14's, 28's/20's, bleached and croydon finish.
text: CROYDONS: A home trade term for good qualities plain cloths 34 in. to 36 in. wide, bleached, and calendered. A standard make is 72 ends, 72 picks, 36's warp, 30's weft. African croydons are a low make of cloth, 28 inches, 125 yards, 48 √ó 50, 50 x 52, or 52 √ó 56, 28's/14's, 28's/20's, bleached and croydon finish.

Definition: a type of fancy yarn twist in which loops are formed of mohair or thick cotton or two ordinary threads. one of the ordinary or thin threads and the thick cotton or mohair are twisted together, the thin thread being tightly held and the thick one slackly twisted round it. this twofold thread is then twisted in the reverse direction with another thin thread. the reverse twisting throws up the thick thread in the form of loops. the curls or loops vary in size from small to large. small loops are usually on yarns intended for dress goods, large ones for astra- khans, etc.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CURL YARN: A type of fancy yarn twist in which loops are formed of mohair or thick cotton or two ordinary threads. One of the ordinary or thin threads and the thick cotton or mohair are twisted together, the thin thread being tightly held and the thick one slackly twisted round it. This twofold thread is then twisted in the reverse direction with another thin thread. The reverse twisting throws up the thick thread in the form of loops. The curls or loops vary in size from small to large. Small loops are usually on yarns intended for dress goods, large ones for astra- khans, etc.
text: CURL YARN: A type of fancy yarn twist in which loops are formed of mohair or thick cotton or two ordinary threads. One of the ordinary or thin threads and the thick cotton or mohair are twisted together, the thin thread being tightly held and the thick one slackly twisted round it. This twofold thread is then twisted in the reverse direction with another thin thread. The reverse twisting throws up the thick thread in the form of loops. The curls or loops vary in size from small to large. Small loops are usually on yarns intended for dress goods, large ones for astra- khans, etc.

Definition: a length of warp required to weave a piece of cloth. also the piece when woven. a worsted cut is usually 70 yards. the length in the cotton trade varies from 50 to 120 yards.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CUT: A length of warp required to weave a piece of cloth. Also the piece when woven. A worsted cut is usually 70 yards. The length in the cotton trade varies from 50 to 120 yards.
text: CUT: A length of warp required to weave a piece of cloth. Also the piece when woven. A worsted cut is usually 70 yards. The length in the cotton trade varies from 50 to 120 yards.

Definition: woollen manufacturers use these patterns largely for coatings and vestings. their characteristic feature is a check produced by two adjoining threads working exactly opposite to each other and forming clear cuts.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CUT CHECKS: Woollen manufacturers use these patterns largely for coatings and vestings. Their characteristic feature is a check produced by two adjoining threads working exactly opposite to each other and forming clear cuts.
text: CUT CHECKS: Woollen manufacturers use these patterns largely for coatings and vestings. Their characteristic feature is a check produced by two adjoining threads working exactly opposite to each other and forming clear cuts.

Definition: the folding of a fabric in laps of 36 inches after finish- ing.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CUTTLING OR (PLAITING): The folding of a fabric in laps of 36 inches after finish- ing.
text: CUTTLING OR (PLAITING): The folding of a fabric in laps of 36 inches after finish- ing.

Definition: the galashiels term for the counts used in the trade in which the cut or lea is 300 yards, and the number of these cuts or leas that weigh 20 ounces indicates the counts. s
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: CUT SYSTEM: The Galashiels term for the counts used in the trade in which the cut or lea is 300 yards, and the number of these cuts or leas that weigh 20 ounces indicates the counts. S
