Definition: probably the finest and most flimsy fabric that has ever been made. for centuries the cloth was made by the natives of dacca from local grown cotton, the cotton being spun by hand by women, whose sense of touch was remark- able, and the counts varied from about 450's to 600's. the cloths were usually 36 inches wide, and many of them so fine that they would pass through a finger ring, and 10 yards weighed about three or four ounces. only one or two weavers are making dacca muslins to-day. the fabrics shipped to india of lancashire manufacture and known as "dacca muslins " are perhaps the finest cloths that can be made by machinery, but they by no means equal in fineness the real article. about 110's to 140's warp and 160's to 200's weft is used.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DACCA MUSLIN: Probably the finest and most flimsy fabric that has ever been made. For centuries the cloth was made by the natives of Dacca from local grown cotton, the cotton being spun by hand by women, whose sense of touch was remark- able, and the counts varied from about 450's to 600's. The cloths were usually 36 inches wide, and many of them so fine that they would pass through a finger ring, and 10 yards weighed about three or four ounces. Only one or two weavers are making Dacca muslins to-day. The fabrics shipped to India of Lancashire manufacture and known as "Dacca muslins " are perhaps the finest cloths that can be made by machinery, but they by no means equal in fineness the real article. About 110's to 140's warp and 160's to 200's weft is used.
text: DACCA MUSLIN: Probably the finest and most flimsy fabric that has ever been made. For centuries the cloth was made by the natives of Dacca from local grown cotton, the cotton being spun by hand by women, whose sense of touch was remark- able, and the counts varied from about 450's to 600's. The cloths were usually 36 inches wide, and many of them so fine that they would pass through a finger ring, and 10 yards weighed about three or four ounces. Only one or two weavers are making Dacca muslins to-day. The fabrics shipped to India of Lancashire manufacture and known as "Dacca muslins " are perhaps the finest cloths that can be made by machinery, but they by no means equal in fineness the real article. About 110's to 140's warp and 160's to 200's weft is used.

Definition: a cotton cloth woven in fancy jacquard patterns and used for table covers, napkins, curtains, upholstery cloth, etc. they can be reversible or one-sided only. designs floral or geometrical. yarns 8's to 40's warp and weft. the ground and figure are bound by uniform weaves, generally twill.or satin. the figure is developed by inter- changing the warp and weft and the pattern so made up that the reflection of light on the threads brings out the effect. linen and silk damasks only differ in material, as cotton damasks are made in very fine yarns.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DAMASK (COTTON): A cotton cloth woven in fancy jacquard patterns and used for table covers, napkins, curtains, upholstery cloth, etc. They can be reversible or one-sided only. Designs floral or geometrical. Yarns 8's to 40's warp and weft. The ground and figure are bound by uniform weaves, generally twill.or satin. The figure is developed by inter- changing the warp and weft and the pattern so made up that the reflection of light on the threads brings out the effect. Linen and silk damasks only differ in material, as cotton damasks are made in very fine yarns.
text: DAMASK (COTTON): A cotton cloth woven in fancy jacquard patterns and used for table covers, napkins, curtains, upholstery cloth, etc. They can be reversible or one-sided only. Designs floral or geometrical. Yarns 8's to 40's warp and weft. The ground and figure are bound by uniform weaves, generally twill.or satin. The figure is developed by inter- changing the warp and weft and the pattern so made up that the reflection of light on the threads brings out the effect. Linen and silk damasks only differ in material, as cotton damasks are made in very fine yarns.

Definition: a term applied to damask-like fabrics, but with a fancy woven design.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DAMASSE: A term applied to damask-like fabrics, but with a fancy woven design.
text: DAMASSE: A term applied to damask-like fabrics, but with a fancy woven design.

Definition: a type of damask fabric in which a gold or other metallic or tinsel weft thread is used.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DAMASSIN: A type of damask fabric in which a gold or other metallic or tinsel weft thread is used.
text: DAMASSIN: A type of damask fabric in which a gold or other metallic or tinsel weft thread is used.

Definition: c a light all-wool cloth of plain weave, usually printed either in the piece or warp printed. the term is derived from mousseline delaine," which signifies "wool mus- lin." a good quality is made 54 ends, 64 picks, 46's/64's botany, but up to 64 ends, 70 picks, and from 40's to 70's yarn are used. cotton delaines are now made as imita- ions of the real cloth. a general term for this cotton is "delainette.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DELAINE: C A light all-wool cloth of plain weave, usually printed either in the piece or warp printed. The term is derived from Mousseline delaine," which signifies "wool mus- lin." A good quality is made 54 ends, 64 picks, 46's/64's botany, but up to 64 ends, 70 picks, and from 40's to 70's yarn are used. Cotton delaines are now made as imita- ions of the real cloth. A general term for this cotton is "delainette.
text: DELAINE: C A light all-wool cloth of plain weave, usually printed either in the piece or warp printed. The term is derived from Mousseline delaine," which signifies "wool mus- lin." A good quality is made 54 ends, 64 picks, 46's/64's botany, but up to 64 ends, 70 picks, and from 40's to 70's yarn are used. Cotton delaines are now made as imita- ions of the real cloth. A general term for this cotton is "delainette.

Definition: the term applied to cotton delaines of many qualities. plain weave; printed designs; 70 x 80 to 80 x 100 ends and picks, and 40's to 54's twist, 50's to 60's weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DELAINETTES: The term applied to cotton delaines of many qualities. Plain weave; printed designs; 70 x 80 to 80 x 100 ends and picks, and 40's to 54's twist, 50's to 60's weft.
text: DELAINETTES: The term applied to cotton delaines of many qualities. Plain weave; printed designs; 70 x 80 to 80 x 100 ends and picks, and 40's to 54's twist, 50's to 60's weft.

Definition: plain grey cloths made in rawtenstall, todmorden, and bacup. heavy sized twist. the cloth is usually finished with a glaze finish. made 28 inches or 37 inches wide to finish 27¬ω inches or 36 inches. a popular cloth is 54 x 48 per inch, 24's warp, 27's weft. shipped to west africa and south america.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DELVERS: Plain grey cloths made in Rawtenstall, Todmorden, and Bacup. Heavy sized twist. The cloth is usually finished with a glaze finish. Made 28 inches or 37 inches wide to finish 27¬Ω inches or 36 inches. A popular cloth is 54 x 48 per inch, 24's warp, 27's weft. Shipped to West Africa and South America.
text: DELVERS: Plain grey cloths made in Rawtenstall, Todmorden, and Bacup. Heavy sized twist. The cloth is usually finished with a glaze finish. Made 28 inches or 37 inches wide to finish 27¬Ω inches or 36 inches. A popular cloth is 54 x 48 per inch, 24's warp, 27's weft. Shipped to West Africa and South America.

Definition: a method of counting or numbering silk yarns. the hank is 520 yards and the weight the denier; 533 deniers weigh one ounce. the number of deniers that one hank weighs gives the counts of the yarn. this method is now used for artificial silk yarns.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DENIER SYSTEM: A method of counting or numbering silk yarns. The hank is 520 yards and the weight the denier; 533 deniers weigh one ounce. The number of deniers that one hank weighs gives the counts of the yarn. This method is now used for artificial silk yarns.
text: DENIER SYSTEM: A method of counting or numbering silk yarns. The hank is 520 yards and the weight the denier; 533 deniers weigh one ounce. The number of deniers that one hank weighs gives the counts of the yarn. This method is now used for artificial silk yarns.

Definition: a coarse twill cloth woven from coloured yarns, usually blue or brown, and made into overalls for work- men. widths from 27 inches to 36 inches, 58 √ó 58 per inch, 20's/22's yarns.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DENIM: A coarse twill cloth woven from coloured yarns, usually blue or brown, and made into overalls for work- men. Widths from 27 inches to 36 inches, 58 √ó 58 per inch, 20's/22's yarns.
text: DENIM: A coarse twill cloth woven from coloured yarns, usually blue or brown, and made into overalls for work- men. Widths from 27 inches to 36 inches, 58 √ó 58 per inch, 20's/22's yarns.

Definition: two, three, or more ends crammed in the reed, work- ing as one to form a cord down the piece. corded cloths made this way can be woven from one beam, whereas when a single thick cord is used two beams are necessary.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DENTED CORDS: Two, three, or more ends crammed in the reed, work- ing as one to form a cord down the piece. Corded cloths made this way can be woven from one beam, whereas when a single thick cord is used two beams are necessary.
text: DENTED CORDS: Two, three, or more ends crammed in the reed, work- ing as one to form a cord down the piece. Corded cloths made this way can be woven from one beam, whereas when a single thick cord is used two beams are necessary.

Definition: the wire in a reed. each wire is space through which the warp ends pass. indicate the set of the cloth. separated by a dents per inch
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis

Definition: this is the simplest form of huckaback weave, and is on 10 ends, 6 picks. the warp threads are usually dented 3 and 2 per dent alternately, which tends to prevent the threads splitting in the cloth and forming cracks.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: "DEVON" OR "MEDICAL HUCK ": This is the simplest form of huckaback weave, and is on 10 ends, 6 picks. The warp threads are usually dented 3 and 2 per dent alternately, which tends to prevent the threads splitting in the cloth and forming cracks.
text: "DEVON" OR "MEDICAL HUCK ": This is the simplest form of huckaback weave, and is on 10 ends, 6 picks. The warp threads are usually dented 3 and 2 per dent alternately, which tends to prevent the threads splitting in the cloth and forming cracks.

Definition: a variety grown in the bombay presidency, and is placed in the surat class, has a short fibre, is fairly clean and strong, and of a light cream tint. principally used for counts heavier than 20's.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DHARWAR COTTON: A variety grown in the Bombay Presidency, and is placed in the Surat class, has a short fibre, is fairly clean and strong, and of a light cream tint. Principally used for counts heavier than 20's.
text: DHARWAR COTTON: A variety grown in the Bombay Presidency, and is placed in the Surat class, has a short fibre, is fairly clean and strong, and of a light cream tint. Principally used for counts heavier than 20's.

Definition: a native indian cotton of a poor class; is not strong. it is very dirty, and only used for a low coarse weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DHOLLERA COTTON: A native Indian cotton of a poor class; is not strong. It is very dirty, and only used for a low coarse weft.
text: DHOLLERA COTTON: A native Indian cotton of a poor class; is not strong. It is very dirty, and only used for a low coarse weft.

Definition: are light-weight cloths of plain weave and used by the natives of india as loin cloths. the cheaper styles have a narrow red stripe near each selvedge and red cross stripes or headings; others have simply grey stripes, made by cramming ends in the reed. the better styles have fancy dobby borders of extra coloured warp threads and crammed cross stripes in the weft. widths are about 40 inches to 43 inches, lengths about 4 to 6 yards each, and the yarns are seldom heavier than 36's warp and weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DHOOTIES: Are light-weight cloths of plain weave and used by the natives of India as loin cloths. The cheaper styles have a narrow red stripe near each selvedge and red cross stripes or headings; others have simply grey stripes, made by cramming ends in the reed. The better styles have fancy dobby borders of extra coloured warp threads and crammed cross stripes in the weft. Widths are about 40 inches to 43 inches, lengths about 4 to 6 yards each, and the yarns are seldom heavier than 36's warp and weft.
text: DHOOTIES: Are light-weight cloths of plain weave and used by the natives of India as loin cloths. The cheaper styles have a narrow red stripe near each selvedge and red cross stripes or headings; others have simply grey stripes, made by cramming ends in the reed. The better styles have fancy dobby borders of extra coloured warp threads and crammed cross stripes in the weft. Widths are about 40 inches to 43 inches, lengths about 4 to 6 yards each, and the yarns are seldom heavier than 36's warp and weft.

Definition: a term used to denote a bold twill weave, varying from 8 to 16 staves. used in both the cotton and woollen trades.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DIAGONAL: A term used to denote a bold twill weave, varying from 8 to 16 staves. Used in both the cotton and woollen trades.
text: DIAGONAL: A term used to denote a bold twill weave, varying from 8 to 16 staves. Used in both the cotton and woollen trades.

Definition: a variety of heavy fustian cloth used for sporting clothing and other garments where rough wear is wanted. usually made with a twofold warp and with a large num- ber of picks. the cords run in a diagonal direction owing to the weave being a bold twill. qualities about 56 ends, 2/24's warp, 300 to 380 picks, 20's or 22's are common.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DIAGONALS: A variety of heavy fustian cloth used for sporting clothing and other garments where rough wear is wanted. Usually made with a twofold warp and with a large num- ber of picks. The cords run in a diagonal direction owing to the weave being a bold twill. Qualities about 56 ends, 2/24's warp, 300 to 380 picks, 20's or 22's are common.
text: DIAGONALS: A variety of heavy fustian cloth used for sporting clothing and other garments where rough wear is wanted. Usually made with a twofold warp and with a large num- ber of picks. The cords run in a diagonal direction owing to the weave being a bold twill. Qualities about 56 ends, 2/24's warp, 300 to 380 picks, 20's or 22's are common.

Definition: a form of cross-reeling which gives a more pronounced crossing of the threads as they cross and recross, at such intervals as to shew a series of open or net-like meshes having a diamond shape.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DIAMOND REELING: A form of cross-reeling which gives a more pronounced crossing of the threads as they cross and recross, at such intervals as to shew a series of open or net-like meshes having a diamond shape.
text: DIAMOND REELING: A form of cross-reeling which gives a more pronounced crossing of the threads as they cross and recross, at such intervals as to shew a series of open or net-like meshes having a diamond shape.

Definition: a term generally applied to all weaves of a diamond character.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DIAMOND WEAVES: A term generally applied to all weaves of a diamond character.
text: DIAMOND WEAVES: A term generally applied to all weaves of a diamond character.

Definition: a compound yarn composed of a thick centre thread and two finer ones. the thick thread, about 4's, is soft twisted, with, say, a 2/36's with 8 turns per inch; this double thread is then twisted with another 2/36's, but about 4 turns per inch, and reverse twist. the fine threads are usually different in colour from the thick one. varying qualities are made by altering the counts and turns per inch.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DIAMOND YARN: A compound yarn composed of a thick centre thread and two finer ones. The thick thread, about 4's, is soft twisted, with, say, a 2/36's with 8 turns per inch; this double thread is then twisted with another 2/36's, but about 4 turns per inch, and reverse twist. The fine threads are usually different in colour from the thick one. Varying qualities are made by altering the counts and turns per inch.
text: DIAMOND YARN: A compound yarn composed of a thick centre thread and two finer ones. The thick thread, about 4's, is soft twisted, with, say, a 2/36's with 8 turns per inch; this double thread is then twisted with another 2/36's, but about 4 turns per inch, and reverse twist. The fine threads are usually different in colour from the thick one. Varying qualities are made by altering the counts and turns per inch.

Definition: the original diaper was of linen, and based on the 5-end sateen weave woven on the damask principle. the cloth has a smooth, even surface. cotton diapers are now made and used for towels. two or threefold warp is usual, such as 2/16's, 3/24's, with 8's weft. in the cheaper qualities a single yarn 16's to 24's is used. the term is also applied to pattern and indicates a small dia- mond effect repeated all over the fabric.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DIAPERS: The original diaper was of linen, and based on the 5-end sateen weave woven on the damask principle. The cloth has a smooth, even surface. Cotton diapers are now made and used for towels. Two or threefold warp is usual, such as 2/16's, 3/24's, with 8's weft. In the cheaper qualities a single yarn 16's to 24's is used. The term is also applied to pattern and indicates a small dia- mond effect repeated all over the fabric.
text: DIAPERS: The original diaper was of linen, and based on the 5-end sateen weave woven on the damask principle. The cloth has a smooth, even surface. Cotton diapers are now made and used for towels. Two or threefold warp is usual, such as 2/16's, 3/24's, with 8's weft. In the cheaper qualities a single yarn 16's to 24's is used. The term is also applied to pattern and indicates a small dia- mond effect repeated all over the fabric.

Definition: this term was given by indian traders to a cotton cloth of the fustian character, and usually figured with raised stripes, the stripes giving an appearance of emboss- ing due to the thick weft floats. to-day the dimity is understood to be a light cloth of the lawn character, but with cords forming stripes. ‚äî
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DIMITY: This term was given by Indian traders to a cotton cloth of the fustian character, and usually figured with raised stripes, the stripes giving an appearance of emboss- ing due to the thick weft floats. To-day the dimity is understood to be a light cloth of the lawn character, but with cords forming stripes. ‚Äî
text: DIMITY: This term was given by Indian traders to a cotton cloth of the fustian character, and usually figured with raised stripes, the stripes giving an appearance of emboss- ing due to the thick weft floats. To-day the dimity is understood to be a light cloth of the lawn character, but with cords forming stripes. ‚Äî

Definition: these are fabrics that are first dyed in a solid colour, such as blue, dried without fixing the colour, then passed through a printing machine and printed with a chemical substance which acting upon the dye discharges or clears it from the fabric. when finished the cloth will have white figuring on a blue ground.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DISCHARGE PRINTS: These are fabrics that are first dyed in a solid colour, such as blue, dried without fixing the colour, then passed through a printing machine and printed with a chemical substance which acting upon the dye discharges or clears it from the fabric. When finished the cloth will have white figuring on a blue ground.
text: DISCHARGE PRINTS: These are fabrics that are first dyed in a solid colour, such as blue, dried without fixing the colour, then passed through a printing machine and printed with a chemical substance which acting upon the dye discharges or clears it from the fabric. When finished the cloth will have white figuring on a blue ground.

Definition: a number obtained from the product of the picks per inch, or quarter-inch, and the number of teeth in the change wheel necessary to produce those picks. to obtain picks per inch produced by a change wheel, divide the dividend by the number of teeth in the wheel. dividing the dividend by the picks will give the required change wheel. ?
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DIVIDEND OF LOOM: A number obtained from the product of the picks per inch, or quarter-inch, and the number of teeth in the change wheel necessary to produce those picks. To obtain picks per inch produced by a change wheel, divide the dividend by the number of teeth in the wheel. Dividing the dividend by the picks will give the required change wheel. ?
text: DIVIDEND OF LOOM: A number obtained from the product of the picks per inch, or quarter-inch, and the number of teeth in the change wheel necessary to produce those picks. To obtain picks per inch produced by a change wheel, divide the dividend by the number of teeth in the wheel. Dividing the dividend by the picks will give the required change wheel. ?

Definition: this machine is the most useful shedding motion used in the cotton trade, since it can be used for both simple and complicated weaves. there are many varieties in use, most of them being of the negative type, which have springs beneath the healds to bring the healds down again after being lifted by the dobby. in the cotton trade up to 18 or 20 healds is usual. the length of pattern in the weft can be very great.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DOBBY MACHINES: This machine is the most useful shedding motion used in the cotton trade, since it can be used for both simple and complicated weaves. There are many varieties in use, most of them being of the negative type, which have springs beneath the healds to bring the healds down again after being lifted by the dobby. In the cotton trade up to 18 or 20 healds is usual. The length of pattern in the weft can be very great.
text: DOBBY MACHINES: This machine is the most useful shedding motion used in the cotton trade, since it can be used for both simple and complicated weaves. There are many varieties in use, most of them being of the negative type, which have springs beneath the healds to bring the healds down again after being lifted by the dobby. In the cotton trade up to 18 or 20 healds is usual. The length of pattern in the weft can be very great.

Definition: these machines form various kinds of sheds, viz., closed sheds, centre sheds, open sheds, and semi-open sheds. closed sheds.-the warp yarn is brought to one level right across at each pick. centre sheds.-every thread of the warp is in motion at each pick. part ascends and part decends. the shed opens from the middle. open sheds.-the warp yarn constantly forms two lines and changes are made by moving threads from one line to the other. semi-open shed.-this shed has a stationary bottom line, and to make a change threads pass from the top to the bottom, or only fall half-way and then go to the top again.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DOBBY SHEDDING: These machines form various kinds of sheds, viz., closed sheds, centre sheds, open sheds, and semi-open sheds. CLOSED SHEDS.-The warp yarn is brought to one level right across at each pick. CENTRE SHEDS.-Every thread of the warp is in motion at each pick. Part ascends and part decends. The shed opens from the middle. OPEN SHEDS.-The warp yarn constantly forms two lines and changes are made by moving threads from one line to the other. SEMI-OPEN SHED.-This shed has a stationary bottom line, and to make a change threads pass from the top to the bottom, or only fall half-way and then go to the top again.
text: DOBBY SHEDDING: These machines form various kinds of sheds, viz., closed sheds, centre sheds, open sheds, and semi-open sheds. CLOSED SHEDS.-The warp yarn is brought to one level right across at each pick. CENTRE SHEDS.-Every thread of the warp is in motion at each pick. Part ascends and part decends. The shed opens from the middle. OPEN SHEDS.-The warp yarn constantly forms two lines and changes are made by moving threads from one line to the other. SEMI-OPEN SHED.-This shed has a stationary bottom line, and to make a change threads pass from the top to the bottom, or only fall half-way and then go to the top again.

Definition: a fine woollen cloth made from the best botany wool. the warp is set very closely in the reed, 5-end warp satin weave. the twill is not visible owing to the closeness of the weave, and a very smooth, level face is given to the cloth. a soft dress finish is applied.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DOESKIN: A fine woollen cloth made from the best botany wool. The warp is set very closely in the reed, 5-end warp satin weave. The twill is not visible owing to the closeness of the weave, and a very smooth, level face is given to the cloth. A soft dress finish is applied.
text: DOESKIN: A fine woollen cloth made from the best botany wool. The warp is set very closely in the reed, 5-end warp satin weave. The twill is not visible owing to the closeness of the weave, and a very smooth, level face is given to the cloth. A soft dress finish is applied.

Definition: the operation of removing the filled bobbins from the various spinning machines and supplying empty ones.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DOFFING: The operation of removing the filled bobbins from the various spinning machines and supplying empty ones.
text: DOFFING: The operation of removing the filled bobbins from the various spinning machines and supplying empty ones.

Definition: a term still heard, but very seldom. it is a weft plush fabric made from a twofold cotton warp and cotton mohair weft; the mohair forms the pile. sometimes called "imitation sealskin."ÿß
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DOGSKIN: A term still heard, but very seldom. It is a weft plush fabric made from a twofold cotton warp and cotton mohair weft; the mohair forms the pile. Sometimes called "imitation sealskin."ÿß
text: DOGSKIN: A term still heard, but very seldom. It is a weft plush fabric made from a twofold cotton warp and cotton mohair weft; the mohair forms the pile. Sometimes called "imitation sealskin."ÿß

Definition: these are of two classes, those with ornament made by the jacquard, which are really damask cloths, and those which have ornament added by hand needlework after weaving. the latter style is woven in the loom in circular or square patterns, and after weaving the com- plete circular or square pieces are cut out of the cloth and edged by a machine to prevent fraying.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DOILY DESIGNS: These are of two classes, those with ornament made by the jacquard, which are really damask cloths, and those which have ornament added by hand needlework after weaving. The latter style is woven in the loom in circular or square patterns, and after weaving the com- plete circular or square pieces are cut out of the cloth and edged by a machine to prevent fraying.
text: DOILY DESIGNS: These are of two classes, those with ornament made by the jacquard, which are really damask cloths, and those which have ornament added by hand needlework after weaving. The latter style is woven in the loom in circular or square patterns, and after weaving the com- plete circular or square pieces are cut out of the cloth and edged by a machine to prevent fraying.

Definition: a term given to a very low style of cotton damask. not often used.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DOMECK: A term given to a very low style of cotton damask. Not often used.
text: DOMECK: A term given to a very low style of cotton damask. Not often used.

Definition: the home trade uses this term to denote grey cloths for domestic purposes which are either plain or twill weave, generally pure sized. widths 30 inches to 36 inches, and qualities are many. shipping domestics are much inferior in quality to the home trade cloths, and are as a rule heavily sized. widths are 30 inches to 36 inches, 54 to 64 reed, 70 to 72 picks, 24's warp, and 36's weft, or somewhere near these yarns. heavy domestics are made from coarse yarns, such as 10's to 14's warp and weft, and about 48 ends and 52 picks.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DOMESTICS: The home trade uses this term to denote grey cloths for domestic purposes which are either plain or twill weave, generally pure sized. Widths 30 inches to 36 inches, and qualities are many. Shipping domestics are much inferior in quality to the home trade cloths, and are as a rule heavily sized. Widths are 30 inches to 36 inches, 54 to 64 reed, 70 to 72 picks, 24's warp, and 36's weft, or somewhere near these yarns. Heavy domestics are made from coarse yarns, such as 10's to 14's warp and weft, and about 48 ends and 52 picks.
text: DOMESTICS: The home trade uses this term to denote grey cloths for domestic purposes which are either plain or twill weave, generally pure sized. Widths 30 inches to 36 inches, and qualities are many. Shipping domestics are much inferior in quality to the home trade cloths, and are as a rule heavily sized. Widths are 30 inches to 36 inches, 54 to 64 reed, 70 to 72 picks, 24's warp, and 36's weft, or somewhere near these yarns. Heavy domestics are made from coarse yarns, such as 10's to 14's warp and weft, and about 48 ends and 52 picks.

Definition: a strong, heavy twill cloth, with a raised face on both sides, grey or bleached. it is similar to canton flannel, but napped both sides. the original domet had a cotton warp and woollen weft and was loosely woven. it was used by dressmakers as wadding.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DOMET: A strong, heavy twill cloth, with a raised face on both sides, grey or bleached. It is similar to canton flannel, but napped both sides. The original domet had a cotton warp and woollen weft and was loosely woven. It was used by dressmakers as wadding.
text: DOMET: A strong, heavy twill cloth, with a raised face on both sides, grey or bleached. It is similar to canton flannel, but napped both sides. The original domet had a cotton warp and woollen weft and was loosely woven. It was used by dressmakers as wadding.

Definition: light fabrics having stripes formed by cramming warp ends in the reed. the stripes may be plain or twill and the ground woven one end in a reed. the qualities vary greatly. doria checks are also made on dobby looms, the checking being simply crammed picks.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DORIA STRIPES: Light fabrics having stripes formed by cramming warp ends in the reed. The stripes may be plain or twill and the ground woven one end in a reed. The qualities vary greatly. Doria checks are also made on dobby looms, the checking being simply crammed picks.
text: DORIA STRIPES: Light fabrics having stripes formed by cramming warp ends in the reed. The stripes may be plain or twill and the ground woven one end in a reed. The qualities vary greatly. Doria checks are also made on dobby looms, the checking being simply crammed picks.

Definition: two ends drawn through the same dent in the reed and same eye in the heald and weaving as one. double ends and double picks are common in many matting cloths. double ends often appear in a cloth where not intended, and this is a weaving fault.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DOUBLE ENDS: Two ends drawn through the same dent in the reed and same eye in the heald and weaving as one. Double ends and double picks are common in many matting cloths. Double ends often appear in a cloth where not intended, and this is a weaving fault.
text: DOUBLE ENDS: Two ends drawn through the same dent in the reed and same eye in the heald and weaving as one. Double ends and double picks are common in many matting cloths. Double ends often appear in a cloth where not intended, and this is a weaving fault.

Definition: two single cloths combined together, each with its own warp and weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DOUBLE CLOTHS: Two single cloths combined together, each with its own warp and weft.
text: DOUBLE CLOTHS: Two single cloths combined together, each with its own warp and weft.

Definition: a fabric with a warp satin face on both sides. two sets of warp threads are used with one weft series inter- weaving with both warps. super yarns are necessary.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DOUBLE-FACED SATINS: A fabric with a warp satin face on both sides. Two sets of warp threads are used with one weft series inter- weaving with both warps. Super yarns are necessary.
text: DOUBLE-FACED SATINS: A fabric with a warp satin face on both sides. Two sets of warp threads are used with one weft series inter- weaving with both warps. Super yarns are necessary.

Definition: a combination of two plain cloths woven together at one weaving. the two cloths, though quite distinct, may change places to form stripes, checks, or figures. largely employed for vestings and suitings in both the cotton and the wool trades.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DOUBLE PLAINS: A combination of two plain cloths woven together at one weaving. The two cloths, though quite distinct, may change places to form stripes, checks, or figures. Largely employed for vestings and suitings in both the cotton and the wool trades.
text: DOUBLE PLAINS: A combination of two plain cloths woven together at one weaving. The two cloths, though quite distinct, may change places to form stripes, checks, or figures. Largely employed for vestings and suitings in both the cotton and the wool trades.

Definition: a super quality of yarn made quite free from knots and faults by the double work put on it in the spinning room.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DOUBLE-SPUN YARN: A super quality of yarn made quite free from knots and faults by the double work put on it in the spinning room.
text: DOUBLE-SPUN YARN: A super quality of yarn made quite free from knots and faults by the double work put on it in the spinning room.

Definition: a term used by home trade buyers for a plain cloth made from twofold warp and single weft, good quality yarns. the cloth is used for pillow cases, underwear, etc. widths 34 inches to 36 inches, 60 ends x 60 picks, or 44 ends, one in a dent, and 72 picks; yarns 2/36's twist, 16's to 20's weft. the finished cloth is bleached and soft finished.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DOUBLE WARPS: A term used by home trade buyers for a plain cloth made from twofold warp and single weft, good quality yarns. The cloth is used for pillow cases, underwear, etc. Widths 34 inches to 36 inches, 60 ends x 60 picks, or 44 ends, one in a dent, and 72 picks; yarns 2/36's twist, 16's to 20's weft. The finished cloth is bleached and soft finished.
text: DOUBLE WARPS: A term used by home trade buyers for a plain cloth made from twofold warp and single weft, good quality yarns. The cloth is used for pillow cases, underwear, etc. Widths 34 inches to 36 inches, 60 ends x 60 picks, or 44 ends, one in a dent, and 72 picks; yarns 2/36's twist, 16's to 20's weft. The finished cloth is bleached and soft finished.

Definition: the twisting together of two or more threads to make a stronger and finer thread. many concerns carry on the separate business of doubling, and buy single yarns from spinners. they double these and sell on bobbins, as cops, or on beams.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DOUBLING: The twisting together of two or more threads to make a stronger and finer thread. Many concerns carry on the separate business of doubling, and buy single yarns from spinners. They double these and sell on bobbins, as cops, or on beams.
text: DOUBLING: The twisting together of two or more threads to make a stronger and finer thread. Many concerns carry on the separate business of doubling, and buy single yarns from spinners. They double these and sell on bobbins, as cops, or on beams.

Definition: special heald shafts used in the manufacture of gauze and leno fabrics. a doup consists of a heald shaft termed the "front standard" and a half heald termed the "doup heald." the twine of the doup heald passes over the eye of the front standard and returns through it.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DOUPS: Special heald shafts used in the manufacture of gauze and leno fabrics. A doup consists of a heald shaft termed the "front standard" and a half heald termed the "doup heald." The twine of the doup heald passes over the eye of the front standard and returns through it.
text: DOUPS: Special heald shafts used in the manufacture of gauze and leno fabrics. A doup consists of a heald shaft termed the "front standard" and a half heald termed the "doup heald." The twine of the doup heald passes over the eye of the front standard and returns through it.

Definition: this term for a great number of years was used to denote a coarse linen fabric used as a clothing material by the peasants of france. it is now applied to a cotton cloth made from rough spun yarn and the woven material linen finished with a glaze. a fair quality is 36 inches wide, 60 ends, 48 picks, 20's warp, 10's weft. ¬∑
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DOWLAS: This term for a great number of years was used to denote a coarse linen fabric used as a clothing material by the peasants of France. It is now applied to a cotton cloth made from rough spun yarn and the woven material linen finished with a glaze. A fair quality is 36 inches wide, 60 ends, 48 picks, 20's warp, 10's weft. ¬∑
text: DOWLAS: This term for a great number of years was used to denote a coarse linen fabric used as a clothing material by the peasants of France. It is now applied to a cotton cloth made from rough spun yarn and the woven material linen finished with a glaze. A fair quality is 36 inches wide, 60 ends, 48 picks, 20's warp, 10's weft. ¬∑

Definition: a thick, heavy, and strong grey cloth, generally a drill weave. tinted yarn of a dull brown shade sometimes is used. also applies to a 3-shaft drill dyed drab, and used for corset making and pocketing.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DRAB: A thick, heavy, and strong grey cloth, generally a drill weave. Tinted yarn of a dull brown shade sometimes is used. Also applies to a 3-shaft drill dyed drab, and used for corset making and pocketing.
text: DRAB: A thick, heavy, and strong grey cloth, generally a drill weave. Tinted yarn of a dull brown shade sometimes is used. Also applies to a 3-shaft drill dyed drab, and used for corset making and pocketing.

Definition: a twill-weave linen fabric, sold unbleached for domes- tic purposes, such as tea towels, etc.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DRABBETT: A twill-weave linen fabric, sold unbleached for domes- tic purposes, such as tea towels, etc.
text: DRABBETT: A twill-weave linen fabric, sold unbleached for domes- tic purposes, such as tea towels, etc.

Definition: the indication of the order of drawing in of the warp threads through the eyes of the healds.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DRAFT: The indication of the order of drawing in of the warp threads through the eyes of the healds.
text: DRAFT: The indication of the order of drawing in of the warp threads through the eyes of the healds.

Definition: the drawing-in of the warp threads through the eyes of the healds on the principle that every end that works alike may be drawn on the same shaft. sometimes the least possible number of shafts is not an advantage. the number of heald shafts required is shewn by the draft as every end that lifts differently from others must be on its own shaft. thus a 6-end twill requires 6 shafts, a 12-end, 12 shafts, and so on.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DRAFTING: The drawing-in of the warp threads through the eyes of the healds on the principle that every end that works alike may be drawn on the same shaft. Sometimes the least possible number of shafts is not an advantage. The number of heald shafts required is shewn by the draft as every end that lifts differently from others must be on its own shaft. Thus a 6-end twill requires 6 shafts, a 12-end, 12 shafts, and so on.
text: DRAFTING: The drawing-in of the warp threads through the eyes of the healds on the principle that every end that works alike may be drawn on the same shaft. Sometimes the least possible number of shafts is not an advantage. The number of heald shafts required is shewn by the draft as every end that lifts differently from others must be on its own shaft. Thus a 6-end twill requires 6 shafts, a 12-end, 12 shafts, and so on.

Definition: a heavy cashmere fabric with a fine twill weave, very closely woven, and all-worsted yarns. used for garments for religious purposes.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DRAP D'ETE: A heavy cashmere fabric with a fine twill weave, very closely woven, and all-worsted yarns. Used for garments for religious purposes.
text: DRAP D'ETE: A heavy cashmere fabric with a fine twill weave, very closely woven, and all-worsted yarns. Used for garments for religious purposes.

Definition: perhaps the most important process in a spinning mill, since it is the first stage in the formation of the actual thread. in this process the fibres of cotton are re- duced to a parellel order, and several slivers taken from the card are here drawn or blended together, the weak points removed, and an even smooth sliver results.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DRAWING: Perhaps the most important process in a spinning mill, since it is the first stage in the formation of the actual thread. In this process the fibres of cotton are re- duced to a parellel order, and several slivers taken from the card are here drawn or blended together, the weak points removed, and an even smooth sliver results.
text: DRAWING: Perhaps the most important process in a spinning mill, since it is the first stage in the formation of the actual thread. In this process the fibres of cotton are re- duced to a parellel order, and several slivers taken from the card are here drawn or blended together, the weak points removed, and an even smooth sliver results.

Definition: the process of drawing each end of the warp separately through the dents of the reed and the eyes of the healds, in the order indicated by the draft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DRAWING-IN OR LOOMING: The process of drawing each end of the warp separately through the dents of the reed and the eyes of the healds, in the order indicated by the draft.
text: DRAWING-IN OR LOOMING: The process of drawing each end of the warp separately through the dents of the reed and the eyes of the healds, in the order indicated by the draft.

Definition: fine yarn such as 80's and upwards, and some super qualities are usually dressed on the yorkshire dressing frame, which treats the yarn more gently and with less friction than would be the case if slashed. dressed warps are very common in the coloured trade. d dressed warps (see warps).
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DRESSED YARN: Fine yarn such as 80's and upwards, and some super qualities are usually dressed on the Yorkshire dressing frame, which treats the yarn more gently and with less friction than would be the case if slashed. Dressed warps are very common in the coloured trade. D DRESSED WARPS (See WARPS).
text: DRESSED YARN: Fine yarn such as 80's and upwards, and some super qualities are usually dressed on the Yorkshire dressing frame, which treats the yarn more gently and with less friction than would be the case if slashed. Dressed warps are very common in the coloured trade. D DRESSED WARPS (See WARPS).

Definition: a cotton cloth of 5-shaft warp satin weave and lighter yarns than the satin drill. it is made largely for the home and many foreign markets, both dyed and finished. a sample quality is 41 inches, 64 yards, 120 ends, 68 picks, 36's warp, 42's weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DRILLETTE: A cotton cloth of 5-shaft warp satin weave and lighter yarns than the satin drill. It is made largely for the home and many foreign markets, both dyed and finished. A sample quality is 41 inches, 64 yards, 120 ends, 68 picks, 36's warp, 42's weft.
text: DRILLETTE: A cotton cloth of 5-shaft warp satin weave and lighter yarns than the satin drill. It is made largely for the home and many foreign markets, both dyed and finished. A sample quality is 41 inches, 64 yards, 120 ends, 68 picks, 36's warp, 42's weft.

Definition: strong, heavy warp faced cloths of 3-end weave, good quality yarns of counts from 12's to 24's warp and weft. usually 28 inches to 30 inches wide for the shipping trade. they are shipped grey, grey finished, white, dyed, and printed.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DRILLS: Strong, heavy warp faced cloths of 3-end weave, good quality yarns of counts from 12's to 24's warp and weft. Usually 28 inches to 30 inches wide for the shipping trade. They are shipped grey, grey finished, white, dyed, and printed.
text: DRILLS: Strong, heavy warp faced cloths of 3-end weave, good quality yarns of counts from 12's to 24's warp and weft. Usually 28 inches to 30 inches wide for the shipping trade. They are shipped grey, grey finished, white, dyed, and printed.

Definition: a four-shaft weave from heavy yarns of good quality, warp faced, with a pronounced twill rib. khaki drills are principally made with this weave. sample cloths are 29 inches wide, 88 x 44, 18/16-88 x 48, 12/12-96 √ó 54, 14/14.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DRILLS, FLORENTINE OR FRENCH TWILL: A four-shaft weave from heavy yarns of good quality, warp faced, with a pronounced twill rib. Khaki drills are principally made with this weave. Sample cloths are 29 inches wide, 88 x 44, 18/16-88 x 48, 12/12-96 √ó 54, 14/14.
text: DRILLS, FLORENTINE OR FRENCH TWILL: A four-shaft weave from heavy yarns of good quality, warp faced, with a pronounced twill rib. Khaki drills are principally made with this weave. Sample cloths are 29 inches wide, 88 x 44, 18/16-88 x 48, 12/12-96 √ó 54, 14/14.

Definition: the five-shaft satin weave, warp. faced, in a finer reed than other drills to throw the weft out of sight on the face. the yarns must be good qualities, and free from hard and soft places.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DRILLS, SATIN: The five-shaft satin weave, warp. faced, in a finer reed than other drills to throw the weft out of sight on the face. The yarns must be good qualities, and free from hard and soft places.
text: DRILLS, SATIN: The five-shaft satin weave, warp. faced, in a finer reed than other drills to throw the weft out of sight on the face. The yarns must be good qualities, and free from hard and soft places.

Definition: a term used by designers to denote that the main feature of the pattern forms the four corners of a diamond. this gives a much better appearance than patterns repeat- ing across the fabric on the square principle.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DROP PATTERN: A term used by designers to denote that the main feature of the pattern forms the four corners of a diamond. This gives a much better appearance than patterns repeat- ing across the fabric on the square principle.
text: DROP PATTERN: A term used by designers to denote that the main feature of the pattern forms the four corners of a diamond. This gives a much better appearance than patterns repeat- ing across the fabric on the square principle.

Definition: several shuttle-boxes placed at one or both ends of a loom, which automatically fall into their selected places to enable different colours or counts of weft to be used.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DROP BOX (SHUTTLE-BOX MOTION): Several shuttle-boxes placed at one or both ends of a loom, which automatically fall into their selected places to enable different colours or counts of weft to be used.
text: DROP BOX (SHUTTLE-BOX MOTION): Several shuttle-boxes placed at one or both ends of a loom, which automatically fall into their selected places to enable different colours or counts of weft to be used.

Definition: a coarse fabric with linen warp and wool weft used as a protection for carpets. also made to-day from jute or coarse cotton. d1 ;
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DRUGGETT: A coarse fabric with linen warp and wool weft used as a protection for carpets. Also made to-day from jute or coarse cotton. D1 ;
text: DRUGGETT: A coarse fabric with linen warp and wool weft used as a protection for carpets. Also made to-day from jute or coarse cotton. D1 ;

Definition: a heavy cotton cloth used for purposes where strength and weight are required, such as for sails, boot linings, tent cloths, etc. the original duck was a linen cloth made from double warp and weft of coarse counts, but nearly all ducks are now made from cotton yarns. usually woven double ends and double picks. a light duck is made. this is bleached and used for men's suitings in tropical countries.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DUCK: A heavy cotton cloth used for purposes where strength and weight are required, such as for sails, boot linings, tent cloths, etc. The original duck was a linen cloth made from double warp and weft of coarse counts, but nearly all ducks are now made from cotton yarns. Usually woven double ends and double picks. A light duck is made. This is bleached and used for men's suitings in tropical countries.
text: DUCK: A heavy cotton cloth used for purposes where strength and weight are required, such as for sails, boot linings, tent cloths, etc. The original duck was a linen cloth made from double warp and weft of coarse counts, but nearly all ducks are now made from cotton yarns. Usually woven double ends and double picks. A light duck is made. This is bleached and used for men's suitings in tropical countries.

Definition: a low-grade blanket made from poor quality woollen yarns, about 60 inches wide, in all colours, and napped both sides.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DUFFLE: A low-grade blanket made from poor quality woollen yarns, about 60 inches wide, in all colours, and napped both sides.
text: DUFFLE: A low-grade blanket made from poor quality woollen yarns, about 60 inches wide, in all colours, and napped both sides.

Definition: cotton cloths, 4-end twill weave, warp face, made from dyed warp and weft of heavy counts. some qualities have a white or grey stripe down each selvedge. really a denim with coloured weft instead of grey.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DUNGAREES: Cotton cloths, 4-end twill weave, warp face, made from dyed warp and weft of heavy counts. Some qualities have a white or grey stripe down each selvedge. Really a denim with coloured weft instead of grey.
text: DUNGAREES: Cotton cloths, 4-end twill weave, warp face, made from dyed warp and weft of heavy counts. Some qualities have a white or grey stripe down each selvedge. Really a denim with coloured weft instead of grey.

Definition: cotton cloths printed on both sides in two distinct operations. the designs may or may not be the same.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DUPLEX PRINTS: Cotton cloths printed on both sides in two distinct operations. The designs may or may not be the same.
text: DUPLEX PRINTS: Cotton cloths printed on both sides in two distinct operations. The designs may or may not be the same.

Definition: a dress goods fabric piece dyed and woven on 18/22 shafts in designs made from a combination of twills; patterns repeat on 70 to 84 ends and 20 to 36 picks 84 reed, 70 picks, 2/28 worsted warp, 16's to 20's worsted weft, 56 inches in loom to finish 52 inches.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: "DUSTER" "CLOTH: A dress goods fabric piece dyed and woven on 18/22 shafts in designs made from a combination of twills; patterns repeat on 70 to 84 ends and 20 to 36 picks 84 reed, 70 picks, 2/28 worsted warp, 16's to 20's worsted weft, 56 inches in loom to finish 52 inches.
text: "DUSTER" "CLOTH: A dress goods fabric piece dyed and woven on 18/22 shafts in designs made from a combination of twills; patterns repeat on 70 to 84 ends and 20 to 36 picks 84 reed, 70 picks, 2/28 worsted warp, 16's to 20's worsted weft, 56 inches in loom to finish 52 inches.

Definition: the process of applying colour to yarns or fabrics.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: DYEING: The process of applying colour to yarns or fabrics.
text: DYEING: The process of applying colour to yarns or fabrics.

Definition: a rib fabric with crossover effect with two colours of weft. woven in check looms from all cotton; about 20's warp and 40's weft. the cloth is actually a double weft rib, and when woven shews two stripes of different colours.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ECOSSE OR TRICOT: A rib fabric with crossover effect with two colours of weft. Woven in check looms from all cotton; about 20's warp and 40's weft. The cloth is actually a double weft rib, and when woven shews two stripes of different colours.
text: ECOSSE OR TRICOT: A rib fabric with crossover effect with two colours of weft. Woven in check looms from all cotton; about 20's warp and 40's weft. The cloth is actually a double weft rib, and when woven shews two stripes of different colours.

Definition: second only in quality to sea islands, and is well adapted for spinning into fine counts of high quality. largely spun into yarn in bolton and district. the pro- duction of this cotton is given in cantars (98 lb. to 100 lb.). bales of egyptian cotton are about 750 lb.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: EGYPTIAN COTTON: Second only in quality to Sea Islands, and is well adapted for spinning into fine counts of high quality. Largely spun into yarn in Bolton and district. The pro- duction of this cotton is given in cantars (98 lb. to 100 lb.). Bales of Egyptian cotton are about 750 lb.
text: EGYPTIAN COTTON: Second only in quality to Sea Islands, and is well adapted for spinning into fine counts of high quality. Largely spun into yarn in Bolton and district. The pro- duction of this cotton is given in cantars (98 lb. to 100 lb.). Bales of Egyptian cotton are about 750 lb.

Definition: a measure of length equal to 40 inches, sometimes met with in scotland.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ELL: A measure of length equal to 40 inches, sometimes met with in Scotland.
text: ELL: A measure of length equal to 40 inches, sometimes met with in Scotland.

Definition: are ordinary twills altered either by structure or weave so as to form a more vertical or horizontal twill.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ELONGATED TWILLS: Are ordinary twills altered either by structure or weave so as to form a more vertical or horizontal twill.
text: ELONGATED TWILLS: Are ordinary twills altered either by structure or weave so as to form a more vertical or horizontal twill.

Definition: ordinary cotton velveteen embossed either by engraved rollers or by blockprinting.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: EMBOSSED VELVET: Ordinary cotton velveteen embossed either by engraved rollers or by blockprinting.
text: EMBOSSED VELVET: Ordinary cotton velveteen embossed either by engraved rollers or by blockprinting.

Definition: a fine linen fabric of plain weave, one end in a dent, and used as ground cloth for embroidery work. cotton yarns of super quality are also used in many weights.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: EMBROIDERIES: A fine linen fabric of plain weave, one end in a dent, and used as ground cloth for embroidery work. Cotton yarns of super quality are also used in many weights.
text: EMBROIDERIES: A fine linen fabric of plain weave, one end in a dent, and used as ground cloth for embroidery work. Cotton yarns of super quality are also used in many weights.

Definition: usually a fourfold yarn used for hand embroidery.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: EMBROIDERY COTTON: Usually a fourfold yarn used for hand embroidery.
text: EMBROIDERY COTTON: Usually a fourfold yarn used for hand embroidery.

Definition: a heavy cotton fabric of coarse yarns closely woven and finished with a glazed finish to imitate leather. used for carriage and cheap furniture decoration..
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ENAMELLED CLOTH: A heavy cotton fabric of coarse yarns closely woven and finished with a glazed finish to imitate leather. Used for carriage and cheap furniture decoration..
text: ENAMELLED CLOTH: A heavy cotton fabric of coarse yarns closely woven and finished with a glazed finish to imitate leather. Used for carriage and cheap furniture decoration..

Definition: the individual threads of warp yarn-90 ends per inch means 90 threads of yarn per inch.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ENDS: The individual threads of warp yarn-90 ends per inch means 90 threads of yarn per inch.
text: ENDS: The individual threads of warp yarn-90 ends per inch means 90 threads of yarn per inch.

Definition: missing threads of warp in the cloth, and is a fault caused by the warp ends breaking during weaving.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ENDS DOWN: Missing threads of warp in the cloth, and is a fault caused by the warp ends breaking during weaving.
text: ENDS DOWN: Missing threads of warp in the cloth, and is a fault caused by the warp ends breaking during weaving.

Definition: a dress goods fabric, plain weave, made in yorkshire from a very fine loosely-twisted gum silk warp of about 14 to 24 deniers and a hard-twisted botany weft, single or twofold, of coarse counts. the silk warp is woven in its green state owing to the loose twist, the gum being removed during finishing.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: EOLIENNE: A dress goods fabric, plain weave, made in Yorkshire from a very fine loosely-twisted gum silk warp of about 14 to 24 deniers and a hard-twisted botany weft, single or twofold, of coarse counts. The silk warp is woven in its green state owing to the loose twist, the gum being removed during finishing.
text: EOLIENNE: A dress goods fabric, plain weave, made in Yorkshire from a very fine loosely-twisted gum silk warp of about 14 to 24 deniers and a hard-twisted botany weft, single or twofold, of coarse counts. The silk warp is woven in its green state owing to the loose twist, the gum being removed during finishing.

Definition: a dress cloth made from organzine silk warp and two wefts. woven on jacquards with warp making repp ground by weaving with the two wefts. the figure is formed by warp-weaving with the silk weft only and the worsted floating at the back; a variety is 120 ends, 88 picks, 2/60's black botany weft, and a silk weft woven pick-and-pick. there are many qualities now made.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: EPINGHUE CREPON: A dress cloth made from organzine silk warp and two wefts. Woven on jacquards with warp making repp ground by weaving with the two wefts. The figure is formed by warp-weaving with the silk weft only and the worsted floating at the back; a variety is 120 ends, 88 picks, 2/60's black botany weft, and a silk weft woven pick-and-pick. There are many qualities now made.
text: EPINGHUE CREPON: A dress cloth made from organzine silk warp and two wefts. Woven on jacquards with warp making repp ground by weaving with the two wefts. The figure is formed by warp-weaving with the silk weft only and the worsted floating at the back; a variety is 120 ends, 88 picks, 2/60's black botany weft, and a silk weft woven pick-and-pick. There are many qualities now made.

Definition: a dress cloth made from silk warp and wool weft with the warp printed. the cloth has a jacquard figure floated on the surface. a round cord is introduced in the weft by weaving four or five picks in a shed. the cloth is a very expensive one.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: EPINGLE BROCADE: A dress cloth made from silk warp and wool weft with the warp printed. The cloth has a jacquard figure floated on the surface. A round cord is introduced in the weft by weaving four or five picks in a shed. The cloth is a very expensive one.
text: EPINGLE BROCADE: A dress cloth made from silk warp and wool weft with the warp printed. The cloth has a jacquard figure floated on the surface. A round cord is introduced in the weft by weaving four or five picks in a shed. The cloth is a very expensive one.

Definition: the french term for sponge cloth.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: EPONGE: The French term for sponge cloth.
text: EPONGE: The French term for sponge cloth.

Definition: a 2 by 2 twill worsted cloth loosely woven from rough yarns. the cloth when finished has a fuzzy fibrous appear- ance due to the " napping " of the fibres during the pro- cess of milling. made to imitate the french cloth (6 estame," which is a knitted worsted.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ESTAMENES: A 2 by 2 twill worsted cloth loosely woven from rough yarns. The cloth when finished has a fuzzy fibrous appear- ance due to the " napping " of the fibres during the pro- cess of milling. Made to imitate the French cloth (6 estame," which is a knitted worsted.
text: ESTAMENES: A 2 by 2 twill worsted cloth loosely woven from rough yarns. The cloth when finished has a fuzzy fibrous appear- ance due to the " napping " of the fibres during the pro- cess of milling. Made to imitate the French cloth (6 estame," which is a knitted worsted.

Definition: a gauze or network cloth loosely woven from coarse yarns, cotton and wool, cotton and linen, all linen, silk and wool, and many other mixtures. used as an outer garment over a skirt of some other colour or material. the term is the french name for bunting, or sifting cloth, and was originally applied to cloths used for sifting purposes.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ETAMINES: A gauze or network cloth loosely woven from coarse yarns, cotton and wool, cotton and linen, all linen, silk and wool, and many other mixtures. Used as an outer garment over a skirt of some other colour or material. The term is the French name for bunting, or sifting cloth, and was originally applied to cloths used for sifting purposes.
text: ETAMINES: A gauze or network cloth loosely woven from coarse yarns, cotton and wool, cotton and linen, all linen, silk and wool, and many other mixtures. Used as an outer garment over a skirt of some other colour or material. The term is the French name for bunting, or sifting cloth, and was originally applied to cloths used for sifting purposes.

Definition: a dress fabric made plain weave from a silk warp and fine botany weft. the cloth requires a box loom, since the wefting is 2 picks right-hand twist and 2 picks left- hand twist yarns. the weft is a very hard twist, which produces in the finished cloth a crinkled crepe effect.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ESTRELLA: A dress fabric made plain weave from a silk warp and fine Botany weft. The cloth requires a box loom, since the wefting is 2 picks right-hand twist and 2 picks left- hand twist yarns. The weft is a very hard twist, which produces in the finished cloth a crinkled crepe effect.
text: ESTRELLA: A dress fabric made plain weave from a silk warp and fine Botany weft. The cloth requires a box loom, since the wefting is 2 picks right-hand twist and 2 picks left- hand twist yarns. The weft is a very hard twist, which produces in the finished cloth a crinkled crepe effect.

Definition: fabrics first printed with a preparation substance and afterwards dyed. after washing, the dye is discharged where it covered the preparation substance to form the design.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: EXTRACTED PRINTS: Fabrics first printed with a preparation substance and afterwards dyed. After washing, the dye is discharged where it covered the preparation substance to form the design.
text: EXTRACTED PRINTS: Fabrics first printed with a preparation substance and afterwards dyed. After washing, the dye is discharged where it covered the preparation substance to form the design.

Definition: a raised figure on the surface, such as seen in figured terry cloths. the french term for "figure
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FACONNE: A raised figure on the surface, such as seen in figured terry cloths. The French term for "figure
text: FACONNE: A raised figure on the surface, such as seen in figured terry cloths. The French term for "figure

Definition: the french term for a fabric used as a head-dress made from all-silk yarns, dyed black with a flat rib effect in the weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FAILLE: The French term for a fabric used as a head-dress made from all-silk yarns, dyed black with a flat rib effect in the weft.
text: FAILLE: The French term for a fabric used as a head-dress made from all-silk yarns, dyed black with a flat rib effect in the weft.

Definition: a light weight matting cloth, woven plain weave, two ends in an eye of the heald. the design is a small check about in. to in., 18 ends white, 2 ends colour, 18 picks white, 2 picks colour; usually 36 inches wide, 72 ends by 36 picks, 2/36 warp, 20's weft, 30's colour. made for south america, and shipped finished with a firm finish in 10 yard pieces.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FALL'S CHECKS: A light weight matting cloth, woven plain weave, two ends in an eye of the heald. The design is a small check about in. to in., 18 ends white, 2 ends colour, 18 picks white, 2 picks colour; usually 36 inches wide, 72 ends by 36 picks, 2/36 warp, 20's weft, 30's colour. Made for South America, and shipped finished with a firm finish in 10 yard pieces.
text: FALL'S CHECKS: A light weight matting cloth, woven plain weave, two ends in an eye of the heald. The design is a small check about in. to in., 18 ends white, 2 ends colour, 18 picks white, 2 picks colour; usually 36 inches wide, 72 ends by 36 picks, 2/36 warp, 20's weft, 30's colour. Made for South America, and shipped finished with a firm finish in 10 yard pieces.

Definition: this term has various meanings. in a plain weaving district as rawtenstall a drill is a fancy cloth, while in a shed where jacquards are used the weavers would call a brocade leno a fancy. generally a fancy cloth is any cloth that is not a plain or a twill.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FANCY WEAVING: This term has various meanings. In a plain weaving district as Rawtenstall a drill is a fancy cloth, while in a shed where jacquards are used the weavers would call a brocade leno a fancy. Generally a fancy cloth is any cloth that is not a plain or a twill.
text: FANCY WEAVING: This term has various meanings. In a plain weaving district as Rawtenstall a drill is a fancy cloth, while in a shed where jacquards are used the weavers would call a brocade leno a fancy. Generally a fancy cloth is any cloth that is not a plain or a twill.

Definition: potato starch, and largely used as a sizing substance. it has good adhesive properties and makes a thick paste. requires a certain amount of softening to neutralise its naturally crisp feel..
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FARINA: Potato starch, and largely used as a sizing substance. It has good adhesive properties and makes a thick paste. Requires a certain amount of softening to neutralise its naturally crisp feel..
text: FARINA: Potato starch, and largely used as a sizing substance. It has good adhesive properties and makes a thick paste. Requires a certain amount of softening to neutralise its naturally crisp feel..

Definition: a good quality satin fabric, woven from cotton warp and wool weft. used as a lining material. finished with a lustre.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FARMERS' SATIN: A good quality satin fabric, woven from cotton warp and wool weft. Used as a lining material. Finished with a lustre.
text: FARMERS' SATIN: A good quality satin fabric, woven from cotton warp and wool weft. Used as a lining material. Finished with a lustre.

Definition: a fast colour" is one which after exposure to light after washing or piece-bleaching still retains its depth of colour. colours that resist bleaching are as a rule fast to other influences, so far as the cotton trade is concerned.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FAST COLOURS: A fast colour" is one which after exposure to light after washing or piece-bleaching still retains its depth of colour. Colours that resist bleaching are as a rule fast to other influences, so far as the cotton trade is concerned.
text: FAST COLOURS: A fast colour" is one which after exposure to light after washing or piece-bleaching still retains its depth of colour. Colours that resist bleaching are as a rule fast to other influences, so far as the cotton trade is concerned.

Definition: for fabrics with heavy weft a fast reed motion is preferable owing to greater rigidity. in a fast reed loom when the shuttle fails to reach its box the loom instantly stops by the impact of a metal blade upon the frog. the shock is a great strain upon many parts of the loom.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FAST REED LOOM: For fabrics with heavy weft a fast reed motion is preferable owing to greater rigidity. In a fast reed loom when the shuttle fails to reach its box the loom instantly stops by the impact of a metal blade upon the frog. The shock is a great strain upon many parts of the loom.
text: FAST REED LOOM: For fabrics with heavy weft a fast reed motion is preferable owing to greater rigidity. In a fast reed loom when the shuttle fails to reach its box the loom instantly stops by the impact of a metal blade upon the frog. The shock is a great strain upon many parts of the loom.

Definition: another name for bearskin, which see.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FEARNOUGHT: Another name for bearskin, which see.
text: FEARNOUGHT: Another name for bearskin, which see.

Definition: a full width pattern, half-yard or more sent out to shew cloth. also applied to the finger used on northrop looms for detecting empty pirns in the shuttle. 1 wor
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FEELER: A full width pattern, half-yard or more sent out to shew cloth. Also applied to the finger used on Northrop looms for detecting empty pirns in the shuttle. 1 wor
text: FEELER: A full width pattern, half-yard or more sent out to shew cloth. Also applied to the finger used on Northrop looms for detecting empty pirns in the shuttle. 1 wor

Definition: a term used by both buyers and sellers to denote the peculiarities of a cloth when handled, such as- boardy feel.-yarn is hard or harsh or sized too hard. thin feel.-cloth is very thin in handle. crackly or paperlike.-the cloth has the peculiar crackle of paper. full and clothy feel.-the conditions generally required.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FEEL OR HANDLE: A term used by both buyers and sellers to denote the peculiarities of a cloth when handled, such as- BOARDY FEEL.-Yarn is hard or harsh or sized too hard. THIN FEEL.-Cloth is very thin in handle. CRACKLY OR PAPERLIKE.-The cloth has the peculiar crackle of paper. FULL AND CLOTHY FEEL.-The conditions generally required.
text: FEEL OR HANDLE: A term used by both buyers and sellers to denote the peculiarities of a cloth when handled, such as- BOARDY FEEL.-Yarn is hard or harsh or sized too hard. THIN FEEL.-Cloth is very thin in handle. CRACKLY OR PAPERLIKE.-The cloth has the peculiar crackle of paper. FULL AND CLOTHY FEEL.-The conditions generally required.

Definition: the edge of the cloth which is nearest to the reed when being woven.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FELL OF CLOTH: The edge of the cloth which is nearest to the reed when being woven.
text: FELL OF CLOTH: The edge of the cloth which is nearest to the reed when being woven.

Definition: a woollen fabric united without weaving by the appli- cation of heat, moisture, and pressure.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FELT: A woollen fabric united without weaving by the appli- cation of heat, moisture, and pressure.
text: FELT: A woollen fabric united without weaving by the appli- cation of heat, moisture, and pressure.

Definition: badly-woven place caused usually by a broken warp thread or the entanglement of adjoining "ends." float. see
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FELTER: Badly-woven place caused usually by a broken warp thread or the entanglement of adjoining "ends." Float. See
text: FELTER: Badly-woven place caused usually by a broken warp thread or the entanglement of adjoining "ends." Float. See

Definition: the characteristic, possessed by most wool fibres to a more or less degree, of interlocking together. fine aus- tralian merino is supposed to be the best felting wool. good felting wools make the firmest cloths.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FELTING: The characteristic, possessed by most wool fibres to a more or less degree, of interlocking together. Fine Aus- tralian merino is supposed to be the best felting wool. Good felting wools make the firmest cloths.
text: FELTING: The characteristic, possessed by most wool fibres to a more or less degree, of interlocking together. Fine Aus- tralian merino is supposed to be the best felting wool. Good felting wools make the firmest cloths.

Definition: the tab ends of cloth-short or damaged bits-sold by the pound.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FENTS: The tab ends of cloth-short or damaged bits-sold by the pound.
text: FENTS: The tab ends of cloth-short or damaged bits-sold by the pound.

Definition: the raw materials used by textile manufacturers which are spun into threads. a fibre is the individual constituent of a thread. they come under four headings, viz. :- mineral origin.-gold, silver, copper, asbestos. animal origin.-silk, wool, hair. vegetable origin.-cotton, flax, jute, hemp, china grass, etc. artificial.-spun glass, artificial silk.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FIBRES: The raw materials used by textile manufacturers which are spun into threads. A fibre is the individual constituent of a thread. They come under four headings, viz. :- MINERAL ORIGIN.-Gold, silver, copper, asbestos. ANIMAL ORIGIN.-Silk, wool, hair. VEGETABLE ORIGIN.-Cotton, flax, jute, hemp, china grass, etc. ARTIFICIAL.-Spun glass, artificial silk.
text: FIBRES: The raw materials used by textile manufacturers which are spun into threads. A fibre is the individual constituent of a thread. They come under four headings, viz. :- MINERAL ORIGIN.-Gold, silver, copper, asbestos. ANIMAL ORIGIN.-Silk, wool, hair. VEGETABLE ORIGIN.-Cotton, flax, jute, hemp, china grass, etc. ARTIFICIAL.-Spun glass, artificial silk.

Definition: cloths are termed figured when they are ornamented by means of coloured yarn, extra warp or weft, or by a combination of weaves.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FIGURED: Cloths are termed figured when they are ornamented by means of coloured yarn, extra warp or weft, or by a combination of weaves.
text: FIGURED: Cloths are termed figured when they are ornamented by means of coloured yarn, extra warp or weft, or by a combination of weaves.

Definition: denotes that the cloth has had some substance added to it in the finishing process, the purpose being to fill in the spaces between the threads by some chemical compound and give the cloth a better appearance.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FILLED CLOTH: Denotes that the cloth has had some substance added to it in the finishing process, the purpose being to fill in the spaces between the threads by some chemical compound and give the cloth a better appearance.
text: FILLED CLOTH: Denotes that the cloth has had some substance added to it in the finishing process, the purpose being to fill in the spaces between the threads by some chemical compound and give the cloth a better appearance.

Definition: term used by american traders to mean weft. a weighting substance such as starch, size, china clay, etc., put on to a cloth generally to add weight, sometimes to make it firmer.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FILLING: Term used by American traders to mean weft. A weighting substance such as starch, size, china clay, etc., put on to a cloth generally to add weight, sometimes to make it firmer.
text: FILLING: Term used by American traders to mean weft. A weighting substance such as starch, size, china clay, etc., put on to a cloth generally to add weight, sometimes to make it firmer.

Definition: the name of a machine used by spinners for the further removal of impurities from cotton following the scutcher and preceding the carding engines.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FINISHER: The name of a machine used by spinners for the further removal of impurities from cotton following the scutcher and preceding the carding engines.
text: FINISHER: The name of a machine used by spinners for the further removal of impurities from cotton following the scutcher and preceding the carding engines.

Definition: nearly all woven fabrics are put through some process after weaving to give handle, weight, strength, appear- ance, lustre, or some other property. all these come under the general term of finishing.
