Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FINISHING: Nearly all woven fabrics are put through some process after weaving to give handle, weight, strength, appear- ance, lustre, or some other property. All these come under the general term of finishing.
text: FINISHING: Nearly all woven fabrics are put through some process after weaving to give handle, weight, strength, appear- ance, lustre, or some other property. All these come under the general term of finishing.

Definition: a yarn composed of two foundation threads with which small pieces of short-fibred and twistless slivers are twisted at intervals. when woven gives a round or elon- gated spot or lump.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FLAKE YARN: A yarn composed of two foundation threads with which small pieces of short-fibred and twistless slivers are twisted at intervals. When woven gives a round or elon- gated spot or lump.
text: FLAKE YARN: A yarn composed of two foundation threads with which small pieces of short-fibred and twistless slivers are twisted at intervals. When woven gives a round or elon- gated spot or lump.

Definition: an all-wool fabric of plain or twill weave, usually quite pure since it is worn as underclothing. the best flannel is made from fully shrunk yarns with a slight twist.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FLANNEL: An all-wool fabric of plain or twill weave, usually quite pure since it is worn as underclothing. The best flannel is made from fully shrunk yarns with a slight twist.
text: FLANNEL: An all-wool fabric of plain or twill weave, usually quite pure since it is worn as underclothing. The best flannel is made from fully shrunk yarns with a slight twist.

Definition: coloured flannel in fancy designs, used as wrappers by ladies. a french production, wool all through, 3 by 1 twill, various qualities. fancy yarns and lappet effects often used.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FLANNELLES DE REIMS: Coloured flannel in fancy designs, used as wrappers by ladies. A French production, wool all through, 3 by 1 twill, various qualities. Fancy yarns and lappet effects often used.
text: FLANNELLES DE REIMS: Coloured flannel in fancy designs, used as wrappers by ladies. A French production, wool all through, 3 by 1 twill, various qualities. Fancy yarns and lappet effects often used.

Definition: a cotton fabric made to imitate flannel. plain or twill weave, raised one or both sides, made in stripes, checks, or self-colours. soft spun mule weft usually used. coloured and mercerised yarns are made use of for blouse cloths and shirtings. common qualities are:- 34 in., 72 √ó 64. 34 in., 88 x 48. 36 in., 72 x 64. innumerable qualities and widths are made for both home and foreign markets. 32/30 plain. 22/8 plain. 18 to 24/10's to 18's twill.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FLANNELETTE: A cotton fabric made to imitate flannel. Plain or twill weave, raised one or both sides, made in stripes, checks, or self-colours. Soft spun mule weft usually used. Coloured and mercerised yarns are made use of for blouse cloths and shirtings. Common qualities are:- 34 in., 72 √ó 64. 34 in., 88 x 48. 36 in., 72 x 64. Innumerable qualities and widths are made for both home and foreign markets. 32/30 plain. 22/8 plain. 18 to 24/10's to 18's twill.
text: FLANNELETTE: A cotton fabric made to imitate flannel. Plain or twill weave, raised one or both sides, made in stripes, checks, or self-colours. Soft spun mule weft usually used. Coloured and mercerised yarns are made use of for blouse cloths and shirtings. Common qualities are:- 34 in., 72 √ó 64. 34 in., 88 x 48. 36 in., 72 x 64. Innumerable qualities and widths are made for both home and foreign markets. 32/30 plain. 22/8 plain. 18 to 24/10's to 18's twill.

Definition: a fibre of probably egyptian origin and of very ancient descent. it is found in mummy cloths. obtained from the stalk of the plant "herium usitatissimum." forms the cloths known as linen.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FLAX: A fibre of probably Egyptian origin and of very ancient descent. It is found in mummy cloths. Obtained from the stalk of the plant "herium usitatissimum." Forms the cloths known as linen.
text: FLAX: A fibre of probably Egyptian origin and of very ancient descent. It is found in mummy cloths. Obtained from the stalk of the plant "herium usitatissimum." Forms the cloths known as linen.

Definition: a brocade fabric made with a linen warp and coloured cotton weft. the figuring is obtained by warp floats; the linen floats when finished give a lustrous appearance to the ornament, while the ground appears dead.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FLAX DAMASK: A brocade fabric made with a linen warp and coloured cotton weft. The figuring is obtained by warp floats; the linen floats when finished give a lustrous appearance to the ornament, while the ground appears dead.
text: FLAX DAMASK: A brocade fabric made with a linen warp and coloured cotton weft. The figuring is obtained by warp floats; the linen floats when finished give a lustrous appearance to the ornament, while the ground appears dead.

Definition: an expensive dress material usually with a dark pattern on a lighter shade ground having bright-coloured spots. a short fleecy nap is given to the face. woven with a pure silk warp and super twofold worsted weft. extra warp is employed of a low grade of silk which floats, and the fabric is sheared after weaving; the low quality silk being sheared off leaves a fluffy nap. the spotting is obtained by the better quality silk.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FLEECED MOZAMBIQUE: An expensive dress material usually with a dark pattern on a lighter shade ground having bright-coloured spots. A short fleecy nap is given to the face. Woven with a pure silk warp and super twofold worsted weft. Extra warp is employed of a low grade of silk which floats, and the fabric is sheared after weaving; the low quality silk being sheared off leaves a fluffy nap. The spotting is obtained by the better quality silk.
text: FLEECED MOZAMBIQUE: An expensive dress material usually with a dark pattern on a lighter shade ground having bright-coloured spots. A short fleecy nap is given to the face. Woven with a pure silk warp and super twofold worsted weft. Extra warp is employed of a low grade of silk which floats, and the fabric is sheared after weaving; the low quality silk being sheared off leaves a fluffy nap. The spotting is obtained by the better quality silk.

Definition: a heavy woollen knitted fabric with three series of threads forming face, back, and binding. the back is raised to form the "fleece lining." an imitation is made of the ordinary single thread woollen underwear fabric with a raised nap on its inner face.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FLEECE-LINED: A heavy woollen knitted fabric with three series of threads forming face, back, and binding. The back is raised to form the "fleece lining." An imitation is made of the ordinary single thread woollen underwear fabric with a raised nap on its inner face.
text: FLEECE-LINED: A heavy woollen knitted fabric with three series of threads forming face, back, and binding. The back is raised to form the "fleece lining." An imitation is made of the ordinary single thread woollen underwear fabric with a raised nap on its inner face.

Definition: a float is a warp or weft thread which lies on top of the opposite series for a distance of several threads; thus a warp float is a warp end floating over weft threads, and a weft float is a weft thread floating over warp threads. many fancy weaves are so designed that the floating of one or the other series of threads is re- quired. there is also the float that is not required, and which is a most objectionable fault in any cloth, and generally caused by careless weaving, although inferior yarn is very liable to produce this fault. when one or more ends break and become entangled with adjoining threads this fault is made.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FLOAT: A float is a warp or weft thread which lies on top of the opposite series for a distance of several threads; thus a warp float is a warp end floating over weft threads, and a weft float is a weft thread floating over warp threads. Many fancy weaves are so designed that the floating of one or the other series of threads is re- quired. There is also the float that is not required, and which is a most objectionable fault in any cloth, and generally caused by careless weaving, although inferior yarn is very liable to produce this fault. When one or more ends break and become entangled with adjoining threads this fault is made.
text: FLOAT: A float is a warp or weft thread which lies on top of the opposite series for a distance of several threads; thus a warp float is a warp end floating over weft threads, and a weft float is a weft thread floating over warp threads. Many fancy weaves are so designed that the floating of one or the other series of threads is re- quired. There is also the float that is not required, and which is a most objectionable fault in any cloth, and generally caused by careless weaving, although inferior yarn is very liable to produce this fault. When one or more ends break and become entangled with adjoining threads this fault is made.

Definition: waste fibres obtained from wool during the different finishing processes. there are three kinds, of different values. milling flocks are the most valuable, as they can be used for blending with wool to produce a lower grade. cropping flocks are very short fibres removed during the cutting or cropping process, and principally used by wall. paper manufacturers. raising flocks are similar to the milling, but not as valuable.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FLOCKS: Waste fibres obtained from wool during the different finishing processes. There are three kinds, of different values. Milling flocks are the most valuable, as they can be used for blending with wool to produce a lower grade. Cropping flocks are very short fibres removed during the cutting or cropping process, and principally used by wall. paper manufacturers. Raising flocks are similar to the milling, but not as valuable.
text: FLOCKS: Waste fibres obtained from wool during the different finishing processes. There are three kinds, of different values. Milling flocks are the most valuable, as they can be used for blending with wool to produce a lower grade. Cropping flocks are very short fibres removed during the cutting or cropping process, and principally used by wall. paper manufacturers. Raising flocks are similar to the milling, but not as valuable.

Definition: the four-shaft 3 up and 1 down drill. see drill.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FLORENTINE DRILL, OR FRENCH TWILL: The four-shaft 3 up and 1 down drill. See Drill.
text: FLORENTINE DRILL, OR FRENCH TWILL: The four-shaft 3 up and 1 down drill. See Drill.

Definition: the short, nepped, and immature fibres of cotton thrown out by the card owing to being of insufficient length for the card teeth to hold.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FLY COTTON: The short, nepped, and immature fibres of cotton thrown out by the card owing to being of insufficient length for the card teeth to hold.
text: FLY COTTON: The short, nepped, and immature fibres of cotton thrown out by the card owing to being of insufficient length for the card teeth to hold.

Definition: a cloth of the denim type, but not so coarse in yarns. usually in stripes from blue and white warps and blue weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FODENS: A cloth of the denim type, but not so coarse in yarns. Usually in stripes from blue and white warps and blue weft.
text: FODENS: A cloth of the denim type, but not so coarse in yarns. Usually in stripes from blue and white warps and blue weft.

Definition: another term for doubled yarns.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FOLDED YARN: Another term for doubled yarns.
text: FOLDED YARN: Another term for doubled yarns.

Definition: the real foulard is a light weight all silk 2 by 2 twill fabric printed blue or black spots on a white ground. cotton foulards are made to imitate the silk kind, from super quality yarns and printed in similar styles; usually plain weave.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FOULARD: The real foulard is a light weight all silk 2 by 2 twill fabric printed blue or black spots on a white ground. Cotton foulards are made to imitate the silk kind, from super quality yarns and printed in similar styles; usually plain weave.
text: FOULARD: The real foulard is a light weight all silk 2 by 2 twill fabric printed blue or black spots on a white ground. Cotton foulards are made to imitate the silk kind, from super quality yarns and printed in similar styles; usually plain weave.

Definition: same as china gum cloth, which see.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FOULARD DE CHINE: Same as China Gum Cloth, which see.
text: FOULARD DE CHINE: Same as China Gum Cloth, which see.

Definition: a serge twill dress fabric from single worsted yarns of good quality. a rough fibrous face is a characteristic of the cloth.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FOULIE: A serge twill dress fabric from single worsted yarns of good quality. A rough fibrous face is a characteristic of the cloth.
text: FOULIE: A serge twill dress fabric from single worsted yarns of good quality. A rough fibrous face is a characteristic of the cloth.

Definition: a strong plain weave cotton cloth used for stiffening dresses. medium weights of yarn are usual, and the cloth is stiff finished. very similar to buckrum, but better quality.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FOUNDATION MUSLIN: A strong plain weave cotton cloth used for stiffening dresses. Medium weights of yarn are usual, and the cloth is stiff finished. Very similar to buckrum, but better quality.
text: FOUNDATION MUSLIN: A strong plain weave cotton cloth used for stiffening dresses. Medium weights of yarn are usual, and the cloth is stiff finished. Very similar to buckrum, but better quality.

Definition: are super table covers in which two warps and four differently coloured wefts are used. the wefts form the figuring.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FOUR-PLY BROCADES: Are super table covers in which two warps and four differently coloured wefts are used. The wefts form the figuring.
text: FOUR-PLY BROCADES: Are super table covers in which two warps and four differently coloured wefts are used. The wefts form the figuring.

Definition: the number of frames used in the manufacture of a brussels carpet will to a certain extent determine the quality. three, four, or five frames are common, each frame holding 256 bobbins of yarn; so a 3-frame has 256x3=768 warp threads, and a 5-frame 256 √ó 5=1,280 warp threads. only 256 threads shew on the face, the remainder form the back of the carpet. thus it will be seen that a 5-frame carpet is much thicker, heavier, and more durable than the others.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FRAME BRUSSELS: The number of frames used in the manufacture of a Brussels carpet will to a certain extent determine the quality. Three, four, or five frames are common, each frame holding 256 bobbins of yarn; so a 3-frame has 256x3=768 warp threads, and a 5-frame 256 √ó 5=1,280 warp threads. Only 256 threads shew on the face, the remainder form the back of the carpet. Thus it will be seen that a 5-frame carpet is much thicker, heavier, and more durable than the others.
text: FRAME BRUSSELS: The number of frames used in the manufacture of a Brussels carpet will to a certain extent determine the quality. Three, four, or five frames are common, each frame holding 256 bobbins of yarn; so a 3-frame has 256x3=768 warp threads, and a 5-frame 256 √ó 5=1,280 warp threads. Only 256 threads shew on the face, the remainder form the back of the carpet. Thus it will be seen that a 5-frame carpet is much thicker, heavier, and more durable than the others.

Definition: a very firm and brittle finish given to fine lawn cloths, with a glossy appearance. the fabric is dried on stretch- ing frames in order to keep it stiff.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FRENCH LAWN FINISH: A very firm and brittle finish given to fine lawn cloths, with a glossy appearance. The fabric is dried on stretch- ing frames in order to keep it stiff.
text: FRENCH LAWN FINISH: A very firm and brittle finish given to fine lawn cloths, with a glossy appearance. The fabric is dried on stretch- ing frames in order to keep it stiff.

Definition: a cambric very fine and closely woven, either bleached or printed. woven from good quality yarns. finished with more filling than other cambrics without gloss.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FRENCH PERCALE: A cambric very fine and closely woven, either bleached or printed. Woven from good quality yarns. Finished with more filling than other cambrics without gloss.
text: FRENCH PERCALE: A cambric very fine and closely woven, either bleached or printed. Woven from good quality yarns. Finished with more filling than other cambrics without gloss.

Definition: a satin cloth made with a twist-way spun weft and twill to the right.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FRENCH TWILL: A satin cloth made with a twist-way spun weft and twill to the right.
text: FRENCH TWILL: A satin cloth made with a twist-way spun weft and twill to the right.

Definition: a heavy woollen fabric with a rough, irregular nap, and a more or less hard feel. originally an irish pro- duction; generally grey in colour, and used for the lower grade clothing. also made from a mixture of wool and shoddy, or mungo.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FRIEZE: A heavy woollen fabric with a rough, irregular nap, and a more or less hard feel. Originally an Irish pro- duction; generally grey in colour, and used for the lower grade clothing. Also made from a mixture of wool and shoddy, or mungo.
text: FRIEZE: A heavy woollen fabric with a rough, irregular nap, and a more or less hard feel. Originally an Irish pro- duction; generally grey in colour, and used for the lower grade clothing. Also made from a mixture of wool and shoddy, or mungo.

Definition: a general term to include all fabrics used for uphol- stery purposes, and includes such cloths as drills, cretonnes, repps, brocades, etc.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FURNITURES: A general term to include all fabrics used for uphol- stery purposes, and includes such cloths as drills, cretonnes, repps, brocades, etc.
text: FURNITURES: A general term to include all fabrics used for uphol- stery purposes, and includes such cloths as drills, cretonnes, repps, brocades, etc.

Definition: a term given to the class of cotton fabrics which in- cludes corduroys, moleskins, constitution cords, cords, heavy bedford cords, etc., used for clothing purposes.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FUSTIAN: A term given to the class of cotton fabrics which in- cludes corduroys, moleskins, constitution cords, cords, heavy Bedford cords, etc., used for clothing purposes.
text: FUSTIAN: A term given to the class of cotton fabrics which in- cludes corduroys, moleskins, constitution cords, cords, heavy Bedford cords, etc., used for clothing purposes.

Definition: undoubtedly there is a large amount of speculation in "futures cotton, but there is also a great legitimate trade done which provides a cover for large orders by the spinner. the purchase of futures enables a spinner to cover or protect himself from fluctuations in the price of cotton. if a spinner on october 6 sells his production for the following january, and does not cover in any way he is speculating on the chance that cotton will be less in price in january than it was on october 6. see also spot cotton.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: FUTURES: Undoubtedly there is a large amount of speculation in "futures cotton, but there is also a great legitimate trade done which provides a cover for large orders by the spinner. The purchase of futures enables a spinner to cover or protect himself from fluctuations in the price of cotton. If a spinner on October 6 sells his production for the following January, and does not cover in any way he is speculating on the chance that cotton will be less in price in January than it was on October 6. See also Spot Cotton.
text: FUTURES: Undoubtedly there is a large amount of speculation in "futures cotton, but there is also a great legitimate trade done which provides a cover for large orders by the spinner. The purchase of futures enables a spinner to cover or protect himself from fluctuations in the price of cotton. If a spinner on October 6 sells his production for the following January, and does not cover in any way he is speculating on the chance that cotton will be less in price in January than it was on October 6. See also Spot Cotton.

Definition: the real gabardine is a fabric made from worsted warp and cotton weft. usually woven on 11 staves in a dobby loom with a fine reed, ends more than double the picks, so the cotton weft is not visible on the face. two- fold worsted and two-fold cotton. all cotton gabardines are made in great quantities, 54 inches or wider, with super qualities two-fold warp and weft. some of the lower qualities have single yarns or single weft only. the 11 stave warp face weave is mostly used, but some are made 3√ó1 warp twill. an example of the better quality is 54 full, 90 ends, 140 x 72, 2/60 2/40. both the worsted and cotton varieties are used for water- proofs and coatings.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GABARDINE: The real gabardine is a fabric made from worsted warp and cotton weft. Usually woven on 11 staves in a dobby loom with a fine reed, ends more than double the picks, so the cotton weft is not visible on the face. Two- fold worsted and two-fold cotton. All cotton gabardines are made in great quantities, 54 inches or wider, with super qualities two-fold warp and weft. Some of the lower qualities have single yarns or single weft only. The 11 stave warp face weave is mostly used, but some are made 3√ó1 warp twill. An example of the better quality is 54 full, 90 ends, 140 x 72, 2/60 2/40. Both the worsted and cotton varieties are used for water- proofs and coatings.
text: GABARDINE: The real gabardine is a fabric made from worsted warp and cotton weft. Usually woven on 11 staves in a dobby loom with a fine reed, ends more than double the picks, so the cotton weft is not visible on the face. Two- fold worsted and two-fold cotton. All cotton gabardines are made in great quantities, 54 inches or wider, with super qualities two-fold warp and weft. Some of the lower qualities have single yarns or single weft only. The 11 stave warp face weave is mostly used, but some are made 3√ó1 warp twill. An example of the better quality is 54 full, 90 ends, 140 x 72, 2/60 2/40. Both the worsted and cotton varieties are used for water- proofs and coatings.

Definition: coloured stripe drills, 3-shaft weave, the warp being all coloured yarn. mostly the 3-shaft twill weave, though the 4-shaft twill weave has been used, as well as dobby spots. many qualities are being made. a good sample is 27 inches, 68 x 72, 24/16. the colours are fast for wash- ing, since the cloth is used for skirtings, boys' suits. nurse uniforms, etc.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GALATEAS: Coloured stripe drills, 3-shaft weave, the warp being all coloured yarn. Mostly the 3-shaft twill weave, though the 4-shaft twill weave has been used, as well as dobby spots. Many qualities are being made. A good sample is 27 inches, 68 x 72, 24/16. The colours are fast for wash- ing, since the cloth is used for skirtings, boys' suits. nurse uniforms, etc.
text: GALATEAS: Coloured stripe drills, 3-shaft weave, the warp being all coloured yarn. Mostly the 3-shaft twill weave, though the 4-shaft twill weave has been used, as well as dobby spots. Many qualities are being made. A good sample is 27 inches, 68 x 72, 24/16. The colours are fast for wash- ing, since the cloth is used for skirtings, boys' suits. nurse uniforms, etc.

Definition: a plain matting cotton cloth shipped to india and used for clothing, hangings, and many domestic purposes. about 26 inches in width, 60 x 60, 16's/16's, or 56 x 56, 14's/12's, warped 2 blue, 2 black, 2 ends to a heald eye. the colour is varied.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GAMBROONS: A plain matting cotton cloth shipped to India and used for clothing, hangings, and many domestic purposes. About 26 inches in width, 60 x 60, 16's/16's, or 56 x 56, 14's/12's, warped 2 blue, 2 black, 2 ends to a heald eye. The colour is varied.
text: GAMBROONS: A plain matting cotton cloth shipped to India and used for clothing, hangings, and many domestic purposes. About 26 inches in width, 60 x 60, 16's/16's, or 56 x 56, 14's/12's, warped 2 blue, 2 black, 2 ends to a heald eye. The colour is varied.

Definition: gassing is the process of passing yarn very rapidly through a series of bunsen gas flames in order to burn off the projecting fibres and make the thread round and smooth and also brighter. only the better qualities of yarn are gassed, such as that used for voiles, poplins, venetians, gabardines, many egyptian qualities, etc. there is a loss of weight in gassing, which varies about 5 to 8 per cent., so that if a 2/60's yarn is required 2/56's would be used. the gassed yarn is darker in shade afterwards, but should not be scorched.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GASSED YARNS: Gassing is the process of passing yarn very rapidly through a series of bunsen gas flames in order to burn off the projecting fibres and make the thread round and smooth and also brighter. Only the better qualities of yarn are gassed, such as that used for voiles, poplins, venetians, gabardines, many Egyptian qualities, etc. There is a loss of weight in gassing, which varies about 5 to 8 per cent., so that if a 2/60's yarn is required 2/56's would be used. The gassed yarn is darker in shade afterwards, but should not be scorched.
text: GASSED YARNS: Gassing is the process of passing yarn very rapidly through a series of bunsen gas flames in order to burn off the projecting fibres and make the thread round and smooth and also brighter. Only the better qualities of yarn are gassed, such as that used for voiles, poplins, venetians, gabardines, many Egyptian qualities, etc. There is a loss of weight in gassing, which varies about 5 to 8 per cent., so that if a 2/60's yarn is required 2/56's would be used. The gassed yarn is darker in shade afterwards, but should not be scorched.

Definition: a pure gauze is a fabric in which the warp ends cross every pick, the doup ends being directly crossed from one side to the other of the crossed threads, and the weave is complete on 2 picks or 2 changes. usually woven on dobby looms and two beams used, one heavily weighted for the crossed or ground threads, the other lightly weighted for the crossing threads. lenos are often termed gauzes. this is not correct, since a leno is a cloth in which the crossing and crossed ends weave plain in parts.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GAUZE: A pure gauze is a fabric in which the warp ends cross every pick, the doup ends being directly crossed from one side to the other of the crossed threads, and the weave is complete on 2 picks or 2 changes. Usually woven on dobby looms and two beams used, one heavily weighted for the crossed or ground threads, the other lightly weighted for the crossing threads. Lenos are often termed gauzes. This is not correct, since a leno is a cloth in which the crossing and crossed ends weave plain in parts.
text: GAUZE: A pure gauze is a fabric in which the warp ends cross every pick, the doup ends being directly crossed from one side to the other of the crossed threads, and the weave is complete on 2 picks or 2 changes. Usually woven on dobby looms and two beams used, one heavily weighted for the crossed or ground threads, the other lightly weighted for the crossing threads. Lenos are often termed gauzes. This is not correct, since a leno is a cloth in which the crossing and crossed ends weave plain in parts.

Definition: a french production made from all silk yarns in fine reeds and closely picked. a pure, very fine and trans- parent gauze.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GAZE DE VOILETTE: A French production made from all silk yarns in fine reeds and closely picked. A pure, very fine and trans- parent gauze.
text: GAZE DE VOILETTE: A French production made from all silk yarns in fine reeds and closely picked. A pure, very fine and trans- parent gauze.

Definition: a corduroy cotton fabric made with a 3 or 4 end twill back.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GENOA CORDS: A corduroy cotton fabric made with a 3 or 4 end twill back.
text: GENOA CORDS: A corduroy cotton fabric made with a 3 or 4 end twill back.

Definition: a cotton velveteen made with a twill back.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GENOA PLUSH: A cotton velveteen made with a twill back.
text: GENOA PLUSH: A cotton velveteen made with a twill back.

Definition: another name for the 3-end twill. its other names are jean, cashmere, jeannette, and 3-shaft twill. cordu- roys woven with this twill backing are known as "genoa cords," velveteens or plushes with same backing as plush.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GENOA TWILL: Another name for the 3-end twill. Its other names are Jean, cashmere, Jeannette, and 3-shaft twill. Cordu- roys woven with this twill backing are known as "Genoa cords," velveteens or plushes with same backing as plush.
text: GENOA TWILL: Another name for the 3-end twill. Its other names are Jean, cashmere, Jeannette, and 3-shaft twill. Cordu- roys woven with this twill backing are known as "Genoa cords," velveteens or plushes with same backing as plush.

Definition: genoa a very fine 8-shaft crepe weave fabric made in many qualities for south america, canada, the home trade, etc. super egyptian yarns are used. fair examples are 100 x 96, 80's/120's; 110 √ó 108, 70's/120's.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GEORGETTES: Genoa A very fine 8-shaft crepe weave fabric made in many qualities for South America, Canada, the home trade, etc. Super Egyptian yarns are used. Fair examples are 100 x 96, 80's/120's; 110 √ó 108, 70's/120's.
text: GEORGETTES: Genoa A very fine 8-shaft crepe weave fabric made in many qualities for South America, Canada, the home trade, etc. Super Egyptian yarns are used. Fair examples are 100 x 96, 80's/120's; 110 √ó 108, 70's/120's.

Definition: the original gimp had a centre core of fine wire or strong twine with silk twisted round. gimp yarns to-day consist of a central hard twisted thread or threads with soft spun thread or threads twisted round. the outside threads are generally coloured and twist round the core so closely as to completely hide it. ""
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GIMP YARNS: The original gimp had a centre core of fine wire or strong twine with silk twisted round. Gimp yarns to-day consist of a central hard twisted thread or threads with soft spun thread or threads twisted round. The outside threads are generally coloured and twist round the core so closely as to completely hide it. ""
text: GIMP YARNS: The original gimp had a centre core of fine wire or strong twine with silk twisted round. Gimp yarns to-day consist of a central hard twisted thread or threads with soft spun thread or threads twisted round. The outside threads are generally coloured and twist round the core so closely as to completely hide it. ""

Definition: an all cotton plain weave fabric woven from dyed yarns in stripes and checks. the widths, qualities, and designs are numerous, as nearly all plain checks or stripes can be placed under this heading.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GINGHAM: An all cotton plain weave fabric woven from dyed yarns in stripes and checks. The widths, qualities, and designs are numerous, as nearly all plain checks or stripes can be placed under this heading.
text: GINGHAM: An all cotton plain weave fabric woven from dyed yarns in stripes and checks. The widths, qualities, and designs are numerous, as nearly all plain checks or stripes can be placed under this heading.

Definition: the object of ginning is to remove the seed from the cotton without damaging the fibre. the fibres cling to the seed very firmly, and their removal is always more or less rough and brutal, causing much broken and damaged fibre. two general kinds of gins are used, known as the saw gin "and the "roller gin." the saw gin is best suited for short stapled cotton, while the roller gin is used for both short and long staples.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GINNING: The object of ginning is to remove the seed from the cotton without damaging the fibre. The fibres cling to the seed very firmly, and their removal is always more or less rough and brutal, causing much broken and damaged fibre. Two general kinds of gins are used, known as the saw gin "and the "roller gin." The saw gin is best suited for short stapled cotton, while the roller gin is used for both short and long staples.
text: GINNING: The object of ginning is to remove the seed from the cotton without damaging the fibre. The fibres cling to the seed very firmly, and their removal is always more or less rough and brutal, causing much broken and damaged fibre. Two general kinds of gins are used, known as the saw gin "and the "roller gin." The saw gin is best suited for short stapled cotton, while the roller gin is used for both short and long staples.

Definition: a lustre fabric made from a fine cotton warp and a thicker mohair weft. the warp is heavily weighted, so that the weft does all the bending. sometimes the cloth is figured. the term really means a glossy, lustrous sur- face. also applied to silk fabrics in which the warp and weft are differently coloured, giving a shot effect.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GLACE: A lustre fabric made from a fine cotton warp and a thicker mohair weft. The warp is heavily weighted, so that the weft does all the bending. Sometimes the cloth is figured. The term really means a glossy, lustrous sur- face. Also applied to silk fabrics in which the warp and weft are differently coloured, giving a shot effect.
text: GLACE: A lustre fabric made from a fine cotton warp and a thicker mohair weft. The warp is heavily weighted, so that the weft does all the bending. Sometimes the cloth is figured. The term really means a glossy, lustrous sur- face. Also applied to silk fabrics in which the warp and weft are differently coloured, giving a shot effect.

Definition: a woollen or worsted cloth, 2√ó2 twill or matt weave. both warp and weft are coloured, such as 2 dark, 2 light ends for, say, 24 threads, then 4 dark, 4 light for another 24 threads-weft pattern same as warp.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GLEN URQUHART CHECKS: A woollen or worsted cloth, 2√ó2 twill or matt weave. Both warp and weft are coloured, such as 2 dark, 2 light ends for, say, 24 threads, then 4 dark, 4 light for another 24 threads-weft pattern same as warp.
text: GLEN URQUHART CHECKS: A woollen or worsted cloth, 2√ó2 twill or matt weave. Both warp and weft are coloured, such as 2 dark, 2 light ends for, say, 24 threads, then 4 dark, 4 light for another 24 threads-weft pattern same as warp.

Definition: good quality lining cloths used for the better class trade. the warp is of polished cotton and yarn dyed or bleached, from 120 to 160 ends per inch. weft good quality, but not polished, 60 to 68 picks per inch, about 40's to 60's warp and 30's to 40's weft. usually black ground with narrow white or coloured stripes. brown grounds are also being made at the present time. the weave is generally an 8-shaft sateen.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GLISSADES: Good quality lining cloths used for the better class trade. The warp is of polished cotton and yarn dyed or bleached, from 120 to 160 ends per inch. Weft good quality, but not polished, 60 to 68 picks per inch, about 40's to 60's warp and 30's to 40's weft. Usually black ground with narrow white or coloured stripes. Brown grounds are also being made at the present time. The weave is generally an 8-shaft sateen.
text: GLISSADES: Good quality lining cloths used for the better class trade. The warp is of polished cotton and yarn dyed or bleached, from 120 to 160 ends per inch. Weft good quality, but not polished, 60 to 68 picks per inch, about 40's to 60's warp and 30's to 40's weft. Usually black ground with narrow white or coloured stripes. Brown grounds are also being made at the present time. The weave is generally an 8-shaft sateen.

Definition: a half-silk fabric, silk warp and cotton weft or woollen weft, plain weave. originally used for dusters. but now made for umbrella cloths. requires very careful weav- ing, since faults are plainly shewn when finished.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GLORIA CLOTH-GLORIA SILK: A half-silk fabric, silk warp and cotton weft or woollen weft, plain weave. Originally used for dusters. but now made for umbrella cloths. Requires very careful weav- ing, since faults are plainly shewn when finished.
text: GLORIA CLOTH-GLORIA SILK: A half-silk fabric, silk warp and cotton weft or woollen weft, plain weave. Originally used for dusters. but now made for umbrella cloths. Requires very careful weav- ing, since faults are plainly shewn when finished.

Definition: the very finest tapestry made, and is produced at the gobelins factories in france, where this beautiful cloth has been made for over 300 years. the fabric is the product of art and great skill. hand labour only being required means that one specimen takes a long time to weave. a high warp loom is used in which the warp is tightly stretched, the warp made from a thick, strong yarn, and into this is woven the variously coloured weft threads of soft wool. the wefts are beaten up very firmly so as to completely hide the warp, and form a rib length- ways. the fabrics are double-faced and very expensive. really gorgeous and artistic designs are woven.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GOBELINS TAPESTRY: The very finest tapestry made, and is produced at the Gobelins factories in France, where this beautiful cloth has been made for over 300 years. The fabric is the product of art and great skill. Hand labour only being required means that one specimen takes a long time to weave. A high warp loom is used in which the warp is tightly stretched, the warp made from a thick, strong yarn, and into this is woven the variously coloured weft threads of soft wool. The wefts are beaten up very firmly so as to completely hide the warp, and form a rib length- ways. The fabrics are double-faced and very expensive. Really gorgeous and artistic designs are woven.
text: GOBELINS TAPESTRY: The very finest tapestry made, and is produced at the Gobelins factories in France, where this beautiful cloth has been made for over 300 years. The fabric is the product of art and great skill. Hand labour only being required means that one specimen takes a long time to weave. A high warp loom is used in which the warp is tightly stretched, the warp made from a thick, strong yarn, and into this is woven the variously coloured weft threads of soft wool. The wefts are beaten up very firmly so as to completely hide the warp, and form a rib length- ways. The fabrics are double-faced and very expensive. Really gorgeous and artistic designs are woven.

Definition: many attempts have been made to imitate this tapes- try, but none have been successful. the best is a very poor imitation. mechanical skill cannot take the place of the artists who weave the real fabrics.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GOBELINS TAPESTRY, IMITATION: Many attempts have been made to imitate this tapes- try, but none have been successful. The best is a very poor imitation. Mechanical skill cannot take the place of the artists who weave the real fabrics.
text: GOBELINS TAPESTRY, IMITATION: Many attempts have been made to imitate this tapes- try, but none have been successful. The best is a very poor imitation. Mechanical skill cannot take the place of the artists who weave the real fabrics.

Definition: name given to a weave of a twilled cord character. (see cords.)
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GORDON CORD: Name given to a weave of a twilled cord character. (See Cords.)
text: GORDON CORD: Name given to a weave of a twilled cord character. (See Cords.)

Definition: a honeycomb style fabric used for ladies' costumes. raised on the back only to imitate woollens. made from all cotton, in stripes and checks, with mercerised yarn stripes sometimes added. about 64 ends, 56 picks, 24's/10's and 2/40's mercerised when used, the weave being on 7 to 12 staves.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GOLF CLOTHS: A honeycomb style fabric used for ladies' costumes. Raised on the back only to imitate woollens. Made from all cotton, in stripes and checks, with mercerised yarn stripes sometimes added. About 64 ends, 56 picks, 24's/10's and 2/40's mercerised when used, the weave being on 7 to 12 staves.
text: GOLF CLOTHS: A honeycomb style fabric used for ladies' costumes. Raised on the back only to imitate woollens. Made from all cotton, in stripes and checks, with mercerised yarn stripes sometimes added. About 64 ends, 56 picks, 24's/10's and 2/40's mercerised when used, the weave being on 7 to 12 staves.

Definition: applies to a style of checking in which the checks are designed in a series of sizes from small to large. many years ago largely used in the woollen trade in black and white combinations. to-day often used in cotton cloths with colour combinations of black and white, red and white, etc.; bleached yarn being used.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GRADUATED CHECKS: Applies to a style of checking in which the checks are designed in a series of sizes from small to large. Many years ago largely used in the woollen trade in black and white combinations. To-day often used in cotton cloths with colour combinations of black and white, red and white, etc.; bleached yarn being used.
text: GRADUATED CHECKS: Applies to a style of checking in which the checks are designed in a series of sizes from small to large. Many years ago largely used in the woollen trade in black and white combinations. To-day often used in cotton cloths with colour combinations of black and white, red and white, etc.; bleached yarn being used.

Definition: << a coloured shirting cloth in which coloured warp threads are introduced of two or three fold yarn known as grandrelle yarn." generally of the heavy drill character, with various colours of dyed yarns, 29in. to 33in. wide, in many qualities, bleached weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GRANDRELLE: << A coloured shirting cloth in which coloured warp threads are introduced of two or three fold yarn known as grandrelle yarn." Generally of the heavy drill character, with various colours of dyed yarns, 29in. to 33in. wide, in many qualities, bleached weft.
text: GRANDRELLE: << A coloured shirting cloth in which coloured warp threads are introduced of two or three fold yarn known as grandrelle yarn." Generally of the heavy drill character, with various colours of dyed yarns, 29in. to 33in. wide, in many qualities, bleached weft.

Definition: are twist yarns made in wool, worsted, and cotton. two or three threads are twisted together (generally two), one dyed blue, the other white. one of the threads is itself a double yarn of two colours. used in the cotton trade for grandrelle shirting, and in many colours.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GRANDRELLE YARNS: Are twist yarns made in wool, worsted, and cotton. Two or three threads are twisted together (generally two), one dyed blue, the other white. One of the threads is itself a double yarn of two colours. Used in the cotton trade for grandrelle shirting, and in many colours.
text: GRANDRELLE YARNS: Are twist yarns made in wool, worsted, and cotton. Two or three threads are twisted together (generally two), one dyed blue, the other white. One of the threads is itself a double yarn of two colours. Used in the cotton trade for grandrelle shirting, and in many colours.

Definition: an effect produced to give a broken, irregular, all over appearance to a cloth, similar to crepes.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GRANITE WEAVE: An effect produced to give a broken, irregular, all over appearance to a cloth, similar to crepes.
text: GRANITE WEAVE: An effect produced to give a broken, irregular, all over appearance to a cloth, similar to crepes.

Definition: are designs made from the ordinary satin base and other adjoining ends lifted in regular order to give small broken effects. largely used as a ground weave for jac- quard designs.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GRANITE PATTERNS: Are designs made from the ordinary satin base and other adjoining ends lifted in regular order to give small broken effects. Largely used as a ground weave for jac- quard designs.
text: GRANITE PATTERNS: Are designs made from the ordinary satin base and other adjoining ends lifted in regular order to give small broken effects. Largely used as a ground weave for jac- quard designs.

Definition: the oldest known method of bleaching, and still used for fine linen cloths. this method depends for its bleaching effect upon sunlight and the oxygen in the air. requires a long time to get a good white, as it is simply exposure of the cloth in the open air.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GRASS BLEACH: The oldest known method of bleaching, and still used for fine linen cloths. This method depends for its bleaching effect upon sunlight and the oxygen in the air. Requires a long time to get a good white, as it is simply exposure of the cloth in the open air.
text: GRASS BLEACH: The oldest known method of bleaching, and still used for fine linen cloths. This method depends for its bleaching effect upon sunlight and the oxygen in the air. Requires a long time to get a good white, as it is simply exposure of the cloth in the open air.

Definition: a honeycomb style of weave, but based on the diaper principle, so that a pattern is formed both sides of the cloth.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GRECIAN WEAVE: A honeycomb style of weave, but based on the diaper principle, so that a pattern is formed both sides of the cloth.
text: GRECIAN WEAVE: A honeycomb style of weave, but based on the diaper principle, so that a pattern is formed both sides of the cloth.

Definition: a low quality check fabric, all cotton, about 64 √ó 56, 36/36's, made for the near east markets in widths 48 splits, 36, and 29 single widths. the designs are of the tartan character, nearly all colour. the cloth is stiff finished.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GREEK CHECKS: A low quality check fabric, all cotton, about 64 √ó 56, 36/36's, made for the Near East markets in widths 48 splits, 36, and 29 single widths. The designs are of the tartan character, nearly all colour. The cloth is stiff finished.
text: GREEK CHECKS: A low quality check fabric, all cotton, about 64 √ó 56, 36/36's, made for the Near East markets in widths 48 splits, 36, and 29 single widths. The designs are of the tartan character, nearly all colour. The cloth is stiff finished.

Definition: a black yarn dyed cotton warp with alpaca weft used for dress purposes. the weave is a 5-end satin weft twill, 3 down and 2 up.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GRENADA: A black yarn dyed cotton warp with alpaca weft used for dress purposes. The weave is a 5-end satin weft twill, 3 down and 2 up.
text: GRENADA: A black yarn dyed cotton warp with alpaca weft used for dress purposes. The weave is a 5-end satin weft twill, 3 down and 2 up.

Definition: this is a dress material of an open gauze-like weave. made from hard twisted yarns; cotton, silk, and wool are made use of in the many qualities on the market. yarns are dyed and of many colours. stripes and checks are formed by crammed work, the stripes or checks being opaque and the groundwork being gauze.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GRENADINE: This is a dress material of an open gauze-like weave. Made from hard twisted yarns; cotton, silk, and wool are made use of in the many qualities on the market. Yarns are dyed and of many colours. Stripes and checks are formed by crammed work, the stripes or checks being opaque and the groundwork being gauze.
text: GRENADINE: This is a dress material of an open gauze-like weave. Made from hard twisted yarns; cotton, silk, and wool are made use of in the many qualities on the market. Yarns are dyed and of many colours. Stripes and checks are formed by crammed work, the stripes or checks being opaque and the groundwork being gauze.

Definition: all cotton cloths not containing bleached or dyed yarns are called greys, whether plain or fancy weaves.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GREYS: All cotton cloths not containing bleached or dyed yarns are called greys, whether plain or fancy weaves.
text: GREYS: All cotton cloths not containing bleached or dyed yarns are called greys, whether plain or fancy weaves.

Definition: all drills came under this term at one time, but gradually the term has come to be applied to the 3-shaft warp face weave, 2 up, 1 down, made from heavy yarns such as 12's to 24's warp and weft. these cloths are used for boot linings, suitings, etc.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GREY DRILLS: All drills came under this term at one time, but gradually the term has come to be applied to the 3-shaft warp face weave, 2 up, 1 down, made from heavy yarns such as 12's to 24's warp and weft. These cloths are used for boot linings, suitings, etc.
text: GREY DRILLS: All drills came under this term at one time, but gradually the term has come to be applied to the 3-shaft warp face weave, 2 up, 1 down, made from heavy yarns such as 12's to 24's warp and weft. These cloths are used for boot linings, suitings, etc.

Definition: these are drills of lighter yarns than from 24's to 36's warp and weft; all cotton. many widths and qualities. grey drills,' made in ‹ô grey sheetings (see sheetings)‚äî the real sheetings are made 2 by 2 twill and up to 120in. wide. waste sheeting: weft is condensor yarn. american sheetings are 30in. to 36in. wide, low reed and pick and 30's to 36's warp, 16's to 24's weft, plain weave. these are not sheetings at all, but a plain cloth.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GREY JEANS: These are drills of lighter yarns than from 24's to 36's warp and weft; all cotton. many widths and qualities. grey drills,' Made in ‹ô GREY SHEETINGS (See SHEETINGS)‚Äî The real sheetings are made 2 by 2 twill and up to 120in. wide. Waste sheeting: weft is condensor yarn. American sheetings are 30in. to 36in. wide, low reed and pick and 30's to 36's warp, 16's to 24's weft, plain weave. These are not sheetings at all, but a plain cloth.
text: GREY JEANS: These are drills of lighter yarns than from 24's to 36's warp and weft; all cotton. many widths and qualities. grey drills,' Made in ‹ô GREY SHEETINGS (See SHEETINGS)‚Äî The real sheetings are made 2 by 2 twill and up to 120in. wide. Waste sheeting: weft is condensor yarn. American sheetings are 30in. to 36in. wide, low reed and pick and 30's to 36's warp, 16's to 24's weft, plain weave. These are not sheetings at all, but a plain cloth.

Definition: a term used by both shippers and merchants to indicate that a cloth is very reedy; two or three ends being together and spaces between each two or three.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GRINNY CLOTH: A term used by both shippers and merchants to indicate that a cloth is very reedy; two or three ends being together and spaces between each two or three.
text: GRINNY CLOTH: A term used by both shippers and merchants to indicate that a cloth is very reedy; two or three ends being together and spaces between each two or three.

Definition: a well woven plain weave silk fabric made from good organzine silk.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GROS DE NAPLES: A well woven plain weave silk fabric made from good organzine silk.
text: GROS DE NAPLES: A well woven plain weave silk fabric made from good organzine silk.

Definition: silk fabrics as gros de naples, but having coloured cross over stripes in the weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GROS DES INDES: Silk fabrics as Gros de Naples, but having coloured cross over stripes in the weft.
text: GROS DES INDES: Silk fabrics as Gros de Naples, but having coloured cross over stripes in the weft.

Definition: a weft rib half silk fabric, silk warp and cotton weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GROSGRAIN: A weft rib half silk fabric, silk warp and cotton weft.
text: GROSGRAIN: A weft rib half silk fabric, silk warp and cotton weft.

Definition: that portion of a figured fabric which does not form figure.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GROUND WEAVES: That portion of a figured fabric which does not form figure.
text: GROUND WEAVES: That portion of a figured fabric which does not form figure.

Definition: grey cloths shipped to the french west african colo- nies. about 39in. wide, 80 ends, 80 picks, various yarns. the natives dye them blue. el
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GUINEA CLOTHS: Grey cloths shipped to the French West African colo- nies. About 39in. wide, 80 ends, 80 picks, various yarns. The natives dye them blue. El
text: GUINEA CLOTHS: Grey cloths shipped to the French West African colo- nies. About 39in. wide, 80 ends, 80 picks, various yarns. The natives dye them blue. El

Definition: the plain weave grey sheeting cloth, 36 in. 40 yards, about 72 √ó 56, 34's/20's, used for the indian trade.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GUMPTY SHEETING: The plain weave grey sheeting cloth, 36 in. 40 yards, about 72 √ó 56, 34's/20's, used for the Indian trade.
text: GUMPTY SHEETING: The plain weave grey sheeting cloth, 36 in. 40 yards, about 72 √ó 56, 34's/20's, used for the Indian trade.

Definition: a very coarse canvas-like fabric, made from jute yarns. first made in india into bags for shipping purposes.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: GUNNY CLOTHS OR BAGS: A very coarse canvas-like fabric, made from jute yarns. First made in India into bags for shipping purposes.
text: GUNNY CLOTHS OR BAGS: A very coarse canvas-like fabric, made from jute yarns. First made in India into bags for shipping purposes.

Definition: a woollen fabric used for ladies' riding costumes. made from all wool of good quality. yarns are dyed dark blue and other dark shades. almost any costume cloth of dark colour can come under this heading if of good quality.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HABIT CLOTH: A woollen fabric used for ladies' riding costumes. Made from all wool of good quality. Yarns are dyed dark blue and other dark shades. Almost any costume cloth of dark colour can come under this heading if of good quality.
text: HABIT CLOTH: A woollen fabric used for ladies' riding costumes. Made from all wool of good quality. Yarns are dyed dark blue and other dark shades. Almost any costume cloth of dark colour can come under this heading if of good quality.

Definition: a name given by the japanese to a silk fabric made on hand looms in matting weave 2 ends and 2 picks working together. also made plain weave, fine reed, and large number of picks. the cloth is very smooth and level and well woven.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HABUTAI: A name given by the Japanese to a silk fabric made on hand looms in matting weave 2 ends and 2 picks working together. Also made plain weave, fine reed, and large number of picks. The cloth is very smooth and level and well woven.
text: HABUTAI: A name given by the Japanese to a silk fabric made on hand looms in matting weave 2 ends and 2 picks working together. Also made plain weave, fine reed, and large number of picks. The cloth is very smooth and level and well woven.

Definition: this fabric is woven from a very strong cotton warp, three-fold yarn and horse-hair weft. other material, such as linen, has been used for the warp. about 32 ends per inch, and 80 to 100 picks. the weave is usually the 5-end satin. horse-hair cannot be dyed, so for this cloth it is taken from the darkest horses, generally black, and is cut from both the tales and manes. the lengths vary from 30in. to 46in. when cut they are brushed together. a special loom is used fitted with mechanism for pick- ing up the short lengths of hair and drawing them into the shed. the shuttle is the mechanism for doing this by means of a pair of nippers.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HAIR CLOTH: This fabric is woven from a very strong cotton warp, three-fold yarn and horse-hair weft. Other material, such as linen, has been used for the warp. About 32 ends per inch, and 80 to 100 picks. The weave is usually the 5-end satin. Horse-hair cannot be dyed, so for this cloth it is taken from the darkest horses, generally black, and is cut from both the tales and manes. The lengths vary from 30in. to 46in. When cut they are brushed together. A special loom is used fitted with mechanism for pick- ing up the short lengths of hair and drawing them into the shed. The shuttle is the mechanism for doing this by means of a pair of nippers.
text: HAIR CLOTH: This fabric is woven from a very strong cotton warp, three-fold yarn and horse-hair weft. Other material, such as linen, has been used for the warp. About 32 ends per inch, and 80 to 100 picks. The weave is usually the 5-end satin. Horse-hair cannot be dyed, so for this cloth it is taken from the darkest horses, generally black, and is cut from both the tales and manes. The lengths vary from 30in. to 46in. When cut they are brushed together. A special loom is used fitted with mechanism for pick- ing up the short lengths of hair and drawing them into the shed. The shuttle is the mechanism for doing this by means of a pair of nippers.

Definition: these are cotton cloths in which a single cord is run in the warp, the cords being about in. apart. two beams are necessary. yarns are about 36's twists 16's cords, 36's or 42's weft. ends, picks, and lengths vary.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HAIR CORDS: These are cotton cloths in which a single cord is run in the warp, the cords being about in. apart. Two beams are necessary. Yarns are about 36's twists 16's cords, 36's or 42's weft. Ends, picks, and lengths vary.
text: HAIR CORDS: These are cotton cloths in which a single cord is run in the warp, the cords being about in. apart. Two beams are necessary. Yarns are about 36's twists 16's cords, 36's or 42's weft. Ends, picks, and lengths vary.

Definition: a plain weave cloth woven with fine warp and weft and hair cords, fin. to in. apart.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HAIR CORD MUSLIN: A plain weave cloth woven with fine warp and weft and hair cords, fin. to in. apart.
text: HAIR CORD MUSLIN: A plain weave cloth woven with fine warp and weft and hair cords, fin. to in. apart.

Definition: the true hairline is a check cloth woven double plain weave in white and black (or other colours) stripe and check, with white warp covered with white weft and black warp with black weft. wefting is the same as the warp. each line of colour in both warp and weft is equal to the width of one thread only. cloths with lines in the warp only are not real hair- lines, although generally termed as such.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HAIRLINES: The true hairline is a check cloth woven double plain weave in white and black (or other colours) stripe and check, with white warp covered with white weft and black warp with black weft. Wefting is the same as the warp. Each line of colour in both warp and weft is equal to the width of one thread only. Cloths with lines in the warp only are not real hair- lines, although generally termed as such.
text: HAIRLINES: The true hairline is a check cloth woven double plain weave in white and black (or other colours) stripe and check, with white warp covered with white weft and black warp with black weft. Wefting is the same as the warp. Each line of colour in both warp and weft is equal to the width of one thread only. Cloths with lines in the warp only are not real hair- lines, although generally termed as such.

Definition: this is a term used by both buyers and salesmen to denote the feel or handle of a cloth so far as its hardness, harshness, softness, smoothness, etc., are concerned.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HANDLE: This is a term used by both buyers and salesmen to denote the feel or handle of a cloth so far as its hardness, harshness, softness, smoothness, etc., are concerned.
text: HANDLE: This is a term used by both buyers and salesmen to denote the feel or handle of a cloth so far as its hardness, harshness, softness, smoothness, etc., are concerned.

Definition: a fixed length of yarn which varies for different material. the cotton hank is 840yds., spun silk 840yds., worsted 560yds., wool 1,600yds., raw silk 1,000yds.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HANK: A fixed length of yarn which varies for different material. The cotton hank is 840yds., spun silk 840yds., worsted 560yds., wool 1,600yds., raw silk 1,000yds.
text: HANK: A fixed length of yarn which varies for different material. The cotton hank is 840yds., spun silk 840yds., worsted 560yds., wool 1,600yds., raw silk 1,000yds.

Definition: a method of sizing used for coloured or white yarns, and those grey yarns that form part of stripe work. weft yarn when sized is hank sized. very small warps can be prepared by this method.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HANK SIZING: A method of sizing used for coloured or white yarns, and those grey yarns that form part of stripe work. Weft yarn when sized is hank sized. Very small warps can be prepared by this method.
text: HANK SIZING: A method of sizing used for coloured or white yarns, and those grey yarns that form part of stripe work. Weft yarn when sized is hank sized. Very small warps can be prepared by this method.

Definition: all spun yarns have twist, but a hard twist yarn has more twist than usual, such extra twist or turns per inch are for some special purpose, such as for weaving voiles, gabardines, crepes, canvas, etc.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HARD TWIST: All spun yarns have twist, but a hard twist yarn has more twist than usual, such extra twist or turns per inch are for some special purpose, such as for weaving voiles, gabardines, crepes, canvas, etc.
text: HARD TWIST: All spun yarns have twist, but a hard twist yarn has more twist than usual, such extra twist or turns per inch are for some special purpose, such as for weaving voiles, gabardines, crepes, canvas, etc.

Definition: plain weave cloths with striking colour combinations in the warp, the colours being brilliant and with no attempt at tone or harmony. as many as five or six different colours are used, generally 30 in. wide, and in many quali- ties. washing colours only are used, as the cloth is finished and not bleached.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HARLEQUIN STRIPES: Plain weave cloths with striking colour combinations in the warp, the colours being brilliant and with no attempt at tone or harmony. As many as five or six different colours are used, generally 30 in. wide, and in many quali- ties. Washing colours only are used, as the cloth is finished and not bleached.
text: HARLEQUIN STRIPES: Plain weave cloths with striking colour combinations in the warp, the colours being brilliant and with no attempt at tone or harmony. As many as five or six different colours are used, generally 30 in. wide, and in many quali- ties. Washing colours only are used, as the cloth is finished and not bleached.

Definition: the harness of a jacquard machine is the series of cords and attachments used to make the pattern. it is built up of several parts; the lingoes or weights at the bottom. to the lingoe is attached a cord called the bottom piece or "hanger, which is connected at its upper end to the eye or mail through which the warp end passes. from the mail and passing through the comber board is another cord called the top piece or sleeper, and this is tied to the neck cord or band, the neck band being tied to the hook of the machine. "( "" there are the following kinds of harness :- ¬∑- full harness.-each thread can be lifted indepen- dently, because one thread of warp is drawn through each eye only. pressure harness.-several threads are drawn through each eye. half harness.-only half the warp threads are drawn through the eyes, the other half are worked by heald shafts, and pass loosely between the harness cords. split harness.-this is largely used in the silk trade. two threads are worked by each hook for figure, the ground of the cloth being woven by other means.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HARNESS: The harness of a jacquard machine is the series of cords and attachments used to make the pattern. It is built up of several parts; the lingoes or weights at the bottom. To the lingoe is attached a cord called the bottom piece or "hanger, which is connected at its upper end to the eye or mail through which the warp end passes. From the mail and passing through the comber board is another cord called the top piece or sleeper, and this is tied to the neck cord or band, the neck band being tied to the hook of the machine. "( "" There are the following kinds of harness :- ¬∑- FULL HARNESS.-Each thread can be lifted indepen- dently, because one thread of warp is drawn through each eye only. PRESSURE HARNESS.-Several threads are drawn through each eye. HALF HARNESS.-Only half the warp threads are drawn through the eyes, the other half are worked by heald shafts, and pass loosely between the harness cords. SPLIT HARNESS.-This is largely used in the silk trade. Two threads are worked by each hook for figure, the ground of the cloth being woven by other means.
