To the lingoe is attached a cord called the bottom piece or "hanger, which is connected at its upper end to the eye or mail through which the warp end passes. From the mail and passing through the comber board is another cord called the top piece or sleeper, and this is tied to the neck cord or band, the neck band being tied to the hook of the machine. "( "" There are the following kinds of harness :- ¬∑- FULL HARNESS.-Each thread can be lifted indepen- dently, because one thread of warp is drawn through each eye only. PRESSURE HARNESS.-Several threads are drawn through each eye. HALF HARNESS.-Only half the warp threads are drawn through the eyes, the other half are worked by heald shafts, and pass loosely between the harness cords. SPLIT HARNESS.-This is largely used in the silk trade. Two threads are worked by each hook for figure, the ground of the cloth being woven by other means.

Definition: a very low quality of lappet spot fabrics made in the glasgow district. lancashire makers as a rule think the cloth is too low in quality to weave on their looms. various widths; about 48 ends, 48 picks per inch, 36's twist, 42's weft, checked with two picks, 14's or 16's yarn, in lin., 2in. checks. the lappet spots are weft yarn. bleached and finished "scotch finish.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HARNESS CHECKS: A very low quality of lappet spot fabrics made in the Glasgow district. Lancashire makers as a rule think the cloth is too low in quality to weave on their looms. Various widths; about 48 ends, 48 picks per inch, 36's twist, 42's weft, checked with two picks, 14's or 16's yarn, in lin., 2in. checks. The lappet spots are weft yarn. Bleached and finished "Scotch finish.
text: HARNESS CHECKS: A very low quality of lappet spot fabrics made in the Glasgow district. Lancashire makers as a rule think the cloth is too low in quality to weave on their looms. Various widths; about 48 ends, 48 picks per inch, 36's twist, 42's weft, checked with two picks, 14's or 16's yarn, in lin., 2in. checks. The lappet spots are weft yarn. Bleached and finished "Scotch finish.

Definition: the word harness is used by american manufacturers to signify shafts, thus a three-harness twill is a three- shaft twill, a six harness twill a six-shaft twill, and so on.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HARNESS TWILLS: The word harness is used by American manufacturers to signify shafts, thus a three-harness twill is a three- shaft twill, a six harness twill a six-shaft twill, and so on.
text: HARNESS TWILLS: The word harness is used by American manufacturers to signify shafts, thus a three-harness twill is a three- shaft twill, a six harness twill a six-shaft twill, and so on.

Definition: a shirting cloth woven with the 2 by 2 twill weave and with coloured stripes. the genuine harvard has the 2 by 2 weave all through. there are many so-called harvards in which stripes of plain, matting, and other twills are used.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HARVARDS: A shirting cloth woven with the 2 by 2 twill weave and with coloured stripes. The genuine harvard has the 2 by 2 weave all through. There are many so-called harvards in which stripes of plain, matting, and other twills are used.
text: HARVARDS: A shirting cloth woven with the 2 by 2 twill weave and with coloured stripes. The genuine harvard has the 2 by 2 weave all through. There are many so-called harvards in which stripes of plain, matting, and other twills are used.

Definition: in colne and other coloured districts the 2 by 2 twill is known as the harvard twill.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HARVARD TWILL: In Colne and other coloured districts the 2 by 2 twill is known as the harvard twill.
text: HARVARD TWILL: In Colne and other coloured districts the 2 by 2 twill is known as the harvard twill.

Definition: an all colour cotton cloth made for the hausa natives of africa. plain weave, warp pattern, about 10 ends dark indigo, 2 ends light indigo, with weft similar. the yarns are hard-twisted and weft-sized, which gives a rough, harsh feel to the cloth. usually made 28in. wide, 58 ends, 42 picks, 18's dark, 2/80's light indigo warp, 16's dark, 60's light indigo weft. shipped in loom state in 10 yard ends.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HAUSA CHECKS: An all colour cotton cloth made for the Hausa natives of Africa. Plain weave, warp pattern, about 10 ends dark indigo, 2 ends light indigo, with weft similar. The yarns are hard-twisted and weft-sized, which gives a rough, harsh feel to the cloth. Usually made 28in. wide, 58 ends, 42 picks, 18's dark, 2/80's light indigo warp, 16's dark, 60's light indigo weft. Shipped in loom state in 10 yard ends.
text: HAUSA CHECKS: An all colour cotton cloth made for the Hausa natives of Africa. Plain weave, warp pattern, about 10 ends dark indigo, 2 ends light indigo, with weft similar. The yarns are hard-twisted and weft-sized, which gives a rough, harsh feel to the cloth. Usually made 28in. wide, 58 ends, 42 picks, 18's dark, 2/80's light indigo warp, 16's dark, 60's light indigo weft. Shipped in loom state in 10 yard ends.

Definition: this is composed of two wooden laths upon which are suspended a series of cords called healds. the healds may be loosely threaded on the shafts or knitted firmly on them. there is a small eye formed in the centre of each heald, through which a warp thread passes. heald shafts are used to divide the warp threads so as to form a shed for the passage of the shuttle. plain cloth can be woven on two heald shafts, but four are generally used. as many as 16 of these heald shafts are used in fancy weaving. heald shafts are in the trade variously termed healds," staves," or shafts.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HEALD-SHAFT: This is composed of two wooden laths upon which are suspended a series of cords called healds. The healds may be loosely threaded on the shafts or knitted firmly on them. There is a small eye formed in the centre of each heald, through which a warp thread passes. Heald shafts are used to divide the warp threads so as to form a shed for the passage of the shuttle. Plain cloth can be woven on two heald shafts, but four are generally used. As many as 16 of these heald shafts are used in fancy weaving. Heald shafts are in the trade variously termed healds," staves," or shafts.
text: HEALD-SHAFT: This is composed of two wooden laths upon which are suspended a series of cords called healds. The healds may be loosely threaded on the shafts or knitted firmly on them. There is a small eye formed in the centre of each heald, through which a warp thread passes. Heald shafts are used to divide the warp threads so as to form a shed for the passage of the shuttle. Plain cloth can be woven on two heald shafts, but four are generally used. As many as 16 of these heald shafts are used in fancy weaving. Heald shafts are in the trade variously termed healds," staves," or shafts.

Definition: a fibre obtained from the stalk of the plant "cannibis sativa." it is inferior in quality to flax, but stronger and easily bleached. it is grown in india, italy, russia, poland, and many other countries. the better grades are used in the manufacture of carpets.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HEMP: A fibre obtained from the stalk of the plant "Cannibis sativa." It is inferior in quality to flax, but stronger and easily bleached. It is grown in India, Italy, Russia, Poland, and many other countries. The better grades are used in the manufacture of carpets.
text: HEMP: A fibre obtained from the stalk of the plant "Cannibis sativa." It is inferior in quality to flax, but stronger and easily bleached. It is grown in India, Italy, Russia, Poland, and many other countries. The better grades are used in the manufacture of carpets.

Definition: a dress cloth woven from a silk warp and fine botany weft-2 by 1 weft twill weave-high number of picks, finished soft and lustrous. it is a fine cashmere.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HENRIETTA: A dress cloth woven from a silk warp and fine botany weft-2 by 1 weft twill weave-high number of picks, finished soft and lustrous. It is a fine cashmere.
text: HENRIETTA: A dress cloth woven from a silk warp and fine botany weft-2 by 1 weft twill weave-high number of picks, finished soft and lustrous. It is a fine cashmere.

Definition: this is a twill weave formed by having stripes opposing each other and giving the appearance of herring-bones. the stripes are made by reversing the direction of the twill, thus alternating a left with a right-hand twill.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HERRING-BONE-FEATHER, ARROW-HEAD, OR POINTED TWILL: This is a twill weave formed by having stripes opposing each other and giving the appearance of herring-bones. The stripes are made by reversing the direction of the twill, thus alternating a left with a right-hand twill.
text: HERRING-BONE-FEATHER, ARROW-HEAD, OR POINTED TWILL: This is a twill weave formed by having stripes opposing each other and giving the appearance of herring-bones. The stripes are made by reversing the direction of the twill, thus alternating a left with a right-hand twill.

Definition: a fabric of strong coarse jute or hemp yarns, plain weave, used as a packing material, also for bags.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HESSIAN: A fabric of strong coarse jute or hemp yarns, plain weave, used as a packing material, also for bags.
text: HESSIAN: A fabric of strong coarse jute or hemp yarns, plain weave, used as a packing material, also for bags.

Definition: an american term for a cotton cloth made from coarse coloured yarns, generally blue and white or brown and white, and twill weave. used for working shirts and pants in many of the states.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HICKORY STRIPES: An American term for a cotton cloth made from coarse coloured yarns, generally blue and white or brown and white, and twill weave. Used for working shirts and pants in many of the States.
text: HICKORY STRIPES: An American term for a cotton cloth made from coarse coloured yarns, generally blue and white or brown and white, and twill weave. Used for working shirts and pants in many of the States.

Definition: an all cotton cloth made to imitate linen hollands. the warp is all colour, blue and black stripes on a drab ground. grey or drab coloured weft. made in stripes and checks. the cloth is finished with a "linen finish,' and creased when made up. shipped to the philippines. a common quality is 27 inches wide, 45 to 50 yards long, 52 ends, 56 picks, 20's warp, 20's weft, 9¬ω lb. 45 yards.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HOLLANDAS: An all cotton cloth made to imitate linen Hollands. The warp is all colour, blue and black stripes on a drab ground. Grey or drab coloured weft. Made in stripes and checks. The cloth is finished with a "linen finish,' and creased when made up. Shipped to the Philippines. A common quality is 27 inches wide, 45 to 50 yards long, 52 ends, 56 picks, 20's warp, 20's weft, 9¬Ω lb. 45 yards.
text: HOLLANDAS: An all cotton cloth made to imitate linen Hollands. The warp is all colour, blue and black stripes on a drab ground. Grey or drab coloured weft. Made in stripes and checks. The cloth is finished with a "linen finish,' and creased when made up. Shipped to the Philippines. A common quality is 27 inches wide, 45 to 50 yards long, 52 ends, 56 picks, 20's warp, 20's weft, 9¬Ω lb. 45 yards.

Definition: a fine linen cloth, plain weave, bleached or left grey and finished soft finish. stripes and checks are made. mostly used for window blinds and aprons, but many good qualities are made for dress purposes. a fabric is shipped to india as "holland" which is all cotton, woven from a bleached yarn warp and a blue and white twist weft, about 26 inches to 30 inches, 52/56 reed, 44/52 picks, 20's warp, 2/36's weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HOLLAND: A fine linen cloth, plain weave, bleached or left grey and finished soft finish. Stripes and checks are made. Mostly used for window blinds and aprons, but many good qualities are made for dress purposes. A fabric is shipped to India as "holland" which is all cotton, woven from a bleached yarn warp and a blue and white twist weft, about 26 inches to 30 inches, 52/56 reed, 44/52 picks, 20's warp, 2/36's weft.
text: HOLLAND: A fine linen cloth, plain weave, bleached or left grey and finished soft finish. Stripes and checks are made. Mostly used for window blinds and aprons, but many good qualities are made for dress purposes. A fabric is shipped to India as "holland" which is all cotton, woven from a bleached yarn warp and a blue and white twist weft, about 26 inches to 30 inches, 52/56 reed, 44/52 picks, 20's warp, 2/36's weft.

Definition: the legal definition of this term is " cloth, the wool of which was hand spun and woven on hand-looms at home." they are coase fabrics of tweed character.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HOMESPUN: The legal definition of this term is " cloth, the wool of which was hand spun and woven on hand-looms at home." They are coase fabrics of tweed character.
text: HOMESPUN: The legal definition of this term is " cloth, the wool of which was hand spun and woven on hand-looms at home." They are coase fabrics of tweed character.

Definition: this is a type of weave and not a fabric (see honey- comb weave). the term is, however, used to describe towels woven with this particular weave, also for dress goods woven from worsted and woollen yarns with the honeycomb weave.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HONEYCOMB: This is a type of weave and not a fabric (see Honey- comb Weave). The term is, however, used to describe towels woven with this particular weave, also for dress goods woven from worsted and woollen yarns with the honeycomb weave.
text: HONEYCOMB: This is a type of weave and not a fabric (see Honey- comb Weave). The term is, however, used to describe towels woven with this particular weave, also for dress goods woven from worsted and woollen yarns with the honeycomb weave.

Definition: this is a fancy weave obtained by certain ends of warp and picks of weft floating for some distance to form ridges, with other threads working plain to form hollows. the weave is largely used in bolton for quilts, toilet covers, etc., and in heywood for towels. the brighton and grecian weaves are fancy adaptations of the honey- comb principle.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HONEYCOMB WEAVE: This is a fancy weave obtained by certain ends of warp and picks of weft floating for some distance to form ridges, with other threads working plain to form hollows. The weave is largely used in Bolton for quilts, toilet covers, etc., and in Heywood for towels. The Brighton and Grecian weaves are fancy adaptations of the honey- comb principle.
text: HONEYCOMB WEAVE: This is a fancy weave obtained by certain ends of warp and picks of weft floating for some distance to form ridges, with other threads working plain to form hollows. The weave is largely used in Bolton for quilts, toilet covers, etc., and in Heywood for towels. The Brighton and Grecian weaves are fancy adaptations of the honey- comb principle.

Definition: a matting weave 2 by 2 or 3 by 3, in which two ends and 2 picks, or 3 ends and 3 picks work together.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HOPSACK: A matting weave 2 by 2 or 3 by 3, in which two ends and 2 picks, or 3 ends and 3 picks work together.
text: HOPSACK: A matting weave 2 by 2 or 3 by 3, in which two ends and 2 picks, or 3 ends and 3 picks work together.

Definition: a simple weave used for towels, glass cloths, etc. a rough surface is given to the cloth. it is obtained by short floats of warp and weft and a plain ground. the weave is now much used as a ground weave for fancies. when first introduced it was only used to weave hemp yarns into towels, etc. it can be woven on 3-heald shafts.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: HUCKABACK: A simple weave used for towels, glass cloths, etc. A rough surface is given to the cloth. It is obtained by short floats of warp and weft and a plain ground. The weave is now much used as a ground weave for fancies. When first introduced it was only used to weave hemp yarns into towels, etc. It can be woven on 3-heald shafts.
text: HUCKABACK: A simple weave used for towels, glass cloths, etc. A rough surface is given to the cloth. It is obtained by short floats of warp and weft and a plain ground. The weave is now much used as a ground weave for fancies. When first introduced it was only used to weave hemp yarns into towels, etc. It can be woven on 3-heald shafts.

Definition: a variety of cotton velvet, but with a longer pile than most velvets. generally 50 inches wide, and made from twofold warp yarn, about 2/28's and 28's or 30's weft, with 300 to 350 picks per inch. when cut after weaving the pile is very soft and thick. dyed and finished to imitate rabbit skins.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: IMITATION RABBIT SKIN: A variety of cotton velvet, but with a longer pile than most velvets. Generally 50 inches wide, and made from twofold warp yarn, about 2/28's and 28's or 30's weft, with 300 to 350 picks per inch. When cut after weaving the pile is very soft and thick. Dyed and finished to imitate rabbit skins.
text: IMITATION RABBIT SKIN: A variety of cotton velvet, but with a longer pile than most velvets. Generally 50 inches wide, and made from twofold warp yarn, about 2/28's and 28's or 30's weft, with 300 to 350 picks per inch. When cut after weaving the pile is very soft and thick. Dyed and finished to imitate rabbit skins.

Definition: a heavy cotton fabric of the fustian class woven from good yarns and 8-end sateen base, 2 up 6 down. generally dyed and raised on the face. the picks usually 3 to 5 times the number of warp ends. a standard make is 54 inches, 102 yards, 64 by 214, 2/20's/22's 102 lb., soft spun, super weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: IMPERIALS: A heavy cotton fabric of the fustian class woven from good yarns and 8-end sateen base, 2 up 6 down. Generally dyed and raised on the face. The picks usually 3 to 5 times the number of warp ends. A standard make is 54 inches, 102 yards, 64 by 214, 2/20's/22's 102 lb., soft spun, super weft.
text: IMPERIALS: A heavy cotton fabric of the fustian class woven from good yarns and 8-end sateen base, 2 up 6 down. Generally dyed and raised on the face. The picks usually 3 to 5 times the number of warp ends. A standard make is 54 inches, 102 yards, 64 by 214, 2/20's/22's 102 lb., soft spun, super weft.

Definition: most shippers send what are known as speculation patterns, to their customers abroad, who may send an order on any pattern that suits their market, the quantity and price to be arranged, and this is called an indent order.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: INDENT ORDERS: Most shippers send what are known as speculation patterns, to their customers abroad, who may send an order on any pattern that suits their market, the quantity and price to be arranged, and this is called an indent order.
text: INDENT ORDERS: Most shippers send what are known as speculation patterns, to their customers abroad, who may send an order on any pattern that suits their market, the quantity and price to be arranged, and this is called an indent order.

Definition: these are usually 36 inches wide and made from two of threefold yarns. this class is the oldest form of machine-made carpet now woven. they are two-ply fab- rics, and the pattern is formed by one cloth passing through the other-the two cloths being of different colours. woven on jacquard looms which have vertical shuttle boxes for as many as six colours. they are very expensive, but very enduring, and either side can be used. scotch or kidderminster carpets come under this term.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: INGRAIN CARPETS: These are usually 36 inches wide and made from two of threefold yarns. This class is the oldest form of machine-made carpet now woven. They are two-ply fab- rics, and the pattern is formed by one cloth passing through the other-the two cloths being of different colours. Woven on jacquard looms which have vertical shuttle boxes for as many as six colours. They are very expensive, but very enduring, and either side can be used. Scotch or Kidderminster carpets come under this term.
text: INGRAIN CARPETS: These are usually 36 inches wide and made from two of threefold yarns. This class is the oldest form of machine-made carpet now woven. They are two-ply fab- rics, and the pattern is formed by one cloth passing through the other-the two cloths being of different colours. Woven on jacquard looms which have vertical shuttle boxes for as many as six colours. They are very expensive, but very enduring, and either side can be used. Scotch or Kidderminster carpets come under this term.

Definition: (" a sliver of cotton after leaving the draw frame is passed through the slubbing," intermediate, and roving" frames. all these machines are used for the same object that of attenuating the sliver until in a fit condition for spinning. they carry on the work of the drawing frame by still further doubling and drawing out the cotton, reducing irregularities, and adding to the fineness of the yarn. the intermediate frame produces finer material than the slubbing frame, but not so fine as the roving frame.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: INTERMEDIATE FRAME: (" A sliver of cotton after leaving the draw frame is passed through the slubbing," intermediate, and roving" frames. All these machines are used for the same object that of attenuating the sliver until in a fit condition for spinning. They carry on the work of the drawing frame by still further doubling and drawing out the cotton, reducing irregularities, and adding to the fineness of the yarn. The intermediate frame produces finer material than the slubbing frame, but not so fine as the roving frame.
text: INTERMEDIATE FRAME: (" A sliver of cotton after leaving the draw frame is passed through the slubbing," intermediate, and roving" frames. All these machines are used for the same object that of attenuating the sliver until in a fit condition for spinning. They carry on the work of the drawing frame by still further doubling and drawing out the cotton, reducing irregularities, and adding to the fineness of the yarn. The intermediate frame produces finer material than the slubbing frame, but not so fine as the roving frame.

Definition: carpets made by native indians from wool, with silk inserted at times. woven on native looms and entirely by hand. the colour and design are all in the weft. colours are inserted as required by the design from bobbins and in the form of small tufts. they are very expensive.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: INDIAN CARPETS: Carpets made by native Indians from wool, with silk inserted at times. Woven on native looms and entirely by hand. The colour and design are all in the weft. Colours are inserted as required by the design from bobbins and in the form of small tufts. They are very expensive.
text: INDIAN CARPETS: Carpets made by native Indians from wool, with silk inserted at times. Woven on native looms and entirely by hand. The colour and design are all in the weft. Colours are inserted as required by the design from bobbins and in the form of small tufts. They are very expensive.

Definition: a light muslin cloth with cords of thick yarn in the warp or in both warp and weft, forming cord checks. various widths, 80's to 100's warp and weft, and 20's or 2/40's cords, plain weave, 72 by 72, and 8 cords per inch.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: INDIAN DIMITY: A light muslin cloth with cords of thick yarn in the warp or in both warp and weft, forming cord checks. Various widths, 80's to 100's warp and weft, and 20's or 2/40's cords, plain weave, 72 by 72, and 8 cords per inch.
text: INDIAN DIMITY: A light muslin cloth with cords of thick yarn in the warp or in both warp and weft, forming cord checks. Various widths, 80's to 100's warp and weft, and 20's or 2/40's cords, plain weave, 72 by 72, and 8 cords per inch.

Definition: this is simply a fine linen cloth from 28in. to 40in. wide, plain weave, 80 by 80 or more, about 80's to 90's linen yarns. the same cloth is used in the home trade for many purposes.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: INDIAN LINEN: This is simply a fine linen cloth from 28in. to 40in. wide, plain weave, 80 by 80 or more, about 80's to 90's linen yarns. The same cloth is used in the home trade for many purposes.
text: INDIAN LINEN: This is simply a fine linen cloth from 28in. to 40in. wide, plain weave, 80 by 80 or more, about 80's to 90's linen yarns. The same cloth is used in the home trade for many purposes.

Definition: all cotton cloths dyed indigo blue with the pattern formed by either a resist or discharge process. this is a general term, and all indigo blue fabrics may come under it.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: INDIGO PRINTS: All cotton cloths dyed indigo blue with the pattern formed by either a resist or discharge process. This is a general term, and all indigo blue fabrics may come under it.
text: INDIGO PRINTS: All cotton cloths dyed indigo blue with the pattern formed by either a resist or discharge process. This is a general term, and all indigo blue fabrics may come under it.

Definition: a wool term, which means that the wool used was dyed before spinning into yarn. ingrain carpets were originally made from this style of yarn, but to-day dyed yarn is chiefly used.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: INGRAIN: A wool term, which means that the wool used was dyed before spinning into yarn. Ingrain carpets were originally made from this style of yarn, but to-day dyed yarn is chiefly used.
text: INGRAIN: A wool term, which means that the wool used was dyed before spinning into yarn. Ingrain carpets were originally made from this style of yarn, but to-day dyed yarn is chiefly used.

Definition: a bleached cotton cloth of plain weave, about 70 by 66, 32's/28's, made in north ireland. finished rather stiffly with a starch finish and glazed. originally the term indicated a pure linen cloth woven in ireland, but this has died out and pure linen" is used instead when a fabric is all linen.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: IRISHES: A bleached cotton cloth of plain weave, about 70 by 66, 32's/28's, made in North Ireland. Finished rather stiffly with a starch finish and glazed. Originally the term indicated a pure linen cloth woven in Ireland, but this has died out and pure linen" is used instead when a fabric is all linen.
text: IRISHES: A bleached cotton cloth of plain weave, about 70 by 66, 32's/28's, made in North Ireland. Finished rather stiffly with a starch finish and glazed. Definition: the real italian cloth is made from a cotton warp and botany weft; woven in the bradford district. the warp is yarn dyed black and the woven piece cross-dyed. the weave is a weft face satin very heavily picked to give an even smooth service. after finishing, the cloth has a beautiful and lasting gloss. a very large trade is done in all cotton italians piece-dyed black. in many widths and qualities, 5-shaft sateen weave, weft face. standard makes are:- 36 inches, 90 yards, 72 by 120, 36's/40's super satin weft. 56 inches, 90 yards, 72 by 140, 36's/32's 41 lb. 56 inches, 90 yards, 72 by 144, 34's/28's 43 lb.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ITALIAN CLOTH: The real Italian cloth is made from a cotton warp and botany weft; woven in the Bradford district. The warp is yarn dyed black and the woven piece cross-dyed. The weave is a weft face satin very heavily picked to give an even smooth service. After finishing, the cloth has a beautiful and lasting gloss. A very large trade is done in all cotton Italians piece-dyed black. In many widths and qualities, 5-shaft sateen weave, weft face. Standard makes are:- 36 inches, 90 yards, 72 by 120, 36's/40's super satin weft. 56 inches, 90 yards, 72 by 140, 36's/32's 41 lb. 56 inches, 90 yards, 72 by 144, 34's/28's 43 lb.

Definition: jacquards are pattern-making machines, and necessary for all designs having more than 16 to 20 warp ends in a repeat of the pattern. there are many varieties of jac- quards, but they all come in two classes, known as single- lift and double-lift machines. the single-lift is the simpler and the older, and consists of a number of up- right hooks inside a framework, which can be lifted by one set of knives or griffes. the warp ends controlled by the hooks lifted are moved to their highest point on each pick. the number of hooks determines the size of the pattern, thus, a 400-hook machine allows a pattern on 400 warp ends to be woven. double-lift machines have two sets of knives so arranged that when one set of hooks rises the other falls, thus saving time and power. jacquards are made from 200 to 900 hooks for the cotton trade, but up to 1,200 for silk work. √æ
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: JACQUARDS: Jacquards are pattern-making machines, and necessary for all designs having more than 16 to 20 warp ends in a repeat of the pattern. There are many varieties of jac- quards, but they all come in two classes, known as single- lift and double-lift machines. The single-lift is the simpler and the older, and consists of a number of up- right hooks inside a framework, which can be lifted by one set of knives or griffes. The warp ends controlled by the hooks lifted are moved to their highest point on each pick. The number of hooks determines the size of the pattern, thus, a 400-hook machine allows a pattern on 400 warp ends to be woven. Double-lift machines have two sets of knives so arranged that when one set of hooks rises the other falls, thus saving time and power. Jacquards are made from 200 to 900 hooks for the cotton trade, but up to 1,200 for silk work. √Æ

The warp ends controlled by the hooks lifted are moved to their highest point on each pick. Double-lift machines have two sets of knives so arranged that when one set of hooks rises the other falls, thus saving time and power. Definition: the tie-up of a jacquard means the manner and order in which the threads of the jacquard mounting are tied up to the neck cords. two systems are in general use, known as the "london tie," in which the cards are placed at one or both sides of the loom, and the "norwich tie," where the cards are in the front or at the back or both back and front. in the london tie each row of harness threads has a half-twist between the comberboard and the machine, while in the norwich tie they go straight.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: JACQUARD TIES: The tie-up of a jacquard means the manner and order in which the threads of the jacquard mounting are tied up to the neck cords. Two systems are in general use, known as the "London tie," in which the cards are placed at one or both sides of the loom, and the "Norwich tie," where the cards are in the front or at the back or both back and front. In the London tie each row of harness threads has a half-twist between the comberboard and the machine, while in the Norwich tie they go straight.
text: JACQUARD TIES: The tie-up of a jacquard means the manner and order in which the threads of the jacquard mounting are tied up to the neck cords. Two systems are in general use, known as the "London tie," in which the cards are placed at one or both sides of the loom, and the "Norwich tie," where the cards are in the front or at the back or both back and front. In the London tie each row of harness threads has a half-twist between the comberboard and the machine, while in the Norwich tie they go straight.

Definition: are light cotton cloths of the lawn or muslin charac- ter, but are finished with a smooth cambric finish, slightly assisted, after bleaching. qualities and widths are many. a good sample is 41 inches, 20 yards, 27 by 32 (4 down), 80's/90's. from 60 by 60 to 80 by 80 per inch and 46's/50's to 80's/100's yarns have been shipped as jaconets.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: JACONETS: Are light cotton cloths of the lawn or muslin charac- ter, but are finished with a smooth cambric finish, slightly assisted, after bleaching. Qualities and widths are many. A good sample is 41 inches, 20 yards, 27 by 32 (4 down), 80's/90's. From 60 by 60 to 80 by 80 per inch and 46's/50's to 80's/100's yarns have been shipped as jaconets.

Definition: a pure silk fabric, plain weave, made from fine yarns, fine reed, and same number of picks as there are ends, printed in japanese or other styles. manufactured in japan. imitations are made by french and swiss silk manufacturers. (see swiss and lyonnesse pongees.) the cloth is imported into europe and printed there. widths usually 22 in. to 25 in. the cloth is known as "habuta√ø among the japanese merchants.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: JAPANESE PONGEE: A pure silk fabric, plain weave, made from fine yarns, fine reed, and same number of picks as there are ends, printed in Japanese or other styles. Manufactured in Japan. Imitations are made by French and Swiss silk manufacturers. (See Swiss and Lyonnesse Pongees.) The cloth is imported into Europe and printed there. Widths usually 22 in. to 25 in. The cloth is known as "Habuta√Ø among the Japanese merchants.
text: JAPANESE PONGEE: A pure silk fabric, plain weave, made from fine yarns, fine reed, and same number of picks as there are ends, printed in Japanese or other styles. Manufactured in Japan. Imitations are made by French and Swiss silk manufacturers. (See Swiss and Lyonnesse Pongees.) The cloth is imported into Europe and printed there. Widths usually 22 in. to 25 in. The cloth is known as "Habuta√Ø among the Japanese merchants.

Definition: are: a cloth similar to a jean, but usually finer yarns; also with a weft face, 3-shaft twill weave. standard makes 37 in. 90 yds., 52 by 120, 36's/28's. 37 in. 90 yds., 52 by 84, 36's/36's. there is very little difference between jeans and jeanettes. many makers make no distinction at all.

Definition: cotton cloth generally dyed or bleached and used for linings. the weave is the 3-shaft twill, weft face, made in widths 27 in. to 44 in. a good shipping cloth for egypt, persia, and other markets is 42 in., 52 by 88, 36's/28's. if made warp face it is known as a drill and used for chil- dren's suitings, corsets, boot linings, etc. a good sample of this is 31 in. 100 yds., 91 by 62, 18's/28's twist way weft, 28 lb. of jeans, peperell (see peperell)‚äî
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: JEANS: Cotton cloth generally dyed or bleached and used for linings. The weave is the 3-shaft twill, weft face, made in widths 27 in. to 44 in. A good shipping cloth for Egypt, Persia, and other markets is 42 in., 52 by 88, 36's/28's. If made warp face it is known as a drill and used for chil- dren's suitings, corsets, boot linings, etc. A good sample of this is 31 in. 100 yds., 91 by 62, 18's/28's twist way weft, 28 lb. of JEANS, PEPERELL (See PEPERELL)‚Äî

Definition: damaged goods of all kinds are termed jobs, and sold by weight as a rule to dealers calling themselves job mer- chants.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: JOBS: Damaged goods of all kinds are termed jobs, and sold by weight as a rule to dealers calling themselves job mer- chants.

Definition: a french style of printing in small floral designs named after the french printer who first introduced the style. jouy prints are now generally silk cloths manufactured and printed in france.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: JOUY: A French style of printing in small floral designs named after the French printer who first introduced the style. Jouy prints are now generally silk cloths manufactured and printed in France.
text: JOUY: A French style of printing in small floral designs named after the French printer who first introduced the style. Jouy prints are now generally silk cloths manufactured and printed in France.

Definition: a fibre principally used for canvas bags, cordage, mats, wrappers, etc. very largely manufactured in india, where the bulk of the fibre is grown. a good trade is done in dundee. the fibre is obtained from the bast of the cor- chorus capsularis, an annual plant grown from seed. the plant grows up to 17 ft. in height. the fibre is very strong, has a good lustre, is uniform in diameter, has good dyeing qualities, but when exposed to the weather soon deterio- rates.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: JUTE (CALCUTTA HEMP): A fibre principally used for canvas bags, cordage, mats, wrappers, etc. Very largely manufactured in India, where the bulk of the fibre is grown. A good trade is done in Dundee. The fibre is obtained from the bast of the Cor- chorus Capsularis, an annual plant grown from seed. The plant grows up to 17 ft. in height. The fibre is very strong, has a good lustre, is uniform in diameter, has good dyeing qualities, but when exposed to the weather soon deterio- rates.
text: JUTE (CALCUTTA HEMP): A fibre principally used for canvas bags, cordage, mats, wrappers, etc. Very largely manufactured in India, where the bulk of the fibre is grown. A good trade is done in Dundee. The fibre is obtained from the bast of the Cor- chorus Capsularis, an annual plant grown from seed. The plant grows up to 17 ft. in height. The fibre is very strong, has a good lustre, is uniform in diameter, has good dyeing qualities, but when exposed to the weather soon deterio- rates.

Definition: large size cops of waste yarn used by waste manufac- turers for weft. the cops are placed loosely inside the special shuttles, which have serrated sides to keep the cop in its place. no spindle is used, but the cop is strapped down. the weft is drawn from the inside of the cop.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: JUMBO COPS: Large size cops of waste yarn used by waste manufac- turers for weft. The cops are placed loosely inside the special shuttles, which have serrated sides to keep the cop in its place. No spindle is used, but the cop is strapped down. The weft is drawn from the inside of the cop.

Definition: a coarse woollen cloth, used for overcoats, made from rough yarns, and has no pattern.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: KALMUCK: A coarse woollen cloth, used for overcoats, made from rough yarns, and has no pattern.
text: KALMUCK: A coarse woollen cloth, used for overcoats, made from rough yarns, and has no pattern.

Definition: a plain woven cloth made 64 to 72 square 30's/30's, with three or four grey cords down each selvedge of 2/14's yarn. the cloth is dyed indigo blue. yarns are of a rather low grade.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: KANIKIS (AFRICA): A plain woven cloth made 64 to 72 square 30's/30's, with three or four grey cords down each selvedge of 2/14's yarn. The cloth is dyed indigo blue. Yarns are of a rather low grade.
text: KANIKIS (AFRICA): A plain woven cloth made 64 to 72 square 30's/30's, with three or four grey cords down each selvedge of 2/14's yarn. The cloth is dyed indigo blue. Yarns are of a rather low grade.

Definition: this fibre is obtained from the white silk-cotton tree grown in the east indies (erisdendron anfractuosum); it is of no use for spinning, and is principally used as a stuffing material for pillows, etc. it is very soft, smooth, light in weight, and very buoyant in water.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: KAPOK: This fibre is obtained from the white silk-cotton tree grown in the East Indies (Erisdendron anfractuosum); it is of no use for spinning, and is principally used as a stuffing material for pillows, etc. It is very soft, smooth, light in weight, and very buoyant in water.

Definition: a defect which is most frequently met with in badly bred wools, and consists of thickened parts of the fibre, which are opaque and have no structure. these opaque parts do not absorb dyes, and shew very clearly in the finished fabric.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: KEMP, KEMPY WOOL: A defect which is most frequently met with in badly bred wools, and consists of thickened parts of the fibre, which are opaque and have no structure. These opaque parts do not absorb dyes, and shew very clearly in the finished fabric.
text: KEMP, KEMPY WOOL: A defect which is most frequently met with in badly bred wools, and consists of thickened parts of the fibre, which are opaque and have no structure. These opaque parts do not absorb dyes, and shew very clearly in the finished fabric.

Definition: the ordinary five-shaft satin weave, weft face, made in cheap qualities with a cotton warp and wool weft. an american term.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: KENTUCKY JEANS: The ordinary five-shaft satin weave, weft face, made in cheap qualities with a cotton warp and wool weft. An American term.
text: KENTUCKY JEANS: The ordinary five-shaft satin weave, weft face, made in cheap qualities with a cotton warp and wool weft. An American term.

Definition: a closely woven woollen cloth made in 30 to 36 inch widths from the best quality yarns. weave 7, 9, or 11 end serge twill. finished with a very close nap and used for coatings.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: KERSEYMERE: A closely woven woollen cloth made in 30 to 36 inch widths from the best quality yarns. Weave 7, 9, or 11 end serge twill. Finished with a very close nap and used for coatings.
text: KERSEYMERE: A closely woven woollen cloth made in 30 to 36 inch widths from the best quality yarns. Weave 7, 9, or 11 end serge twill. Finished with a very close nap and used for coatings.

Definition: a japanese cloth made from fine silk varns and in a plain weave.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: KHAIKI: A Japanese cloth made from fine silk varns and in a plain weave.

Definition: a good quality florentine drill cloth, four-shaft weave, such as 88 x 72 20's/18's dyed khaki colour and used for military purposes. widths vary from 27 to 40 inches.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: KHAKI DRILLS: A good quality florentine drill cloth, four-shaft weave, such as 88 x 72 20's/18's dyed khaki colour and used for military purposes. Widths vary from 27 to 40 inches.
text: KHAKI DRILLS: A good quality florentine drill cloth, four-shaft weave, such as 88 x 72 20's/18's dyed khaki colour and used for military purposes. Widths vary from 27 to 40 inches.

Definition: a carpet without a pile. also known as scotch car- pets and in america as ingrain carpets. they are double plain fabrics, each fabric of a different colour. one cloth is carried through the other for ornament, and this trans- posing of the two cloths very firmly binds them together. the finished carpet is reversible. this style of carpet was the first to be made on the loom in this country. the best qualities are made from all wool yarn-cotton warps being used to make inferior qualities. many scotch made carpets are three-ply cloths the third cloth being introduced to give a thicker fabric, and by using other colours gives much richer designs. <
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: KIDDERMINSTER CARPETS: A carpet without a pile. Also known as Scotch car- pets and in America as Ingrain carpets. They are double plain fabrics, each fabric of a different colour. One cloth is carried through the other for ornament, and this trans- posing of the two cloths very firmly binds them together. The finished carpet is reversible. This style of carpet was the first to be made on the loom in this country. The best qualities are made from all wool yarn-cotton warps being used to make inferior qualities. Many Scotch made carpets are three-ply cloths the third cloth being introduced to give a thicker fabric, and by using other colours gives much richer designs. <

One cloth is carried through the other for ornament, and this trans- posing of the two cloths very firmly binds them together. The finished carpet is reversible. This style of carpet was the first to be made on the loom in this country. The best qualities are made from all wool yarn-cotton warps being used to make inferior qualities. Many Scotch made carpets are three-ply cloths the third cloth being introduced to give a thicker fabric, and by using other colours gives much richer designs. <

Definition: a good quality cambric about 30 in. wide 110 x 100 50's/60's egyptian yarns, with a very soft finish. used as linings for ladies' summer dresses.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: KID-FINISHED CAMBRIC: A good quality cambric about 30 in. wide 110 x 100 50's/60's Egyptian yarns, with a very soft finish. Used as linings for ladies' summer dresses.
text: KID-FINISHED CAMBRIC: A good quality cambric about 30 in. wide 110 x 100 50's/60's Egyptian yarns, with a very soft finish. Used as linings for ladies' summer dresses.

Definition: a cloth similar to loongies, but made in stripes only, about 32 to 40 inches wide and 4 yards to 8 yards long. often the cloth is woven with coloured borders. the qualities vary considerably. some are made with silk borders for the use of the wealthier natives.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: KIKOIS (AFRICA): A cloth similar to loongies, but made in stripes only, about 32 to 40 inches wide and 4 yards to 8 yards long. Often the cloth is woven with coloured borders. The qualities vary considerably. Some are made with silk borders for the use of the wealthier natives.
text: KIKOIS (AFRICA): A cloth similar to loongies, but made in stripes only, about 32 to 40 inches wide and 4 yards to 8 yards long. Often the cloth is woven with coloured borders. The qualities vary considerably. Some are made with silk borders for the use of the wealthier natives.

Definition: a cloth used for shawls, 39 to 48 inches wide, with fancy headings at each end and coloured borders down each side, generally fringed each end. made in many lengths and qualities.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: KILOYES: A cloth used for shawls, 39 to 48 inches wide, with fancy headings at each end and coloured borders down each side, generally fringed each end. Made in many lengths and qualities.
text: KILOYES: A cloth used for shawls, 39 to 48 inches wide, with fancy headings at each end and coloured borders down each side, generally fringed each end. Made in many lengths and qualities.

Definition: a fancy yarn with spots or small stripes in colour. the spotting material is flecked on to the carder. several colours can be used.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: KNICKERBOCKER YARN: A fancy yarn with spots or small stripes in colour. The spotting material is flecked on to the carder. Several colours can be used.
text: KNICKERBOCKER YARN: A fancy yarn with spots or small stripes in colour. The spotting material is flecked on to the carder. Several colours can be used.

Definition: a yarn with lumps or thick places appearing at in- tervals; either same colour as the bulk or other colours are introduced. a foundation thread is twisted with another, which is very loosely and irregularly twisted, and the irregularities shew up in small lumps. this fancy yarn is seen in fancy poplins and other cotton fabrics.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: KNOP YARN: A yarn with lumps or thick places appearing at in- tervals; either same colour as the bulk or other colours are introduced. A foundation thread is twisted with another, which is very loosely and irregularly twisted, and the irregularities shew up in small lumps. This fancy yarn is seen in fancy poplins and other cotton fabrics.
text: KNOP YARN: A yarn with lumps or thick places appearing at in- tervals; either same colour as the bulk or other colours are introduced. A foundation thread is twisted with another, which is very loosely and irregularly twisted, and the irregularities shew up in small lumps. This fancy yarn is seen in fancy poplins and other cotton fabrics.

Definition: a japanese term given to a plain silk or mixture fabric with a cord stripe. the warp and cords are often of cotton, but the weft always silk.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: KOBAI: A Japanese term given to a plain silk or mixture fabric with a cord stripe. The warp and cords are often of cotton, but the weft always silk.
text: KOBAI: A Japanese term given to a plain silk or mixture fabric with a cord stripe. The warp and cords are often of cotton, but the weft always silk.

Definition: a gauze cloth, very open, in which stripes are formed of leno effects on a plain ground. the term is seldom used here, as the cloth would be called leno stripes.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: KUTARS (INDIAN): A gauze cloth, very open, in which stripes are formed of leno effects on a plain ground. The term is seldom used here, as the cloth would be called leno stripes.
text: KUTARS (INDIAN): A gauze cloth, very open, in which stripes are formed of leno effects on a plain ground. The term is seldom used here, as the cloth would be called leno stripes.

Definition: a plain cloth with mock leno stripes made on dobby lcoms. the ground is about 40's/36's and the figuring either of the same yarns or 30's to 36's, in which case two beams are used.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: LACE STRIPE CLOTH: A plain cloth with mock leno stripes made on dobby lcoms. The ground is about 40's/36's and the figuring either of the same yarns or 30's to 36's, in which case two beams are used.
text: LACE STRIPE CLOTH: A plain cloth with mock leno stripes made on dobby lcoms. The ground is about 40's/36's and the figuring either of the same yarns or 30's to 36's, in which case two beams are used.

Definition: these are tapes used for blinds known as venetian window blinds, and up to about 1878 they were made by hand from two broad tapes with the narrow ones stitched on at the required distances. the patent was the inven- tion of the late james carr, in manchester, and the british patent was issued to him on the 25th day of january, 1869, for manufacturing the complete ladder tape. owing to the large demand, a licence was issued to a firm in the midlands in 1874 to manufacture under mr. carr's patent. in 1878 carl vorwerk made a slight improvement to a part of the loom in which these ladder webs were being then made. the two broad outer tapes, with the required num- ber of narrow cross tapes, are woven together. the nar- row tapes are placed alternately near to the left and the right hand edges of the broad tapes in order to leave a space for the cord which draws up the blind.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: LADDER TAPES: These are tapes used for blinds known as Venetian window blinds, and up to about 1878 they were made by hand from two broad tapes with the narrow ones stitched on at the required distances. The patent was the inven- tion of the late James Carr, in Manchester, and the British patent was issued to him on the 25th day of January, 1869, for manufacturing the complete ladder tape. Owing to the large demand, a licence was issued to a firm in the Midlands in 1874 to manufacture under Mr. Carr's patent. In 1878 Carl Vorwerk made a slight improvement to a part of the loom in which these ladder webs were being then made. The two broad outer tapes, with the required num- ber of narrow cross tapes, are woven together. The nar- row tapes are placed alternately near to the left and the right hand edges of the broad tapes in order to leave a space for the cord which draws up the blind.
text: LADDER TAPES: These are tapes used for blinds known as Venetian window blinds, and up to about 1878 they were made by hand from two broad tapes with the narrow ones stitched on at the required distances. The patent was the inven- tion of the late James Carr, in Manchester, and the British patent was issued to him on the 25th day of January, 1869, for manufacturing the complete ladder tape. Owing to the large demand, a licence was issued to a firm in the Midlands in 1874 to manufacture under Mr. Carr's patent. In 1878 Carl Vorwerk made a slight improvement to a part of the loom in which these ladder webs were being then made. The two broad outer tapes, with the required num- ber of narrow cross tapes, are woven together. The nar- row tapes are placed alternately near to the left and the right hand edges of the broad tapes in order to leave a space for the cord which draws up the blind.

Definition: a heavy sateen cloth, with weft preponderating over warp in a ratio of 6:2 or even more. a strong twofold warp is used, such as 2/18's or 2/20's, with 18's to 24's weft, woven in a 60-reed and 400 to 480 picks per inch. the cloth is raised on the back to imitate lambskin, and owing to the long weft floats the result is good. when the cloth is not raised it is known as the "imperial sateen.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: LAMBSKIN: A heavy sateen cloth, with weft preponderating over warp in a ratio of 6:2 or even more. A strong twofold warp is used, such as 2/18's or 2/20's, with 18's to 24's weft, woven in a 60-reed and 400 to 480 picks per inch. The cloth is raised on the back to imitate lambskin, and owing to the long weft floats the result is good. When the cloth is not raised it is known as the "Imperial sateen.
text: LAMBSKIN: A heavy sateen cloth, with weft preponderating over warp in a ratio of 6:2 or even more. A strong twofold warp is used, such as 2/18's or 2/20's, with 18's to 24's weft, woven in a 60-reed and 400 to 480 picks per inch. The cloth is raised on the back to imitate lambskin, and owing to the long weft floats the result is good. When the cloth is not raised it is known as the "Imperial sateen.

Definition: a coloured stripe cloth made for south and east africa. usually 36 in. wide and in 6 yard ends, shipped loom state or soft finish. woven matting, 96 ends, 32 picks per inch, 28's black, 24's red, 24's yellow warp yarns, 22's weft. weft is grey, and sometimes sized to give a rough native feel to the cloth. the warp is all colour, but the black used sparingly. stripes vary in widths. >
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: LAPPAS: A coloured stripe cloth made for South and East Africa. Usually 36 in. wide and in 6 yard ends, shipped loom state or soft finish. Woven matting, 96 ends, 32 picks per inch, 28's black, 24's red, 24's yellow warp yarns, 22's weft. Weft is grey, and sometimes sized to give a rough native feel to the cloth. The warp is all colour, but the black used sparingly. Stripes vary in widths. >
text: LAPPAS: A coloured stripe cloth made for South and East Africa. Usually 36 in. wide and in 6 yard ends, shipped loom state or soft finish. Woven matting, 96 ends, 32 picks per inch, 28's black, 24's red, 24's yellow warp yarns, 22's weft. Weft is grey, and sometimes sized to give a rough native feel to the cloth. The warp is all colour, but the black used sparingly. Stripes vary in widths. >

Definition: cloths of a light muslin character in plain weave for the ground and figuring produced by a more or less zig- zag arrangement. the figuring threads are extra warp ends, and do not interweave with any other warp ends, but are simply held in position by passing underneath picks of weft. each spot or other figure is made from one thread only, which is drawn through the eye of a needle fixed in a frame in front of the reed. the movement of the frame is controlled by a groove cut in a circular disc of wood. this wheel or disc, known as the "scotch lappet motion," is the most generally used, and a specially-built loom is required. the figuring or whip "thread is not bound into the cloth, but floats from one extreme edge of the outline to the other. if spots are woven, the whip thread floats from one spot to the next, and the floating portion is cut away after weaving. the general appearance is that of embroidery, and the figuring is on one side of the cloth only. (6
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: LAPPETS: Cloths of a light muslin character in plain weave for the ground and figuring produced by a more or less zig- zag arrangement. The figuring threads are extra warp ends, and do not interweave with any other warp ends, but are simply held in position by passing underneath picks of weft. Each spot or other figure is made from one thread only, which is drawn through the eye of a needle fixed in a frame in front of the reed. The movement of the frame is controlled by a groove cut in a circular disc of wood. This wheel or disc, known as the "Scotch lappet motion," is the most generally used, and a specially-built loom is required. The figuring or whip "thread is not bound into the cloth, but floats from one extreme edge of the outline to the other. If spots are woven, the whip thread floats from one spot to the next, and the floating portion is cut away after weaving. The general appearance is that of embroidery, and the figuring is on one side of the cloth only. (6
text: LAPPETS: Cloths of a light muslin character in plain weave for the ground and figuring produced by a more or less zig- zag arrangement. The figuring threads are extra warp ends, and do not interweave with any other warp ends, but are simply held in position by passing underneath picks of weft. Each spot or other figure is made from one thread only, which is drawn through the eye of a needle fixed in a frame in front of the reed. The movement of the frame is controlled by a groove cut in a circular disc of wood. This wheel or disc, known as the "Scotch lappet motion," is the most generally used, and a specially-built loom is required. The figuring or whip "thread is not bound into the cloth, but floats from one extreme edge of the outline to the other. If spots are woven, the whip thread floats from one spot to the next, and the floating portion is cut away after weaving. The general appearance is that of embroidery, and the figuring is on one side of the cloth only. (6

Definition: a very stout twill cloth woven from hard-twisted yarns, generally cotton all through, although wool is used at times. it is used chiefly for boot and bag linings when of the twill weave. this style of cloth when figured is used for church furniture. when dyed and of plain weave it is shipped to parts of south america as lastings"-usually with a stiff glaze finish, and used as trouserings by the natives. made in various widths and qualities. a popu- lar qualty is 24 in., 64 x 60 ends and picks, 20's warp, 24's weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: LASTINGS: A very stout twill cloth woven from hard-twisted yarns, generally cotton all through, although wool is used at times. It is used chiefly for boot and bag linings when of the twill weave. This style of cloth when figured is used for church furniture. When dyed and of plain weave it is shipped to parts of South America as lastings"-usually with a stiff glaze finish, and used as trouserings by the natives. Made in various widths and qualities. A popu- lar qualty is 24 in., 64 x 60 ends and picks, 20's warp, 24's weft.
text: LASTINGS: A very stout twill cloth woven from hard-twisted yarns, generally cotton all through, although wool is used at times. It is used chiefly for boot and bag linings when of the twill weave. This style of cloth when figured is used for church furniture. When dyed and of plain weave it is shipped to parts of South America as lastings"-usually with a stiff glaze finish, and used as trouserings by the natives. Made in various widths and qualities. A popu- lar qualty is 24 in., 64 x 60 ends and picks, 20's warp, 24's weft.

Definition: very fine plain cloths. the original lawn was a fine linen cloth used for dress purposes. this cloth when now made is known as linen lawn." indian lawn is from 30 in. to 36 in. wide, 24 yards long, 72 √ó 64, calendered and made up book fold, or if 40 in. wide in long fold; yarns about 50/60 to 60/80's, both american and egyptian yarns. victoria lawn is a stiff-finished lawn, 24/26 in. wide, 92 √ó 92, and similar yarns to indian lawns. persian lawns: 32 in. 24 yds., 100 x 100, 60's/80's and finer. egyptian yarns, soft finish. bishops' lawn: a bleached and finished cloth with a blue tint, similar quality to victoria lawn.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: LAWNS: Very fine plain cloths. The original lawn was a fine linen cloth used for dress purposes. This cloth when now made is known as linen lawn." BISHOPS' LAWN: A bleached and finished cloth with a blue tint, similar quality to Victoria lawn.

Definition: the divisions into which a hank (740 yards) of yarn is tied during reeling, and each lea measures 120 yards, so there are seven leas n one cotton hank. linen manufac- turers use the term to indicate the counts of yarn, and each lea is 300 yards long, which is the linen hank.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: LEA: The divisions into which a hank (740 yards) of yarn is tied during reeling, and each lea measures 120 yards, so there are seven leas n one cotton hank. Linen manufac- turers use the term to indicate the counts of yarn, and each lea is 300 yards long, which is the linen hank.

Definition: the divisions of the threads in a warp, as 1 and 1, 2 and 2, and so on.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis

Definition: a kind of melton fabric woven from a cotton warp, two ends as one, and a wool weft, plain weave, and gene- rally dyed black or very dark grey. made principally in yorkshire from very heavy yarns
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: LEATHER CLOTH: A kind of melton fabric woven from a cotton warp, two ends as one, and a wool weft, plain weave, and gene- rally dyed black or very dark grey. Made principally in Yorkshire from very heavy yarns
text: LEATHER CLOTH: A kind of melton fabric woven from a cotton warp, two ends as one, and a wool weft, plain weave, and gene- rally dyed black or very dark grey. Made principally in Yorkshire from very heavy yarns

Definition: a fabric in which an open effect is woven to resemble lace stripes, and is obtained by certain ends making a half- turn around others. many very fancy and beautiful cloths are produced by combining this cross-weaving with other weaves. this term is applied generally to all light fabrics in which the cross-weaving principle is used. gauzes are called lenos by some makers and shippers.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: LENO: A fabric in which an open effect is woven to resemble lace stripes, and is obtained by certain ends making a half- turn around others. Many very fancy and beautiful cloths are produced by combining this cross-weaving with other weaves. This term is applied generally to all light fabrics in which the cross-weaving principle is used. Gauzes are called lenos by some makers and shippers.
text: LENO: A fabric in which an open effect is woven to resemble lace stripes, and is obtained by certain ends making a half- turn around others. Many very fancy and beautiful cloths are produced by combining this cross-weaving with other weaves. This term is applied generally to all light fabrics in which the cross-weaving principle is used. Gauzes are called lenos by some makers and shippers.

Definition: this is a brocade cloth with figuring formed by intro- ducing the gauze weave. many varieties and qualities are made. doups and healds are necessary in addition to a jacquard machine.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: LENO BROCADE: This is a brocade cloth with figuring formed by intro- ducing the gauze weave. Many varieties and qualities are made. Doups and healds are necessary in addition to a jacquard machine.
text: LENO BROCADE: This is a brocade cloth with figuring formed by intro- ducing the gauze weave. Many varieties and qualities are made. Doups and healds are necessary in addition to a jacquard machine.

Definition: a four-shaft weft face twill cloth used for linings, and finished after dyeing with a glaze surface. it was brought here from the levant and originally made from silk lancashire imitation is a poor one.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: LEVANTINE: A four-shaft weft face twill cloth used for linings, and finished after dyeing with a glaze surface. It was brought here from the Levant and originally made from silk Lancashire imitation is a poor one.
text: LEVANTINE: A four-shaft weft face twill cloth used for linings, and finished after dyeing with a glaze surface. It was brought here from the Levant and originally made from silk Lancashire imitation is a poor one.

Definition: the operation of raising the various heald shafts in their required order to form the pattern is termed "lift- ing," and the various styles of lifting are termed " lifts," such as straight lift, reduced lift, pointed lift.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: LIFTS: LIFTING: The operation of raising the various heald shafts in their required order to form the pattern is termed "lift- ing," and the various styles of lifting are termed " lifts," such as straight lift, reduced lift, pointed lift.
text: LIFTS: LIFTING: The operation of raising the various heald shafts in their required order to form the pattern is termed "lift- ing," and the various styles of lifting are termed " lifts," such as straight lift, reduced lift, pointed lift.

Definition: a fine worsted warp and silk weft fabric of crepe weave woven from dyed worsted yarn and white silk weft. term is seldom used to-day.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: LINDIANA: A fine worsted warp and silk weft fabric of crepe weave woven from dyed worsted yarn and white silk weft. term is seldom used to-day.
text: LINDIANA: A fine worsted warp and silk weft fabric of crepe weave woven from dyed worsted yarn and white silk weft. term is seldom used to-day.

Definition: such fabrics as travelling rugs, cloakings, overcoatings, etc., which consist of a face cloth of one design or colour to which is woven another cloth as a lining and of a different design or colour. a product of yorkshire, and generally made from heavy worsted and wool yarns. cotton is at times used to cheapen the fabric.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: LINED CLOTHS: Such fabrics as travelling rugs, cloakings, overcoatings, etc., which consist of a face cloth of one design or colour to which is woven another cloth as a lining and of a different design or colour. A product of Yorkshire, and generally made from heavy worsted and wool yarns. Cotton is at times used to cheapen the fabric.
text: LINED CLOTHS: Such fabrics as travelling rugs, cloakings, overcoatings, etc., which consist of a face cloth of one design or colour to which is woven another cloth as a lining and of a different design or colour. A product of Yorkshire, and generally made from heavy worsted and wool yarns. Cotton is at times used to cheapen the fabric.

Definition: one of the oldest known fabrics is that made from flax yarn and called linen. the egyptians thought linen was an emblem of purity, and used it as a wrapping for their dead. by the term linen is generally meant a medium weight cloth, plain weave, and one that takes the same standing in the linen trade as calico does in the cotton trade.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: LINEN: One of the oldest known fabrics is that made from flax yarn and called linen. The Egyptians thought linen was an emblem of purity, and used it as a wrapping for their dead. By the term linen is generally meant a medium weight cloth, plain weave, and one that takes the same standing in the linen trade as calico does in the cotton trade.
text: LINEN: One of the oldest known fabrics is that made from flax yarn and called linen. The Egyptians thought linen was an emblem of purity, and used it as a wrapping for their dead. By the term linen is generally meant a medium weight cloth, plain weave, and one that takes the same standing in the linen trade as calico does in the cotton trade.

Definition: it linen or flax yarn is very strong and weaves well. has no elasticity, and can be bleached to a snowy white. (see also flax.)
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: LINEN YARN: It Linen or flax yarn is very strong and weaves well. has no elasticity, and can be bleached to a snowy white. (See also Flax.)
text: LINEN YARN: It Linen or flax yarn is very strong and weaves well. has no elasticity, and can be bleached to a snowy white. (See also Flax.)

Definition: fabrics used for dress and coat linings. the term does not indicate any particular cloth, but is a general term and includes such linings as glissades, italians, beatrice twill linings, levantines, etc.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: LININGS: Fabrics used for dress and coat linings. The term does not indicate any particular cloth, but is a general term and includes such linings as glissades, Italians, Beatrice twill linings, levantines, etc.
text: LININGS: Fabrics used for dress and coat linings. The term does not indicate any particular cloth, but is a general term and includes such linings as glissades, Italians, Beatrice twill linings, levantines, etc.

Definition: a plain weave cloth made for south america, generally 26 in. wide and in 50 yard pieces, stiff finish, to weigh 10 lb.; 60 reed, 60 picks per inch, 26's/40's warp in red and blue stripes, 5 to 10 per cent. colour, heavy sized warp. f1
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: LIOTARDO STRIPES: A plain weave cloth made for South America, generally 26 in. wide and in 50 yard pieces, stiff finish, to weigh 10 lb.; 60 reed, 60 picks per inch, 26's/40's warp in red and blue stripes, 5 to 10 per cent. colour, heavy sized warp. F1
text: LIOTARDO STRIPES: A plain weave cloth made for South America, generally 26 in. wide and in 50 yard pieces, stiff finish, to weigh 10 lb.; 60 reed, 60 picks per inch, 26's/40's warp in red and blue stripes, 5 to 10 per cent. colour, heavy sized warp. F1

Definition: yarns made from the finest of long staple cotton, hard twisted, and gassed to give a smooth surface.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: LISLE THREAD: Yarns made from the finest of long staple cotton, hard twisted, and gassed to give a smooth surface.
