Definition: a plain grey cloth, sized warp, 24 in. 36 yds., 16 √ó 14, 30/24 (or about). it is a mexican cloth, but made up in longer lengths.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: PUNJUM: A plain grey cloth, sized warp, 24 in. 36 yds., 16 √ó 14, 30/24 (or about). It is a Mexican cloth, but made up in longer lengths.
text: PUNJUM: A plain grey cloth, sized warp, 24 in. 36 yds., 16 √ó 14, 30/24 (or about). It is a Mexican cloth, but made up in longer lengths.

Definition: a style of madras handkerchief, generally with yellow or orange coloured grounds in check designs. made for mexico, brazil, etc.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: PULLICATES: A style of Madras handkerchief, generally with yellow or orange coloured grounds in check designs. Made for Mexico, Brazil, etc.
text: PULLICATES: A style of Madras handkerchief, generally with yellow or orange coloured grounds in check designs. Made for Mexico, Brazil, etc.

Definition: broad striped cloths, all cotton, cotton warp and wool weft, or all wool, used for pyjamas. the designs are broad coloured stripes on a white or cream ground.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: PYJAMA STRIPES: Broad striped cloths, all cotton, cotton warp and wool weft, or all wool, used for pyjamas. The designs are broad coloured stripes on a white or cream ground.
text: PYJAMA STRIPES: Broad striped cloths, all cotton, cotton warp and wool weft, or all wool, used for pyjamas. The designs are broad coloured stripes on a white or cream ground.

Definition: quilts were first made by stitching two pieces of fine cloth together by hand, a layer of thick soft wadding being first placed between the two cloths. the term is now somewhat a general one, and includes most of the fabrics used for bed and table covers, as given below.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: QUILTS: Quilts were first made by stitching two pieces of fine cloth together by hand, a layer of thick soft wadding being first placed between the two cloths. The term is now somewhat a general one, and includes most of the fabrics used for bed and table covers, as given below.
text: QUILTS: Quilts were first made by stitching two pieces of fine cloth together by hand, a layer of thick soft wadding being first placed between the two cloths. The term is now somewhat a general one, and includes most of the fabrics used for bed and table covers, as given below.

Definition: in these fabrics the warp is generally in two colours drawn in end and end. the colours change to form ground and figure. the face of the fabric is warp, and the weft is practically covered.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: QUILTS, BROCHE: In these fabrics the warp is generally in two colours drawn in end and end. The colours change to form ground and figure. The face of the fabric is warp, and the weft is practically covered.
text: QUILTS, BROCHE: In these fabrics the warp is generally in two colours drawn in end and end. The colours change to form ground and figure. The face of the fabric is warp, and the weft is practically covered.

Definition: these are reversible, and only one beam is used. no healds are required, and only one shuttle. the yarns are 3 or 4 fold, both warp and weft. both ground and figure are developed in twill and satin weaves. a smooth surface. the fabric has
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: QUILTS, GRECIAN: These are reversible, and only one beam is used. No healds are required, and only one shuttle. The yarns are 3 or 4 fold, both warp and weft. Both ground and figure are developed in twill and satin weaves. a smooth surface. The fabric has
text: QUILTS, GRECIAN: These are reversible, and only one beam is used. No healds are required, and only one shuttle. The yarns are 3 or 4 fold, both warp and weft. Both ground and figure are developed in twill and satin weaves. a smooth surface. The fabric has

Definition: the ordinary honeycomb weaves are used for the groundwork, and figuring produced by twills and satins, or various sizes of honeycombs may be employed. large and bold designs are the best to shew up the peculiar cellular appearance of the weave. both warp and weft yarns are 2 or 3 fold, and usually of bleached yarn. fabrics can be woven from one beam and one shuttle. the
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: QUILTS, HONEYCOMB: The ordinary honeycomb weaves are used for the groundwork, and figuring produced by twills and satins, or various sizes of honeycombs may be employed. Large and bold designs are the best to shew up the peculiar cellular appearance of the weave. Both warp and weft yarns are 2 or 3 fold, and usually of bleached yarn. fabrics can be woven from one beam and one shuttle. The
text: QUILTS, HONEYCOMB: The ordinary honeycomb weaves are used for the groundwork, and figuring produced by twills and satins, or various sizes of honeycombs may be employed. Large and bold designs are the best to shew up the peculiar cellular appearance of the weave. Both warp and weft yarns are 2 or 3 fold, and usually of bleached yarn. fabrics can be woven from one beam and one shuttle. The

Definition: so called because of the smooth raised figures. this is the most recent style of quilt. the cloth is made from two warps and two wefts-two beams and two shuttles being necessary. there are 2 figuring ends to one ground. the figure is made from a coarse weft and fine warp upon a smooth level ground of fine weft and coarse warp. the coarse warp is controlled by the jacquard and the fine warp by heald shafts. the cloth is piece bleached.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: QUILTS, SATIN: So called because of the smooth raised figures. This is the most recent style of quilt. The cloth is made from two warps and two wefts-two beams and two shuttles being necessary. There are 2 figuring ends to one ground. The figure is made from a coarse weft and fine warp upon a smooth level ground of fine weft and coarse warp. The coarse warp is controlled by the jacquard and the fine warp by heald shafts. The cloth is piece bleached.
text: QUILTS, SATIN: So called because of the smooth raised figures. This is the most recent style of quilt. The cloth is made from two warps and two wefts-two beams and two shuttles being necessary. There are 2 figuring ends to one ground. The figure is made from a coarse weft and fine warp upon a smooth level ground of fine weft and coarse warp. The coarse warp is controlled by the jacquard and the fine warp by heald shafts. The cloth is piece bleached.

Definition: a style of heavy pique cloth, with a stitching warp controlled by jacquard to form pattern, a face warp being drawn through healds. two beams are used, one for the jacquard ends and the other for the heald ends. a fine and coarse weft also used, the fine for face and coarse for the padding to give weight. all grey yarns, the cloth being piece-bleached.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: QUILTS, TOILET: A style of heavy pique cloth, with a stitching warp controlled by jacquard to form pattern, a face warp being drawn through healds. Two beams are used, one for the jacquard ends and the other for the heald ends. A fine and coarse weft also used, the fine for face and coarse for the padding to give weight. All grey yarns, the cloth being piece-bleached.
text: QUILTS, TOILET: A style of heavy pique cloth, with a stitching warp controlled by jacquard to form pattern, a face warp being drawn through healds. Two beams are used, one for the jacquard ends and the other for the heald ends. A fine and coarse weft also used, the fine for face and coarse for the padding to give weight. All grey yarns, the cloth being piece-bleached.

Definition: a fibre obtained from the leaves of the raphia palm, which is grown in africa. strips about 3 feet long and to inch wide are usual, and these can be separated into finer fibres. much used for mats and other plaited articles.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: RAFIA, RAPHIA, OR RAFFIA FIBRE: A fibre obtained from the leaves of the raphia palm, which is grown in Africa. Strips about 3 feet long and to inch wide are usual, and these can be separated into finer fibres. Much used for mats and other plaited articles.
text: RAFIA, RAPHIA, OR RAFFIA FIBRE: A fibre obtained from the leaves of the raphia palm, which is grown in Africa. Strips about 3 feet long and to inch wide are usual, and these can be separated into finer fibres. Much used for mats and other plaited articles.

Definition: a term given to cloths that are to be raised on the back, such as cotton pyjama cloth, flanelettes, cotton trouserings, etc. the weft in these fabrics is usually more at the back and soft spun.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: RAISED-BACKS: A term given to cloths that are to be raised on the back, such as cotton pyjama cloth, flanelettes, cotton trouserings, etc. The weft in these fabrics is usually more at the back and soft spun.
text: RAISED-BACKS: A term given to cloths that are to be raised on the back, such as cotton pyjama cloth, flanelettes, cotton trouserings, etc. The weft in these fabrics is usually more at the back and soft spun.

Definition: cotton cloth, plain weave, made with a hard spun twist and a coarse soft spun weft, such as 56 √ó 52 32's/10's condenser. also known as 66 waste plains.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: RAISING PLAINS: Cotton cloth, plain weave, made with a hard spun twist and a coarse soft spun weft, such as 56 √ó 52 32's/10's condenser. Also known as 66 waste plains.
text: RAISING PLAINS: Cotton cloth, plain weave, made with a hard spun twist and a coarse soft spun weft, such as 56 √ó 52 32's/10's condenser. Also known as 66 waste plains.

Definition: a very strong and durable fibre, and perhaps the strongest vegetable fibre used for textile purposes. it is grown in china, japan, java, india, etc. the leaves of this plant are green on both sides, while the lower surface of the china grass plant is white; otherwise both plants are similar. ramie fibre is very white, has a high lustre, and can be separated into threads as fine as silk. lengths vary from 4 inches to 72 inches. it can be dyed in very delicate shades. much used for gas mantles. when woven the take-up is greater than cotton owing to the very slight elasticity the fibre has. ramie counts are usually in the worsted system. the
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: RAMIE OR RHEA FIBRE: A very strong and durable fibre, and perhaps the strongest vegetable fibre used for textile purposes. It is grown in China, Japan, Java, India, etc. The leaves of this plant are green on both sides, while the lower surface of the China grass plant is white; otherwise both plants are similar. Ramie fibre is very white, has a high lustre, and can be separated into threads as fine as silk. lengths vary from 4 inches to 72 inches. It can be dyed in very delicate shades. Much used for gas mantles. When woven the take-up is greater than cotton owing to the very slight elasticity the fibre has. Ramie counts are usually in the worsted system. The
text: RAMIE OR RHEA FIBRE: A very strong and durable fibre, and perhaps the strongest vegetable fibre used for textile purposes. It is grown in China, Japan, Java, India, etc. The leaves of this plant are green on both sides, while the lower surface of the China grass plant is white; otherwise both plants are similar. Ramie fibre is very white, has a high lustre, and can be separated into threads as fine as silk. lengths vary from 4 inches to 72 inches. It can be dyed in very delicate shades. Much used for gas mantles. When woven the take-up is greater than cotton owing to the very slight elasticity the fibre has. Ramie counts are usually in the worsted system. The

Definition: are extremely strong, can be bleached pure white or dyed in the most delicate shades, and are smooth and very durable. usually woven in plains or twills.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: RAMIE CLOTHS: Are extremely strong, can be bleached pure white or dyed in the most delicate shades, and are smooth and very durable. Usually woven in plains or twills.
text: RAMIE CLOTHS: Are extremely strong, can be bleached pure white or dyed in the most delicate shades, and are smooth and very durable. Usually woven in plains or twills.

Definition: this term was first used by continental manufacturers for a rough frieze cloth used as a lining for dress goods, and made from rough wool. the ratines made in yorkshire are all-wool fabrics in plain, fancy, and stripe effects for dress purposes. usually made from spiral yarns in coarse reeds. the warps are 3's to 5's spiral yarn, weft 3's spiral, 16 to 20 ends and picks per inch. when stripes are made the colour yarn is not spiral. always plain weave. either dyed yarns are used, or grey yarns and the cloth piece- dyed.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: RATINES: This term was first used by continental manufacturers for a rough frieze cloth used as a lining for dress goods, and made from rough wool. The ratines made in Yorkshire are all-wool fabrics in plain, fancy, and stripe effects for dress purposes. Usually made from spiral yarns in coarse reeds. The warps are 3's to 5's spiral yarn, weft 3's spiral, 16 to 20 ends and picks per inch. When stripes are made the colour yarn is not spiral. Always plain weave. Either dyed yarns are used, or grey yarns and the cloth piece- dyed.
text: RATINES: This term was first used by continental manufacturers for a rough frieze cloth used as a lining for dress goods, and made from rough wool. The ratines made in Yorkshire are all-wool fabrics in plain, fancy, and stripe effects for dress purposes. Usually made from spiral yarns in coarse reeds. The warps are 3's to 5's spiral yarn, weft 3's spiral, 16 to 20 ends and picks per inch. When stripes are made the colour yarn is not spiral. Always plain weave. Either dyed yarns are used, or grey yarns and the cloth piece- dyed.

Definition: striped cotton cloths 44 to 50 inches wide, about 18 yards long, used for trouserings and dress purposes in the philippines. made in many qualities, and shipped stiff finish. usually half-blue and half-bleached warp, with an all-colour weft. a narrow stripe of red or white yarn is woven at each selvedge.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: RAYADILLOS: Striped cotton cloths 44 to 50 inches wide, about 18 yards long, used for trouserings and dress purposes in the Philippines. Made in many qualities, and shipped stiff finish. Usually half-blue and half-bleached warp, with an all-colour weft. A narrow stripe of red or white yarn is woven at each selvedge.
text: RAYADILLOS: Striped cotton cloths 44 to 50 inches wide, about 18 yards long, used for trouserings and dress purposes in the Philippines. Made in many qualities, and shipped stiff finish. Usually half-blue and half-bleached warp, with an all-colour weft. A narrow stripe of red or white yarn is woven at each selvedge.

Definition: the french word for "striped" patterns running down the piece.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: RAYE: The French word for "striped" patterns running down the piece.
text: RAYE: The French word for "striped" patterns running down the piece.

Definition: a term applied to the number of threads in a given space, usually inch and 1 inch. shippers and makers understand the term "17 reed" to mean 64 ends per inch in the cloth, that is 4 down. when a cloth is indicated by a reed in the quarter-inch count it usually means that the number of threads per inch is 4 less than the reed number x by 4. if the ends per inch are stated, it means that number actual.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: REED (IN CLOTH): A term applied to the number of threads in a given space, usually inch and 1 inch. Shippers and makers understand the term "17 reed" to mean 64 ends per inch in the cloth, that is 4 down. When a cloth is indicated by a reed in the quarter-inch count it usually means that the number of threads per inch is 4 less than the reed number x by 4. If the ends per inch are stated, it means that number actual.
text: REED (IN CLOTH): A term applied to the number of threads in a given space, usually inch and 1 inch. Shippers and makers understand the term "17 reed" to mean 64 ends per inch in the cloth, that is 4 down. When a cloth is indicated by a reed in the quarter-inch count it usually means that the number of threads per inch is 4 less than the reed number x by 4. If the ends per inch are stated, it means that number actual.

Definition: a metal comb fixed in a frame; the closeness of its teeth determines the fineness of a cloth; it keeps the warp threads in their positions, forms a guide for the shuttle to run against, and it beats up the weft to its place at the fell of the cloth.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: REED (IN LOOM): A metal comb fixed in a frame; the closeness of its teeth determines the fineness of a cloth; it keeps the warp threads in their positions, forms a guide for the shuttle to run against, and it beats up the weft to its place at the fell of the cloth.
text: REED (IN LOOM): A metal comb fixed in a frame; the closeness of its teeth determines the fineness of a cloth; it keeps the warp threads in their positions, forms a guide for the shuttle to run against, and it beats up the weft to its place at the fell of the cloth.

Definition: fabrics contract from the width in reed about 6 per cent.; thus a 68 reed will count from 70 to 72 ends per inch in the cloth when on the table. lancashire makers use principally reeds made on the stockport system, which is named from the number of dents contained over 2 inches, each dent with 2 threads; thus a stockport reed number also gives the number of ends per inch.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: REED COUNTING: Fabrics contract from the width in reed about 6 per cent.; thus a 68 reed will count from 70 to 72 ends per inch in the cloth when on the table. Lancashire makers use principally reeds made on the Stockport system, which is named from the number of dents contained over 2 inches, each dent with 2 threads; thus a Stockport reed number also gives the number of ends per inch.
text: REED COUNTING: Fabrics contract from the width in reed about 6 per cent.; thus a 68 reed will count from 70 to 72 ends per inch in the cloth when on the table. Lancashire makers use principally reeds made on the Stockport system, which is named from the number of dents contained over 2 inches, each dent with 2 threads; thus a Stockport reed number also gives the number of ends per inch.

Definition: a patented reed used to weave ondul√© or wave pat- terns in the weft. the wires are specially shaped, and the reeds are raised and depressed in the loom while weav- ing.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: REED, ERDMANN: A patented reed used to weave ondul√© or wave pat- terns in the weft. The wires are specially shaped, and the reeds are raised and depressed in the loom while weav- ing.
text: REED, ERDMANN: A patented reed used to weave ondul√© or wave pat- terns in the weft. The wires are specially shaped, and the reeds are raised and depressed in the loom while weav- ing.

Definition: specially constructed reeds used for leno_weaving where the douping threads are very thick. they are made by wrapping the wires on one side only with pitched cord, the other side being unpitched.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: REED, FLEXIBLE: Specially constructed reeds used for leno_weaving where the douping threads are very thick. They are made by wrapping the wires on one side only with pitched cord, the other side being unpitched.
text: REED, FLEXIBLE: Specially constructed reeds used for leno_weaving where the douping threads are very thick. They are made by wrapping the wires on one side only with pitched cord, the other side being unpitched.

Definition: faulty weaving shewn by the warp threads running in two's " or "three's." this fault is caused by the warp and weft threads not being close enough to cover the space left by the dents of the reed when the reed has left the fell of the cloth.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: REED MARKS: Faulty weaving shewn by the warp threads running in two's " or "three's." This fault is caused by the warp and weft threads not being close enough to cover the space left by the dents of the reed when the reed has left the fell of the cloth.
text: REED MARKS: Faulty weaving shewn by the warp threads running in two's " or "three's." This fault is caused by the warp and weft threads not being close enough to cover the space left by the dents of the reed when the reed has left the fell of the cloth.

Definition: specially constructed reeds used for weaving wave effects down the cloth. they are of many forms, and when weaving are raised and depressed as required for pattern.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: REEDS, ONDULE, FAN, OR PAQUET: Specially constructed reeds used for weaving wave effects down the cloth. They are of many forms, and when weaving are raised and depressed as required for pattern.
text: REEDS, ONDULE, FAN, OR PAQUET: Specially constructed reeds used for weaving wave effects down the cloth. They are of many forms, and when weaving are raised and depressed as required for pattern.

Definition: cloth shewing reed marks. (see also" reed marks" and cover.")
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: REEDY CLOTH: Cloth shewing reed marks. (See also" reed marks" and cover.")
text: REEDY CLOTH: Cloth shewing reed marks. (See also" reed marks" and cover.")

Definition: the process of unwinding yarn from cops or bobbins and rewinding on to a revolving reel in the form of a skein or hank, in which form it is most suitable for export or for dyeing, bleaching, or mercerising. reformer (see bullhide).
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: REELING: The process of unwinding yarn from cops or bobbins and rewinding on to a revolving reel in the form of a skein or hank, in which form it is most suitable for export or for dyeing, bleaching, or mercerising. REFORMER (See BULLHIDE).
text: REELING: The process of unwinding yarn from cops or bobbins and rewinding on to a revolving reel in the form of a skein or hank, in which form it is most suitable for export or for dyeing, bleaching, or mercerising. REFORMER (See BULLHIDE).

Definition: a coloured stripe cotton cloth woven with the 2 x 1 twill weave-much used for boys' summer suits, washing dresses, aprons, etc. the coloured yarns are fast washing colours only, and sometimes bleached weft is used. when woven the cloth is usually soft finished. colours are generally blue, red, or black. a popular cloth is made 27 in. and 32¬ω in. wide, 64 ends, 60 picks, 24's warp, 20's weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: REGATTAS: A coloured stripe cotton cloth woven with the 2 x 1 twill weave-much used for boys' summer suits, washing dresses, aprons, etc. The coloured yarns are fast washing colours only, and sometimes bleached weft is used. When woven the cloth is usually soft finished. Colours are generally blue, red, or black. A popular cloth is made 27 in. and 32¬Ω in. wide, 64 ends, 60 picks, 24's warp, 20's weft.
text: REGATTAS: A coloured stripe cotton cloth woven with the 2 x 1 twill weave-much used for boys' summer suits, washing dresses, aprons, etc. The coloured yarns are fast washing colours only, and sometimes bleached weft is used. When woven the cloth is usually soft finished. Colours are generally blue, red, or black. A popular cloth is made 27 in. and 32¬Ω in. wide, 64 ends, 60 picks, 24's warp, 20's weft.

Definition: this cloth is the same as rayadillos, but made narrow widths, from 25 in., and in 27-yard lengths.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: REGRETTAS: This cloth is the same as rayadillos, but made narrow widths, from 25 in., and in 27-yard lengths.
text: REGRETTAS: This cloth is the same as rayadillos, but made narrow widths, from 25 in., and in 27-yard lengths.

Definition: an american term given to a so-called waterproof cloth used for coatings. they are made from a cotton warp and woollen weft, and in 4 or 6 end twill weaves- weft faced cloths and finished with a nap face-generally dyed.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: REPELLANTS: An American term given to a so-called waterproof cloth used for coatings. They are made from a cotton warp and woollen weft, and in 4 or 6 end twill weaves- weft faced cloths and finished with a nap face-generally dyed.
text: REPELLANTS: An American term given to a so-called waterproof cloth used for coatings. They are made from a cotton warp and woollen weft, and in 4 or 6 end twill weaves- weft faced cloths and finished with a nap face-generally dyed.

Definition: the true repp is a plain woven fabric having both warp and weft arranged one thread fine, one thread coarse. the coarse ends are always lifted above the coarse picks, and fine ends over fine picks, thus producing prominent trans- verse ribs of a sharper nature than those of the poplin. two beams are used, with the fine warp more heavily weighted than the coarse warp. two shuttles also should be used, although many makers use one only and one weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: REPPS: The true repp is a plain woven fabric having both warp and weft arranged one thread fine, one thread coarse. The coarse ends are always lifted above the coarse picks, and fine ends over fine picks, thus producing prominent trans- verse ribs of a sharper nature than those of the poplin. Two beams are used, with the fine warp more heavily weighted than the coarse warp. Two shuttles also should be used, although many makers use one only and one weft.
text: REPPS: The true repp is a plain woven fabric having both warp and weft arranged one thread fine, one thread coarse. The coarse ends are always lifted above the coarse picks, and fine ends over fine picks, thus producing prominent trans- verse ribs of a sharper nature than those of the poplin. Two beams are used, with the fine warp more heavily weighted than the coarse warp. Two shuttles also should be used, although many makers use one only and one weft.

Definition: in this style of work the design is printed on the cloth in a substance that is afterwards removed, and this sub- stance resists the dye into which the piece is placed. after dyeing and finishing the design shews in white on a coloured ground.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: RESIST PRINTING: In this style of work the design is printed on the cloth in a substance that is afterwards removed, and this sub- stance resists the dye into which the piece is placed. After dyeing and finishing the design shews in white on a coloured ground.
text: RESIST PRINTING: In this style of work the design is printed on the cloth in a substance that is afterwards removed, and this sub- stance resists the dye into which the piece is placed. After dyeing and finishing the design shews in white on a coloured ground.

Definition: designs which are turned over instead of repeating straight across. each half is alike, but reversed. a 10- inch pattern when turned over gives a 20-inch repeat.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: REVERSE OR TURN-OVER DESIGNS: Designs which are turned over instead of repeating straight across. Each half is alike, but reversed. A 10- inch pattern when turned over gives a 20-inch repeat.
text: REVERSE OR TURN-OVER DESIGNS: Designs which are turned over instead of repeating straight across. Each half is alike, but reversed. A 10- inch pattern when turned over gives a 20-inch repeat.

Definition: a good quality lining cloth woven with the 3 x 1 twill weave, and usually 52 to 56 inches in width-generally dyed black and shreiner finished. many qualities are made, such as: 76 x 150 32's/44's. 76 √ó 200 32/50e.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: REVERSED JEANETTES: A good quality lining cloth woven with the 3 x 1 twill weave, and usually 52 to 56 inches in width-generally dyed black and shreiner finished. Many qualities are made, such as: 76 x 150 32's/44's. 76 √ó 200 32/50E.
text: REVERSED JEANETTES: A good quality lining cloth woven with the 3 x 1 twill weave, and usually 52 to 56 inches in width-generally dyed black and shreiner finished. Many qualities are made, such as: 76 x 150 32's/44's. 76 √ó 200 32/50E.

Definition: the ordinary cretonne cloth printed on both sides.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: REVERSIBLE CRETONNES: The ordinary cretonne cloth printed on both sides.
text: REVERSIBLE CRETONNES: The ordinary cretonne cloth printed on both sides.

Definition: nearly all textile fabrics which have a pattern on both sides and which will allow either side of the cloth to be used can be termed reversible. the term was originally given to tapestries and other compound fabrics made from two or more warps and wefts of different colours, and in which the design on one side was exactly opposite to the design on the other.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: REVERSIBLES: Nearly all textile fabrics which have a pattern on both sides and which will allow either side of the cloth to be used can be termed reversible. The term was originally given to tapestries and other compound fabrics made from two or more warps and wefts of different colours, and in which the design on one side was exactly opposite to the design on the other.
text: REVERSIBLES: Nearly all textile fabrics which have a pattern on both sides and which will allow either side of the cloth to be used can be termed reversible. The term was originally given to tapestries and other compound fabrics made from two or more warps and wefts of different colours, and in which the design on one side was exactly opposite to the design on the other.

Definition: a warp rib fabric with the rib effect broken up into a crepe style.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: RIB CREPES OR CREPOLINE: A warp rib fabric with the rib effect broken up into a crepe style.
text: RIB CREPES OR CREPOLINE: A warp rib fabric with the rib effect broken up into a crepe style.

Definition: the term given to certain cord effects produced by running two or more threads of warp together, or by using a thicker yarn, to form a distinct line. the thicker yarn gives the bolder cord, but the cloth requires two beams to weave. fair examples are:-331/100 yards, 76 √ó 86 26's/36's, with 8 cords per inch of 2/12's. 331/100 yards, 76 x 82 26/36's. cords made by run- ning 3 ends of 26's together.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: RIBS: The term given to certain cord effects produced by running two or more threads of warp together, or by using a thicker yarn, to form a distinct line. The thicker yarn gives the bolder cord, but the cloth requires two beams to weave. Fair examples are:-331/100 yards, 76 √ó 86 26's/36's, with 8 cords per inch of 2/12's. 331/100 yards, 76 x 82 26/36's. Cords made by run- ning 3 ends of 26's together.
text: RIBS: The term given to certain cord effects produced by running two or more threads of warp together, or by using a thicker yarn, to form a distinct line. The thicker yarn gives the bolder cord, but the cloth requires two beams to weave. Fair examples are:-331/100 yards, 76 √ó 86 26's/36's, with 8 cords per inch of 2/12's. 331/100 yards, 76 x 82 26/36's. Cords made by run- ning 3 ends of 26's together.

Definition: fancy weaves formed from the simple 6 end and 8 end twills. these twills are broken at the middle and reversed, thus the 6 end rice weave is drawn in 1, 2, 3, 6, 5, 4, and the 8 end 1, 2, 3, 4, 8, 7, 6, 5.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: RICE WEAVES: Fancy weaves formed from the simple 6 end and 8 end twills. These twills are broken at the middle and reversed, thus the 6 end rice weave is drawn in 1, 2, 3, 6, 5, 4, and the 8 end 1, 2, 3, 4, 8, 7, 6, 5.
text: RICE WEAVES: Fancy weaves formed from the simple 6 end and 8 end twills. These twills are broken at the middle and reversed, thus the 6 end rice weave is drawn in 1, 2, 3, 6, 5, 4, and the 8 end 1, 2, 3, 4, 8, 7, 6, 5.

Definition: the ring frame draws out the rove and spins it into yarn on the continuous system, the yarn usually being spun on bobbins or paper tubes. ring spinning is cheaper than mule, but the yarn is more wiry and hard than mule yarn. the mule spins the best quality yarns at the pre- sent time.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: RING SPINNING: The ring frame draws out the rove and spins it into yarn on the continuous system, the yarn usually being spun on bobbins or paper tubes. Ring spinning is cheaper than mule, but the yarn is more wiry and hard than mule yarn. The mule spins the best quality yarns at the pre- sent time.
text: RING SPINNING: The ring frame draws out the rove and spins it into yarn on the continuous system, the yarn usually being spun on bobbins or paper tubes. Ring spinning is cheaper than mule, but the yarn is more wiry and hard than mule yarn. The mule spins the best quality yarns at the pre- sent time.

Definition: a printed twill cotton cloth originally used for wraps, and printed in beautiful all-over cashmere effects-the quality being 64 √ó 64 30's/34's to 36's/40's. the term now denotes style of design, which is very bold and full of colour. all the face of the fabric being covered with pattern.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ROBES: A printed twill cotton cloth originally used for wraps, and printed in beautiful all-over cashmere effects-the quality being 64 √ó 64 30's/34's to 36's/40's. The term now denotes style of design, which is very bold and full of colour. all the face of the fabric being covered with pattern.
text: ROBES: A printed twill cotton cloth originally used for wraps, and printed in beautiful all-over cashmere effects-the quality being 64 √ó 64 30's/34's to 36's/40's. The term now denotes style of design, which is very bold and full of colour. all the face of the fabric being covered with pattern.

Definition: a french term given to a method of forming fancy edges to narrow fabrics. figuring threads are wound on special bobbins and used as extra warp, very slightly weighted so that the yarn can be drawn off quickly. these extra warp or roquetin threads take the place of weft, and interweave with the ordinary warp at each side of the fabric. h
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ROQUETIN: A French term given to a method of forming fancy edges to narrow fabrics. Figuring threads are wound on special bobbins and used as extra warp, very slightly weighted so that the yarn can be drawn off quickly. These extra warp or roquetin threads take the place of weft, and interweave with the ordinary warp at each side of the fabric. H
text: ROQUETIN: A French term given to a method of forming fancy edges to narrow fabrics. Figuring threads are wound on special bobbins and used as extra warp, very slightly weighted so that the yarn can be drawn off quickly. These extra warp or roquetin threads take the place of weft, and interweave with the ordinary warp at each side of the fabric. H

Definition: the term given to woollen cloths just after leaving the loom, as they usually appear to be coarse and look rough. finishing takes this rough, fuzzy look off the fabrics.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ROUGHERS: The term given to woollen cloths just after leaving the loom, as they usually appear to be coarse and look rough. Finishing takes this rough, fuzzy look off the fabrics.
text: ROUGHERS: The term given to woollen cloths just after leaving the loom, as they usually appear to be coarse and look rough. Finishing takes this rough, fuzzy look off the fabrics.

Definition: a heavy fustian cord made from good quality yarns about 20's/16's. the pattern is on 14 or 16 ends and 10 or 12 picks, with a larger number of picks than ends per inch. much used for suitings for hard wear.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ROUND TOP: A heavy fustian cord made from good quality yarns about 20's/16's. The pattern is on 14 or 16 ends and 10 or 12 picks, with a larger number of picks than ends per inch. Much used for suitings for hard wear.
text: ROUND TOP: A heavy fustian cord made from good quality yarns about 20's/16's. The pattern is on 14 or 16 ends and 10 or 12 picks, with a larger number of picks than ends per inch. Much used for suitings for hard wear.

Definition: this machine reduces the slubbing to a finer thread or roving, makes it more regular and even, puts more twist in, and winds it upon a smaller tube. from this machine the material goes to the spinning frame.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ROVING FRAME: This machine reduces the slubbing to a finer thread or roving, makes it more regular and even, puts more twist in, and winds it upon a smaller tube. From this machine the material goes to the spinning frame.
text: ROVING FRAME: This machine reduces the slubbing to a finer thread or roving, makes it more regular and even, puts more twist in, and winds it upon a smaller tube. From this machine the material goes to the spinning frame.

Definition: a yorkshire cloth woven usually in a 5-shaft satin weave, with weft face, from a cotton warp and wool weft. the warp is often 2/40's, and picks 100 to 150.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ROYALETTE: A Yorkshire cloth woven usually in a 5-shaft satin weave, with weft face, from a cotton warp and wool weft. The warp is often 2/40's, and picks 100 to 150.
text: ROYALETTE: A Yorkshire cloth woven usually in a 5-shaft satin weave, with weft face, from a cotton warp and wool weft. The warp is often 2/40's, and picks 100 to 150.

Definition: an all-cotton cloth, plain weave, with the whole of the warp threads working in pairs. the picks are about twice the number of ends per inch. fair samples are 36 in. 100 yards, 72 ends 140 picks, 28's/32's-50 in. 90 yards, 68 √ó 136, 30's/36's. when dyed and finished the effect is that of a rib down the piece.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ROYAL RIBS: An all-cotton cloth, plain weave, with the whole of the warp threads working in pairs. The picks are about twice the number of ends per inch. Fair samples are 36 in. 100 yards, 72 ends 140 picks, 28's/32's-50 in. 90 yards, 68 √ó 136, 30's/36's. When dyed and finished the effect is that of a rib down the piece.
text: ROYAL RIBS: An all-cotton cloth, plain weave, with the whole of the warp threads working in pairs. The picks are about twice the number of ends per inch. Fair samples are 36 in. 100 yards, 72 ends 140 picks, 28's/32's-50 in. 90 yards, 68 √ó 136, 30's/36's. When dyed and finished the effect is that of a rib down the piece.

Definition: the a simple matting cloth woven from a cotton warp, weaving 2 ends together, and a fine worsted weft. warp is weighted, and weft does the bending, giving a rib effect.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: RUSSEL CORD: The A simple matting cloth woven from a cotton warp, weaving 2 ends together, and a fine worsted weft. warp is weighted, and weft does the bending, giving a rib effect.
text: RUSSEL CORD: The A simple matting cloth woven from a cotton warp, weaving 2 ends together, and a fine worsted weft. warp is weighted, and weft does the bending, giving a rib effect.

Definition: an all-wool costume cloth, plain weave, made in widths from 50 to 74 inches. the cloth is well shrunk.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: RUSSIAN CLOTH: An all-wool costume cloth, plain weave, made in widths from 50 to 74 inches. The cloth is well shrunk.
text: RUSSIAN CLOTH: An all-wool costume cloth, plain weave, made in widths from 50 to 74 inches. The cloth is well shrunk.

Definition: a combination of plain stripes with bold cords from toinch apart. the plain effect is of a different colour to the cords. the cords form a very bold solid rib down the piece, and are made by working three thick cords to- gether, with a douping thread of same colour crossing from side to side at every pick. this crossing thread is about three times the length of the ordinary warp.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: RUSSIAN CORDS: A combination of plain stripes with bold cords from toinch apart. The plain effect is of a different colour to the cords. The cords form a very bold solid rib down the piece, and are made by working three thick cords to- gether, with a douping thread of same colour crossing from side to side at every pick. This crossing thread is about three times the length of the ordinary warp.
text: RUSSIAN CORDS: A combination of plain stripes with bold cords from toinch apart. The plain effect is of a different colour to the cords. The cords form a very bold solid rib down the piece, and are made by working three thick cords to- gether, with a douping thread of same colour crossing from side to side at every pick. This crossing thread is about three times the length of the ordinary warp.

Definition: a cotton grown in brazil from the orleans variety of seed. it is rather harsh and wiry, and generally mixed with other varieties.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SANTOS COTTON: A cotton grown in Brazil from the Orleans variety of seed. It is rather harsh and wiry, and generally mixed with other varieties.
text: SANTOS COTTON: A cotton grown in Brazil from the Orleans variety of seed. It is rather harsh and wiry, and generally mixed with other varieties.

Definition: a shawl or dhooty, usually 40 inches wide and 7 to 8 yards long, worn as a skirt by the native women of india and the east indies. made in many qualities, but all have a woven or printed border at each side and a very fancy deep heading at each end.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SARI, SARRIE: A shawl or dhooty, usually 40 inches wide and 7 to 8 yards long, worn as a skirt by the native women of India and the East Indies. Made in many qualities, but all have a woven or printed border at each side and a very fancy deep heading at each end.
text: SARI, SARRIE: A shawl or dhooty, usually 40 inches wide and 7 to 8 yards long, worn as a skirt by the native women of India and the East Indies. Made in many qualities, but all have a woven or printed border at each side and a very fancy deep heading at each end.

Definition: a cotton cloth, plain weave, with brilliant coloured stripes down the piece. used in the east as scarves or loin cloths. made with fancy headings at each end of the piece, which varies from 5 to 7 yards. the colours are fast to washing and light. made about 60 to 66 ends and 44 to 50 picks, and 40's warp, 30's to 40's weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SARONG: A cotton cloth, plain weave, with brilliant coloured stripes down the piece. Used in the East as scarves or loin cloths. Made with fancy headings at each end of the piece, which varies from 5 to 7 yards. The colours are fast to washing and light. Made about 60 to 66 ends and 44 to 50 picks, and 40's warp, 30's to 40's weft.
text: SARONG: A cotton cloth, plain weave, with brilliant coloured stripes down the piece. Used in the East as scarves or loin cloths. Made with fancy headings at each end of the piece, which varies from 5 to 7 yards. The colours are fast to washing and light. Made about 60 to 66 ends and 44 to 50 picks, and 40's warp, 30's to 40's weft.

Definition: a term, not much used, denoting a woollen cloth woven with various rib weaves and given a lustrous finish.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SATARAS: A term, not much used, denoting a woollen cloth woven with various rib weaves and given a lustrous finish.
text: SATARAS: A term, not much used, denoting a woollen cloth woven with various rib weaves and given a lustrous finish.

Definition: an all-cotton cloth largely made in nelson and district, principally in 30 to 32 inches, 90 yards, 72 reed, 36's/38's yarns, and picks varying from 88 to 130 or more. the 5-end satin weave is used with weft face. a good twist is necessary, and a soft spun even weft, spun weft way. the cloth is mostly dyed and used for linings, though a great quantity is printed for dress goods. generally woven with shaft looms, which make a better cloth than where dobbies are used.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SATEENS: An all-cotton cloth largely made in Nelson and district, principally in 30 to 32 inches, 90 yards, 72 reed, 36's/38's yarns, and picks varying from 88 to 130 or more. The 5-end satin weave is used with weft face. A good twist is necessary, and a soft spun even weft, spun weft way. The cloth is mostly dyed and used for linings, though a great quantity is printed for dress goods. Generally woven with shaft looms, which make a better cloth than where dobbies are used.
text: SATEENS: An all-cotton cloth largely made in Nelson and district, principally in 30 to 32 inches, 90 yards, 72 reed, 36's/38's yarns, and picks varying from 88 to 130 or more. The 5-end satin weave is used with weft face. A good twist is necessary, and a soft spun even weft, spun weft way. The cloth is mostly dyed and used for linings, though a great quantity is printed for dress goods. Generally woven with shaft looms, which make a better cloth than where dobbies are used.

Definition: a finish to imitate satins. it is glossy, with as much lustre as possible and with a fairly crisp feel. the goods are usually starched, then dried on the tins, damped, and glazed on the calender.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SATEEN FINISH: A finish to imitate satins. It is glossy, with as much lustre as possible and with a fairly crisp feel. The goods are usually starched, then dried on the tins, damped, and glazed on the calender.
text: SATEEN FINISH: A finish to imitate satins. It is glossy, with as much lustre as possible and with a fairly crisp feel. The goods are usually starched, then dried on the tins, damped, and glazed on the calender.

Definition: a cotton cloth used for upholstery purposes, made from heavy yarns in stripes of colour and 5 or 8 shaft satin weave. about 98 x 56, 7's combed warp, and 14's super weft, warp face.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SATEEN TICK: A cotton cloth used for upholstery purposes, made from heavy yarns in stripes of colour and 5 or 8 shaft satin weave. About 98 x 56, 7's combed warp, and 14's super weft, warp face.
text: SATEEN TICK: A cotton cloth used for upholstery purposes, made from heavy yarns in stripes of colour and 5 or 8 shaft satin weave. About 98 x 56, 7's combed warp, and 14's super weft, warp face.

Definition: originally a silk cloth with warp predominating over weft. the weft is completely covered, giving a very smooth warp face. the cotton satin distinguishes the warp face from the weft face sateen. the broken satin has the warp threads and weft threads so twisted that the slight twill of the satin weave is not visible. the satin weave is a style of weave in which no two consecutive warp ends intersect with successive picks; this gives a smooth, even face to the cloth, and allows one set of threads to be completely covered, the face threads being much greater in number than the other series of threads.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SATIN: Originally a silk cloth with warp predominating over weft. The weft is completely covered, giving a very smooth warp face. The cotton satin distinguishes the warp face from the weft face sateen. The broken satin has the warp threads and weft threads so twisted that the slight twill of the satin weave is not visible. The satin weave is a style of weave in which no two consecutive warp ends intersect with successive picks; this gives a smooth, even face to the cloth, and allows one set of threads to be completely covered, the face threads being much greater in number than the other series of threads.
text: SATIN: Originally a silk cloth with warp predominating over weft. The weft is completely covered, giving a very smooth warp face. The cotton satin distinguishes the warp face from the weft face sateen. The broken satin has the warp threads and weft threads so twisted that the slight twill of the satin weave is not visible. The satin weave is a style of weave in which no two consecutive warp ends intersect with successive picks; this gives a smooth, even face to the cloth, and allows one set of threads to be completely covered, the face threads being much greater in number than the other series of threads.

Definition: a cheap wool mixture cloth, usually printed in stripes and used for nightgowns. about 30 per cent. cotton. an imitation of the true satin woven from very fine mercerised yarns. a fabric woven with a warp face on both sides. one warp only used, but each end is raised for a certain num- ber of picks in satin order and then left down for the same number.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SATINETS: A cheap wool mixture cloth, usually printed in stripes and used for nightgowns. About 30 per cent. cotton. An imitation of the true satin woven from very fine mercerised yarns. A fabric woven with a warp face on both sides. One warp only used, but each end is raised for a certain num- ber of picks in satin order and then left down for the same number.
text: SATINETS: A cheap wool mixture cloth, usually printed in stripes and used for nightgowns. About 30 per cent. cotton. An imitation of the true satin woven from very fine mercerised yarns. A fabric woven with a warp face on both sides. One warp only used, but each end is raised for a certain num- ber of picks in satin order and then left down for the same number.

Definition: a yorkshire cloth, used for cheap dress goods, made from wool and cotton mixture yarns. usually dyed.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SAXONIES: A Yorkshire cloth, used for cheap dress goods, made from wool and cotton mixture yarns. Usually dyed.
text: SAXONIES: A Yorkshire cloth, used for cheap dress goods, made from wool and cotton mixture yarns. Usually dyed.

Definition: a special finish used largely in the finishing of black sateens, italians, etc. it is obtained by means of specially engraved rollers used with heat and pressure, the engrav- ing being very fine parallel lines.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SCHREINER FINISH: A special finish used largely in the finishing of black sateens, Italians, etc. It is obtained by means of specially engraved rollers used with heat and pressure, the engrav- ing being very fine parallel lines.
text: SCHREINER FINISH: A special finish used largely in the finishing of black sateens, Italians, etc. It is obtained by means of specially engraved rollers used with heat and pressure, the engrav- ing being very fine parallel lines.

Definition: (see kidderminster)‚äî kidderminster, ingrain, and scotch carpets are the same fabric. they were originally made in kidderminster, but now the chief centre is scotland.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SCOTCH CARPETS : (See KIDDERMINSTER)‚Äî Kidderminster, Ingrain, and Scotch carpets are the same fabric. They were originally made in Kidderminster, but now the chief centre is Scotland.
text: SCOTCH CARPETS : (See KIDDERMINSTER)‚Äî Kidderminster, Ingrain, and Scotch carpets are the same fabric. They were originally made in Kidderminster, but now the chief centre is Scotland.

Definition: a system of sizing used for very fine yarns and super cloths. it is much slower than slashing, as only 4 to 5 beams a day can be sized, against 14 to 15 slashed. the warp from the warper's beams passes through the size box, then through a revolving brush and over a fan in hot air, through another brush, and on to the weaver's beam. the brushing lays down the projecting fibres and makes strong round thread. there is no matting or caking of the a threads.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SCOTCH DRESSING: A system of sizing used for very fine yarns and super cloths. It is much slower than slashing, as only 4 to 5 beams a day can be sized, against 14 to 15 slashed. The warp from the warper's beams passes through the size box, then through a revolving brush and over a fan in hot air, through another brush, and on to the weaver's beam. The brushing lays down the projecting fibres and makes strong round thread. There is no matting or caking of the a threads.
text: SCOTCH DRESSING: A system of sizing used for very fine yarns and super cloths. It is much slower than slashing, as only 4 to 5 beams a day can be sized, against 14 to 15 slashed. The warp from the warper's beams passes through the size box, then through a revolving brush and over a fan in hot air, through another brush, and on to the weaver's beam. The brushing lays down the projecting fibres and makes strong round thread. There is no matting or caking of the a threads.

Title: Glossary of textile terms

Definition: when two or more kinds of fibres have been mixed before being spun into a thread they are said to have been scribbled."
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SCRIBBLED: When two or more kinds of fibres have been mixed before being spun into a thread they are said to have been scribbled."
text: SCRIBBLED: When two or more kinds of fibres have been mixed before being spun into a thread they are said to have been scribbled."

Definition: a very loosely woven muslin style of cloth with fancy colour stripes. intended for curtains or drapery. a very low muslin cloth is also given this name, and is used for hat linings by being pasted to another cloth- generally made about 12 ends and picks per inch, from a poor grade of yarn, counts about 34's/28's. ƒº
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SCRIM: A very loosely woven muslin style of cloth with fancy colour stripes. Intended for curtains or drapery. A very low muslin cloth is also given this name, and is used for hat linings by being pasted to another cloth- generally made about 12 ends and picks per inch, from a poor grade of yarn, counts about 34's/28's. ƒº

A very low muslin cloth is also given this name, and is used for hat linings by being pasted to another cloth- generally made about 12 ends and picks per inch, from a poor grade of yarn, counts about 34's/28's. ƒº

Definition: an operation in spinning that has two objects that of a further removal of impurities after opening, and the for- mation of a lap web or sheet of cotton wound on to a roller.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SCUTCHING: An operation in spinning that has two objects that of a further removal of impurities after opening, and the for- mation of a lap web or sheet of cotton wound on to a roller.
text: SCUTCHING: An operation in spinning that has two objects that of a further removal of impurities after opening, and the for- mation of a lap web or sheet of cotton wound on to a roller.

Definition: perhaps the finest cotton known. it is grown on the islands near the coast of georgia and the carolinas, also on the coastline of the mainland. it is the most uniform and perfect of cotton, has a long staple, which is silky, fine, and regular. used for the best and finest of yarns.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SEA ISLANDS COTTON: Perhaps the finest cotton known. It is grown on the islands near the coast of Georgia and the Carolinas, also on the coastline of the mainland. It is the most uniform and perfect of cotton, has a long staple, which is silky, fine, and regular. Used for the best and finest of yarns.
text: SEA ISLANDS COTTON: Perhaps the finest cotton known. It is grown on the islands near the coast of Georgia and the Carolinas, also on the coastline of the mainland. It is the most uniform and perfect of cotton, has a long staple, which is silky, fine, and regular. Used for the best and finest of yarns.

Definition: all cotton or hessian bags woven on looms in tubular form on the double-plain weave principle and heavy yarns.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SEAMLESS BAGS: All cotton or hessian bags woven on looms in tubular form on the double-plain weave principle and heavy yarns.
text: SEAMLESS BAGS: All cotton or hessian bags woven on looms in tubular form on the double-plain weave principle and heavy yarns.

Definition: a system of warping for coloured stripe work from dyed yarns. the warps are made in sections, several sec- tions being run simultaneously and side by side on to the weaver's beam. grey warps for ball sizing are also made in sections.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SECTIONAL WARPING: A system of warping for coloured stripe work from dyed yarns. The warps are made in sections, several sec- tions being run simultaneously and side by side on to the weaver's beam. Grey warps for ball sizing are also made in sections.
text: SECTIONAL WARPING: A system of warping for coloured stripe work from dyed yarns. The warps are made in sections, several sec- tions being run simultaneously and side by side on to the weaver's beam. Grey warps for ball sizing are also made in sections.

Definition: a designer's term for designs made up from very small dots.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SEED EFFECTS: A designer's term for designs made up from very small dots.
text: SEED EFFECTS: A designer's term for designs made up from very small dots.

Definition: the edge of a piece of cloth. selvedges are generally made from a different yarn to the body of the cloth, and as a rule two-fold yarn. a good selvedge usually means a good cloth.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SELVEDGE: The edge of a piece of cloth. Selvedges are generally made from a different yarn to the body of the cloth, and as a rule two-fold yarn. A good selvedge usually means a good cloth.
text: SELVEDGE: The edge of a piece of cloth. Selvedges are generally made from a different yarn to the body of the cloth, and as a rule two-fold yarn. A good selvedge usually means a good cloth.

Definition: this term originally meant woollen cloths woven in twill weaves on 8 or more shafts. the cotton trade now use it to denote a cloth woven in twill weave on 8 or more shafts from all-cotton yarns.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SERGES: This term originally meant woollen cloths woven in twill weaves on 8 or more shafts. The cotton trade now use it to denote a cloth woven in twill weave on 8 or more shafts from all-cotton yarns.
text: SERGES: This term originally meant woollen cloths woven in twill weaves on 8 or more shafts. The cotton trade now use it to denote a cloth woven in twill weave on 8 or more shafts from all-cotton yarns.

Definition: the number of back beams required to make one weaver's beam (or one warp) is termed a "set."
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SET (TAPERS): The number of back beams required to make one weaver's beam (or one warp) is termed a "set."
text: SET (TAPERS): The number of back beams required to make one weaver's beam (or one warp) is termed a "set."

Definition: a cotton cloth in large floral patterns, and used for curtains. woven from a printed warp and coarse white or dyed weft. the effect when woven is a blurred one, and the finished cloth is reversible.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SHADOW CRETONNES: A cotton cloth in large floral patterns, and used for curtains. Woven from a printed warp and coarse white or dyed weft. The effect when woven is a blurred one, and the finished cloth is reversible.
text: SHADOW CRETONNES: A cotton cloth in large floral patterns, and used for curtains. Woven from a printed warp and coarse white or dyed weft. The effect when woven is a blurred one, and the finished cloth is reversible.

Definition: a cloth made into a stripe without change of weave. this is done by using warp yarns of different twists; one stripe has left hand and the next right hand twisted yarn.y when dyed a shadowy effect is produced. the left hand twisted yarn is tinted in sizing with a loose colour to enable the manufacturer to distinguish it from his ordi- nary yarns.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SHADOW STRIPES: A cloth made into a stripe without change of weave. This is done by using warp yarns of different twists; one stripe has left hand and the next right hand twisted yarn.y When dyed a shadowy effect is produced. The left hand twisted yarn is tinted in sizing with a loose colour to enable the manufacturer to distinguish it from his ordi- nary yarns.
text: SHADOW STRIPES: A cloth made into a stripe without change of weave. This is done by using warp yarns of different twists; one stripe has left hand and the next right hand twisted yarn.y When dyed a shadowy effect is produced. The left hand twisted yarn is tinted in sizing with a loose colour to enable the manufacturer to distinguish it from his ordi- nary yarns.

Definition: a light woollen cloth used as linings for coats, liveries, etc., made from hard twisted yarns in 2 x 2 twill weave, usually 30 to 40 inches wide and 36 yards long. dyed in browns and blacks principally.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SHALLOON: A light woollen cloth used as linings for coats, liveries, etc., made from hard twisted yarns in 2 x 2 twill weave, usually 30 to 40 inches wide and 36 yards long. Dyed in browns and blacks principally.
text: SHALLOON: A light woollen cloth used as linings for coats, liveries, etc., made from hard twisted yarns in 2 x 2 twill weave, usually 30 to 40 inches wide and 36 yards long. Dyed in browns and blacks principally.

Definition: a tussah silk cloth woven plain weave with a rough surface because the lumps and knots and other imper- fections are retained on the yarns. some of the china silk pongee cloths are given this name, especially those printed in large designs.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SHANTUNG: A Tussah silk cloth woven plain weave with a rough surface because the lumps and knots and other imper- fections are retained on the yarns. Some of the China silk pongee cloths are given this name, especially those printed in large designs.
text: SHANTUNG: A Tussah silk cloth woven plain weave with a rough surface because the lumps and knots and other imper- fections are retained on the yarns. Some of the China silk pongee cloths are given this name, especially those printed in large designs.

Definition: the space between the two lines of warp threads caused by raising one portion and depressing the other. the mechanism employed for this raising and lowering, termed shedding motions,' are healds. tappets, dobbies, and jacquards. the shuttle passes through this space or shed and leaves a pick of weft behind, which is beaten up by the reed and the shed changed for the next pick. "c
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SHED: The space between the two lines of warp threads caused by raising one portion and depressing the other. The mechanism employed for this raising and lowering, termed shedding motions,' are healds. tappets, dobbies, and jacquards. The shuttle passes through this space or shed and leaves a pick of weft behind, which is beaten up by the reed and the shed changed for the next pick. "C

Definition: the operation of dividing the warp into two lines, so that the shuttle can pass between these lines. there are two general kinds of sheds-"open" and closed.' "" open shed. the warp threads are only moved when the pattern requires it-from one line to the other. closed shed. the warp threads are all placed level in one line after each pick. 1.

The warp threads are only moved when the pattern requires it-from one line to the other. Closed Shed. The warp threads are all placed level in one line after each pick. 1.

Definition: bed sheetings, sometimes called bolton sheetings, are made up to 120 inches wide in 2 x 2 twill, the warp and weft threads being equal from coarse yarns. condenser sheetings are same as above, but condenser weft is used. ordinary sheetings are plain weave, in widths over 40 inches, and woven from fairly coarse yarns. american sheetings (see american). brown sheetings (see brown).
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SHEETINGS: Bed sheetings, sometimes called Bolton sheetings, are made up to 120 inches wide in 2 x 2 twill, the warp and weft threads being equal from coarse yarns. Condenser sheetings are same as above, but condenser weft is used. Ordinary sheetings are plain weave, in widths over 40 inches, and woven from fairly coarse yarns. American sheetings (see American). Brown sheetings (see Brown).
text: SHEETINGS: Bed sheetings, sometimes called Bolton sheetings, are made up to 120 inches wide in 2 x 2 twill, the warp and weft threads being equal from coarse yarns. Condenser sheetings are same as above, but condenser weft is used. Ordinary sheetings are plain weave, in widths over 40 inches, and woven from fairly coarse yarns. American sheetings (see American). Brown sheetings (see Brown).

Definition: this is a small check design in black and white yarns, 2 x 2 and 4 x 4 twill weaves. the colours, warp, and weave are arranged to produce a fancy check.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SHEPHERD'S CHECK: This is a small check design in black and white yarns, 2 x 2 and 4 x 4 twill weaves. The colours, warp, and weave are arranged to produce a fancy check.
text: SHEPHERD'S CHECK: This is a small check design in black and white yarns, 2 x 2 and 4 x 4 twill weaves. The colours, warp, and weave are arranged to produce a fancy check.

Definition: when this term only is used the cloth meant is a plain weave, grey yarns heavily sized, 34 to 45 inches wide, various lengths from 30 to 40 yards, 64 to 72 reed and pick, and 36's to 40's warp and weft. shipped loom state to india and china. this cloth, made from pure sized yarns, is bleached for the china. india. home trade, and other markets. harvard shirtings (see harvard). grandrille shirtings (see grandrille). oxford shirtings (see oxford). zephyr shirtings (see zephyr).
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SHIRTING: When this term only is used the cloth meant is a plain weave, grey yarns heavily sized, 34 to 45 inches wide, various lengths from 30 to 40 yards, 64 to 72 reed and pick, and 36's to 40's warp and weft. Shipped loom state to India and China. This cloth, made from pure sized yarns, is bleached for the China. India. home trade, and other markets. Harvard shirtings (see Harvard). Grandrille shirtings (see Grandrille). Oxford shirtings (see Oxford). Zephyr shirtings (see Zephyr).

Grandrille shirtings (see Grandrille). Oxford shirtings (see Oxford). Zephyr shirtings (see Zephyr).

Definition: a recovered wool yarn manufactured from soft woollen rags which still retain felting properties, such as flannel, stockings, etc. a better grade of yarn than that known as "mungo." prior to about 1813 these rags had very little value, but at the present time a very large trade is done in yorkshire in converting the rags into yarn.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SHODDY: A recovered wool yarn manufactured from soft woollen rags which still retain felting properties, such as flannel, stockings, etc. A better grade of yarn than that known as "mungo." Prior to about 1813 these rags had very little value, but at the present time a very large trade is done in Yorkshire in converting the rags into yarn.

Definition: this term denotes that the folding or plaiting of a piece of cloth is in yards of 36 inches, thus 100ss means 100 laps of 36 inches each. the 36-inch yard is always understood when "long stick" or "l.s." is not men- tioned.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SHORT STICK: This term denotes that the folding or plaiting of a piece of cloth is in yards of 36 inches, thus 100ss means 100 laps of 36 inches each. The 36-inch yard is always understood when "Long Stick" or "L.S." is not men- tioned.
text: SHORT STICK: This term denotes that the folding or plaiting of a piece of cloth is in yards of 36 inches, thus 100ss means 100 laps of 36 inches each. The 36-inch yard is always understood when "Long Stick" or "L.S." is not men- tioned.

Definition: the american term for picks; also used in some parts of scotland. when applied to fabrics, as "shot silks," it indicates a fabric in which the warp and weft are differently coloured, so that according to the manner of holding the fabric the colours appear to change.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SHOT: The American term for picks; also used in some parts of Scotland. When applied to fabrics, as "shot silks," it indicates a fabric in which the warp and weft are differently coloured, so that according to the manner of holding the fabric the colours appear to change.

Definition: originally a plain weave fabric made from silk warp and wool weft, heavy yarns and corded. a light silk fabric has this name, and is very similar to the "mousse- line-de-soie.‚äù yorkshire manufacturers make a cloth under this term which is plain weave and from a fine cotton warp and a coarse counts mohair weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis

A light silk fabric has this name, and is very similar to the "Mousse- line-de-soie.‚Äù Yorkshire manufacturers make a cloth under this term which is plain weave and from a fine cotton warp and a coarse counts mohair weft.

Definition: a fibre obtained from the sida plant and grown in india. it closely resembles jute, but is longer, has fewer impurities, and is easier to manufacture and much superior.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SIDA FIBRE: A fibre obtained from the sida plant and grown in India. It closely resembles jute, but is longer, has fewer impurities, and is easier to manufacture and much superior.
text: SIDA FIBRE: A fibre obtained from the sida plant and grown in India. It closely resembles jute, but is longer, has fewer impurities, and is easier to manufacture and much superior.

Definition: plain weave all-cotton cloths made for the west african markets. from 27 to 30 inches wide, 27 yards long, about 64 √ó 64, 24's/28's. shipped in a firm finish. the body of the cloth is made in small coloured checks, but there is a broad stripe at each side; the stripe is usually red.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SIDEBAND CHECKS: Plain weave all-cotton cloths made for the West African markets. From 27 to 30 inches wide, 27 yards long, about 64 √ó 64, 24's/28's. Shipped in a firm finish. The body of the cloth is made in small coloured checks, but there is a broad stripe at each side; the stripe is usually red.
text: SIDEBAND CHECKS: Plain weave all-cotton cloths made for the West African markets. From 27 to 30 inches wide, 27 yards long, about 64 √ó 64, 24's/28's. Shipped in a firm finish. The body of the cloth is made in small coloured checks, but there is a broad stripe at each side; the stripe is usually red.

Definition: a table cover for use under the white cloth, usually 54 to 64 inches wide and 60 to 140 inches long, made in damask designs reversible, and from coarse cotton yarns. used as a padding cloth.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SILENCE CLOTH (or TABLE FELTING)‚Äî : A table cover for use under the white cloth, usually 54 to 64 inches wide and 60 to 140 inches long, made in damask designs reversible, and from coarse cotton yarns. Used as a padding cloth.
text: SILENCE CLOTH (or TABLE FELTING)‚Äî : A table cover for use under the white cloth, usually 54 to 64 inches wide and 60 to 140 inches long, made in damask designs reversible, and from coarse cotton yarns. Used as a padding cloth.

Definition: very low quality cotton cloths in twill or satin weaves. heavily filled in finishing, has a smooth, glossy finish, and used as linings for cheap clothing. printed some- times in stripes. reeds and picks vary, but always low yarns, 30's to 40's warp and 36's to 44's weft. originally a low linen cloth made in silesia in plain, twill, and satin weaves. i
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SILESIAS: Very low quality cotton cloths in twill or satin weaves. Heavily filled in finishing, has a smooth, glossy finish, and used as linings for cheap clothing. Printed some- times in stripes. Reeds and picks vary, but always low yarns, 30's to 40's warp and 36's to 44's weft. Originally a low linen cloth made in Silesia in plain, twill, and satin weaves. i
