Printed some- times in stripes. Reeds and picks vary, but always low yarns, 30's to 40's warp and 36's to 44's weft. Originally a low linen cloth made in Silesia in plain, twill, and satin weaves. i

Definition: the most beautiful and strongest of fibres, and is pro- duced by the silkworms of bombay and mori, tussah and arindy. our supplies are chiefly from china, india, italy, and the levant. the chinese were the first people to use this material about 2700 b.c. silk is a solidified secre- tion of the worm, and has no cellular structure. more than 2,000 silkworms are required to produce 1 lb. of fibre. the filaments are drawn from the cocoons in pairs and twisted together. as many as 10 to 15 pairs are used to make one thread. its characteristics are fineness, lustre, strength, elasticity, and it is easily dyed in the most beautiful colours.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SILK: The most beautiful and strongest of fibres, and is pro- duced by the silkworms of Bombay and Mori, Tussah and Arindy. Our supplies are chiefly from China, India, Italy, and the Levant. The Chinese were the first people to use this material about 2700 B.C. Silk is a solidified secre- tion of the worm, and has no cellular structure. More than 2,000 silkworms are required to produce 1 lb. of fibre. The filaments are drawn from the cocoons in pairs and twisted together. As many as 10 to 15 pairs are used to make one thread. Its characteristics are fineness, lustre, strength, elasticity, and it is easily dyed in the most beautiful colours.
text: SILK: The most beautiful and strongest of fibres, and is pro- duced by the silkworms of Bombay and Mori, Tussah and Arindy. Our supplies are chiefly from China, India, Italy, and the Levant. The Chinese were the first people to use this material about 2700 B.C. Silk is a solidified secre- tion of the worm, and has no cellular structure. More than 2,000 silkworms are required to produce 1 lb. of fibre. The filaments are drawn from the cocoons in pairs and twisted together. As many as 10 to 15 pairs are used to make one thread. Its characteristics are fineness, lustre, strength, elasticity, and it is easily dyed in the most beautiful colours.

Definition: a fabric intended to imitate the fur of the beaver. it is a velvet cloth, cotton warp and silk weft. the pile is very close. dyed a rich brown.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SILK BEAVER: A fabric intended to imitate the fur of the beaver. It is a velvet cloth, cotton warp and silk weft. The pile is very close. Dyed a rich brown.
text: SILK BEAVER: A fabric intended to imitate the fur of the beaver. It is a velvet cloth, cotton warp and silk weft. The pile is very close. Dyed a rich brown.

Definition: a fabric very similar to the beaver silk, but dyed black. the floats are longer, and when cut give a longer pile.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SILK SEAL: A fabric very similar to the beaver silk, but dyed black. The floats are longer, and when cut give a longer pile.
text: SILK SEAL: A fabric very similar to the beaver silk, but dyed black. The floats are longer, and when cut give a longer pile.

Definition: spun silk. the same as cotton. the number of hanks of 840 yards weighing 1 lb. give the counts. two- fold or other folds are indicated by the number of folds being placed after the counts thus, 40/2, 40/3, etc. raw silks. the weight of 1,000 yards in drams gives the counts, thus if 1,000 yards weighs 6 drams it is known "6-dram silk." another system is the number of yards per ounce, thus 25,000 organzine or tram yarn means 25,000 yards per ounce. as denier system.-the weight of 520 yards in deniers represents counts, thus 1 hank 520 yards weighs 20 deniers, the counts equal 20's denier. (533 deniers 1 ounce.) =
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SILK YARN COUNTS: Spun Silk. The same as cotton. The number of hanks of 840 yards weighing 1 lb. give the counts. Two- fold or other folds are indicated by the number of folds being placed after the counts thus, 40/2, 40/3, etc. Raw Silks. The weight of 1,000 yards in drams gives the counts, thus if 1,000 yards weighs 6 drams it is known "6-dram silk." Another system is the number of yards per ounce, thus 25,000 organzine or tram yarn means 25,000 yards per ounce. as Denier System.-The weight of 520 yards in deniers represents counts, thus 1 hank 520 yards weighs 20 deniers, the counts equal 20's denier. (533 deniers 1 ounce.) =
text: SILK YARN COUNTS: Spun Silk. The same as cotton. The number of hanks of 840 yards weighing 1 lb. give the counts. Two- fold or other folds are indicated by the number of folds being placed after the counts thus, 40/2, 40/3, etc. Raw Silks. The weight of 1,000 yards in drams gives the counts, thus if 1,000 yards weighs 6 drams it is known "6-dram silk." Another system is the number of yards per ounce, thus 25,000 organzine or tram yarn means 25,000 yards per ounce. as Denier System.-The weight of 520 yards in deniers represents counts, thus 1 hank 520 yards weighs 20 deniers, the counts equal 20's denier. (533 deniers 1 ounce.) =

Definition: all raw silks are composed of a number of filaments twisted together, usually 8 to 12 to form a thread. these threads have a natural coating of gum, which gives the strength and elasticity, but reduces lustre. the gum must be boiled off if lustre is wanted, which may be done either in the yarn state or when woven in cloth. silk yarns are divided into two classes, thrown silk and spun silk, the first being yarns that are made by the processes of reeling and throwing, and the second consisting of yarns spun from waste silk. thrown silk, or net silk, is again divided into organzine and tram yarns, organzine being made from the most perfect cocoons, and used for warps. tram is made from the inferior cocoons, and used as weft. all silk contains very nearly half its weight of natural gum, and according to the amount of gum removed we have the following terms:- hard silk. yarn that has not undergone any boiling- off process. ecru silk. yarn boiled to remove about one-twentieth of the gum. souple silk.-yarn boiled to remove about one-sixth of the gum. boiled-off silk.-yarn which has had all the gum re- moved. spun silk.-silks that have been spun. there are two grades of spun silk, schappe and bourette. schappe is made from silk waste from the fibrous portions of the cocoons, and the waste from this process is manufactured into a coarser yarn called bourette.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SILK YARNS: All raw silks are composed of a number of filaments twisted together, usually 8 to 12 to form a thread. These threads have a natural coating of gum, which gives the strength and elasticity, but reduces lustre. The gum must be boiled off if lustre is wanted, which may be done either in the yarn state or when woven in cloth. Silk yarns are divided into two classes, Thrown Silk and Spun Silk, the first being yarns that are made by the processes of reeling and throwing, and the second consisting of yarns spun from waste silk. Thrown Silk, or net silk, is again divided into organzine and tram yarns, organzine being made from the most perfect cocoons, and used for warps. Tram is made from the inferior cocoons, and used as weft. All silk contains very nearly half its weight of natural gum, and according to the amount of gum removed we have the following terms:- Hard Silk. Yarn that has not undergone any boiling- off process. Ecru Silk. Yarn boiled to remove about one-twentieth of the gum. Souple Silk.-Yarn boiled to remove about one-sixth of the gum. Boiled-off Silk.-Yarn which has had all the gum re- moved. Spun Silk.-Silks that have been spun. There are two grades of spun silk, Schappe and Bourette. Schappe is made from silk waste from the fibrous portions of the cocoons, and the waste from this process is manufactured into a coarser yarn called bourette.
text: SILK YARNS: All raw silks are composed of a number of filaments twisted together, usually 8 to 12 to form a thread. These threads have a natural coating of gum, which gives the strength and elasticity, but reduces lustre. The gum must be boiled off if lustre is wanted, which may be done either in the yarn state or when woven in cloth. Silk yarns are divided into two classes, Thrown Silk and Spun Silk, the first being yarns that are made by the processes of reeling and throwing, and the second consisting of yarns spun from waste silk. Thrown Silk, or net silk, is again divided into organzine and tram yarns, organzine being made from the most perfect cocoons, and used for warps. Tram is made from the inferior cocoons, and used as weft. All silk contains very nearly half its weight of natural gum, and according to the amount of gum removed we have the following terms:- Hard Silk. Yarn that has not undergone any boiling- off process. Ecru Silk. Yarn boiled to remove about one-twentieth of the gum. Souple Silk.-Yarn boiled to remove about one-sixth of the gum. Boiled-off Silk.-Yarn which has had all the gum re- moved. Spun Silk.-Silks that have been spun. There are two grades of spun silk, Schappe and Bourette. Schappe is made from silk waste from the fibrous portions of the cocoons, and the waste from this process is manufactured into a coarser yarn called bourette.

Definition: a term given to a proprietary cloth made from all cotton in satin weave, and finished with a soft glaze finish -dyed in all colours, made in 31 in. 90 yards, 17 x 17. 36's/42's.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SILKETTE: A term given to a proprietary cloth made from all cotton in satin weave, and finished with a soft glaze finish -dyed in all colours, made in 31 in. 90 yards, 17 x 17. 36's/42's.
text: SILKETTE: A term given to a proprietary cloth made from all cotton in satin weave, and finished with a soft glaze finish -dyed in all colours, made in 31 in. 90 yards, 17 x 17. 36's/42's.

Definition: an operation by which projecting fibres are removed from the face of a cloth. in the cotton trade the cloth is passed over a rounded plate which is heated to a white heat.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SINGEING: An operation by which projecting fibres are removed from the face of a cloth. In the cotton trade the cloth is passed over a rounded plate which is heated to a white heat.
text: SINGEING: An operation by which projecting fibres are removed from the face of a cloth. In the cotton trade the cloth is passed over a rounded plate which is heated to a white heat.

Definition: cotton yarns are sized in order to lay down the pro- jecting fibres and to enable the strain and friction of healds and reeds during weaving to be overcome. size is also added to many cloths to give more weight, which means that size is added to take the place of cotton and produce a cheaper cloth. there are three general kinds of sizing, light or pure, medium, and heavy. light sizing is up to 10 per cent., and adds from 3 per cent. to 5 per cent. of weight. this gives a better handle to a cloth. all cloths for dyeing or bleaching are usually light or pure sized. medium sizing. from 10 to 40 per cent. of size is added to make the cloth heavier. drills, jeans, china, and india shirtings, home trade domestics, and many other cloths are medium sized. heavy sizing. as much as 100 per cent. can be added to a cloth, such as may be seen in many cloths for west africa, east africa, china, etc.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SIZING: Cotton yarns are sized in order to lay down the pro- jecting fibres and to enable the strain and friction of healds and reeds during weaving to be overcome. Size is also added to many cloths to give more weight, which means that size is added to take the place of cotton and produce a cheaper cloth. There are three general kinds of sizing, light or pure, medium, and heavy. Light Sizing is up to 10 per cent., and adds from 3 per cent. to 5 per cent. of weight. This gives a better handle to a cloth. All cloths for dyeing or bleaching are usually light or pure sized. Medium Sizing. From 10 to 40 per cent. of size is added to make the cloth heavier. Drills, Jeans, China, and India shirtings, home trade domestics, and many other cloths are medium sized. Heavy Sizing. As much as 100 per cent. can be added to a cloth, such as may be seen in many cloths for West Africa, East Africa, China, etc.
text: SIZING: Cotton yarns are sized in order to lay down the pro- jecting fibres and to enable the strain and friction of healds and reeds during weaving to be overcome. Size is also added to many cloths to give more weight, which means that size is added to take the place of cotton and produce a cheaper cloth. There are three general kinds of sizing, light or pure, medium, and heavy. Light Sizing is up to 10 per cent., and adds from 3 per cent. to 5 per cent. of weight. This gives a better handle to a cloth. All cloths for dyeing or bleaching are usually light or pure sized. Medium Sizing. From 10 to 40 per cent. of size is added to make the cloth heavier. Drills, Jeans, China, and India shirtings, home trade domestics, and many other cloths are medium sized. Heavy Sizing. As much as 100 per cent. can be added to a cloth, such as may be seen in many cloths for West Africa, East Africa, China, etc.

Definition: a cotton cloth used for ladies' underwear. in the finer makes the plain weave is used; the warp is all colour in stripes, and coloured weft. an average cloth is 88 √ó 72, 32's/32's. the heavier makes are generally sateen weave, also with all colour warp in stripes in qualities about 92 √ó 52, 34's or 36's warp, 16's to 24's weft. this heavy cloth is much used by market and field workers as an outer skirt.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SKIRTING: A cotton cloth used for ladies' underwear. In the finer makes the plain weave is used; the warp is all colour in stripes, and coloured weft. An average cloth is 88 √ó 72, 32's/32's. The heavier makes are generally sateen weave, also with all colour warp in stripes in qualities about 92 √ó 52, 34's or 36's warp, 16's to 24's weft. This heavy cloth is much used by market and field workers as an outer skirt.
text: SKIRTING: A cotton cloth used for ladies' underwear. In the finer makes the plain weave is used; the warp is all colour in stripes, and coloured weft. An average cloth is 88 √ó 72, 32's/32's. The heavier makes are generally sateen weave, also with all colour warp in stripes in qualities about 92 √ó 52, 34's or 36's warp, 16's to 24's weft. This heavy cloth is much used by market and field workers as an outer skirt.

Definition: a cotton cloth in five end sateen weave made from about 36's to 40's light indigo blue warp and 32's to 36's tinted blue weft. soft finished, and used as a shirting.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SKYTEEN: A cotton cloth in five end sateen weave made from about 36's to 40's light indigo blue warp and 32's to 36's tinted blue weft. Soft finished, and used as a shirting.
text: SKYTEEN: A cotton cloth in five end sateen weave made from about 36's to 40's light indigo blue warp and 32's to 36's tinted blue weft. Soft finished, and used as a shirting.

Definition: a bad weaving fault which may cause much damage during finishing. caused by the yarn being wound care- lessly on the warp beam at the sides; by the selvedge yarn being too coarse, or not so elastic as the other yarn; temples worn and not keeping the cloth out; and in many other ways.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SLACK SELVEDGES: A bad weaving fault which may cause much damage during finishing. Caused by the yarn being wound care- lessly on the warp beam at the sides; by the selvedge yarn being too coarse, or not so elastic as the other yarn; temples worn and not keeping the cloth out; and in many other ways.
text: SLACK SELVEDGES: A bad weaving fault which may cause much damage during finishing. Caused by the yarn being wound care- lessly on the warp beam at the sides; by the selvedge yarn being too coarse, or not so elastic as the other yarn; temples worn and not keeping the cloth out; and in many other ways.

Definition: this machine is one of the most important used in cotton manufacturing, and its use is to size the warp yarn with a mixture that will lay all the fibres parallel, and add strength to the yarn to enable it to go through the strain and friction of weaving without damage. the re- quired number of beams to make the complete warp (from 4 to 8) are placed in the beam creel at the back of the machine. all the threads from these beams are drawn together into one sheet of ends, passed through the size box, between squeezing rollers, taken round hot cylinders to dry, then past fans and round measuring rollers on to the weaver's beam at the front. the slasher to take beams up to 54 inches between the flanges is termed a 9/8's machine, that to take 60 inches a 6/4's machine, and that for beams up to 78 inches an 8/4's machine
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SLASHER-TAPE SIZING MACHINE: This machine is one of the most important used in cotton manufacturing, and its use is to size the warp yarn with a mixture that will lay all the fibres parallel, and add strength to the yarn to enable it to go through the strain and friction of weaving without damage. The re- quired number of beams to make the complete warp (from 4 to 8) are placed in the beam creel at the back of the machine. All the threads from these beams are drawn together into one sheet of ends, passed through the size box, between squeezing rollers, taken round hot cylinders to dry, then past fans and round measuring rollers on to the weaver's beam at the front. The slasher to take beams up to 54 inches between the flanges is termed a 9/8's machine, that to take 60 inches a 6/4's machine, and that for beams up to 78 inches an 8/4's machine
text: SLASHER-TAPE SIZING MACHINE: This machine is one of the most important used in cotton manufacturing, and its use is to size the warp yarn with a mixture that will lay all the fibres parallel, and add strength to the yarn to enable it to go through the strain and friction of weaving without damage. The re- quired number of beams to make the complete warp (from 4 to 8) are placed in the beam creel at the back of the machine. All the threads from these beams are drawn together into one sheet of ends, passed through the size box, between squeezing rollers, taken round hot cylinders to dry, then past fans and round measuring rollers on to the weaver's beam at the front. The slasher to take beams up to 54 inches between the flanges is termed a 9/8's machine, that to take 60 inches a 6/4's machine, and that for beams up to 78 inches an 8/4's machine

Definition: the frame in which the reed is fixed and which moves the reed forward to beat up the weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SLAY, SLEY: The frame in which the reed is fixed and which moves the reed forward to beat up the weft.
text: SLAY, SLEY: The frame in which the reed is fixed and which moves the reed forward to beat up the weft.

Definition: cotton scarves or shawls made 25 to 30 inches wide, 68 to 75 inches long, with fancy headings and fringes at each end. very similar to sarongs, but narrower.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SLENDONGS OR PAHONES: Cotton scarves or shawls made 25 to 30 inches wide, 68 to 75 inches long, with fancy headings and fringes at each end. Very similar to sarongs, but narrower.
text: SLENDONGS OR PAHONES: Cotton scarves or shawls made 25 to 30 inches wide, 68 to 75 inches long, with fancy headings and fringes at each end. Very similar to sarongs, but narrower.

Definition: cotton in a loose, untwisted strand or rope, and ready for the process of slubbing or roving. the cotton is con- densed into a sliver at the carding machine. the drawing frame makes this sliver more regular and uniform in thickness. the slubbing frame draws it out, puts more twist in, and winds it on to a bobbin or tube. the sliver is now called ‚äúslubbing.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SLIVER: Cotton in a loose, untwisted strand or rope, and ready for the process of slubbing or roving. The cotton is con- densed into a sliver at the carding machine. The drawing frame makes this sliver more regular and uniform in thickness. The slubbing frame draws it out, puts more twist in, and winds it on to a bobbin or tube. The sliver is now called ‚Äúslubbing.
text: SLIVER: Cotton in a loose, untwisted strand or rope, and ready for the process of slubbing or roving. The cotton is con- densed into a sliver at the carding machine. The drawing frame makes this sliver more regular and uniform in thickness. The slubbing frame draws it out, puts more twist in, and winds it on to a bobbin or tube. The sliver is now called ‚Äúslubbing.

Definition: the operation of combining slivers together and draw- ing the strand out, adding twist, and winding on to bobbins. from this machine the slubbing passes to the roving frame, where it is reduced to a finer thread, given more twist, made more regular and even in thickness, and wound on to a smaller tube. when required for super yarns the slubbing is passed through the intermediate frame, which is a second slubbing process.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SLUBBING: The operation of combining slivers together and draw- ing the strand out, adding twist, and winding on to bobbins. From this machine the slubbing passes to the roving frame, where it is reduced to a finer thread, given more twist, made more regular and even in thickness, and wound on to a smaller tube. When required for super yarns the slubbing is passed through the intermediate frame, which is a second slubbing process.
text: SLUBBING: The operation of combining slivers together and draw- ing the strand out, adding twist, and winding on to bobbins. From this machine the slubbing passes to the roving frame, where it is reduced to a finer thread, given more twist, made more regular and even in thickness, and wound on to a smaller tube. When required for super yarns the slubbing is passed through the intermediate frame, which is a second slubbing process.

Definition: a defect in yarn consisting of thick, soft places made up of a mass of untwisted fibres.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SLUBBINGS: A defect in yarn consisting of thick, soft places made up of a mass of untwisted fibres.
text: SLUBBINGS: A defect in yarn consisting of thick, soft places made up of a mass of untwisted fibres.

Definition: the name given to tapes, narrow bindings, sash cords, braids, braces, ties, etc., woven on narrow looms.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SMALLWARES: The name given to tapes, narrow bindings, sash cords, braids, braces, ties, etc., woven on narrow looms.
text: SMALLWARES: The name given to tapes, narrow bindings, sash cords, braids, braces, ties, etc., woven on narrow looms.

Definition: small curly or kinked places in yarn, made by twisting a hard twist thread with one that has less twist, and the hard twist thread curls up, forming a snarl. lumpy places in yarns are often called " snarls," but this is a defect.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SNARLS: Small curly or kinked places in yarn, made by twisting a hard twist thread with one that has less twist, and the hard twist thread curls up, forming a snarl. Lumpy places in yarns are often called " snarls," but this is a defect.
text: SNARLS: Small curly or kinked places in yarn, made by twisting a hard twist thread with one that has less twist, and the hard twist thread curls up, forming a snarl. Lumpy places in yarns are often called " snarls," but this is a defect.

Definition: are of two classes, plain and ribbed. the plain is formed from satin weaves which are doubled or trebled, giving a very close intersection of threads and producing very strong fabrics. the ribbed is made by adding a plain weave to a warp rib weave, the warp being arranged so that the ribs are alternately right and left hand twist.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SOLEIL WEAVES: Are of two classes, plain and ribbed. The plain is formed from satin weaves which are doubled or trebled, giving a very close intersection of threads and producing very strong fabrics. The ribbed is made by adding a plain weave to a warp rib weave, the warp being arranged so that the ribs are alternately right and left hand twist.
text: SOLEIL WEAVES: Are of two classes, plain and ribbed. The plain is formed from satin weaves which are doubled or trebled, giving a very close intersection of threads and producing very strong fabrics. The ribbed is made by adding a plain weave to a warp rib weave, the warp being arranged so that the ribs are alternately right and left hand twist.

Definition: raw silk just sufficiently scoured to remove about 8 or 9 per cent. of its weight, the loss being caused by remov- ing part of the outer gum layer.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SOUPLE SILK: Raw silk just sufficiently scoured to remove about 8 or 9 per cent. of its weight, the loss being caused by remov- ing part of the outer gum layer.
text: SOUPLE SILK: Raw silk just sufficiently scoured to remove about 8 or 9 per cent. of its weight, the loss being caused by remov- ing part of the outer gum layer.

Definition: a plain weave cotton cloth with a black stripe about one inch wide at each selvedge, woven 50 to 56 inches wide, about 64 reed, 24 to 32 picks, 36's hard spun twist, and 10's to 16's weft. the cloth is raised one side and piece- dyed.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SPANISH STRIPES: A plain weave cotton cloth with a black stripe about one inch wide at each selvedge, woven 50 to 56 inches wide, about 64 reed, 24 to 32 picks, 36's hard spun twist, and 10's to 16's weft. The cloth is raised one side and piece- dyed.
text: SPANISH STRIPES: A plain weave cotton cloth with a black stripe about one inch wide at each selvedge, woven 50 to 56 inches wide, about 64 reed, 24 to 32 picks, 36's hard spun twist, and 10's to 16's weft. The cloth is raised one side and piece- dyed.

Definition: the operation of drawing out the roving to the re- quired counts or thickness at which any given number of hanks of 840 yards will weigh 1 lb. also to put the re- quired number of turns per inch in the yarn, and wind it upon a small bobbin, spool, or spindle.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SPINNING: The operation of drawing out the roving to the re- quired counts or thickness at which any given number of hanks of 840 yards will weigh 1 lb. Also to put the re- quired number of turns per inch in the yarn, and wind it upon a small bobbin, spool, or spindle.
text: SPINNING: The operation of drawing out the roving to the re- quired counts or thickness at which any given number of hanks of 840 yards will weigh 1 lb. Also to put the re- quired number of turns per inch in the yarn, and wind it upon a small bobbin, spool, or spindle.

Definition: a fancy yarn made up of two threads twisted tightly together, and round this a soft spun thread is spirally twisted. these several threads may be of different colours or counts. two threads of different counts twisted to- gether will also give a spiral effect; the greater the differ- ence in thickness the more prominent is the spiral.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SPIRAL YARN: A fancy yarn made up of two threads twisted tightly together, and round this a soft spun thread is spirally twisted. These several threads may be of different colours or counts. Two threads of different counts twisted to- gether will also give a spiral effect; the greater the differ- ence in thickness the more prominent is the spiral.
text: SPIRAL YARN: A fancy yarn made up of two threads twisted tightly together, and round this a soft spun thread is spirally twisted. These several threads may be of different colours or counts. Two threads of different counts twisted to- gether will also give a spiral effect; the greater the differ- ence in thickness the more prominent is the spiral.

Definition: are cloths woven with a selvedge in the centre, so that after finishing the cloth can be spit into two pieces. the inner edges are never perfect selvedges.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SPLITS: Are cloths woven with a selvedge in the centre, so that after finishing the cloth can be spit into two pieces. The inner edges are never perfect selvedges.
text: SPLITS: Are cloths woven with a selvedge in the centre, so that after finishing the cloth can be spit into two pieces. The inner edges are never perfect selvedges.

Definition: cotton dress goods fabrics woven with a sponge or honeycomb weave on 10 ends, which form hollows and ridges. made in all widths and coarse yarns. another style made with the leno weave is used for cleaning cloths, or may be made plain weave, about 10 or 12 ends and 10 to 14 picks per inch, 6's to 10's warp and weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SPONGE CLOTHS: Cotton dress goods fabrics woven with a sponge or honeycomb weave on 10 ends, which form hollows and ridges. Made in all widths and coarse yarns. Another style made with the leno weave is used for cleaning cloths, or may be made plain weave, about 10 or 12 ends and 10 to 14 picks per inch, 6's to 10's warp and weft.
text: SPONGE CLOTHS: Cotton dress goods fabrics woven with a sponge or honeycomb weave on 10 ends, which form hollows and ridges. Made in all widths and coarse yarns. Another style made with the leno weave is used for cleaning cloths, or may be made plain weave, about 10 or 12 ends and 10 to 14 picks per inch, 6's to 10's warp and weft.

Definition: a variety of honeycomb weave largely used for ground- work in counterpanes, toilet covers, shawls, etc. it is formed by arranging a satin base, usually on 10 ends and picks, giving a cellular formation.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SPONGE WEAVE: A variety of honeycomb weave largely used for ground- work in counterpanes, toilet covers, shawls, etc. It is formed by arranging a satin base, usually on 10 ends and picks, giving a cellular formation.
text: SPONGE WEAVE: A variety of honeycomb weave largely used for ground- work in counterpanes, toilet covers, shawls, etc. It is formed by arranging a satin base, usually on 10 ends and picks, giving a cellular formation.

Definition: cotton in stock at liverpool, and actually ready for delivery.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SPOT COTTON: Cotton in stock at Liverpool, and actually ready for delivery.
text: SPOT COTTON: Cotton in stock at Liverpool, and actually ready for delivery.

Definition: a yarn spun from the filaments obtained from the waste or outside part of the cocoons and from damaged cocoons.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SPUN SILK: A yarn spun from the filaments obtained from the waste or outside part of the cocoons and from damaged cocoons.
text: SPUN SILK: A yarn spun from the filaments obtained from the waste or outside part of the cocoons and from damaged cocoons.

Definition: a style of toilet cloth with twice as many face picks and ends as back ones. the face is plain weave, with pattern formed by stitching in diamond and other geo- metrical designs. wadding picks at times are put in to throw up the pattern.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: STOCKING-BACK CLOTHS: A style of toilet cloth with twice as many face picks and ends as back ones. The face is plain weave, with pattern formed by stitching in diamond and other geo- metrical designs. Wadding picks at times are put in to throw up the pattern.
text: STOCKING-BACK CLOTHS: A style of toilet cloth with twice as many face picks and ends as back ones. The face is plain weave, with pattern formed by stitching in diamond and other geo- metrical designs. Wadding picks at times are put in to throw up the pattern.

Definition: a term used by designers to denote that the design repeats across or straight over. it is the simplest form of jacquard designing.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: STRAIGHT-OVER DESIGNS: A term used by designers to denote that the design repeats across or straight over. It is the simplest form of jacquard designing.
text: STRAIGHT-OVER DESIGNS: A term used by designers to denote that the design repeats across or straight over. It is the simplest form of jacquard designing.

Definition: a jute substitute manufactured from straw with a small proportion of jute, and can be produced very cheaply. it is made under a german patent.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: STRANFA: A jute substitute manufactured from straw with a small proportion of jute, and can be produced very cheaply. It is made under a German patent.
text: STRANFA: A jute substitute manufactured from straw with a small proportion of jute, and can be produced very cheaply. It is made under a German patent.

Definition: plain weave cloth, all cotton, woven with red, blue, and grey stripes. generally made 42 inches wide, 24 yards long, 60 x 60, 24's/30's. also known as "" supers." singapore
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SUPERS: Plain weave cloth, all cotton, woven with red, blue, and grey stripes. Generally made 42 inches wide, 24 yards long, 60 x 60, 24's/30's. Also known as "" Supers." Singapore
text: SUPERS: Plain weave cloth, all cotton, woven with red, blue, and grey stripes. Generally made 42 inches wide, 24 yards long, 60 x 60, 24's/30's. Also known as "" Supers." Singapore

Definition: a very level and good quality yarn specially spun for good class fabrics. usually mule spun.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SUPER WEFT: A very level and good quality yarn specially spun for good class fabrics. Usually mule spun.
text: SUPER WEFT: A very level and good quality yarn specially spun for good class fabrics. Usually mule spun.

Definition: a french made silk cloth used for dress purposes, handkerchiefs, etc. twill weave, and made on both hand and power looms-very light yarns of jap silk are used.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SURAH: A French made silk cloth used for dress purposes, handkerchiefs, etc. Twill weave, and made on both hand and power looms-very light yarns of Jap silk are used.
text: SURAH: A French made silk cloth used for dress purposes, handkerchiefs, etc. Twill weave, and made on both hand and power looms-very light yarns of Jap silk are used.

Definition: a french-made silk cloth used for dress purposes, about 26 inches wide, with raw silk warp and spun silk weft. the cloth is printed in foulard style.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SURAH FANTASIE: A French-made silk cloth used for dress purposes, about 26 inches wide, with raw silk warp and spun silk weft. The cloth is printed in Foulard style.
text: SURAH FANTASIE: A French-made silk cloth used for dress purposes, about 26 inches wide, with raw silk warp and spun silk weft. The cloth is printed in Foulard style.

Definition: an indian grown variety of cotton, comprising dharwar, broach, dhollera, and hinganghat. they are coarse, dark colours, vary greatly in length of staple, and are seldom used alone in lancashire. when mixed with other cotton, spinners can get yarns to about 28's or 30's.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SURAT COTTON: An Indian grown variety of cotton, comprising Dharwar, Broach, Dhollera, and Hinganghat. They are coarse, dark colours, vary greatly in length of staple, and are seldom used alone in Lancashire. When mixed with other cotton, spinners can get yarns to about 28's or 30's.
text: SURAT COTTON: An Indian grown variety of cotton, comprising Dharwar, Broach, Dhollera, and Hinganghat. They are coarse, dark colours, vary greatly in length of staple, and are seldom used alone in Lancashire. When mixed with other cotton, spinners can get yarns to about 28's or 30's.

Definition: a very heavy sateen cloth, all cotton, woven with a large number of picks, finished both white and cream and raised on the face, such as 72 x 150, 18's/24's.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SWANSDOWN: A very heavy sateen cloth, all cotton, woven with a large number of picks, finished both white and cream and raised on the face, such as 72 x 150, 18's/24's.
text: SWANSDOWN: A very heavy sateen cloth, all cotton, woven with a large number of picks, finished both white and cream and raised on the face, such as 72 x 150, 18's/24's.

Definition: the real muslin is woven in switzerland on hand looms, and ornamented with small spots or sprigs of many colours. in scotland and bolton a fine lappet cloth is made to imitate this fabric, and usually 50 in. x 60 yards, split, 120 √ó 80, 80's/60's, both egyptian, with a 3/40's lappet yarn. the figures are small.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SWISS MUSLIN: The real muslin is woven in Switzerland on hand looms, and ornamented with small spots or sprigs of many colours. In Scotland and Bolton a fine lappet cloth is made to imitate this fabric, and usually 50 in. x 60 yards, split, 120 √ó 80, 80's/60's, both Egyptian, with a 3/40's lappet yarn. The figures are small.

In Scotland and Bolton a fine lappet cloth is made to imitate this fabric, and usually 50 in. x 60 yards, split, 120 √ó 80, 80's/60's, both Egyptian, with a 3/40's lappet yarn. The figures are small.

Definition: an imitation of the japanese pongee made from mer- cerised cotton yarn, plain weave, about 80 √ó 76, 50's/46's. the imitation is not a good one.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SWISS PONGEE: An imitation of the Japanese pongee made from mer- cerised cotton yarn, plain weave, about 80 √ó 76, 50's/46's. The imitation is not a good one.
text: SWISS PONGEE: An imitation of the Japanese pongee made from mer- cerised cotton yarn, plain weave, about 80 √ó 76, 50's/46's. The imitation is not a good one.

Definition: an imitation embroidery, made on looms. small spots or figures are produced upon a ground cloth, whose weave may be plain or figured. the swivel figures are in stripes, and separate shuttles are used for each figure, and passed from side to side of the figure space through specially formed sheds. the weft is firmly bound in at the edges of the figure, and the material used is just the amount necessary for the figure. there are no floats of figuring material. the cloths are expensive. both hand and power looms are used, but not many of either.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: SWIVELS: An imitation embroidery, made on looms. Small spots or figures are produced upon a ground cloth, whose weave may be plain or figured. The swivel figures are in stripes, and separate shuttles are used for each figure, and passed from side to side of the figure space through specially formed sheds. The weft is firmly bound in at the edges of the figure, and the material used is just the amount necessary for the figure. There are no floats of figuring material. The cloths are expensive. Both hand and power looms are used, but not many of either.
text: SWIVELS: An imitation embroidery, made on looms. Small spots or figures are produced upon a ground cloth, whose weave may be plain or figured. The swivel figures are in stripes, and separate shuttles are used for each figure, and passed from side to side of the figure space through specially formed sheds. The weft is firmly bound in at the edges of the figure, and the material used is just the amount necessary for the figure. There are no floats of figuring material. The cloths are expensive. Both hand and power looms are used, but not many of either.

Definition: a term used in many districts to describe plain weave. tabby back means that the back of the cloth is plain weave on the back. tabby velvet-a velvet woven with the plain weave on the back.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TABBY: A term used in many districts to describe plain weave. Tabby back means that the back of the cloth is plain weave on the back. Tabby Velvet-A velvet woven with the plain weave on the back.
text: TABBY: A term used in many districts to describe plain weave. Tabby back means that the back of the cloth is plain weave on the back. Tabby Velvet-A velvet woven with the plain weave on the back.

Definition: a table cover used as a padding cloth under the white tablecloth. usually 54 to 64 inches wide and 60 to 140 inches long. made in damask designs and reversible. from 8's to 16's warp and weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TABLE FELT, OR SILENCE CLOTH: A table cover used as a padding cloth under the white tablecloth. Usually 54 to 64 inches wide and 60 to 140 inches long. Made in damask designs and reversible. From 8's to 16's warp and weft.
text: TABLE FELT, OR SILENCE CLOTH: A table cover used as a padding cloth under the white tablecloth. Usually 54 to 64 inches wide and 60 to 140 inches long. Made in damask designs and reversible. From 8's to 16's warp and weft.

Definition: small cuttings and ends of cloth under one yard in length. over one yard they are called fents.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TABS: Small cuttings and ends of cloth under one yard in length. Over one yard they are called fents.
text: TABS: Small cuttings and ends of cloth under one yard in length. Over one yard they are called fents.

Definition: cotton cloths, plain weave, low quality yarns, heavily sized warp, made from 27 to 32 inches wide and always 24 yards long. the warp is soft spun in order to absorb size. yarns 18's to 24's warp and weft. shipped loom state.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: T CLOTHS: Cotton cloths, plain weave, low quality yarns, heavily sized warp, made from 27 to 32 inches wide and always 24 yards long. The warp is soft spun in order to absorb size. Yarns 18's to 24's warp and weft. Shipped loom state.
text: T CLOTHS: Cotton cloths, plain weave, low quality yarns, heavily sized warp, made from 27 to 32 inches wide and always 24 yards long. The warp is soft spun in order to absorb size. Yarns 18's to 24's warp and weft. Shipped loom state.

Definition: originally made from all silk yarns in plain weave. then botany weft was used. bradford produces a wool taffeta much used for better class shirts. a large trade is done in cotton taffeta 36 to 40 inches wide, 100 x 100, 2/80's/2/20's, sea island cotton. this cloth is both bleached and dyed.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TAFFETAS: Originally made from all silk yarns in plain weave. Then botany weft was used. Bradford produces a wool taffeta much used for better class shirts. A large trade is done in cotton taffeta 36 to 40 inches wide, 100 x 100, 2/80's/2/20's, Sea Island cotton. This cloth is both bleached and dyed.
text: TAFFETAS: Originally made from all silk yarns in plain weave. Then botany weft was used. Bradford produces a wool taffeta much used for better class shirts. A large trade is done in cotton taffeta 36 to 40 inches wide, 100 x 100, 2/80's/2/20's, Sea Island cotton. This cloth is both bleached and dyed.

Definition: an expensive lining fabric used almost solely for lining ladies' dresses. made from 28 to 42 inches wide, 180 to 200 ends, 60 to 70 picks, very fine silk warp and much coarser weft. the weft at times is 2/60's cotton.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TAFFETA LINING: An expensive lining fabric used almost solely for lining ladies' dresses. Made from 28 to 42 inches wide, 180 to 200 ends, 60 to 70 picks, very fine silk warp and much coarser weft. The weft at times is 2/60's cotton.
text: TAFFETA LINING: An expensive lining fabric used almost solely for lining ladies' dresses. Made from 28 to 42 inches wide, 180 to 200 ends, 60 to 70 picks, very fine silk warp and much coarser weft. The weft at times is 2/60's cotton.

Definition: a fabric made from the waste silk known as schappe, principally used as a lining for dress skirts. plain weave; qualities vary. an imitation silk taffeta.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TAFFETALINE OR TAMTINE: A fabric made from the waste silk known as schappe, principally used as a lining for dress skirts. Plain weave; qualities vary. An imitation silk taffeta.
text: TAFFETALINE OR TAMTINE: A fabric made from the waste silk known as schappe, principally used as a lining for dress skirts. Plain weave; qualities vary. An imitation silk taffeta.

Definition: the object is to take up the cloth when woven and wind on to a roller, also to regulate the picks per inch put into the cloth. there are two classes, namely, "posi- tive" and " negative." the negative or drag motion is most suitable for looms weaving heavy cloths, such as velvets, corduroys, etc. the positive motion is the one most used in lancashire, and consists of a train of wheels (either 5 or 7); the first wheel, being a ratchet, and actuated by a pawl from the sley, transfers motion to a beam, whose roughened surface draws the cloth forward.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TAKING-UP MOTIONS: The object is to take up the cloth when woven and wind on to a roller, also to regulate the picks per inch put into the cloth. There are two classes, namely, "posi- tive" and " negative." The negative or drag motion is most suitable for looms weaving heavy cloths, such as velvets, corduroys, etc. The positive motion is the one most used in Lancashire, and consists of a train of wheels (either 5 or 7); the first wheel, being a ratchet, and actuated by a pawl from the sley, transfers motion to a beam, whose roughened surface draws the cloth forward.
text: TAKING-UP MOTIONS: The object is to take up the cloth when woven and wind on to a roller, also to regulate the picks per inch put into the cloth. There are two classes, namely, "posi- tive" and " negative." The negative or drag motion is most suitable for looms weaving heavy cloths, such as velvets, corduroys, etc. The positive motion is the one most used in Lancashire, and consists of a train of wheels (either 5 or 7); the first wheel, being a ratchet, and actuated by a pawl from the sley, transfers motion to a beam, whose roughened surface draws the cloth forward.

Definition: plain weave cloths made about 26 inches wide from a cotton warp and wool weft in various reeds and picks. they are piece-dyed and heavily glazed. used for underskirts.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TAMMIES: Plain weave cloths made about 26 inches wide from a cotton warp and wool weft in various reeds and picks. They are piece-dyed and heavily glazed. Used for underskirts.
text: TAMMIES: Plain weave cloths made about 26 inches wide from a cotton warp and wool weft in various reeds and picks. They are piece-dyed and heavily glazed. Used for underskirts.

Definition: a light weight cloth, all cotton, made 30 to 50 inches wide, 38 yards long, with two fancy headings in the centre, about 48 ends and picks per inch, 40's/36's to 32's/40's. pure sized.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TANGIBS, TANJIBS: A light weight cloth, all cotton, made 30 to 50 inches wide, 38 yards long, with two fancy headings in the centre, about 48 ends and picks per inch, 40's/36's to 32's/40's. Pure sized.
text: TANGIBS, TANJIBS: A light weight cloth, all cotton, made 30 to 50 inches wide, 38 yards long, with two fancy headings in the centre, about 48 ends and picks per inch, 40's/36's to 32's/40's. Pure sized.

Definition: all narrow plain weave fabrics can be termed tapes up to 10 or 12 inches wide.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TAPE: All narrow plain weave fabrics can be termed tapes up to 10 or 12 inches wide.
text: TAPE: All narrow plain weave fabrics can be termed tapes up to 10 or 12 inches wide.

Definition: as (" a strong selvedge woven on light cloths, such voiles, crepes, georgettes, etc. they are made by cram- ming ends, as many as 50 to 60 being used in -inch tape." two-fold yarn is used in many cloths. widths vary from inch to inch.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TAPE SELVEDGE: as (" A strong selvedge woven on light cloths, such voiles, crepes, georgettes, etc. They are made by cram- ming ends, as many as 50 to 60 being used in -inch tape." Two-fold yarn is used in many cloths. widths vary from inch to inch.
text: TAPE SELVEDGE: as (" A strong selvedge woven on light cloths, such voiles, crepes, georgettes, etc. They are made by cram- ming ends, as many as 50 to 60 being used in -inch tape." Two-fold yarn is used in many cloths. widths vary from inch to inch.

Definition: (see slasher sizing)‚äî "" this is another name for slasher sizing. this kind of sizing is termed tape sizing probably because the yarn is wound on beams in a wide tape form, and to dis- tinguish this style from ball or hank sizing.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TAPE SIZING: (See SLASHER SIZING)‚Äî "" This is another name for slasher sizing. This kind of sizing is termed tape sizing probably because the yarn is wound on beams in a wide tape form, and to dis- tinguish this style from ball or hank sizing.
text: TAPE SIZING: (See SLASHER SIZING)‚Äî "" This is another name for slasher sizing. This kind of sizing is termed tape sizing probably because the yarn is wound on beams in a wide tape form, and to dis- tinguish this style from ball or hank sizing.

Definition: these are true pile fabrics, but the loops are not cut. they are similar to brussels, but not so smart looking and much inferior in quality. they can be woven with tap- pets, and so are cheap to produce. the design is printed on the warp yarn before weaving. heavy yarns are usual, from 2/10's to 2/16's or 3/20's to 3/60's. the bulk of these carpets are now made in squares, 9 feet, 12 feet, and larger.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TAPESTRY CARPETS: These are true pile fabrics, but the loops are not cut. They are similar to Brussels, but not so smart looking and much inferior in quality. They can be woven with tap- pets, and so are cheap to produce. The design is printed on the warp yarn before weaving. Heavy yarns are usual, from 2/10's to 2/16's or 3/20's to 3/60's. The bulk of these carpets are now made in squares, 9 feet, 12 feet, and larger.
text: TAPESTRY CARPETS: These are true pile fabrics, but the loops are not cut. They are similar to Brussels, but not so smart looking and much inferior in quality. They can be woven with tap- pets, and so are cheap to produce. The design is printed on the warp yarn before weaving. Heavy yarns are usual, from 2/10's to 2/16's or 3/20's to 3/60's. The bulk of these carpets are now made in squares, 9 feet, 12 feet, and larger.

Definition: figured cloths in which pattern is developed by using coloured threads either in warp or weft; usually compound weaves using several warps or wefts, or both. a warp tapestry is one in which warp only is on the face and forms figure, and weft tapestry has weft only on the face. all are woven on jacquard looms. super two or three fold yarns are used in the best makes. the gobelins tapestry works in paris is perhaps the largest factory for weaving real tapestries. the original tapestry was just a plain cloth used as a ground cloth, and figures were embroidered by hand with extra threads of all colours.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TAPESTRY FABRICS: Figured cloths in which pattern is developed by using coloured threads either in warp or weft; usually compound weaves using several warps or wefts, or both. A warp tapestry is one in which warp only is on the face and forms figure, and weft tapestry has weft only on the face. All are woven on jacquard looms. Super two or three fold yarns are used in the best makes. The Gobelins Tapestry Works in Paris is perhaps the largest factory for weaving real tapestries. The original tapestry was just a plain cloth used as a ground cloth, and figures were embroidered by hand with extra threads of all colours.
text: TAPESTRY FABRICS: Figured cloths in which pattern is developed by using coloured threads either in warp or weft; usually compound weaves using several warps or wefts, or both. A warp tapestry is one in which warp only is on the face and forms figure, and weft tapestry has weft only on the face. All are woven on jacquard looms. Super two or three fold yarns are used in the best makes. The Gobelins Tapestry Works in Paris is perhaps the largest factory for weaving real tapestries. The original tapestry was just a plain cloth used as a ground cloth, and figures were embroidered by hand with extra threads of all colours.

Definition: a shedding motion for plains, twills, sateens, and other simple fabrics. they are of two kinds, "positive " and negative." the first both raises and depresses the heald shafts, while the other kind only operates one way, and other mechanism is required to work the opposite position.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TAPPETS: A shedding motion for plains, twills, sateens, and other simple fabrics. They are of two kinds, "positive " and negative." The first both raises and depresses the heald shafts, while the other kind only operates one way, and other mechanism is required to work the opposite position.
text: TAPPETS: A shedding motion for plains, twills, sateens, and other simple fabrics. They are of two kinds, "positive " and negative." The first both raises and depresses the heald shafts, while the other kind only operates one way, and other mechanism is required to work the opposite position.

Definition: a very fine open muslin cloth, plain weave, and origin- ally made in india from the finest of yarns. it is very similar to pongees.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TARLATAN: A very fine open muslin cloth, plain weave, and origin- ally made in India from the finest of yarns. It is very similar to pongees.
text: TARLATAN: A very fine open muslin cloth, plain weave, and origin- ally made in India from the finest of yarns. It is very similar to pongees.

Definition: a plain cloth, open weave, all cotton, made from dyed yarns, and used for curtains and draping purposes. fine yarns are used, and made from egyptian cotton.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TARLTAN, TARLTON: A plain cloth, open weave, all cotton, made from dyed yarns, and used for curtains and draping purposes. Fine yarns are used, and made from Egyptian cotton.
text: TARLTAN, TARLTON: A plain cloth, open weave, all cotton, made from dyed yarns, and used for curtains and draping purposes. Fine yarns are used, and made from Egyptian cotton.

Definition: all cotton dress goods made to imitate the tartans used by the scotch clans. they are made in vivid colours in checks, in many widths and qualities. a large trade is done in colne and district in 27 in. to 30 in., about 50 to 70 ends and picks, 20's to 30's warp, and 16's to 24's weft. yorkshire has a fair trade in tartans made from woollen yarns.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TARTANS, TARTAN PLAIDS, SCOTCH PLAIDS: All cotton dress goods made to imitate the tartans used by the Scotch clans. They are made in vivid colours in checks, in many widths and qualities. A large trade is done in Colne and district in 27 in. to 30 in., about 50 to 70 ends and picks, 20's to 30's warp, and 16's to 24's weft. Yorkshire has a fair trade in tartans made from woollen yarns.
text: TARTANS, TARTAN PLAIDS, SCOTCH PLAIDS: All cotton dress goods made to imitate the tartans used by the Scotch clans. They are made in vivid colours in checks, in many widths and qualities. A large trade is done in Colne and district in 27 in. to 30 in., about 50 to 70 ends and picks, 20's to 30's warp, and 16's to 24's weft. Yorkshire has a fair trade in tartans made from woollen yarns.

Definition: a cotton cloth of very good quality made from bleached or cream warp and weft and soft finished. in narrow widths 28 to 33 inches, 76 ends, 52 to 60 picks, 16's warp, 16's weft, 2 x 2 matting or 2 x 2 twill weaves. stripes of 2/40's mercerised yarn introduced in many of them. used for dress purposes. also made in bradford, 80 x 72, 18's/18's, 2 x 2 twill, all cotton or cotton warp and wool weft. the original fabric was an all-wool production.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TENNIS CLOTH: A cotton cloth of very good quality made from bleached or cream warp and weft and soft finished. In narrow widths 28 to 33 inches, 76 ends, 52 to 60 picks, 16's warp, 16's weft, 2 x 2 matting or 2 x 2 twill weaves. Stripes of 2/40's mercerised yarn introduced in many of them. Used for dress purposes. Also made in Bradford, 80 x 72, 18's/18's, 2 x 2 twill, all cotton or cotton warp and wool weft. The original fabric was an all-wool production.
text: TENNIS CLOTH: A cotton cloth of very good quality made from bleached or cream warp and weft and soft finished. In narrow widths 28 to 33 inches, 76 ends, 52 to 60 picks, 16's warp, 16's weft, 2 x 2 matting or 2 x 2 twill weaves. Stripes of 2/40's mercerised yarn introduced in many of them. Used for dress purposes. Also made in Bradford, 80 x 72, 18's/18's, 2 x 2 twill, all cotton or cotton warp and wool weft. The original fabric was an all-wool production.

Definition: very heavy cotton cloths, used for tent cloths or sail making. made in all widths, from two or three fold warp and weft yarns, plain weave or matting, such as 52 √ó 52 3. 40's warp, 2, 36's weft. also made from linen yarns.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TENT DUCKS: Very heavy cotton cloths, used for tent cloths or sail making. Made in all widths, from two or three fold warp and weft yarns, plain weave or matting, such as 52 √ó 52 3. 40's warp, 2, 36's weft. Also made from linen yarns.
text: TENT DUCKS: Very heavy cotton cloths, used for tent cloths or sail making. Made in all widths, from two or three fold warp and weft yarns, plain weave or matting, such as 52 √ó 52 3. 40's warp, 2, 36's weft. Also made from linen yarns.

Definition: terry is uncut pile. the term, however, is used to distinguish woven fabrics in which the principal ornament is a series of loops projecting from the main cloth. the loops are formed by an extra slack warp, and may be formed on one or both sides of the cloth, and all over the fabric or only at parts. the loop pile is produced by using wires or by what is known as the " terry motion.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TERRY CLOTHS: Terry is uncut pile. The term, however, is used to distinguish woven fabrics in which the principal ornament is a series of loops projecting from the main cloth. The loops are formed by an extra slack warp, and may be formed on one or both sides of the cloth, and all over the fabric or only at parts. The loop pile is produced by using wires or by what is known as the " terry motion.
text: TERRY CLOTHS: Terry is uncut pile. The term, however, is used to distinguish woven fabrics in which the principal ornament is a series of loops projecting from the main cloth. The loops are formed by an extra slack warp, and may be formed on one or both sides of the cloth, and all over the fabric or only at parts. The loop pile is produced by using wires or by what is known as the " terry motion.

Definition: the ordinary velvet, but with the pile weft left uncut.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TERRY VELVET: The ordinary velvet, but with the pile weft left uncut.
text: TERRY VELVET: The ordinary velvet, but with the pile weft left uncut.

Definition: burning.-cotton, flax, ramie, and other vegetable fibres burn readily without smoke or smell, and leave little ash. wool gives when burning the odour of burning bones or hoofs, and a small knob is formed at the end of the thread. pure silk burns as wool. weighted silk burns easily, but does not curl up as pure silk does, and leaves an ash somewhat of the shape of the original thread. arti- ficial silks burn easily, similar to cotton. chemical. caustic potash turns artificial silk yellow, but pure silk does not change colour. artificial silk when wet becomes soft, and can easily be broken, shewing no fibre, but pure silk always has fibre and strength. strong hydrochloric acid dissolves silk, but beyond a swelling of the fibre wool is not altered. caustic potash dissolves wool, but does not alter vegetable fibres. concentrated sulphuric acid dissolves cotton, but not flax or wool; also dissolves silk.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TESTS-YARN: Burning.-Cotton, flax, ramie, and other vegetable fibres burn readily without smoke or smell, and leave little ash. Wool gives when burning the odour of burning bones or hoofs, and a small knob is formed at the end of the thread. Pure silk burns as wool. Weighted silk burns easily, but does not curl up as pure silk does, and leaves an ash somewhat of the shape of the original thread. Arti- ficial silks burn easily, similar to cotton. Chemical. Caustic potash turns artificial silk yellow, but pure silk does not change colour. Artificial silk when wet becomes soft, and can easily be broken, shewing no fibre, but pure silk always has fibre and strength. Strong hydrochloric acid dissolves silk, but beyond a swelling of the fibre wool is not altered. Caustic potash dissolves wool, but does not alter vegetable fibres. Concentrated sulphuric acid dissolves cotton, but not flax or wool; also dissolves silk.
text: TESTS-YARN: Burning.-Cotton, flax, ramie, and other vegetable fibres burn readily without smoke or smell, and leave little ash. Wool gives when burning the odour of burning bones or hoofs, and a small knob is formed at the end of the thread. Pure silk burns as wool. Weighted silk burns easily, but does not curl up as pure silk does, and leaves an ash somewhat of the shape of the original thread. Arti- ficial silks burn easily, similar to cotton. Chemical. Caustic potash turns artificial silk yellow, but pure silk does not change colour. Artificial silk when wet becomes soft, and can easily be broken, shewing no fibre, but pure silk always has fibre and strength. Strong hydrochloric acid dissolves silk, but beyond a swelling of the fibre wool is not altered. Caustic potash dissolves wool, but does not alter vegetable fibres. Concentrated sulphuric acid dissolves cotton, but not flax or wool; also dissolves silk.

Definition: anything woven or suitable for weaving. this is a very comprehensive term, and includes all clothing, car- pets, curtains, tapes, upholstery, mats, etc.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TEXTILE: Anything woven or suitable for weaving. This is a very comprehensive term, and includes all clothing, car- pets, curtains, tapes, upholstery, mats, etc.
text: TEXTILE: Anything woven or suitable for weaving. This is a very comprehensive term, and includes all clothing, car- pets, curtains, tapes, upholstery, mats, etc.

Definition: a plain weave all wool cloth, used largely for men's wear goods. woven from soft yarns and unfinished.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: THIBET: A plain weave all wool cloth, used largely for men's wear goods. Woven from soft yarns and unfinished.
text: THIBET: A plain weave all wool cloth, used largely for men's wear goods. Woven from soft yarns and unfinished.

Definition: the simplest and smallest corduroy cloth woven on 6 ends and 9 picks, ground weave, the 3-end twill, 2-pile picks to 1 ground. short weft floats, which are firmly bound in. when cut a very thick pile is thrown up.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: THICKSET, THICKSET CORD: The simplest and smallest corduroy cloth woven on 6 ends and 9 picks, ground weave, the 3-end twill, 2-pile picks to 1 ground. Short weft floats, which are firmly bound in. When cut a very thick pile is thrown up.
text: THICKSET, THICKSET CORD: The simplest and smallest corduroy cloth woven on 6 ends and 9 picks, ground weave, the 3-end twill, 2-pile picks to 1 ground. Short weft floats, which are firmly bound in. When cut a very thick pile is thrown up.

Definition: a twisted strand of cotton, wool, silk, etc., spun out. to any length is termed a thread.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: THREAD: A twisted strand of cotton, wool, silk, etc., spun out. to any length is termed a thread.
text: THREAD: A twisted strand of cotton, wool, silk, etc., spun out. to any length is termed a thread.

Definition: a term used principally among makers-up to indicate a dress lining woven with the three-end twill weave, and usually of good quality. some cloths are woven stripes, other cloths are printed stripes, but all have a glazed finish.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: THREE-LEAF TWILL LININGS: A term used principally among makers-up to indicate a dress lining woven with the three-end twill weave, and usually of good quality. Some cloths are woven stripes, other cloths are printed stripes, but all have a glazed finish.
text: THREE-LEAF TWILL LININGS: A term used principally among makers-up to indicate a dress lining woven with the three-end twill weave, and usually of good quality. Some cloths are woven stripes, other cloths are printed stripes, but all have a glazed finish.

Definition: silk filaments as drawn from the cocoons are of great length, so they are ''thrown " together to make a thread, several filaments being twisted into the sizes of thread required. the short lengths of silk, such as various kinds of waste, are spun into threads as with other short staple material, such as wool, cotton, etc.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: THROWN SILK: Silk filaments as drawn from the cocoons are of great length, so they are ''thrown " together to make a thread, several filaments being twisted into the sizes of thread required. The short lengths of silk, such as various kinds of waste, are spun into threads as with other short staple material, such as wool, cotton, etc.
text: THROWN SILK: Silk filaments as drawn from the cocoons are of great length, so they are ''thrown " together to make a thread, several filaments being twisted into the sizes of thread required. The short lengths of silk, such as various kinds of waste, are spun into threads as with other short staple material, such as wool, cotton, etc.

Definition: a wool trade term for piece ends.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: THRUMS: A wool trade term for piece ends.
text: THRUMS: A wool trade term for piece ends.

Definition: fabrics principally used for covering beds. made in widths up to 72 inches, about 72 x 60, 14's/18's, 14's/20's, etc., 2 x 1 or 3 x 1 twill weave, warp face, stiff finished. generally in stripes, blue and white, red and white, etc. also made with a linen warp and sized weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TICKS, TICKING, BED TICKS: Fabrics principally used for covering beds. Made in widths up to 72 inches, about 72 x 60, 14's/18's, 14's/20's, etc., 2 x 1 or 3 x 1 twill weave, warp face, stiff finished. Generally in stripes, blue and white, red and white, etc. Also made with a linen warp and sized weft.
text: TICKS, TICKING, BED TICKS: Fabrics principally used for covering beds. Made in widths up to 72 inches, about 72 x 60, 14's/18's, 14's/20's, etc., 2 x 1 or 3 x 1 twill weave, warp face, stiff finished. Generally in stripes, blue and white, red and white, etc. Also made with a linen warp and sized weft.

Definition: the harness of a jacquard machine is tied up in four principal systems, as follows:- - single tie-in this there are as many hooks as there are ends in the warp, the warp threads being drawn through the mails of the harness in regular order from first to last. this system can only be used when the pattern extends from one side to the other of the cloth. lay-over or repeating tie.-all designs which contain more than one repeat in the width of the fabric come in this system. it is the one most used in lancashire. centre or turn-over tie.-used when one-half of the pat- tern if turned over gives the complete design. complex ties.-combinations of two or more of above.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TIES, JACQUARD HARNESS: The harness of a jacquard machine is tied up in four principal systems, as follows:- - Single Tie-In this there are as many hooks as there are ends in the warp, the warp threads being drawn through the mails of the harness in regular order from first to last. This system can only be used when the pattern extends from one side to the other of the cloth. Lay-over or Repeating Tie.-All designs which contain more than one repeat in the width of the fabric come in this system. It is the one most used in Lancashire. Centre or Turn-over Tie.-Used when one-half of the pat- tern if turned over gives the complete design. Complex Ties.-Combinations of two or more of above.
text: TIES, JACQUARD HARNESS: The harness of a jacquard machine is tied up in four principal systems, as follows:- - Single Tie-In this there are as many hooks as there are ends in the warp, the warp threads being drawn through the mails of the harness in regular order from first to last. This system can only be used when the pattern extends from one side to the other of the cloth. Lay-over or Repeating Tie.-All designs which contain more than one repeat in the width of the fabric come in this system. It is the one most used in Lancashire. Centre or Turn-over Tie.-Used when one-half of the pat- tern if turned over gives the complete design. Complex Ties.-Combinations of two or more of above.

Definition: the operation of tying the healds to the treadles, viz., the order of lifting the healds so as to produce a required pattern. also termed pegging plan and " treading plan.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TIE-UP: The operation of tying the healds to the treadles, viz., the order of lifting the healds so as to produce a required pattern. Also termed pegging plan and " treading plan.
text: TIE-UP: The operation of tying the healds to the treadles, viz., the order of lifting the healds so as to produce a required pattern. Also termed pegging plan and " treading plan.

Definition: a process by which warp yarn is coloured with a loose colour in order to distinguish when with other yarns. the yarn tinted is generally twisted the reverse way to ordinary warp yarn.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TINTING: A process by which warp yarn is coloured with a loose colour in order to distinguish when with other yarns. The yarn tinted is generally twisted the reverse way to ordinary warp yarn.
text: TINTING: A process by which warp yarn is coloured with a loose colour in order to distinguish when with other yarns. The yarn tinted is generally twisted the reverse way to ordinary warp yarn.

Definition: very fine muslins used for curtains, etc., which have large jacquard designs produced by extra weft. the ground cloth is a plain open weave muslin made from a fine warp and weft. a thick figuring weft interweaves with the ground warp only where required for pattern, and the remainder floats loosely on the back. the float- ing yarn is cropped off. two shuttles are necessary.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TISSUE FIGURED CLOTH: Very fine muslins used for curtains, etc., which have large jacquard designs produced by extra weft. The ground cloth is a plain open weave muslin made from a fine warp and weft. A thick figuring weft interweaves with the ground warp only where required for pattern, and the remainder floats loosely on the back. The float- ing yarn is cropped off. Two shuttles are necessary.
text: TISSUE FIGURED CLOTH: Very fine muslins used for curtains, etc., which have large jacquard designs produced by extra weft. The ground cloth is a plain open weave muslin made from a fine warp and weft. A thick figuring weft interweaves with the ground warp only where required for pattern, and the remainder floats loosely on the back. The float- ing yarn is cropped off. Two shuttles are necessary.

Definition: a toilet is a double fabric in which the face is stitched to the back cloth, the stitches producing the figure. a jac- quard machine is used, and the back ends are operated by the machine, which lifts the back ends into the face all round the edges of the figure. a single shuttle can be used, but if wadding picks are required to throw up the figure then two shuttles must be used, because the wadding weft is usually of coarse counts. the plain face cloth is operated by healds and tappets. two beams are used, and there are usually two face ends to one back. fast-back toilets are those in which the figuring or stitch- ing ends weave plain cloth with the weft when not form- ing figure; thus there are no floating threads on the back. loose-back toilets. in these the figuring ends float loosely from one stitching point to the next. these floats are liable to get broken after leaving the loom.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TOILET CLOTHS: A toilet is a double fabric in which the face is stitched to the back cloth, the stitches producing the figure. A jac- quard machine is used, and the back ends are operated by the machine, which lifts the back ends into the face all round the edges of the figure. A single shuttle can be used, but if wadding picks are required to throw up the figure then two shuttles must be used, because the wadding weft is usually of coarse counts. The plain face cloth is operated by healds and tappets. Two beams are used, and there are usually two face ends to one back. Fast-back Toilets are those in which the figuring or stitch- ing ends weave plain cloth with the weft when not form- ing figure; thus there are no floating threads on the back. Loose-back Toilets. In these the figuring ends float loosely from one stitching point to the next. These floats are liable to get broken after leaving the loom.
text: TOILET CLOTHS: A toilet is a double fabric in which the face is stitched to the back cloth, the stitches producing the figure. A jac- quard machine is used, and the back ends are operated by the machine, which lifts the back ends into the face all round the edges of the figure. A single shuttle can be used, but if wadding picks are required to throw up the figure then two shuttles must be used, because the wadding weft is usually of coarse counts. The plain face cloth is operated by healds and tappets. Two beams are used, and there are usually two face ends to one back. Fast-back Toilets are those in which the figuring or stitch- ing ends weave plain cloth with the weft when not form- ing figure; thus there are no floating threads on the back. Loose-back Toilets. In these the figuring ends float loosely from one stitching point to the next. These floats are liable to get broken after leaving the loom.

Definition: a cotton and silk warp and wool weft waistcoating. very expensive and elaborate designs frequently used. pro- bably france only produces this cloth at the present time.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TOILINETTE: A cotton and silk warp and wool weft waistcoating. Very expensive and elaborate designs frequently used. Pro- bably France only produces this cloth at the present time.
text: TOILINETTE: A cotton and silk warp and wool weft waistcoating. Very expensive and elaborate designs frequently used. Pro- bably France only produces this cloth at the present time.

Definition: a plain weave cloth which may have the warp all one colour or in stripes. the weft is bleached and coloured, and forms broad weft stripes. woven on box looms. the picks are greatly in excess of the number of warp ends. made in many widths and qualities.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TOLLANETTE: A plain weave cloth which may have the warp all one colour or in stripes. The weft is bleached and coloured, and forms broad weft stripes. Woven on box looms. The picks are greatly in excess of the number of warp ends. Made in many widths and qualities.
text: TOLLANETTE: A plain weave cloth which may have the warp all one colour or in stripes. The weft is bleached and coloured, and forms broad weft stripes. Woven on box looms. The picks are greatly in excess of the number of warp ends. Made in many widths and qualities.

Definition: several varieties of towels are manufactured, such as huckaback or huck, honeycomb, turkish or terry, and crash. the huckaback is most used and is common in hotels, railway companies, steamship companies, and other large corporations, who have their names woven in. can be woven on plain looms with dobbies or jacquards added. about 17 inches wide, 56 √ó 56, 2/20's/2/20's cotton or linen may be used. many qualities are made. the 10- end weave is very largely used. (see huckaback.) honeycomb towels.-also made in a great variety of qualities. the best qualities are woven from bleached warp and weft to prevent damage after weaving. (see honeycomb.) terry or turkish towels are fabrics made with the terry weave. two beams are used, one for the loop pile, the other for ground warp, which is tightly weighted. terry towels are named three, four, five, or more pick terrys. the three pick" has that number of picks inserted be- tween each row of loops, the ‚äúfour pick " has four, and so on. the "three pick" is the common towel, and the greater the number of picks to a row of loops the better the quality of the cloth.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TOWELS: Several varieties of towels are manufactured, such as huckaback or huck, honeycomb, Turkish or terry, and crash. The huckaback is most used and is common in hotels, railway companies, steamship companies, and other large corporations, who have their names woven in. Can be woven on plain looms with dobbies or jacquards added. About 17 inches wide, 56 √ó 56, 2/20's/2/20's cotton or linen may be used. Many qualities are made. The 10- end weave is very largely used. (See Huckaback.) Honeycomb Towels.-Also made in a great variety of qualities. The best qualities are woven from bleached warp and weft to prevent damage after weaving. (See Honeycomb.) Terry or Turkish Towels are fabrics made with the terry weave. Two beams are used, one for the loop pile, the other for ground warp, which is tightly weighted. Terry towels are named three, four, five, or more pick terrys. The three pick" has that number of picks inserted be- tween each row of loops, the ‚Äúfour pick " has four, and so on. The "three pick" is the common towel, and the greater the number of picks to a row of loops the better the quality of the cloth.
