Definition: the a loosely twisted silk thread used for weft. name is obtained from the french word " tram," which means "weft." it is a thrown silk, and has much less twist than organzine, is softer, and more bulky, with more lustre.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TRAM SILK: The A loosely twisted silk thread used for weft. name is obtained from the French word " tram," which means "weft." It is a thrown silk, and has much less twist than organzine, is softer, and more bulky, with more lustre.
text: TRAM SILK: The A loosely twisted silk thread used for weft. name is obtained from the French word " tram," which means "weft." It is a thrown silk, and has much less twist than organzine, is softer, and more bulky, with more lustre.

Definition: a double weft rib effect either down or across the piece. two colours of weft are used and all-wool yarns. (see ecosi√©.)
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TRICOTS OR ECOSIE: A double weft rib effect either down or across the piece. Two colours of weft are used and all-wool yarns. (See Ecosi√©.)
text: TRICOTS OR ECOSIE: A double weft rib effect either down or across the piece. Two colours of weft are used and all-wool yarns. (See Ecosi√©.)

Definition: only met with in the woollen trade, and implies that three sets of warp and weft threads forming three separate cloths, one above the other. are united into one fabric. this method of weaving is used to give weight and yet allow a fine face fabric to be produced. the weave used is usually the 5-end satin, and there is a warp face and warp back.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TREBLE CLOTHS: Only met with in the woollen trade, and implies that three sets of warp and weft threads forming three separate cloths, one above the other. are united into one fabric. This method of weaving is used to give weight and yet allow a fine face fabric to be produced. The weave used is usually the 5-end satin, and there is a warp face and warp back.
text: TREBLE CLOTHS: Only met with in the woollen trade, and implies that three sets of warp and weft threads forming three separate cloths, one above the other. are united into one fabric. This method of weaving is used to give weight and yet allow a fine face fabric to be produced. The weave used is usually the 5-end satin, and there is a warp face and warp back.

Definition: coloured stripe or check cotton fabrics used in india, the philippines, egypt, and many south american markets for trousers. generally made from all colour yarns in drab, black, brown, and blue, from 27 to 48 inches wide, plain or twill weaves. the cloths are sometimes raised on the back. a fair style is 64 x 48, 30/24's; another 90 √ó 84, 36/32's; a better cloth 80 x 74, 2/40's/16's.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TROUSERINGS, COTTON: Coloured stripe or check cotton fabrics used in India, the Philippines, Egypt, and many South American markets for trousers. Generally made from all colour yarns in drab, black, brown, and blue, from 27 to 48 inches wide, plain or twill weaves. The cloths are sometimes raised on the back. A fair style is 64 x 48, 30/24's; another 90 √ó 84, 36/32's; a better cloth 80 x 74, 2/40's/16's.

Definition: a very fine net fabric made from silk yarns, plain weave. first made in france.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TULLE: A very fine net fabric made from silk yarns, plain weave. First made in France.
text: TULLE: A very fine net fabric made from silk yarns, plain weave. First made in France.

Definition: cotton cloths dyed with turkey red dye and shipped to india. a great many qualities are made. plain weave.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TURKEY REDS: Cotton cloths dyed with Turkey red dye and shipped to India. A great many qualities are made. Plain weave.
text: TURKEY REDS: Cotton cloths dyed with Turkey red dye and shipped to India. A great many qualities are made. Plain weave.

Definition: the genuine turkish carpet is a hand loom production made on the native looms. these consist of two posts fixed to form a vertical frame with a roller at the top and another at the bottom, the warp being stretched between. the weaver sits in front with his design before him, and has a number of bobbins upon which are wound the different colours required. he selects a bobbin, forms a small loop round two warp threads, and cuts off the thread, leaving a small tuft on the warp. he completes a row of these tufts, opens a shed, and throws across a pick of strong ground weft, beats this down firmly, and then works on the next row of tufts, and so on. the ground cloth is a plain weave, with a row of tufts between each pick. after leaving the frame the tufts are sheared level. these carpets are very expensive. the best wool is used for the tuft yarn, so the fabric is very lasting.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TURKISH CARPETS: The genuine Turkish carpet is a hand loom production made on the native looms. These consist of two posts fixed to form a vertical frame with a roller at the top and another at the bottom, the warp being stretched between. The weaver sits in front with his design before him, and has a number of bobbins upon which are wound the different colours required. He selects a bobbin, forms a small loop round two warp threads, and cuts off the thread, leaving a small tuft on the warp. He completes a row of these tufts, opens a shed, and throws across a pick of strong ground weft, beats this down firmly, and then works on the next row of tufts, and so on. The ground cloth is a plain weave, with a row of tufts between each pick. After leaving the frame the tufts are sheared level. These carpets are very expensive. The best wool is used for the tuft yarn, so the fabric is very lasting.
text: TURKISH CARPETS: The genuine Turkish carpet is a hand loom production made on the native looms. These consist of two posts fixed to form a vertical frame with a roller at the top and another at the bottom, the warp being stretched between. The weaver sits in front with his design before him, and has a number of bobbins upon which are wound the different colours required. He selects a bobbin, forms a small loop round two warp threads, and cuts off the thread, leaving a small tuft on the warp. He completes a row of these tufts, opens a shed, and throws across a pick of strong ground weft, beats this down firmly, and then works on the next row of tufts, and so on. The ground cloth is a plain weave, with a row of tufts between each pick. After leaving the frame the tufts are sheared level. These carpets are very expensive. The best wool is used for the tuft yarn, so the fabric is very lasting.

Definition: a cotton fabric made 28 to 36 inches wide in 20 yard lengths, and shipped to west africa and south america; the quality is about 96 √ó 40, 22's matting warp and 20's weft. the centre of the cloth is a small blue and white check, and there is a broad border about 4 to 6 inches wide at each side of stripe only. the colour weft only weaves with the centre portion, and turns back at the edges of the border. thus the centre has more picks than the borders.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TURNBACK CHECKS: A cotton fabric made 28 to 36 inches wide in 20 yard lengths, and shipped to West Africa and South America; the quality is about 96 √ó 40, 22's matting warp and 20's weft. The centre of the cloth is a small blue and white check, and there is a broad border about 4 to 6 inches wide at each side of stripe only. The colour weft only weaves with the centre portion, and turns back at the edges of the border. Thus the centre has more picks than the borders.

Definition: a designer's term for those designs which reverse or turn over instead of repeating across the fabric. either half of the design is exactly like the other if turned over; thus a 10-inch pattern looks like a 20-inch one.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TURN-OVER OR REVERSE DESIGNS: A designer's term for those designs which reverse or turn over instead of repeating across the fabric. Either half of the design is exactly like the other if turned over; thus a 10-inch pattern looks like a 20-inch one.
text: TURN-OVER OR REVERSE DESIGNS: A designer's term for those designs which reverse or turn over instead of repeating across the fabric. Either half of the design is exactly like the other if turned over; thus a 10-inch pattern looks like a 20-inch one.

Definition: a wild silk, brownish in colour, produced by the silk- worm antheraea mylitta. the most important of the wild silks, and imported from india and china. the chinese variety is of a darker colour than the indian.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TUSSAH SILK: A wild silk, brownish in colour, produced by the silk- worm Antheraea Mylitta. The most important of the wild silks, and imported from India and China. The Chinese variety is of a darker colour than the Indian.
text: TUSSAH SILK: A wild silk, brownish in colour, produced by the silk- worm Antheraea Mylitta. The most important of the wild silks, and imported from India and China. The Chinese variety is of a darker colour than the Indian.

Definition: a good quality dress fabric made from mercerised yarns in a plain weave. the fine warp used bends round a coarse weft, giving the cloth a cord effect. about 72 to 100 ends and 36 to 44 picks, 60's or 2/100's warp and 6's to 10's weft, or 2/14's 2/16's. the tussores for egypt and other near east markets are made from all colour warp yarns and grey weft. brown, fawn, and light grounds, with darker coloured yarns form- ing stripes. about 72 x 38, 36's/10's or 24's/12's.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TUSSORES: A good quality dress fabric made from mercerised yarns in a plain weave. The fine warp used bends round a coarse weft, giving the cloth a cord effect. About 72 to 100 ends and 36 to 44 picks, 60's or 2/100's warp and 6's to 10's weft, or 2/14's 2/16's. The tussores for Egypt and other Near East markets are made from all colour warp yarns and grey weft. Brown, fawn, and light grounds, with darker coloured yarns form- ing stripes. About 72 x 38, 36's/10's or 24's/12's.
text: TUSSORES: A good quality dress fabric made from mercerised yarns in a plain weave. The fine warp used bends round a coarse weft, giving the cloth a cord effect. About 72 to 100 ends and 36 to 44 picks, 60's or 2/100's warp and 6's to 10's weft, or 2/14's 2/16's. The tussores for Egypt and other Near East markets are made from all colour warp yarns and grey weft. Brown, fawn, and light grounds, with darker coloured yarns form- ing stripes. About 72 x 38, 36's/10's or 24's/12's.

Definition: the original tweeds were hand-made woollen cloths made on the banks of the river tweed from soft, rough yarns, the weave being mostly twill, but plain sometimes used, and open and elastic in texture. both checks and stripes were produced. the tweeds manufactured in york- shire are imitations of the genuine cloths.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TWEED: The original tweeds were hand-made woollen cloths made on the banks of the river Tweed from soft, rough yarns, the weave being mostly twill, but plain sometimes used, and open and elastic in texture. Both checks and stripes were produced. The tweeds manufactured in York- shire are imitations of the genuine cloths.
text: TWEED: The original tweeds were hand-made woollen cloths made on the banks of the river Tweed from soft, rough yarns, the weave being mostly twill, but plain sometimes used, and open and elastic in texture. Both checks and stripes were produced. The tweeds manufactured in York- shire are imitations of the genuine cloths.

Definition: all fabrics having an appearance of diagonal lines can be termed twills. by using the twill weaves fabrics can be made heavier and more compact than if a plain weave was used. in nearly all twills the warp is harder twisted than the weft, and picks usually are in excess of the ends per inch to give a soft handle. shipping twills are gene- rally made 2 x 2 weave, 19 reed, 17 to 30 picks, 36 to 40's warp, and 36's to 40's weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TWILLS: All fabrics having an appearance of diagonal lines can be termed twills. By using the twill weaves fabrics can be made heavier and more compact than if a plain weave was used. In nearly all twills the warp is harder twisted than the weft, and picks usually are in excess of the ends per inch to give a soft handle. Shipping twills are gene- rally made 2 x 2 weave, 19 reed, 17 to 30 picks, 36 to 40's warp, and 36's to 40's weft.
text: TWILLS: All fabrics having an appearance of diagonal lines can be termed twills. By using the twill weaves fabrics can be made heavier and more compact than if a plain weave was used. Definition: the simplest twill weave is the 2 √ó 1, where one thread lifts once and is down twice, and this or any weave that produces a diagonal line across the cloth is called a twill. the 3 shaft or 2 x 1 twill is known as the " 'jean," nankeen," or regatta " twill. the 4 shaft (2 x 2 weave) as the ‚äú harvard," sheeting," shalloon," or "cassimere " twill; the 4 shaft (3 √ó 1 weave) as the " florentine," and the 5 shaft (1 √ó 4 weave) is known as the "beatrice" twill.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TWILL WEAVE: The simplest twill weave is the 2 √ó 1, where one thread lifts once and is down twice, and this or any weave that produces a diagonal line across the cloth is called a twill. The 3 shaft or 2 x 1 twill is known as the " 'Jean," Nankeen," or Regatta " twill. The 4 shaft (2 x 2 weave) as the ‚Äú Harvard," Sheeting," Shalloon," or "Cassimere " twill; the 4 shaft (3 √ó 1 weave) as the " Florentine," and the 5 shaft (1 √ó 4 weave) is known as the "Beatrice" twill.
text: TWILL WEAVE: The simplest twill weave is the 2 √ó 1, where one thread lifts once and is down twice, and this or any weave that produces a diagonal line across the cloth is called a twill. The 3 shaft or 2 x 1 twill is known as the " 'Jean," Nankeen," or Regatta " twill. The 4 shaft (2 x 2 weave) as the ‚Äú Harvard," Sheeting," Shalloon," or "Cassimere " twill; the 4 shaft (3 √ó 1 weave) as the " Florentine," and the 5 shaft (1 √ó 4 weave) is known as the "Beatrice" twill.

Definition: twills are usually classified under the following general heads :‚äî continuous or regular.‚äîa regular diagonal line is produced, and the lift is regular all across. zig-zag.‚äîthe diagonal line is reversed at fixed inter- vals, producing a series of waves. rearranged. a regular twill is taken as a basis, and the lifting is rearranged to a definite plan. satin twills give a very smooth face both warp and weft, and are produced by rearranging a regular twill. corkscrews are also rearranged twills, but step two or more instead of one. broken.‚äîa regular twill is broken in its direction at any desired interval. figured. simple spots or figures are combined with some simple twill. combined. formed by taking two regular twills and arranging them as one by taking the threads alternately either end and end or pick and pick.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TWILLS, CLASSIFICATION: Twills are usually classified under the following general heads :‚Äî Continuous or Regular.‚ÄîA regular diagonal line is produced, and the lift is regular all across. Zig-Zag.‚ÄîThe diagonal line is reversed at fixed inter- vals, producing a series of waves. Rearranged. A regular twill is taken as a basis, and the lifting is rearranged to a definite plan. Satin Twills give a very smooth face both warp and weft, and are produced by rearranging a regular twill. Corkscrews are also rearranged twills, but step two or more instead of one. Broken.‚ÄîA regular twill is broken in its direction at any desired interval. Figured. Simple spots or figures are combined with some simple twill. Combined. Formed by taking two regular twills and arranging them as one by taking the threads alternately either end and end or pick and pick.

Zig-Zag.‚ÄîThe diagonal line is reversed at fixed inter- vals, producing a series of waves. Rearranged. A regular twill is taken as a basis, and the lifting is rearranged to a definite plan. Satin Twills give a very smooth face both warp and weft, and are produced by rearranging a regular twill. Corkscrews are also rearranged twills, but step two or more instead of one. Broken.‚ÄîA regular twill is broken in its direction at any desired interval. Figured. Simple spots or figures are combined with some simple twill. Combined. Formed by taking two regular twills and arranging them as one by taking the threads alternately either end and end or pick and pick.

Definition: a term much used by traders for warp yarn; thus 30's twist means 30's warp yarn, and usually spun "twist " way. the direction of the twist in yarn is important; so is the amount of twist or number of turns per inch. a distinct stripe is produced by using, say, 20 ends twist way spun " and 20 ends weft way spun yarn alter- nately.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TWIST: A term much used by traders for warp yarn; thus 30's twist means 30's warp yarn, and usually spun "twist " way. The direction of the twist in yarn is important; so is the amount of twist or number of turns per inch. A distinct stripe is produced by using, say, 20 ends twist way spun " and 20 ends weft way spun yarn alter- nately.
text: TWIST: A term much used by traders for warp yarn; thus 30's twist means 30's warp yarn, and usually spun "twist " way. The direction of the twist in yarn is important; so is the amount of twist or number of turns per inch. A distinct stripe is produced by using, say, 20 ends twist way spun " and 20 ends weft way spun yarn alter- nately.

Definition: these are large cops upon which warp yarn is wound, and which is rewound upon bobbins for the warping frame. the cops containing weft are termed pin cops."
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TWIST COPS: These are large cops upon which warp yarn is wound, and which is rewound upon bobbins for the warping frame. The cops containing weft are termed pin cops."
text: TWIST COPS: These are large cops upon which warp yarn is wound, and which is rewound upon bobbins for the warping frame. The cops containing weft are termed pin cops."

Definition: warp yarns are nearly always spun what is known as "twist way," that is to the right. hold a piece of thread horizontally and twist to the right or from you, and if it unravels it is twist way spun or "t.w." weft way spun is the reverse, that is twist to the left. way spun.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TWIST WAY SPUN: Warp yarns are nearly always spun what is known as "twist way," that is to the right. Hold a piece of thread horizontally and twist to the right or from you, and if it unravels it is twist way spun or "T.W." Weft way spun is the reverse, that is twist to the left. way spun.
text: TWIST WAY SPUN: Warp yarns are nearly always spun what is known as "twist way," that is to the right. Hold a piece of thread horizontally and twist to the right or from you, and if it unravels it is twist way spun or "T.W." Weft way spun is the reverse, that is twist to the left. way spun.

Definition: very strong cotton fabrics in narrow widths woven on special looms from good staple cotton. the yarns are from six to twelve folds. the warp is very closely set in the reed and picks much fewer per inch. owing to the great care required to manufacture these fabrics and the large trade done in them, the tyre manufacturers have large mills equipped solely for their production.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: TYRE FABRICS: Very strong cotton fabrics in narrow widths woven on special looms from good staple cotton. The yarns are from six to twelve folds. The warp is very closely set in the reed and picks much fewer per inch. Owing to the great care required to manufacture these fabrics and the large trade done in them, the tyre manufacturers have large mills equipped solely for their production.
text: TYRE FABRICS: Very strong cotton fabrics in narrow widths woven on special looms from good staple cotton. The yarns are from six to twelve folds. The warp is very closely set in the reed and picks much fewer per inch. Owing to the great care required to manufacture these fabrics and the large trade done in them, the tyre manufacturers have large mills equipped solely for their production.

Definition: a fine cloth made specially for covering umbrellas from super long staple cotton. usually 36 to 44 inches wide, 75 to 90 yards long, fine reed and pick (from 96 to 110 reed and pick), and fine yarns (30 to 60's warp and weft), always plain weave. the cloth is also used for dress purposes. many makes have a coloured cotton or worsted selvedge.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: UMBRELLA CLOTH: A fine cloth made specially for covering umbrellas from super long staple cotton. Usually 36 to 44 inches wide, 75 to 90 yards long, fine reed and pick (from 96 to 110 reed and pick), and fine yarns (30 to 60's warp and weft), always plain weave. The cloth is also used for dress purposes. Many makes have a coloured cotton or worsted selvedge.
text: UMBRELLA CLOTH: A fine cloth made specially for covering umbrellas from super long staple cotton. Usually 36 to 44 inches wide, 75 to 90 yards long, fine reed and pick (from 96 to 110 reed and pick), and fine yarns (30 to 60's warp and weft), always plain weave. The cloth is also used for dress purposes. Many makes have a coloured cotton or worsted selvedge.

Definition: many fabrics are termed unions, such as alpacas, italians, cashmeres, twills, and others in which the warp and weft are of different material, as, for example, cotton and wool.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: UNION CLOTHS: Many fabrics are termed unions, such as alpacas, Italians, cashmeres, twills, and others in which the warp and weft are of different material, as, for example, cotton and wool.
text: UNION CLOTHS: Many fabrics are termed unions, such as alpacas, Italians, cashmeres, twills, and others in which the warp and weft are of different material, as, for example, cotton and wool.

Definition: principally made in ireland from a cotton warp and uax weft in many qualities, plain weave and fine yarns.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: UNION LINEN LAWNS: Principally made in Ireland from a cotton warp and uax weft in many qualities, plain weave and fine yarns.
text: UNION LINEN LAWNS: Principally made in Ireland from a cotton warp and uax weft in many qualities, plain weave and fine yarns.

Definition: suiting cloths made from cotton and wool or worsted yarns. the amount of cotton varies considerably accord- ing to the price the shipper requires to sell at. they are imitations of the real all wool fabrics and are shewn in plains, twills, stripes, and checks. the bulk of the trade is done in yorkshire. the lowest qualities are shipped to china, india, south america, etc.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: UNIONS: Suiting cloths made from cotton and wool or worsted yarns. The amount of cotton varies considerably accord- ing to the price the shipper requires to sell at. They are imitations of the real all wool fabrics and are shewn in plains, twills, stripes, and checks. The bulk of the trade is done in Yorkshire. The lowest qualities are shipped to China, India, South America, etc.
text: UNIONS: Suiting cloths made from cotton and wool or worsted yarns. The amount of cotton varies considerably accord- ing to the price the shipper requires to sell at. They are imitations of the real all wool fabrics and are shewn in plains, twills, stripes, and checks. The bulk of the trade is done in Yorkshire. The lowest qualities are shipped to China, India, South America, etc.

Definition: yarns made by combining two or more different ma- terials. in the lancashire and yorkshire trade wool and cotton is the principal union yarn.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: UNION YARNS: Yarns made by combining two or more different ma- terials. In the Lancashire and Yorkshire trade wool and cotton is the principal union yarn.
text: UNION YARNS: Yarns made by combining two or more different ma- terials. In the Lancashire and Yorkshire trade wool and cotton is the principal union yarn.

Definition: cotton grown in georgia and south carolina, the higher lands of the cotton district. the cotton is soft and clean, but rather short in staple. used principally for weft yarns up to 50's.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: UPLANDS COTTON: Cotton grown in Georgia and South Carolina, the higher lands of the cotton district. The cotton is soft and clean, but rather short in staple. Used principally for weft yarns up to 50's.
text: UPLANDS COTTON: Cotton grown in Georgia and South Carolina, the higher lands of the cotton district. The cotton is soft and clean, but rather short in staple. Used principally for weft yarns up to 50's.

Definition: a lower grade of fabric than the ordinary velvet. the design is complete on 6 ends and 6 picks and can be woven on 4 shafts. two picks separate one pile wire from the next, and only half the pile ends are raised over the pile wires. the pile threads are firmly bound in the fabric. yarns usually all cotton about 2/24's warp and 2/20's weft, 60 to 70 ends, 60 to 70 picks, with 32 wires per inch.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: UTRECHT VELVET: A lower grade of fabric than the ordinary velvet. The design is complete on 6 ends and 6 picks and can be woven on 4 shafts. Two picks separate one pile wire from the next, and only half the pile ends are raised over the pile wires. The pile threads are firmly bound in the fabric. Yarns usually all cotton about 2/24's warp and 2/20's weft, 60 to 70 ends, 60 to 70 picks, with 32 wires per inch.
text: UTRECHT VELVET: A lower grade of fabric than the ordinary velvet. The design is complete on 6 ends and 6 picks and can be woven on 4 shafts. Two picks separate one pile wire from the next, and only half the pile ends are raised over the pile wires. The pile threads are firmly bound in the fabric. Yarns usually all cotton about 2/24's warp and 2/20's weft, 60 to 70 ends, 60 to 70 picks, with 32 wires per inch.

Definition: a fancy elaborate waistcoating made from cotton and silk warp and worsted weft. the designs are developed in silk warp figures.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: VALENTIA: A fancy elaborate waistcoating made from cotton and silk warp and worsted weft. The designs are developed in silk warp figures.
text: VALENTIA: A fancy elaborate waistcoating made from cotton and silk warp and worsted weft. The designs are developed in silk warp figures.

Definition: the french word for velvet. a velour is made for curtains from coarse cotton yarns and piece dyed. the pile is very stiff and appears on both sides of the fabric. cotton velours are made from heavier yarns than used for velvets and velveteens, and the weave develops a cord or rib. if this rib is warp way the cloth is termed " long velour," if weft way generally piece dyed. the fabrics are intended to stand hard wear. gros velour."
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: VELOUR: The French word for velvet. A velour is made for curtains from coarse cotton yarns and piece dyed. The pile is very stiff and appears on both sides of the fabric. Cotton velours are made from heavier yarns than used for velvets and velveteens, and the weave develops a cord or rib. If this rib is warp way the cloth is termed " long velour," if weft way Generally piece dyed. The fabrics are intended to stand hard wear. gros velour."
text: VELOUR: The French word for velvet. A velour is made for curtains from coarse cotton yarns and piece dyed. The pile is very stiff and appears on both sides of the fabric. Cotton velours are made from heavier yarns than used for velvets and velveteens, and the weave develops a cord or rib. If this rib is warp way the cloth is termed " long velour," if weft way Generally piece dyed. The fabrics are intended to stand hard wear. gros velour."

Definition: the term by which the 6-shaft plain back velveteen is known.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: VELVERET: The term by which the 6-shaft plain back velveteen is known.
text: VELVERET: The term by which the 6-shaft plain back velveteen is known.

Definition: the real velvet is made with a cotton back of twofold yarn and silk pile. a cotton velvet is now understood to be a warp pile fabric in which the pile is formed by looping over wires which on being drawn out cut the warp to form the pile. twill back velvets are those with a twill ground weave- this weave allows more threads to be put in than if plain weave were used. when pile is made by weft the cloth is termed velveteen.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: VELVET: The real velvet is made with a cotton back of twofold yarn and silk pile. A cotton velvet is now understood to be a warp pile fabric in which the pile is formed by looping over wires which on being drawn out cut the warp to form the pile. Twill back velvets are those with a twill ground weave- this weave allows more threads to be put in than if plain weave were used. When pile is made by weft the cloth is termed velveteen.
text: VELVET: The real velvet is made with a cotton back of twofold yarn and silk pile. A cotton velvet is now understood to be a warp pile fabric in which the pile is formed by looping over wires which on being drawn out cut the warp to form the pile. Twill back velvets are those with a twill ground weave- this weave allows more threads to be put in than if plain weave were used. When pile is made by weft the cloth is termed velveteen.

Definition: the usual velvet or velveteen fabric with a pattern embossed on the face, produced by heat and pressure. the embossing machine has engraved rollers heated by gas.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: VELVET, EMBOSSED: The usual velvet or velveteen fabric with a pattern embossed on the face, produced by heat and pressure. The embossing machine has engraved rollers heated by gas.
text: VELVET, EMBOSSED: The usual velvet or velveteen fabric with a pattern embossed on the face, produced by heat and pressure. The embossing machine has engraved rollers heated by gas.

Definition: a cotton fabric which as it leaves the loom resembles a satin with long weft floats. these floats are cut both by hand and machine and the cut threads rise to form a small tuft. the large number of tufts give a soft smooth face. a standard cloth is 72 reed 500 picks, 2/80's/50's super, and is usually sold grey at a fixed price per pound weight. one shuttle only is used for both pile and ground picks. the ground picks weave with warp to form the back of the fabric. the usual quality of velveteen has the pile weft bound in by one warp thread. fast pile cloths have pile weft bound in by two or three ends, thus preventing the pile when cut being drawn out. velveteen has the shortest pile and cotton plus the longest.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: VELVETEEN: A cotton fabric which as it leaves the loom resembles a satin with long weft floats. These floats are cut both by hand and machine and the cut threads rise to form a small tuft. The large number of tufts give a soft smooth face. A standard cloth is 72 reed 500 picks, 2/80's/50's super, and is usually sold grey at a fixed price per pound weight. One shuttle only is used for both pile and ground picks. The ground picks weave with warp to form the back of the fabric. The usual quality of velveteen has the pile weft bound in by one warp thread. Fast pile cloths have pile weft bound in by two or three ends, thus preventing the pile when cut being drawn out. Velveteen has the shortest pile and cotton plus the longest.
text: VELVETEEN: A cotton fabric which as it leaves the loom resembles a satin with long weft floats. These floats are cut both by hand and machine and the cut threads rise to form a small tuft. The large number of tufts give a soft smooth face. A standard cloth is 72 reed 500 picks, 2/80's/50's super, and is usually sold grey at a fixed price per pound weight. One shuttle only is used for both pile and ground picks. The ground picks weave with warp to form the back of the fabric. The usual quality of velveteen has the pile weft bound in by one warp thread. Fast pile cloths have pile weft bound in by two or three ends, thus preventing the pile when cut being drawn out. Velveteen has the shortest pile and cotton plus the longest.

Definition: a cotton velveteen, but the weft has longer floats, the pile is also firmly which when cut give a longer pile. bound.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: VELVETEEN PLUSH: A cotton velveteen, but the weft has longer floats, The pile is also firmly which when cut give a longer pile. bound.
text: VELVETEEN PLUSH: A cotton velveteen, but the weft has longer floats, The pile is also firmly which when cut give a longer pile. bound.

Definition: cotton venetians used for linings and dress purposes are made all widths and qualities, well woven from super yarns and generally piece dyed. many qualities have a coloured selvedge. from 9 to 11 shafts, 160 to 240 ends, and 96 to 110 picks per inch; 2/120's warp, 40's weft. egyptian warp is most used. venetians are also made from all wool.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: VENETIANS: Cotton venetians used for linings and dress purposes are made all widths and qualities, well woven from super yarns and generally piece dyed. Many qualities have a coloured selvedge. From 9 to 11 shafts, 160 to 240 ends, and 96 to 110 picks per inch; 2/120's warp, 40's weft. Egyptian warp is most used. Venetians are also made from all wool.
text: VENETIANS: Cotton venetians used for linings and dress purposes are made all widths and qualities, well woven from super yarns and generally piece dyed. Many qualities have a coloured selvedge. From 9 to 11 shafts, 160 to 240 ends, and 96 to 110 picks per inch; 2/120's warp, 40's weft. Egyptian warp is most used. Venetians are also made from all wool.

Definition: a trade name given to a cellular cloth used for shirts and underwear, all cotton.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: VENTILETTE: A trade name given to a cellular cloth used for shirts and underwear, all cotton.
text: VENTILETTE: A trade name given to a cellular cloth used for shirts and underwear, all cotton.

Definition: a term covering a large variety of fabrics used both for fancy vests and dress purposes. it includes pique, bedford cords, welts, ribs, etc. the china market takes a large quantity of colour vestings for use as clothing in 26 to 28 inch widths, all cotton, stripes and checks, and in many qualities. a standard cloth is 29in. 120 yards, 80 √ó 74, 32/30, 2/40's colour for bleaching up 10 ends of colour per inch. the cloths are bleached.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: VESTINGS: A term covering a large variety of fabrics used both for fancy vests and dress purposes. It includes pique, Bedford cords, welts, ribs, etc. The China market takes a large quantity of colour vestings for use as clothing in 26 to 28 inch widths, all cotton, stripes and checks, and in many qualities. A standard cloth is 29in. 120 yards, 80 √ó 74, 32/30, 2/40's colour for bleaching up 10 ends of colour per inch. The cloths are bleached.
text: VESTINGS: A term covering a large variety of fabrics used both for fancy vests and dress purposes. It includes pique, Bedford cords, welts, ribs, etc. The China market takes a large quantity of colour vestings for use as clothing in 26 to 28 inch widths, all cotton, stripes and checks, and in many qualities. A standard cloth is 29in. 120 yards, 80 √ó 74, 32/30, 2/40's colour for bleaching up 10 ends of colour per inch. The cloths are bleached.

Definition: a crepe weave cotton cloth of good quality shipped to the near east, made from dyed yarns (black weft) both single and twofold yarns used, such as 84 x 80 30's/20's, or 78 √ó 72 2/40/2/40. brocade effects are now produced on the cloth.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: VIELEY CLOTH: A crepe weave cotton cloth of good quality shipped to the Near East, made from dyed yarns (black weft) both single and twofold yarns used, such as 84 x 80 30's/20's, or 78 √ó 72 2/40/2/40. Brocade effects are now produced on the cloth.
text: VIELEY CLOTH: A crepe weave cotton cloth of good quality shipped to the Near East, made from dyed yarns (black weft) both single and twofold yarns used, such as 84 x 80 30's/20's, or 78 √ó 72 2/40/2/40. Brocade effects are now produced on the cloth.

Definition: a fine cotton musln, plain weave, soft yarns, about 60's to 80's warp and weft, weighing 9 to 12 yards per lb.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: VICTORIA LAWN: A fine cotton musln, plain weave, soft yarns, about 60's to 80's warp and weft, weighing 9 to 12 yards per lb.
text: VICTORIA LAWN: A fine cotton musln, plain weave, soft yarns, about 60's to 80's warp and weft, weighing 9 to 12 yards per lb.

Definition: a dress goods fabric made from the wool of the vicuna goat of peru and other south american countries and also of thibet. the bulk of the wool is used by the natives in the manufacture of shawls, rugs, etc. bradford manu- facturers make a plain cloth, which is dyed black. has a very soft handle and used for suitings and ladies' wear.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: VICUNA: A dress goods fabric made from the wool of the Vicuna goat of Peru and other South American countries and also of Thibet. The bulk of the wool is used by the natives in the manufacture of shawls, rugs, etc. Bradford manu- facturers make a plain cloth, which is dyed black. Has a very soft handle and used for suitings and ladies' wear.
text: VICUNA: A dress goods fabric made from the wool of the Vicuna goat of Peru and other South American countries and also of Thibet. The bulk of the wool is used by the natives in the manufacture of shawls, rugs, etc. Bradford manu- facturers make a plain cloth, which is dyed black. Has a very soft handle and used for suitings and ladies' wear.

Definition: the wool from the goat-like camel of peru, thibet, and other warm countries. it is the best wool fibre used in textiles, but is very scarce. its colour is a reddish brown, it is very soft, long in fibre, and very lustrous.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: VICUNA WOOL: The wool from the goat-like camel of Peru, Thibet, and other warm countries. It is the best wool fibre used in textiles, but is very scarce. Its colour is a reddish brown, it is very soft, long in fibre, and very lustrous.
text: VICUNA WOOL: The wool from the goat-like camel of Peru, Thibet, and other warm countries. It is the best wool fibre used in textiles, but is very scarce. Its colour is a reddish brown, it is very soft, long in fibre, and very lustrous.

Definition: this yarn is an imitation vicuna, but of a poor quality. it is a mixture of sheep's wool and cotton and used princip- ally in france in the lower class of dress goods manufac- ture.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: VIGOGNE OR VICOGNE YARN: This yarn is an imitation vicuna, but of a poor quality. It is a mixture of sheep's wool and cotton and used princip- ally in France in the lower class of dress goods manufac- ture.
text: VIGOGNE OR VICOGNE YARN: This yarn is an imitation vicuna, but of a poor quality. It is a mixture of sheep's wool and cotton and used princip- ally in France in the lower class of dress goods manufac- ture.

Definition: this is a colour speciality yarn, and is made from prin- ted sliver. the sliver is printed by a special machine, generally black and white, and is then drawn and twisted into a thread. the effect is striking. usually worsted fibre and woven into cloth by yorkshire manufacturers.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: VIGOUREUX YARN: This is a colour speciality yarn, and is made from prin- ted sliver. The sliver is printed by a special machine, generally black and white, and is then drawn and twisted into a thread. The effect is striking. Usually worsted fibre and woven into cloth by Yorkshire manufacturers.
text: VIGOUREUX YARN: This is a colour speciality yarn, and is made from prin- ted sliver. The sliver is printed by a special machine, generally black and white, and is then drawn and twisted into a thread. The effect is striking. Usually worsted fibre and woven into cloth by Yorkshire manufacturers.

Definition: an artificial silk made from cellulose prepared from wood pulp dissolved in caustic soda. it can be exposed to the action of water without serious damage. this yarn is principally used for ornament in stripes or checks on a ground fabric.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: VISCOSE SILK: An artificial silk made from cellulose prepared from wood pulp dissolved in caustic soda. It can be exposed to the action of water without serious damage. This yarn is principally used for ornament in stripes or checks on a ground fabric.
text: VISCOSE SILK: An artificial silk made from cellulose prepared from wood pulp dissolved in caustic soda. It can be exposed to the action of water without serious damage. This yarn is principally used for ornament in stripes or checks on a ground fabric.

Definition: a registered trade name for a ceylon fabric used for underclothing. it is made from a mixture yarn of wool and cotton scribbled together.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: VIYELLA: A registered trade name for a Ceylon fabric used for underclothing. It is made from a mixture yarn of wool and cotton scribbled together.
text: VIYELLA: A registered trade name for a Ceylon fabric used for underclothing. It is made from a mixture yarn of wool and cotton scribbled together.

Definition: very light open plain weave dress fabrics made all plain for dyeing, printing, or bleaching, or in stripes with art. silk or coloured mercerised effects. made in all widths up to 60 inches. a large trade is done in 41 inch 60 ends, 60 picks, 2/100's/2/100's. the yarns are super quality and specially hard twisted. woven one end in a dent. the fabrics must be well woven and free from faults. both all cotton and all wool voiles are made.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: VOILES: Very light open plain weave dress fabrics made all plain for dyeing, printing, or bleaching, or in stripes with art. silk or coloured mercerised effects. Made in all widths up to 60 inches. A large trade is done in 41 inch 60 ends, 60 picks, 2/100's/2/100's. The yarns are super quality and specially hard twisted. Woven one end in a dent. The fabrics must be well woven and free from faults. Both all cotton and all wool voiles are made.
text: VOILES: Very light open plain weave dress fabrics made all plain for dyeing, printing, or bleaching, or in stripes with art. silk or coloured mercerised effects. Made in all widths up to 60 inches. A large trade is done in 41 inch 60 ends, 60 picks, 2/100's/2/100's. The yarns are super quality and specially hard twisted. Woven one end in a dent. The fabrics must be well woven and free from faults. Both all cotton and all wool voiles are made.

Definition: a specially hard twisted yarn used for making voile fabrics. both single and twofold-single 1/50's, twofold 2/100's. other counts are spun, but the above-named are spun generally when voile yarn is asked for.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: VOILE YARN: A specially hard twisted yarn used for making voile fabrics. Both single and twofold-single 1/50's, twofold 2/100's. Other counts are spun, but the above-named are spun generally when voile yarn is asked for.
text: VOILE YARN: A specially hard twisted yarn used for making voile fabrics. Both single and twofold-single 1/50's, twofold 2/100's. Other counts are spun, but the above-named are spun generally when voile yarn is asked for.

Definition: pure double cloths in which a third warp or weft is introduced to add weight and make a bulky fabric but still allow a fine face weave to be used. warp wadding is most used because it is the most economical and when used is usually of a coarser count than the other two warps. the wadding threads simply lie between the two fabrics and are not seen.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WADDED DOUBLE CLOTHS: Pure double cloths in which a third warp or weft is introduced to add weight and make a bulky fabric but still allow a fine face weave to be used. Warp wadding is most used because it is the most economical and when used is usually of a coarser count than the other two warps. The wadding threads simply lie between the two fabrics and are not seen.
text: WADDED DOUBLE CLOTHS: Pure double cloths in which a third warp or weft is introduced to add weight and make a bulky fabric but still allow a fine face weave to be used. Warp wadding is most used because it is the most economical and when used is usually of a coarser count than the other two warps. The wadding threads simply lie between the two fabrics and are not seen.

Definition: yarn used to give weight or throw up a design with- out being seen. generally of coarser counts than the ground cloth, and as it does not interweave with the cloth its face appearance is not affected.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WADDING THREADS: Yarn used to give weight or throw up a design with- out being seen. Generally of coarser counts than the ground cloth, and as it does not interweave with the cloth its face appearance is not affected.
text: WADDING THREADS: Yarn used to give weight or throw up a design with- out being seen. Generally of coarser counts than the ground cloth, and as it does not interweave with the cloth its face appearance is not affected.

Definition: the series of threads placed lengthways in the loom over any desired width and passing from the back beam through the healds and reed. the term "end" signifies one thread of warp.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WARP: The series of threads placed lengthways in the loom over any desired width and passing from the back beam through the healds and reed. The term "end" signifies one thread of warp.
text: WARP: The series of threads placed lengthways in the loom over any desired width and passing from the back beam through the healds and reed. The term "end" signifies one thread of warp.

Definition: cloths that have a greater number of warp threads shewing on the face than weft threads.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WARP FACED CLOTHS: Cloths that have a greater number of warp threads shewing on the face than weft threads.
text: WARP FACED CLOTHS: Cloths that have a greater number of warp threads shewing on the face than weft threads.

Definition: fabrics in which the pile is formed by the warp yarn, such as terry towels, warp plushes, velvet ribbons, some figured velvets, brussels carpets, etc.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WARP PILE FABRICS: Fabrics in which the pile is formed by the warp yarn, such as terry towels, warp plushes, velvet ribbons, some figured velvets, Brussels carpets, etc.
text: WARP PILE FABRICS: Fabrics in which the pile is formed by the warp yarn, such as terry towels, warp plushes, velvet ribbons, some figured velvets, Brussels carpets, etc.

Definition: a warp faced cloth in which the weft is thicker or grouped two or more together and lies straight so that the warp does all the bending. the warp is thus thrown to the face, producing a rib from selvedge to selvedge, as seen in poplins.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WARP RIBS: A warp faced cloth in which the weft is thicker or grouped two or more together and lies straight so that the warp does all the bending. The warp is thus thrown to the face, producing a rib from selvedge to selvedge, as seen in poplins.
text: WARP RIBS: A warp faced cloth in which the weft is thicker or grouped two or more together and lies straight so that the warp does all the bending. The warp is thus thrown to the face, producing a rib from selvedge to selvedge, as seen in poplins.

Definition: a five shaft sateen woven with a much greater num- ber of ends of warp than picks. four-fifths of the warp is on the face and only one-fifth of the weft. these fabrics much stronger lengthways than in the width. a large trade is done in cloths about 160 ends, 72 picks, 60's warp, 40's weft, or 60's/60's. all cotton, either dyed and schreinered or printed for linings and dress goods.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WARP SATEEN: A five shaft sateen woven with a much greater num- ber of ends of warp than picks. Four-fifths of the warp is on the face and only one-fifth of the weft. These fabrics much stronger lengthways than in the width. A large trade is done in cloths about 160 ends, 72 picks, 60's warp, 40's weft, or 60's/60's. All cotton, either dyed and schreinered or printed for linings and dress goods.
text: WARP SATEEN: A five shaft sateen woven with a much greater num- ber of ends of warp than picks. Four-fifths of the warp is on the face and only one-fifth of the weft. These fabrics much stronger lengthways than in the width. A large trade is done in cloths about 160 ends, 72 picks, 60's warp, 40's weft, or 60's/60's. All cotton, either dyed and schreinered or printed for linings and dress goods.

Definition: piqu√©s and bedford cords are warp welt. is not much in use.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WARP WELT: Piqu√©s and Bedford cords are warp welt. is not much in use.
text: WARP WELT: Piqu√©s and Bedford cords are warp welt. is not much in use.

Definition: the operation of winding yarn on to the beams for the loom. there are three general methods in use, viz., ball, beam, and section warping. ball warping is the oldest system and now seldom used except for certain kinds of coloured goods and for shipping in the ball. this system consists of large balls of yarn made by running the threads in the form of a rope. (see ball warping.) beam warping is the system commonly used, and here the threads are wound side by side on to a beam. several of these beams are used and run together through the slasher to make one weaver's beam. (see beam warping.) section warping consists of making narrow sections of cheeses 4 to 6 inches wide, placing the required number of sections together and running on to the weaver's beam. principally used in the coloured goods trade. the yarns used have been dyed and sized in the hank and wound on to warper's bobbins. (see section warping.)
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WARPING: The operation of winding yarn on to the beams for the loom. There are three general methods in use, viz., ball, beam, and section warping. Ball warping is the oldest system and now seldom used except for certain kinds of coloured goods and for shipping in the ball. This system consists of large balls of yarn made by running the threads in the form of a rope. (See Ball Warping.) Beam warping is the system commonly used, and here the threads are wound side by side on to a beam. Several of these beams are used and run together through the slasher to make one weaver's beam. (See Beam Warping.) Section warping consists of making narrow sections of cheeses 4 to 6 inches wide, placing the required number of sections together and running on to the weaver's beam. Principally used in the coloured goods trade. The yarns used have been dyed and sized in the hank and wound on to warper's bobbins. (See Section Warping.)
text: WARPING: The operation of winding yarn on to the beams for the loom. There are three general methods in use, viz., ball, beam, and section warping. Ball warping is the oldest system and now seldom used except for certain kinds of coloured goods and for shipping in the ball. This system consists of large balls of yarn made by running the threads in the form of a rope. (See Ball Warping.) Beam warping is the system commonly used, and here the threads are wound side by side on to a beam. Several of these beams are used and run together through the slasher to make one weaver's beam. (See Beam Warping.) Section warping consists of making narrow sections of cheeses 4 to 6 inches wide, placing the required number of sections together and running on to the weaver's beam. Principally used in the coloured goods trade. The yarns used have been dyed and sized in the hank and wound on to warper's bobbins. (See Section Warping.)

Definition: a term used to signify that the warp has been treated by cold size and hot air dried. this method is only used for very fine counts and super qualities and results in a round full yarn. the appearance of the yarn is much better than if slashed.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WARPS, DRESSED: A term used to signify that the warp has been treated by cold size and hot air dried. This method is only used for very fine counts and super qualities and results in a round full yarn. The appearance of the yarn is much better than if slashed.
text: WARPS, DRESSED: A term used to signify that the warp has been treated by cold size and hot air dried. This method is only used for very fine counts and super qualities and results in a round full yarn. The appearance of the yarn is much better than if slashed.

Definition: special warps that are very lightly sized and intended for some subsequent process.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WARPS, HALF-DRESSED: Special warps that are very lightly sized and intended for some subsequent process.
text: WARPS, HALF-DRESSED: Special warps that are very lightly sized and intended for some subsequent process.

Definition: warps that do not require sizing to prepare them for weaving, such as those made from twofold yarns.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WARPS UNDRESSED: Warps that do not require sizing to prepare them for weaving, such as those made from twofold yarns.
text: WARPS UNDRESSED: Warps that do not require sizing to prepare them for weaving, such as those made from twofold yarns.

Definition: low cotton fabrics made from a hard twisted warp and waste weft in plain or twill weave. crepes and spots are also in use. the warp is about 28's to 34's and weft from 8's to 1's or even coarser. wastes plains are simply plain weave. waste twills or sheetings are the 2 x 2 weave. waste crepes are usu- ally on about 8 to 10 shafts. waste spots also up to 10 shafts. waste cotton blankets are made in wide widths and a special shuttle and cop are required. the cop is known as a "jumbo cop "-it is longer than any other and is simply pressed in the shuttle, which has no peg; the weft is drawn from the inside of the cop and the shuttle inside has serrated edges to keep the cop in its place. blankets.)
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WASTE CLOTHS: Low cotton fabrics made from a hard twisted warp and waste weft in plain or twill weave. Crepes and spots are also in use. The warp is about 28's to 34's and weft from 8's to 1's or even coarser. Wastes plains are simply plain weave. Waste twills or sheetings are the 2 x 2 weave. Waste crepes are usu- ally on about 8 to 10 shafts. Waste spots also up to 10 shafts. Waste cotton blankets are made in wide widths and a special shuttle and cop are required. The cop is known as a "Jumbo cop "-it is longer than any other and is simply pressed in the shuttle, which has no peg; the weft is drawn from the inside of the cop and the shuttle inside has serrated edges to keep the cop in its place. blankets.)
text: WASTE CLOTHS: Low cotton fabrics made from a hard twisted warp and waste weft in plain or twill weave. Crepes and spots are also in use. The warp is about 28's to 34's and weft from 8's to 1's or even coarser. Wastes plains are simply plain weave. Waste twills or sheetings are the 2 x 2 weave. Waste crepes are usu- ally on about 8 to 10 shafts. Waste spots also up to 10 shafts. Waste cotton blankets are made in wide widths and a special shuttle and cop are required. The cop is known as a "Jumbo cop "-it is longer than any other and is simply pressed in the shuttle, which has no peg; the weft is drawn from the inside of the cop and the shuttle inside has serrated edges to keep the cop in its place. blankets.)

Definition: consists of cop bottoms, weavers', winders', warpers', and reelers' waste yarn. generally used up for condenser yarns.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WASTE, HARD: Consists of cop bottoms, weavers', winders', warpers', and reelers' waste yarn. Generally used up for condenser yarns.
text: WASTE, HARD: Consists of cop bottoms, weavers', winders', warpers', and reelers' waste yarn. Generally used up for condenser yarns.

Definition: this is comprised of all waste that has not been finally twisted, such as clearer waste, roller lap waste, spinning mill sweepings, sliver, and lap ends.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WASTE, SOFT: This is comprised of all waste that has not been finally twisted, such as clearer waste, roller lap waste, spinning mill sweepings, sliver, and lap ends.
text: WASTE, SOFT: This is comprised of all waste that has not been finally twisted, such as clearer waste, roller lap waste, spinning mill sweepings, sliver, and lap ends.
