Definition: a finishing process by which moire or watered effects are produced on fabrics. this effect is produced by doub- ling the piece so that the face sides are together, and then pressure is applied under heat; this pressure flattens the weft and those picks that come in a groove are un- touched, while those that are together are pressed out. the flat picks by not reflecting light the same as those not flattened give the peculiar and irregular effect desired. the finer the cloth and the finer will be the markings. the cloth must be very well woven. this watered effect can also be obtained by means of suitably engraved rollers.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WATERING, WATERED CLOTHS: A finishing process by which moire or watered effects are produced on fabrics. This effect is produced by doub- ling the piece so that the face sides are together, and then pressure is applied under heat; this pressure flattens the weft and those picks that come in a groove are un- touched, while those that are together are pressed out. The flat picks by not reflecting light the same as those not flattened give the peculiar and irregular effect desired. The finer the cloth and the finer will be the markings. The cloth must be very well woven. This watered effect can also be obtained by means of suitably engraved rollers.
text: WATERING, WATERED CLOTHS: A finishing process by which moire or watered effects are produced on fabrics. This effect is produced by doub- ling the piece so that the face sides are together, and then pressure is applied under heat; this pressure flattens the weft and those picks that come in a groove are un- touched, while those that are together are pressed out. The flat picks by not reflecting light the same as those not flattened give the peculiar and irregular effect desired. The finer the cloth and the finer will be the markings. The cloth must be very well woven. This watered effect can also be obtained by means of suitably engraved rollers.

Definition: a term used in a general way describing the weave and signifies that the cloth has a wave design. they are simple twills with the direction of the twill reversed at intervals and these give a wave or zig-zag effect.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WAVE TWILLS: A term used in a general way describing the weave and signifies that the cloth has a wave design. They are simple twills with the direction of the twill reversed at intervals and these give a wave or zig-zag effect.
text: WAVE TWILLS: A term used in a general way describing the weave and signifies that the cloth has a wave design. They are simple twills with the direction of the twill reversed at intervals and these give a wave or zig-zag effect.

Definition: the series of threads that pass from selvedge to selv- edge of the fabric and known as picks. the weft is put into the fabric by means of the shuttle. weft yarn is usually on smaller cops and softer spun than warp yarns. the bulk is mule spun. this yarn is seldom sized.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WEFT: The series of threads that pass from selvedge to selv- edge of the fabric and known as picks. The weft is put into the fabric by means of the shuttle. Weft yarn is usually on smaller cops and softer spun than warp yarns. The bulk is mule spun. This yarn is seldom sized.
text: WEFT: The series of threads that pass from selvedge to selv- edge of the fabric and known as picks. The weft is put into the fabric by means of the shuttle. Weft yarn is usually on smaller cops and softer spun than warp yarns. The bulk is mule spun. This yarn is seldom sized.

Definition: cloths that have more picks on the face than ends or threads of warp, such as ordinary sateens.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WEFT-FACED FABRICS: Cloths that have more picks on the face than ends or threads of warp, such as ordinary sateens.
text: WEFT-FACED FABRICS: Cloths that have more picks on the face than ends or threads of warp, such as ordinary sateens.

Definition: most velvets are weft pile cloths, and in all weft pile cloths the weft forms the pile.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WEFT PILE: Most velvets are weft pile cloths, and in all weft pile cloths the weft forms the pile.
text: WEFT PILE: Most velvets are weft pile cloths, and in all weft pile cloths the weft forms the pile.

Definition: cloths in which the warp is coarser than weft, or warp is in groups of two or more, so that the weft does all the bending and forms ribs running down the piece. weft usually preponderates on the face.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WEFT RIBS: Cloths in which the warp is coarser than weft, or warp is in groups of two or more, so that the weft does all the bending and forms ribs running down the piece. Weft usually preponderates on the face.
text: WEFT RIBS: Cloths in which the warp is coarser than weft, or warp is in groups of two or more, so that the weft does all the bending and forms ribs running down the piece. Weft usually preponderates on the face.

Definition: the ordinary cotton sateen cloth and is generally termed sateen.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WEFT SATEEN: The ordinary cotton sateen cloth and is generally termed sateen.
text: WEFT SATEEN: The ordinary cotton sateen cloth and is generally termed sateen.

Definition: weft yarns are usually spun in the opposite direction to warp yarns. if a thread untwists when turning the thread towards you it is weft-way spun. weft is spun when required in the other direction and is then known as 't.w." weft, thus " 30's weft t.w." is known as twist- way spun.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WEFT-WAY SPUN: Weft yarns are usually spun in the opposite direction to warp yarns. If a thread untwists when turning the thread towards you it is weft-way spun. Weft is spun when required in the other direction and is then known as 'T.W." weft, thus " 30's weft T.W." is known as twist- way spun.
text: WEFT-WAY SPUN: Weft yarns are usually spun in the opposite direction to warp yarns. If a thread untwists when turning the thread towards you it is weft-way spun. Weft is spun when required in the other direction and is then known as 'T.W." weft, thus " 30's weft T.W." is known as twist- way spun.

Definition: the process of adding weight to a cloth by the use of chemical or other substance. sizing adds weight, and weight is also added in many finishing processes.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WEIGHTING: The process of adding weight to a cloth by the use of chemical or other substance. Sizing adds weight, and weight is also added in many finishing processes.
text: WEIGHTING: The process of adding weight to a cloth by the use of chemical or other substance. Sizing adds weight, and weight is also added in many finishing processes.

Definition: true welts are the finest of cotton fabrics and woven practically without faults from the very best quality of yarn. piques and welts are very similar, but a welt is a cloth with ribs across the piece, woven from two warps and two wefts, with the binding points of the back warp weaving with the face cloth on certain picks at exact distances. when fancy effects are introduced the term 'pique" is generally used. a bedford cord is sometimes i called a welt, but the term is wrong, because the bedford cord is only a very poor imitation, and the cords run down the piece. welts are used for ladies' summer costumes, ties, vestings, shirts, and shirt facings, etc. "" a well-known welt is made 98 ends, 140 picks, 40's face, 34's back warp, 32's face, 16's wadding wefts, design on 12 ends. the best welts are made from sea islands cotton.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WELTS: True welts are the finest of cotton fabrics and woven practically without faults from the very best quality of yarn. Piques and welts are very similar, but a welt is a cloth with ribs across the piece, woven from two warps and two wefts, with the binding points of the back warp weaving with the face cloth on certain picks at exact distances. When fancy effects are introduced the term 'pique" is generally used. A Bedford cord is sometimes I called a welt, but the term is wrong, because the Bedford cord is only a very poor imitation, and the cords run down the piece. Welts are used for ladies' summer costumes, ties, vestings, shirts, and shirt facings, etc. "" A well-known welt is made 98 ends, 140 picks, 40's face, 34's back warp, 32's face, 16's wadding wefts, design on 12 ends. The best welts are made from Sea Islands cotton.
text: WELTS: True welts are the finest of cotton fabrics and woven practically without faults from the very best quality of yarn. Piques and welts are very similar, but a welt is a cloth with ribs across the piece, woven from two warps and two wefts, with the binding points of the back warp weaving with the face cloth on certain picks at exact distances. When fancy effects are introduced the term 'pique" is generally used. A Bedford cord is sometimes I called a welt, but the term is wrong, because the Bedford cord is only a very poor imitation, and the cords run down the piece. Welts are used for ladies' summer costumes, ties, vestings, shirts, and shirt facings, etc. "" A well-known welt is made 98 ends, 140 picks, 40's face, 34's back warp, 32's face, 16's wadding wefts, design on 12 ends. The best welts are made from Sea Islands cotton.

Definition: worsted dress goods made in twill weaves from hard twisted warp. on 9 shafts usually and with the twill so raised that the effect is something like the lash of a whip. cotton whipcords are made, but are inferior imita- tions.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WHIPCORDS: Worsted dress goods made in twill weaves from hard twisted warp. On 9 shafts usually and with the twill so raised that the effect is something like the lash of a whip. Cotton whipcords are made, but are inferior imita- tions.
text: WHIPCORDS: Worsted dress goods made in twill weaves from hard twisted warp. On 9 shafts usually and with the twill so raised that the effect is something like the lash of a whip. Cotton whipcords are made, but are inferior imita- tions.

Definition: the crossing threads that are worked by the doups in lenos or gauzes.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WHIP-THREAD: The crossing threads that are worked by the doups in lenos or gauzes.
text: WHIP-THREAD: The crossing threads that are worked by the doups in lenos or gauzes.

Definition: a linen fabric made from very fine counts, plain weave, fine reed and pick. it is not much used to-day, as no particular cloth is meant.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WIDOW'S LAWN: A linen fabric made from very fine counts, plain weave, fine reed and pick. It is not much used to-day, as no particular cloth is meant.
text: WIDOW'S LAWN: A linen fabric made from very fine counts, plain weave, fine reed and pick. It is not much used to-day, as no particular cloth is meant.

Definition: cotton fabrics are bought and sold in lancashire either actual or "nominal" width. the trade allows the use of these two terms, and understands that "actual" means full width, whereas "nominal" means less than full width, thus 36 inches actual will measure 36 inches on the table and no less, and 36 inches nominal may measure 35 inches on the table.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WIDTH: Cotton fabrics are bought and sold in Lancashire either actual or "nominal" width. The trade allows the use of these two terms, and understands that "actual" means full width, whereas "nominal" means less than full width, thus 36 inches actual will measure 36 inches on the table and no less, and 36 inches nominal may measure 35 inches on the table.
text: WIDTH: Cotton fabrics are bought and sold in Lancashire either actual or "nominal" width. The trade allows the use of these two terms, and understands that "actual" means full width, whereas "nominal" means less than full width, thus 36 inches actual will measure 36 inches on the table and no less, and 36 inches nominal may measure 35 inches on the table.

Definition: plain weave grey cotton cloths used both for home trade and shipping. made in widths from 28 inches to 36 inches, and generally in long lengths about 64 to 72 ends √ó 64 to 68 picks, 20's to 28's warp and 20's to 24's weft. the warp is sized. the cloth is sold in the loom state.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WIGANS: Plain weave grey cotton cloths used both for home trade and shipping. Made in widths from 28 inches to 36 inches, and generally in long lengths about 64 to 72 ends √ó 64 to 68 picks, 20's to 28's warp and 20's to 24's weft. The warp is sized. The cloth is sold in the loom state.
text: WIGANS: Plain weave grey cotton cloths used both for home trade and shipping. Made in widths from 28 inches to 36 inches, and generally in long lengths about 64 to 72 ends √ó 64 to 68 picks, 20's to 28's warp and 20's to 24's weft. The warp is sized. The cloth is sold in the loom state.

Definition: a similar carpet to a brussels, but the pile is cut and usually made from much superior yarns. the pile is longer and more firmly bound in the fabric and is cut by means of the wires having knife edges, which, when drawn out cut the warp threads. wilton carpets are in every respect superior to brussels.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WILTON CARPETS: A similar carpet to a Brussels, but the pile is cut and usually made from much superior yarns. The pile is longer and more firmly bound in the fabric and is cut by means of the wires having knife edges, which, when drawn out cut the warp threads. Wilton carpets are in every respect superior to Brussels.
text: WILTON CARPETS: A similar carpet to a Brussels, but the pile is cut and usually made from much superior yarns. The pile is longer and more firmly bound in the fabric and is cut by means of the wires having knife edges, which, when drawn out cut the warp threads. Wilton carpets are in every respect superior to Brussels.

Definition: the operation of transferring yarn from hanks or cheeses on to bobbins. also to wind warp threads from bobbins or cops upon which it has been spun on to the flanged bobbins ready for warping.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WINDING: The operation of transferring yarn from hanks or cheeses on to bobbins. Also to wind warp threads from bobbins or cops upon which it has been spun on to the flanged bobbins ready for warping.
text: WINDING: The operation of transferring yarn from hanks or cheeses on to bobbins. Also to wind warp threads from bobbins or cops upon which it has been spun on to the flanged bobbins ready for warping.

Definition: a cotton cloth, plain weave, used for blinds. made from 20's to 26's warp and weft. heavily finished with a starch finish and sometimes glazed (see holland). piece- dyed in drab, blue, green, etc.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WINDOW HOLLAND: A cotton cloth, plain weave, used for blinds. Made from 20's to 26's warp and weft. Heavily finished with a starch finish and sometimes glazed (see Holland). Piece- dyed in drab, blue, green, etc.
text: WINDOW HOLLAND: A cotton cloth, plain weave, used for blinds. Made from 20's to 26's warp and weft. Heavily finished with a starch finish and sometimes glazed (see Holland). Piece- dyed in drab, blue, green, etc.

Definition: a cotton flannelette made from super yarns in 35 to 40 inch widths, about 72 √ó 72, 30's to 36's warp, 20's to 24's weft, piece-dyed and nap finish. better qualities are made with a proportion of wool. woven plain weave. the original winsey had a cotton warp and a wool weft.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WINSEYS: A cotton flannelette made from super yarns in 35 to 40 inch widths, about 72 √ó 72, 30's to 36's warp, 20's to 24's weft, piece-dyed and nap finish. Better qualities are made with a proportion of wool. Woven plain weave. The original winsey had a cotton warp and a wool weft.
text: WINSEYS: A cotton flannelette made from super yarns in 35 to 40 inch widths, about 72 √ó 72, 30's to 36's warp, 20's to 24's weft, piece-dyed and nap finish. Better qualities are made with a proportion of wool. Woven plain weave. The original winsey had a cotton warp and a wool weft.

Definition: all wool blankets produced in witney. these fabrics are known as a superior make, and no other blanket can have the word " witney" attached to it.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WITNEY BLANKETS: All wool blankets produced in Witney. These fabrics are known as a superior make, and no other blanket can have the word " Witney" attached to it.
text: WITNEY BLANKETS: All wool blankets produced in Witney. These fabrics are known as a superior make, and no other blanket can have the word " Witney" attached to it.

Definition: a registered trade name for an all wool fabric used for underclothing.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WOLSEY: A registered trade name for an all wool fabric used for underclothing.
text: WOLSEY: A registered trade name for an all wool fabric used for underclothing.

Definition: the soft curly coat of the sheep, goat, alpaca, llama camel, and other animals. hair that is fine and wavy is termed wool. they all have a surface of overlapping scales, are easy to dye, but difficult to bleach. sheep's wool is by far the most abundant, and is produced all over the world. there are many varieties of sheep. wool fibres are long, curly, fine, have lustre, are very elastic, strong, and uniform.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WOOL: The soft curly coat of the sheep, goat, alpaca, llama camel, and other animals. Hair that is fine and wavy is termed wool. They all have a surface of overlapping scales, are easy to dye, but difficult to bleach. Sheep's wool is by far the most abundant, and is produced all over the world. There are many varieties of sheep. Wool fibres are long, curly, fine, have lustre, are very elastic, strong, and uniform.
text: WOOL: The soft curly coat of the sheep, goat, alpaca, llama camel, and other animals. Hair that is fine and wavy is termed wool. They all have a surface of overlapping scales, are easy to dye, but difficult to bleach. Sheep's wool is by far the most abundant, and is produced all over the world. There are many varieties of sheep. Wool fibres are long, curly, fine, have lustre, are very elastic, strong, and uniform.

Definition: a fabric used to imitate the genuine flannel and is made from mixture yarns composed of wool and cotton. the yarns are carded and the cloth well woven in both plain and twill weaves. the qualities are many, but in every case the percentage of wool should be stated.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WOOL AND COTTON FLANNEL: A fabric used to imitate the genuine flannel and is made from mixture yarns composed of wool and cotton. The yarns are carded and the cloth well woven in both plain and twill weaves. The qualities are many, but in every case the percentage of wool should be stated.
text: WOOL AND COTTON FLANNEL: A fabric used to imitate the genuine flannel and is made from mixture yarns composed of wool and cotton. The yarns are carded and the cloth well woven in both plain and twill weaves. The qualities are many, but in every case the percentage of wool should be stated.

Definition: a remanufactured or recovered wool obtained from old cloth, rags etc., in which cotton, flax, etc., had been used. the vegetable fibres are removed by carbonising.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WOOL EXTRACT: A remanufactured or recovered wool obtained from old cloth, rags etc., in which cotton, flax, etc., had been used. The vegetable fibres are removed by carbonising.
text: WOOL EXTRACT: A remanufactured or recovered wool obtained from old cloth, rags etc., in which cotton, flax, etc., had been used. The vegetable fibres are removed by carbonising.

Definition: cloths manufactured from carded wool yarns.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WOOLLEN FABRICS: Cloths manufactured from carded wool yarns.
text: WOOLLEN FABRICS: Cloths manufactured from carded wool yarns.

Definition: there are several systems of stating the counts of wool yarn as follows:- = "run" system, used in america. standard length of 1,600 yards, and the number of lengths of 1,600 yards that weigh 1 lb. gives the counts thus, 1,600 yards = 1 lb. = 1's run. 3,200 yards 1 lb. 2's run. run 200 yards to 1 lb., 4 run = 400 yards to 1 lb., etc. "cut" system. the number of cuts of 300 yards that weigh 1 lb. counts; thus, 6's cut has 1,800 yards to 1 lb. used in scotland.  "yorkshire skein " system has a length of 256 yards, and the number of these lengths that weigh 1 √èb. counts. = "west of england" system has a hank of 320 yards, and the number of these hanks in 1 lb. gives the counts.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WOOLLEN YARN COUNTS: There are several systems of stating the counts of wool yarn as follows:- = "Run" system, used in America. Standard length of 1,600 yards, and the number of lengths of 1,600 yards that weigh 1 lb. gives the counts thus, 1,600 yards = 1 lb. = 1's run. 3,200 yards 1 lb. 2's run. run 200 yards to 1 lb., 4 run = 400 yards to 1 lb., etc. "Cut" system. The number of cuts of 300 yards that weigh 1 lb. counts; thus, 6's cut has 1,800 yards to 1 lb. Used in Scotland.  "Yorkshire Skein " system has a length of 256 yards, and the number of these lengths that weigh 1 √èb. counts. = "West of England" system has a hank of 320 yards, and the number of these hanks in 1 lb. gives the counts.
text: WOOLLEN YARN COUNTS: There are several systems of stating the counts of wool yarn as follows:- = "Run" system, used in America. Standard length of 1,600 yards, and the number of lengths of 1,600 yards that weigh 1 lb. gives the counts thus, 1,600 yards = 1 lb. = 1's run. 3,200 yards 1 lb. 2's run. run 200 yards to 1 lb., 4 run = 400 yards to 1 lb., etc. "Cut" system. The number of cuts of 300 yards that weigh 1 lb. counts; thus, 6's cut has 1,800 yards to 1 lb. Used in Scotland.  "Yorkshire Skein " system has a length of 256 yards, and the number of these lengths that weigh 1 √èb. counts. = "West of England" system has a hank of 320 yards, and the number of these hanks in 1 lb. gives the counts.

Definition: yarn spun from wool in which there is no parallel position of the fibres. carded, but not combed, and is a cheaper yarn to produce than worsted. used for tweeds, cheviots, flannels, etc.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WOOLLEN YARN: Yarn spun from wool in which there is no parallel position of the fibres. Carded, but not combed, and is a cheaper yarn to produce than worsted. Used for tweeds, cheviots, flannels, etc.
text: WOOLLEN YARN: Yarn spun from wool in which there is no parallel position of the fibres. Carded, but not combed, and is a cheaper yarn to produce than worsted. Used for tweeds, cheviots, flannels, etc.

Definition: wool yarns that have been carded and combed until they are quite parallel. they are then twisted to make a regular smooth yarn, which is bright, lustrous, elastic, level, and very strong. easy to dye. used in the manu- facture of suitings and dress fabrics.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WORSTED: Wool yarns that have been carded and combed until they are quite parallel. They are then twisted to make a regular smooth yarn, which is bright, lustrous, elastic, level, and very strong. Easy to dye. Used in the manu- facture of suitings and dress fabrics.
text: WORSTED: Wool yarns that have been carded and combed until they are quite parallel. They are then twisted to make a regular smooth yarn, which is bright, lustrous, elastic, level, and very strong. Easy to dye. Used in the manu- facture of suitings and dress fabrics.

Definition: an all wool fabric with a diagonal twill weave, made in many qualities and used for dress goods.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WORSTED DIAGONAL: An all wool fabric with a diagonal twill weave, made in many qualities and used for dress goods.
text: WORSTED DIAGONAL: An all wool fabric with a diagonal twill weave, made in many qualities and used for dress goods.

Definition: cotton sateens made from super yarns with a few ends of worsted at each selvedge. the worsted is usually white, yellow, or red. widths 30 to 40 inches.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WORSTED EDGE SATEENS: Cotton sateens made from super yarns with a few ends of worsted at each selvedge. The worsted is usually white, yellow, or red. Widths 30 to 40 inches.
text: WORSTED EDGE SATEENS: Cotton sateens made from super yarns with a few ends of worsted at each selvedge. The worsted is usually white, yellow, or red. Widths 30 to 40 inches.

Definition: the number of hanks of 560 yards that weigh 1 lb. equals counts.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WORSTED YARN COUNTS: The number of hanks of 560 yards that weigh 1 lb. equals counts.
text: WORSTED YARN COUNTS: The number of hanks of 560 yards that weigh 1 lb. equals counts.

Definition: the yarn from the bobbin is wound on a reel for 120 yards, and when this length has been reeled the guide is moved forward and another 120 yards reeled, and so on until the hank of 840 yards has been reeled.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: WRAP REELED HANKS: The yarn from the bobbin is wound on a reel for 120 yards, and when this length has been reeled the guide is moved forward and another 120 yards reeled, and so on until the hank of 840 yards has been reeled.
text: WRAP REELED HANKS: The yarn from the bobbin is wound on a reel for 120 yards, and when this length has been reeled the guide is moved forward and another 120 yards reeled, and so on until the hank of 840 yards has been reeled.

Definition: a fabric made for umbrella covering, in twill weave and from super yarns. silk is often used with cotton, according to the quality required.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ZANELLA: A fabric made for umbrella covering, in twill weave and from super yarns. Silk is often used with cotton, according to the quality required.
text: ZANELLA: A fabric made for umbrella covering, in twill weave and from super yarns. Silk is often used with cotton, according to the quality required.

Definition: a dress goods fabric made from a worsted warp and silk weft, plain weave, and printed. or the warp is a worsted and silk doubled yarn with a fine hard spun weft of worsted.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ZEPHYR SILK BAREGE: A dress goods fabric made from a worsted warp and silk weft, plain weave, and printed. Or the warp is a worsted and silk doubled yarn with a fine hard spun weft of worsted.
text: ZEPHYR SILK BAREGE: A dress goods fabric made from a worsted warp and silk weft, plain weave, and printed. Or the warp is a worsted and silk doubled yarn with a fine hard spun weft of worsted.

Definition: cotton fabrics, plain weave, woven from coloured and white warp and bleached weft. if checks, coloured weft is also used. the coloured yarns are not bleaching colours, since the cloth is usually soft finished only. used for dress goods and blouses. about 88 ends, 90 picks, 32's/32's. the zephyr shipped to egypt and other markets is not so good a quality as the above cloth, and is generally lower in reed, pick, and yarns.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ZEPHYRS: Cotton fabrics, plain weave, woven from coloured and white warp and bleached weft. If checks, coloured weft is also used. The coloured yarns are not bleaching colours, since the cloth is usually soft finished only. Used for dress goods and blouses. About 88 ends, 90 picks, 32's/32's. The zephyr shipped to Egypt and other markets is not so good a quality as the above cloth, and is generally lower in reed, pick, and yarns.
text: ZEPHYRS: Cotton fabrics, plain weave, woven from coloured and white warp and bleached weft. If checks, coloured weft is also used. The coloured yarns are not bleaching colours, since the cloth is usually soft finished only. Used for dress goods and blouses. About 88 ends, 90 picks, 32's/32's. The zephyr shipped to Egypt and other markets is not so good a quality as the above cloth, and is generally lower in reed, pick, and yarns.

Definition: the french term for a dress fabric with a hairy sur- face made from crossbred wool yarns in heavily coloured stripes. the piece is slightly raised.
Title: Glossary of textile terms
Author: H.P. Curtis
Combined: ZIBELINE: The French term for a dress fabric with a hairy sur- face made from crossbred wool yarns in heavily coloured stripes. The piece is slightly raised.
text: ZIBELINE: The French term for a dress fabric with a hairy sur- face made from crossbred wool yarns in heavily coloured stripes. The piece is slightly raised.

Definition: a steel cup placed with the mouth downwards over the spindle of a cap frame, just large enough to cover the spinning bobbin.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Cap: a steel cup placed with the mouth downwards over the spindle of a cap frame, just large enough to cover the spinning bobbin.

Definition: burning by acid any vegetable matter which is found in wool.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Carbonisation: burning by acid any vegetable matter which is found in wool.

Definition: that portion of a mule spinning frame which contains the spindles, and travels backwards and forwards.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Carriage Of A Mule: that portion of a mule spinning frame which contains the spindles, and travels backwards and forwards.

Definition: small rollers for supporting the slubbing, or roving, between the back and front rollers of drawing machines and spinning frames.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Carriers, Or Carrying Rollers: small rollers for supporting the slubbing, or roving, between the back and front rollers of drawing machines and spinning frames.

Definition: the portion of the nip comb which carries the wool from the nip to the circle.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Carrying Comb: the portion of the nip comb which carries the wool from the nip to the circle.

Definition: a term applied to the cellular, or vesicular matter found in the nervous centres. it consists essentially of vesicles or cells. it has until lately been presumed to be limited to vegetable structures.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Cellulose: a term applied to the cellular, or vesicular matter found in the nervous centres. it consists essentially of vesicles or cells. it has until lately been presumed to be limited to vegetable structures.

Definition: that part of a woollen carding machine which separates the wool when it comes off the last doffer into a number of small rovings or rubbings ready for mule spinning.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Condenser: that part of a woollen carding machine which separates the wool when it comes off the last doffer into a number of small rovings or rubbings ready for mule spinning.

Definition: the number of wires set in a straight line across a sheet of clothing five inches wide.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Count Of Card Clothing: the number of wires set in a straight line across a sheet of clothing five inches wide.

Definition: the number given to any size of thread according to the number of hanks (560 yards) that weigh 1 lb., i.e., 36's yarn has 36 hanks of 560 yards each in 1 lb.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Counts Of Yarn: the number given to any size of thread according to the number of hanks (560 yards) that weigh 1 lb., i.e., 36's yarn has 36 hanks of 560 yards each in 1 lb.

Definition: the number of wires in one inch along a sheet of clothing.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Crown Of Card Clothing: the number of wires in one inch along a sheet of clothing.

Definition: the wheels which make a bobbin revolve at a varying speed as it becomes fuller, independently of the flyer.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Differential Motion Of Cone Drawing: the wheels which make a bobbin revolve at a varying speed as it becomes fuller, independently of the flyer.

Definition: the roller, or cylinder, of a carding machine between any two swifts which carries the wool from the one to the other.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Doffer: the roller, or cylinder, of a carding machine between any two swifts which carries the wool from the one to the other.

Definition: the drawing out of one or more ends of sliver or slubbing delivered by a pair of rollers into one thinner end by means of another pair of rollers.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Draft: the drawing out of one or more ends of sliver or slubbing delivered by a pair of rollers into one thinner end by means of another pair of rollers.

Definition: the resistance of a bobbin on the spindle and washer, as it is pulled round by the yarn when it is being spun.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Drag: the resistance of a bobbin on the spindle and washer, as it is pulled round by the yarn when it is being spun.

Definition: the preparation of wool previous to spinning, but after combinfj or cardinsr.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Drawing: the preparation of wool previous to spinning, but after combinfj or cardinsr.

Definition: a pulley, or wheel, which is driven (though it may itself drive others), and which, if increased in size, causes those which follow it to work at a decreased speed.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Driven: a pulley, or wheel, which is driven (though it may itself drive others), and which, if increased in size, causes those which follow it to work at a decreased speed.

Definition: a pulley, or wheel, which drives others (though it may itself be driven), and which, if increased in size, causes those which follow it to work at an increased speed.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Driver: a pulley, or wheel, which drives others (though it may itself be driven), and which, if increased in size, causes those which follow it to work at an increased speed.

Definition: the wool derived from waste woollen materials which have been woven, or otherwise mixed with cotton or linen.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Extract: the wool derived from waste woollen materials which have been woven, or otherwise mixed with cotton or linen.

Definition: the steel bars with upright pins set in them, which are carried by means of a pair of screws from the back rollers of a gill box to the front rollers, and then fall down to a lower pair of screws, and are carried back again.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Fallers: the steel bars with upright pins set in them, which are carried by means of a pair of screws from the back rollers of a gill box to the front rollers, and then fall down to a lower pair of screws, and are carried back again.

Definition: a roller on a carding machine which acts as a brush to raise the wool out of the swift.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Fancy: a roller on a carding machine which acts as a brush to raise the wool out of the swift.

Definition: the property which enables a number of fibres of wool to interlock and join together, so that they form a compact whole, and each fibre cannot be separated.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Felting: the property which enables a number of fibres of wool to interlock and join together, so that they form a compact whole, and each fibre cannot be separated.

Definition: the waste from finishing machines in cloth mills, whicli is used again to cheapen yarn and make it bulky.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Flocks: the waste from finishing machines in cloth mills, whicli is used again to cheapen yarn and make it bulky.

Definition: a horizontal steel bar with two vertical arms, each with an eye or twizzle at their lower extremities, which is placed on the spindle, and round one arm of which the yarn is wound as it passes on to the bobbin. owing to its rotatory speed being greater than that of the bobbin, it puts twist into the yarn.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Flyer: a horizontal steel bar with two vertical arms, each with an eye or twizzle at their lower extremities, which is placed on the spindle, and round one arm of which the yarn is wound as it passes on to the bobbin. owing to its rotatory speed being greater than that of the bobbin, it puts twist into the yarn.

Definition: the twist, or curl, which is given to the extremities of the flyer, forming a sort of ring for the yam to pass through, sometimes called the twizzle.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Flyer-Eye: the twist, or curl, which is given to the extremities of the flyer, forming a sort of ring for the yam to pass through, sometimes called the twizzle.

Definition: a fixed number which can be used to shorten calculations for finding the draft and twist of yarn, and which is obtained by condensing all the fixed quantities in any such process of calculation, and extracting from them their result.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Gauge Point: a fixed number which can be used to shorten calculations for finding the draft and twist of yarn, and which is obtained by condensing all the fixed quantities in any such process of calculation, and extracting from them their result.

Definition: a machine for drawing out and levelling wool, either before or after combing. its essential features are a pair of back and a pair of front rollers, with a set of fallers travelling between them by means of screws.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Gill Box: a machine for drawing out and levelling wool, either before or after combing. its essential features are a pair of back and a pair of front rollers, with a set of fallers travelling between them by means of screws.

Definition: a skein of thread of a fixed length, 560 yards for worsted ; 840 yards for cotton
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Hank: a skein of thread of a fixed length, 560 yards for worsted ; 840 yards for cotton

Definition: the name given to the wool of one-year-old sheep which have not been previously clipped.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Hog: the name given to the wool of one-year-old sheep which have not been previously clipped.

Definition: a solid, glazed, and horny kind of hair which grows on badly-bred sheep, rarely more than two inches long, which cannot be twisted into the thread in spinning, and will not take the same colour when dyed as the rest of the wool.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Kemp: a solid, glazed, and horny kind of hair which grows on badly-bred sheep, rarely more than two inches long, which cannot be twisted into the thread in spinning, and will not take the same colour when dyed as the rest of the wool.

Definition: the parts into which a hank or skein is divided when it is being reeled.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Lea, Or Rap: the parts into which a hank or skein is divided when it is being reeled.

Definition: flyer is leading the bobbin when the former revolves faster than the latter. in cone drawing, either can lead the other, but in all other drawings the flyer must lead.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Leading: flyer is leading the bobbin when the former revolves faster than the latter. in cone drawing, either can lead the other, but in all other drawings the flyer must lead.

Definition: the tying separately of each lea or rap. the band with which this is done is called "lease band."
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Leasing: the tying separately of each lea or rap. the band with which this is done is called "lease band."

Definition: the first rollers of a carding machine which draw or lick-in the wool.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Licker In: the first rollers of a carding machine which draw or lick-in the wool.

Definition: the plate which travels up and down the spindles of a drawing box or spinning frame, and on which the bobbins rest, and are thus lifted up and down.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Lifter: the plate which travels up and down the spindles of a drawing box or spinning frame, and on which the bobbins rest, and are thus lifted up and down.

Definition: the glossy or shiny appearance which alpaca, mohair, and some english wools, such as lincoln and yorkshire, possess, and which causes materials made of them to look bright
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Lustre: the glossy or shiny appearance which alpaca, mohair, and some english wools, such as lincoln and yorkshire, possess, and which causes materials made of them to look bright

Definition: the same as felting; also, the process by which the felting is carried on.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Milling: the same as felting; also, the process by which the felting is carried on.

Definition: the hair or wool of the angora goat.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Mohair: the hair or wool of the angora goat.

Definition: a sort of spinning frame, on which all woollen yarn is spun. another form of it is also used for cotton and worsted.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Mule: a sort of spinning frame, on which all woollen yarn is spun. another form of it is also used for cotton and worsted.

Definition: the worked-up waste from hard-spun or felted cloth, which is used again for low woollen yams.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Mungo: the worked-up waste from hard-spun or felted cloth, which is used again for low woollen yams.

Definition: the portion of the lister or nip comb which is formed by two plates closing together and drawing the wool which is between them through the fallers.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Nip Of Comb: the portion of the lister or nip comb which is formed by two plates closing together and drawing the wool which is between them through the fallers.

Definition: the point where a pair of rollers touch each other, and where, consequently, they hold or nip the wool.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Nip Of Rollers: the point where a pair of rollers touch each other, and where, consequently, they hold or nip the wool.

Definition: the short wool which is separated from the long by a combing machine.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Noil: the short wool which is separated from the long by a combing machine.

Definition: the travelling of the bobbin up and down the spindle in the process of being filled, so that it may be equally full all over.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Picking: the travelling of the bobbin up and down the spindle in the process of being filled, so that it may be equally full all over.

Definition: a little cup with a slit in it, set in a spinning frame for the thread to run down, and to avoid friction.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Pot-Eye: a little cup with a slit in it, set in a spinning frame for the thread to run down, and to avoid friction.

Definition: the distance between the back and front rollers in a drawing machine or spinning frame.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Hatch: the distance between the back and front rollers in a drawing machine or spinning frame.

Definition: the process of drawing next before spinning.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Roving: the process of drawing next before spinning.

Definition: the steel bars in a gill box on which the fallers travel.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Saddles: the steel bars in a gill box on which the fallers travel.

Definition: the name usually given to the first and second cards in the woollen trade.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Scribbler: the name usually given to the first and second cards in the woollen trade.

Definition: the fine teeth or points which project from the surfaces of fibres of wool, and which interlock with each other in the process of felting.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Serrations, Or Serratures: the fine teeth or points which project from the surfaces of fibres of wool, and which interlock with each other in the process of felting.

Definition: the worked-up waste of soft woollen or worsted goods which have not been milled, such as stockings, merinos, and, also, opened-out spinning waste.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Shoddy: the worked-up waste of soft woollen or worsted goods which have not been milled, such as stockings, merinos, and, also, opened-out spinning waste.

Definition: the process of dipping a warp into a thin paste composed of flour, starch, or other similar material, in order to give it strength and bind together all loose hairs.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Sizing: the process of dipping a warp into a thin paste composed of flour, starch, or other similar material, in order to give it strength and bind together all loose hairs.

Definition: a long ribbon of wool drawn out by a gill box and run into a can. it has no twist in it, and clings together by the nature of the wool.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Sliver: a long ribbon of wool drawn out by a gill box and run into a can. it has no twist in it, and clings together by the nature of the wool.

Definition: the equivalent of sliver, but with twist in it, and therefore in the form of a slack-twisted rope. it is made by a flyer winding it round a bobbin.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Slubbing: the equivalent of sliver, but with twist in it, and therefore in the form of a slack-twisted rope. it is made by a flyer winding it round a bobbin.

Definition: a lump of hard spinning waste, caused by the yarn curling round the top of the flyer instead of being wound on to the bobbin.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Snarl: a lump of hard spinning waste, caused by the yarn curling round the top of the flyer instead of being wound on to the bobbin.

Definition: an upright steel rod, on which the bobbin revolves, and at the top of which the flyer is fastened.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Spindle: an upright steel rod, on which the bobbin revolves, and at the top of which the flyer is fastened.

Definition: a wooden bobbin, consisting of a barrel and one end with a flange on it, the other end being merely the size of the barrel, to enable the yarn to be drawn off it when lying horizontal.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Spool: a wooden bobbin, consisting of a barrel and one end with a flange on it, the other end being merely the size of the barrel, to enable the yarn to be drawn off it when lying horizontal.

Definition: a lock of wool formed naturally on the sheep's back by a number of fibres clinging together.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Staple: a lock of wool formed naturally on the sheep's back by a number of fibres clinging together.

Definition: small rollers which run on the top of the swifts of a carding machine, and carry the wool from the workers back to the swift.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Strippers: small rollers which run on the top of the swifts of a carding machine, and carry the wool from the workers back to the swift.

Definition: a fixed iron or steel pin or rod, on which a wheel revolves.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Stud: a fixed iron or steel pin or rod, on which a wheel revolves.

Definition: the largest roller of a carding machine. it carries the wool round to the workers from the strippers, and thence to the dofier.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Swift: the largest roller of a carding machine. it carries the wool round to the workers from the strippers, and thence to the dofier.

Definition: a name for the ordinary spinning frame on which english worsted yarn is spun.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Throstle: a name for the ordinary spinning frame on which english worsted yarn is spun.

Definition: a ball of combed wool from which the noil has been separated.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Top: a ball of combed wool from which the noil has been separated.

Definition: a small hook of finely tempered steel, which runs round on the ring of a ring spinning frame, being pulled by the yarn, which is put through it.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Traveller: a small hook of finely tempered steel, which runs round on the ring of a ring spinning frame, being pulled by the yarn, which is put through it.

Definition: a thin place in a piece of yarn, caused by uneven drawing or too much draft in the spinning.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Twit: a thin place in a piece of yarn, caused by uneven drawing or too much draft in the spinning.

Definition: another name for the flyer-eye.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Twizzle: another name for the flyer-eye.

Definition: a small round piece of cloth, with a hole in the centre of it, which is placed on the spindle, and upon which the bobbin runs.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Washer: a small round piece of cloth, with a hole in the centre of it, which is placed on the spindle, and upon which the bobbin runs.

Definition: the name given to the wool of sheep of one year old and upwards which have previously been clipped.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Wether: the name given to the wool of sheep of one year old and upwards which have previously been clipped.

Definition: the small pulley fastened on to the spindle, on which the band runs which drives the spindle.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Wharl, Or Wharve: the small pulley fastened on to the spindle, on which the band runs which drives the spindle.

Definition: the wheel by altering which the amount of draft in a machine is changed.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Wheel-Draft: the wheel by altering which the amount of draft in a machine is changed.

Definition: a wheel which has its circumference covered with teeth.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Wheel-Tooth: a wheel which has its circumference covered with teeth.

Definition: the wheel by altering which the amount of twist in slubbing or yarn is changed.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Wheel-Twine: the wheel by altering which the amount of twist in slubbing or yarn is changed.

Definition: a wheel with a thread like that of a screw cut round its circumference.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Wheel-Worm: a wheel with a thread like that of a screw cut round its circumference.

Definition: the grease which is found in the wool of sheep, and which comes from perspii-ation.
Title: Spinning woolen and worsted : being a practical treatise for the use of all persons engaged in those trades
Author: McLaren, Walter S. Bright
text: Yolk: the grease which is found in the wool of sheep, and which comes from perspii-ation.

Definition: a  light-weight  lining  material  with  cotton  warp  and spun-silk  filling.  plain  weave,  white  or  plain  colors,  and  only  one grade.  used  for  linings  and  underwear.
Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Combined: ABC  silk: A  light-weight  lining  material  with  cotton  warp  and spun-silk  filling.  Plain  weave,  white  or  plain  colors,  and  only  one grade.  Used  for  linings  and  underwear.
text: ABC  silk: A  light-weight  lining  material  with  cotton  warp  and spun-silk  filling.  Plain  weave,  white  or  plain  colors,  and  only  one grade.  Used  for  linings  and  underwear.

Definition: the  trade  name  of  a  certain  manufacturer  for  his  cellulose- acetate-rayon  materials.
Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Combined: Acele: The  trade  name  of  a  certain  manufacturer  for  his  cellulose- acetate-rayon  materials.
text: Acele: The  trade  name  of  a  certain  manufacturer  for  his  cellulose- acetate-rayon  materials.

Definition: strong  linen  or  mercerized  cotton  ma¬¨ terial  with  plain  weave,  made  to  exact  specifications  for  the  wings of  airplanes.  after  the  world  war  the  surplus  was  sold  in  retail stores  for  civilian  purposes.  used  for  shirts,  house  dresses,  children‚äôs garments,  etc.
Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Combined: Airplane  cotton  and  linen: Strong  linen  or  mercerized  cotton  ma¬¨ terial  with  plain  weave,  made  to  exact  specifications  for  the  wings of  airplanes.  After  the  World  War  the  surplus  was  sold  in  retail stores  for  civilian  purposes.  Used  for  shirts,  house  dresses,  children‚Äôs garments,  etc.
text: Airplane  cotton  and  linen: Strong  linen  or  mercerized  cotton  ma¬¨ terial  with  plain  weave,  made  to  exact  specifications  for  the  wings of  airplanes.  After  the  World  War  the  surplus  was  sold  in  retail stores  for  civilian  purposes.  Used  for  shirts,  house  dresses,  children‚Äôs garments,  etc.

Definition: a  smooth,  lustrous,  wiry  fabric.  originally  made  with cotton  warp  and  filling  of  pure  alpaca.  now  made  with  cotton  warp and  filling  of  mohair  or  any  lustrous  wool.  used  for  linings,  dresses, and  men‚äôs  summer  coats  and  suits.  different  grades  and  weights called  angora,  brilliantine,  sicilian,  mohair,  palm  beach  cloth,  etc.
Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Combined: Alpaca: A  smooth,  lustrous,  wiry  fabric.  Originally  made  with cotton  warp  and  filling  of  pure  alpaca.  Now  made  with  cotton  warp and  filling  of  mohair  or  any  lustrous  wool.  Used  for  linings,  dresses, and  men‚Äôs  summer  coats  and  suits.  Different  grades  and  weights called  Angora,  brilliantine,  Sicilian,  mohair,  Palm  Beach  cloth,  etc.
text: Alpaca: A  smooth,  lustrous,  wiry  fabric.  Originally  made  with cotton  warp  and  filling  of  pure  alpaca.  Now  made  with  cotton  warp and  filling  of  mohair  or  any  lustrous  wool.  Used  for  linings,  dresses, and  men‚Äôs  summer  coats  and  suits.  Different  grades  and  weights called  Angora,  brilliantine,  Sicilian,  mohair,  Palm  Beach  cloth,  etc.

Definition: angora  or  mohair  fiber  used  particularly  in braids,  automobile  tops,  and  pile  fabrics  for  blankets,  upholstery, artificial  furs,  etc.  see  alpaca.
Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Combined: Angora  or  mohair: Angora  or  mohair  fiber  used  particularly  in braids,  automobile  tops,  and  pile  fabrics  for  blankets,  upholstery, artificial  furs,  etc.  See  Alpaca.
text: Angora  or  mohair: Angora  or  mohair  fiber  used  particularly  in braids,  automobile  tops,  and  pile  fabrics  for  blankets,  upholstery, artificial  furs,  etc.  See  Alpaca.

Definition: a  manufactured  fiber  made  in  imitation  of natural,  or  worm,  silk.  artificial-silk  materials  closely  resemble  those of  silk  and  are  used  for  the  same  purposes.  artificial  silk  is  often combined  with  other  fibers  for  all  kinds  of  woven  and  knitted  fabrics. called  at  first  fiber  silk,  vegetable  silk,  wood  silk,  glos,  etc.
Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Combined: Artificial  silk  or  rayon: A  manufactured  fiber  made  in  imitation  of natural,  or  worm,  silk.  Artificial-silk  materials  closely  resemble  those of  silk  and  are  used  for  the  same  purposes.  Artificial  silk  is  often combined  with  other  fibers  for  all  kinds  of  woven  and  knitted  fabrics. Called  at  first  fiber  silk,  vegetable  silk,  wood  silk,  glos,  etc.
text: Artificial  silk  or  rayon: A  manufactured  fiber  made  in  imitation  of natural,  or  worm,  silk.  Artificial-silk  materials  closely  resemble  those of  silk  and  are  used  for  the  same  purposes.  Artificial  silk  is  often combined  with  other  fibers  for  all  kinds  of  woven  and  knitted  fabrics. Called  at  first  fiber  silk,  vegetable  silk,  wood  silk,  glos,  etc.

Definition: a  fireproof,  undyed  material  woven  or  pressed  from asbestos,  a  mineral  fiber.  used  for  acid  filters,  fireproof  stage  cur¬¨ tains,  gloves,  and  other  garments  or  articles  to  be  used  around  fire  or great  heat.
Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Combined: Asbestos: A  fireproof,  undyed  material  woven  or  pressed  from asbestos,  a  mineral  fiber.  Used  for  acid  filters,  fireproof  stage  cur¬¨ tains,  gloves,  and  other  garments  or  articles  to  be  used  around  fire  or great  heat.
text: Asbestos: A  fireproof,  undyed  material  woven  or  pressed  from asbestos,  a  mineral  fiber.  Used  for  acid  filters,  fireproof  stage  cur¬¨ tains,  gloves,  and  other  garments  or  articles  to  be  used  around  fire  or great  heat.

Definition: a  pile  fabric  made  in  imitation  of  the  real  astrakhan fur  and  used  for  the  same  purpose.  the  curly,  lustrous  pile  is  usually of  mohair.
Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Combined: Astrakhan: A  pile  fabric  made  in  imitation  of  the  real  Astrakhan fur  and  used  for  the  same  purpose.  The  curly,  lustrous  pile  is  usually of  mohair.
text: Astrakhan: A  pile  fabric  made  in  imitation  of  the  real  Astrakhan fur  and  used  for  the  same  purpose.  The  curly,  lustrous  pile  is  usually of  mohair.

Definition: a  heavy  canvas  or  duck,  usually  with  wide,  bright stripes.  used  for  awnings,  hammocks,  etc.  see  canvas  and  duck.
Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Combined: Awning  cloth: A  heavy  canvas  or  duck,  usually  with  wide,  bright stripes.  Used  for  awnings,  hammocks,  etc.  See  Canvas  and  Duck.
text: Awning  cloth: A  heavy  canvas  or  duck,  usually  with  wide,  bright stripes.  Used  for  awnings,  hammocks,  etc.  See  Canvas  and  Duck.

Definition: carpeting  with  long,  soft  pile  (on one  side),  originally  hand  tufted.  first  made  in  axminster,  england, on  hand  looms.  now  machine  woven.  compare  with  wilton.
Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Combined: Axminster  rugs  and  carpets: Carpeting  with  long,  soft  pile  (on one  side),  originally  hand  tufted.  First  made  in  Axminster,  England, on  hand  looms.  Now  machine  woven.  Compare  with  Wilton.
text: Axminster  rugs  and  carpets: Carpeting  with  long,  soft  pile  (on one  side),  originally  hand  tufted.  First  made  in  Axminster,  England, on  hand  looms.  Now  machine  woven.  Compare  with  Wilton.

Definition: the  name  formerly  stood  for  fine,  strong  knitted undergarments  made  of  egyptian  cotton.  now  applied  to  certain kinds  of  unbleached  knitted  underwear.
Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Combined: Balbriggan: The  name  formerly  stood  for  fine,  strong  knitted undergarments  made  of  Egyptian  cotton.  Now  applied  to  certain kinds  of  unbleached  knitted  underwear.
text: Balbriggan: The  name  formerly  stood  for  fine,  strong  knitted undergarments  made  of  Egyptian  cotton.  Now  applied  to  certain kinds  of  unbleached  knitted  underwear.

Definition: a  novelty  satin  with  warp  of  artificial  silk  and filling  of  cotton.  has  brilliant  luster  but  is  stiff  and  rather  coarse. used  for  sports  wear,  trimmings,  and  decorative  fabrics.
Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Combined: Baronette  satin: A  novelty  satin  with  warp  of  artificial  silk  and filling  of  cotton.  Has  brilliant  luster  but  is  stiff  and  rather  coarse. Used  for  sports  wear,  trimmings,  and  decorative  fabrics.
text: Baronette  satin: A  novelty  satin  with  warp  of  artificial  silk  and filling  of  cotton.  Has  brilliant  luster  but  is  stiff  and  rather  coarse. Used  for  sports  wear,  trimmings,  and  decorative  fabrics.

Definition: a  thick,  soft,  light-weight  cotton  fabric,  heavily napped  on  both  sides.  colored  figures  and  background  usually reversible  on  face  and  back  of  cloth.  used  for  bathrobes,  infants‚äô blankets,  etc.
Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Combined: Bathrobe  material: A  thick,  soft,  light-weight  cotton  fabric,  heavily napped  on  both  sides.  Colored  figures  and  background  usually reversible  on  face  and  back  of  cloth.  Used  for  bathrobes,  infants‚Äô blankets,  etc.
text: Bathrobe  material: A  thick,  soft,  light-weight  cotton  fabric,  heavily napped  on  both  sides.  Colored  figures  and  background  usually reversible  on  face  and  back  of  cloth.  Used  for  bathrobes,  infants‚Äô blankets,  etc.

Definition: (ba'teks).  fabrics,  either  silk  or  cotton,  that  have  been colored  by  the  batik  process  of  printing,  originated  by  the  javanese.
Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Combined: Batiks:   (ba'teks).  Fabrics,  either  silk  or  cotton,  that  have  been colored  by  the  batik  process  of  printing,  originated  by  the  Javanese.
text: Batiks:   (ba'teks).  Fabrics,  either  silk  or  cotton,  that  have  been colored  by  the  batik  process  of  printing,  originated  by  the  Javanese.

Definition: (batest'),  from  jean  baptiste.  a  soft,  fine  cotton  fabric, either  white  or  in  delicate  tints.  better  grades  highly  mercerized. used  for  baby  clothes  and  fine  lingerie
Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Combined: Batiste  : (batest'),  from  Jean  Baptiste.  A  soft,  fine  cotton  fabric, either  white  or  in  delicate  tints.  Better  grades  highly  mercerized. Used  for  baby  clothes  and  fine  lingerie
text: Batiste  : (batest'),  from  Jean  Baptiste.  A  soft,  fine  cotton  fabric, either  white  or  in  delicate  tints.  Better  grades  highly  mercerized. Used  for  baby  clothes  and  fine  lingerie

Definition: a  rather  coarse  cotton  material  in  white  or  plain colors,  somewhat  resembling  linen  crash.  used  for  dresses  and  chil¬¨ dren‚äôs  suits.
Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Combined: Beach  cloth: A  rather  coarse  cotton  material  in  white  or  plain colors,  somewhat  resembling  linen  crash.  Used  for  dresses  and  chil¬¨ dren‚Äôs  suits.
text: Beach  cloth: A  rather  coarse  cotton  material  in  white  or  plain colors,  somewhat  resembling  linen  crash.  Used  for  dresses  and  chil¬¨ dren‚Äôs  suits.

Definition: a  strong,  closely  woven,  twilled  cotton  material  usu¬¨ ally  found  in  blue  and  white  or  brown  and  white  stripes.  yarn  dyed. used  for  feather  beds,  mattresses,  pillows,  etc.
Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Combined: Bed  ticking: A  strong,  closely  woven,  twilled  cotton  material  usu¬¨ ally  found  in  blue  and  white  or  brown  and  white  stripes.  Yarn  dyed. Used  for  feather  beds,  mattresses,  pillows,  etc.
text: Bed  ticking: A  strong,  closely  woven,  twilled  cotton  material  usu¬¨ ally  found  in  blue  and  white  or  brown  and  white  stripes.  Yarn  dyed. Used  for  feather  beds,  mattresses,  pillows,  etc.

Definition: (from  bengal).  a  heavily  corded  silk  material  in  white or  plain  colors.  used  for  dresses,  coats,  suits,  etc.  not  always  in  style.
Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Combined: Bengaline: (from  Bengal).  A  heavily  corded  silk  material  in  white or  plain  colors.  Used  for  dresses,  coats,  suits,  etc.  Not  always  in  style.
text: Bengaline: (from  Bengal).  A  heavily  corded  silk  material  in  white or  plain  colors.  Used  for  dresses,  coats,  suits,  etc.  Not  always  in  style.

Definition: a  white  linen  or  cotton  material,  the  design  of  which  is a  small  diamond  figure  with  dot  in  center  resembling  a  bird‚äôs  eye. used  for  towels,  and  for  diapers  and  sanitary  napkins.  also  called diaper  cloth.
Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine

Definition: (cor'duroi),  from  french  corde  du  roi ,  ''king‚äôs  cord.‚äù a  fabric,  usually  of  cotton,  with  lengthwise  rows,  or  cords,  of  pile  on the  face.  found  in  white  or  any  plain  color.  much  used  for  suits and  trousers  for  men  and  boys,  lounging  robes  and  sports  wear  for women,  coats  and  wraps  for  children.  found  also  in  wool.  certain qualities  used  for  hangings  and  upholstery.
Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine

Definition: an  undyed  cotton  material,  heavily  napped  on  both sides,  used  for  silence  cloths  under  tablecloths.

Definition: a  cotton  imitation  of  silk  foulard.  see  foulard.

Definition: cotton  material  of  same  weave  as  wool  gabar¬¨ dine.  used  for  dresses,  skirts,  blouses,  etc.  see  gabardine.

Definition: a  thin  silk  or  cotton  material  treated  on  one  side with  a  medicated  glue  which  will  adhere  to  the  skin.  found  in  white, flesh  color,  and  black.  the  beauty  patches  of  colonial  times  were  of black  court  plaster.
Title: How to Know Textiles

Definition: a  coarse,  rough,  plain-woven  fabric  found  in  cotton,  linen, and  union  materials.  may  be  unbleached,  partly  bleached,  white,  or dyed.  found  in  many  widths  and  qualities.  used  for  towels,  covers, and  decorative  household  articles.  at  times  fashionable  for  suits  and dresses.
Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine

Definition: a  medium-weight  cotton  material  usually  printed  with elaborate  floral  designs.  found  in  various  qualities,  the  better  ones often  warp  printed.  used  for  pillows  and  draperies  and  for  decora¬¨ tive  household  articles.

Definition: a  fine,  crisp,  light-weight  cotton  material,  white  or  in plain  colors.  used  for  aprons,  dresses,  and  underwear.  see  striped dimity  and  crossbar  dimity.

Definition: swiss,  or  muslin,  having  a  pattern of  dots  woven  in  at  regular  intervals  with  soft,  heavy  yarn.  many qualities.  used  for  aprons,  curtains,  trimmings  on  wash  dresses,  etc. see  swiss

Definition: any  fabric  which  is  made  by the  use  of  more  than  one  warp  or  filling  in  its  construction,  or  by  the simultaneous  weaving  and  fastening  together  of  two  or  more  cloths. examples,  bathrobe  material,  marseilles  counterpanes,  steamer  rugs. name  usually  applied  to  double  cloth  used  for  suits  and  coats
Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine

Examples,  bathrobe  material,  Marseilles  counterpanes,  steamer  rugs. Name  usually  applied  to  double  cloth  used  for  suits  and  coats

Definition: a  close,  heavy  cotton  fabric  of  plain  weave.  sometimes two  yarns  used  as  one  in  the  warp.  white  or  colored.  many  widths and  weights.  heavy  grades  practically  water  tight  and  used  for  tents, awnings,  sails,  tarpaulins,  sea  kits,  etc.  lighter  weights  used  for clothing.  see  canvas,  awning  cloth,  and  sailcloth.

Definition: (from  the  down  of  the  eider  duck).  a  light-weight knitted  material  with  a  thick,  fluffy  nap  of  wool  on  one  or  both  sides. formerly  much  used  for  bathrobes,  baby  blankets,  etc.  now  replaced somewhat  by  bathrobe  material.

Definition: a  fabric  having  a  long,  straight  pile  on  one  side.  made  of silk,  wool,  cotton,  or  a  mixture.  used  for  millinery  and  trimmings. plush  made  of  mohair  is  used  especially  for  upholstery  in  boats,  cars, automobiles,  etc.

Definition: a  firm,  strong  wool  material  made  with  the  standard  2-2 twill  weave.  may  be  coarse,  harsh,  and  wiry,  as  some  storm  serges, or  fine  and  soft,  as  certain  high-grade  dress  serges.  many  grades  and weights.  also  found  in  silk,  cotton,  and  cotton-and-wool  mixtures. a  fabric  of  universal  use,  always  to  be  found.  used  for  suits  and coats  for  men  and  women,  caps,  skirts,  dresses,  etc.

Definition: the  process,  in  the  manufacture  of  yarn,  in  which  many slivers  are  drawn  into  one.  the  more  times  this  doubling  process  is performed,  the  more  thoroughly  the  fibers  are  mixed  and  blended.

Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Combined: Filling: The  powder,  starch,  or  clay  used  in  the  finishing  process to  increase  the  weight  or  fill  the  interstices  in  coarse  or  loosely  woven cloth.  Cheap  cottons,  linens,  and  pongees  often  contain  much  filling.
text: Filling: The  powder,  starch,  or  clay  used  in  the  finishing  process to  increase  the  weight  or  fill  the  interstices  in  coarse  or  loosely  woven cloth.  Cheap  cottons,  linens,  and  pongees  often  contain  much  filling.

Definition: a  term  used  in  dyeing  or  printing  when  the  colors  are  made permanent  or  fast.
Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Combined: Fixed: A  term  used  in  dyeing  or  printing  when  the  colors  are  made permanent  or  fast.

Definition: the  machine  or  implement  used  for  breaking  the  flax straw  so  that  the  woody  substance  can  be  cleaned  from  the  fiber. breaking  is  the  first  process  in  flax  preparation  after  retting
Title: How to Know Textiles

Combined: Flax  brake: The  machine  or  implement  used  for  breaking  the  flax straw  so  that  the  woody  substance  can  be  cleaned  from  the  fiber. Breaking  is  the  first  process  in  flax  preparation  after  retting

Definition: the  long  yarn,  either  warp  or  filling,  exposed  on  the  sur¬¨ face  of  cloth  in  weaving.  these  floats  give  smoothness  to  satins, sateens,  plain  damasks,  etc.  and  beauty  to  pattern  weaving.

Definition: a  term  used  in  the  manufacture  of  wool  materials  when they  are  reduced  in  width  and  length.  other  terms  for  the  same process  are  shrunk,  milled,  felted.
Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine

Definition: term  used  of  knitted  underwear  and  hosiery.  in full-fashioned  garments  flat,  shaped  pieces  are  knitted  and  then  sewed together  to  form  a  permanently  shaped  garment.  circular  knitted garments  are  knitted  in  tubular  form  and  then  shaped  by  pressing.
Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine
Combined: Full-fashioned: Term  used  of  knitted  underwear  and  hosiery.  In full-fashioned  garments  flat,  shaped  pieces  are  knitted  and  then  sewed together  to  form  a  permanently  shaped  garment.  Circular  knitted garments  are  knitted  in  tubular  form  and  then  shaped  by  pressing.
text: Full-fashioned: Term  used  of  knitted  underwear  and  hosiery. Circular  knitted garments  are  knitted  in  tubular  form  and  then  shaped  by  pressing.

Definition: the  tearing  of  manufactured  materials  into  fibers. one  of  the  first  processes  in  securing  wool  for  remanufacture

Definition: the  removal  of  the  short  fiber  ends  on  the  surface  of  yarn or  cloth  by  burning.  used  particularly  with  cottons.  another  term for  the  same  process  is  singeing.
Title: How to Know Textiles

text: Gassing: The  removal  of  the  short  fiber  ends  on  the  surface  of  yarn or  cloth  by  burning.  Used  particularly  with  cottons.  Another  term for  the  same  process  is  singeing.

Definition: one  of  the  early  processes  in  the  cleaning  of  flax.  after the  breaking  process  the  flax  is  drawn  by  hand  or  machine  over combs  which  rake  out  the  woody  tissue  and  separate  the  flax  fibers.

Definition: a  chemical  process  used  with  cotton.  mercerizing straightens  and  plumps  the  cotton  fiber,  causing  it  to  be  more  lustrous and  take  dye  better.  mercerizing  correctly  done  strengthens  the cotton  fiber.

text: Singles: one  of  the  several  yarns  which  are  twisted  together  to make  thread  or  a  coarser  yarn.

Definition: stiffened  or  starched.

Combined: Sized: Stiffened  or  starched.
text: Sized: Stiffened  or  starched.

Definition: the  removal  of  the  tag  ends  and  torn  edges  from  a  fleece.

text: Skirting: The  removal  of  the  tag  ends  and  torn  edges  from  a  fleece.

text: Slabbing: A  stage  in  the  manufacture  of  yarn  before  it  is  drawn into  roving.

Definition: the  machine,  used  in  linen  manufacture,  on  which the  dressed  flax  is  placed,  or  spread,  for  the  first  drawing  process.

Definition: silk  or  silk  materials  made  from  pierced  cocoons,  and all  other  forms  of  waste  silk  which  cannot  be  reeled  but  must  be spun  into  yarns.

text: Staple  fibers: Rayon  fibers  cut  into  uniform  lengths  of  a  few inches.  Used  for  spun  rayon  or  to  mix  with  other  fibers.

Definition: in  silk  manufacture  the  operatives  who  do  the  throw¬¨ ing  are  called  throwsters. tie  dyed ,  or  tied  and  dyed.  see  tie  dyeing.

Definition: producing  a  pattern  by  winding  string  around  certain parts  of  the  cloth  before  it  is  dyed.  the  string  prevents  the  dye  from acting  on  those  spots,  which  remain  their  original  color.
Title: How to Know Textiles

text: Tie  dyeing: Producing  a  pattern  by  winding  string  around  certain parts  of  the  cloth  before  it  is  dyed.  The  string  prevents  the  dye  from acting  on  those  spots,  which  remain  their  original  color.

Definition: a  general  name  among  loggers  and  lumbermen  for trousers  so  treated  with  a  paraffin  preparation  as  to  be  hard,  stiff,  and impervious  to  water.

Title: How to Know Textiles
Author: Small, Cassie Paine

Definition: yarn  used  for  the  filling  in  silk  weaving.  it  is  usually coarser  and  has  less  twist  than  the  organzine,  or  warp.
Title: How to Know Textiles

Combined: Tram: Yarn  used  for  the  filling  in  silk  weaving.  It  is  usually coarser  and  has  less  twist  than  the  organzine,  or  warp.
